A Dark Mask


Chapter One

Forest of Ages


The forest was oddly still and silent. There were no signs of scurrying woodland creatures, nor were there any whispers of a single breeze rustling through the trees. It was as if the land was under some sort of spell, cast into a dreamlike sleep. The very air itself, still as death. The massive trees transformed the bright, noon sunlight into a soft gloom. Looking around, I could see no living thing, aside from the lethargic trees, and I grew doubtful that I would ever find a way out of these woods.

I had been traveling with Epona, my faithful horse, in these seemingly endless woods for the past few days. I truly hoped I would be at the edge soon, and riding into the next kingdom. Or whatever lands lay beyond Hyrule, that is. Not many Hylians had been outside of Hyrule proper, let alone this deep within the Laost Woods...if we even were in the Lost Woods for that matter.

Epona continued to trot along at a relaxed gait, not a care in the world. I rubbed a gauntleted hand along her white mane, grateful that she was wit me. Epona shook her light brown head and whinnied happily, her white speckled nose bobbing in delight. I could tell that she was enjoying this easy canter through the serene forest.

I chuckled at my companion, giving her another pat on head. Epona had been a close friend since the day we met, and I was very thankful that she joined me on this new adventure. Who knew how long I'd have been stuck in this place without her. Weeks? Months?

I took another lazy glance around to see if anything changed. Nothing new, nothing in the distance but towering trees and placid, almost suffocating forest air. We were seemingly all alone, and there wasn't a single soul in sight. I began to get drowsy with the combination of Epona's gentle strides and boredom, the environment lulling me into deep sleep. I shut my eyes and began to dream of Zelda, and of our last conversation before I left Hyrule...

The castle garden was bright and cheerful, flowers splashed vibrant colors amongst the white castle walls and green grass. Statues dotted the area, immortalizing valiant heroes and noble kings. In the middle of the garden stood a grand effigy of the three Hylian Goddesses Farore, Nayru, and Din. Above their heads rose the Triforce, the magnificent gift the Goddesses gave the world before they departed to the next realm. It was because of the Triforce that I was thrust into my destiny.

I was the Hero of Time, a child bound to the fate of the land. A child destined to fight the greatest evil that had ever befallen Hyrule, the self proclaimed King of Evil, Ganondorf. After a perilous, lengthy, and exhausting adventure, I had won. Following the battle, I met with a fully grown Zelda one last time. We were adults at that time, because I had to travel through time itself to defeat the wicked Gerudo lord, but I still had the mind of a child. Zelda and I stood there on the ruined remains of what was once Ganon's immense fortress. The wind was howling, and dust flew all around us. The princess took my gauntleted hands in her own and knelt down. Tears traced down her beautiful face, streaks of clean lines amidst the caked on dust and sweat. She thanked me and begged for my forgiveness. She blamed her lack of foresight as the reason behind Ganondorf's rise to ultimate power. I shook my head and tried to protest, but she stood up and put a soft finger on my lips to silence me. She said the only thing she could do for me, was to send me back to my own time. Permanently.

The adult princess told me to live my life to the fullest, to experience the full essence of the world...to have a childhood. Zelda took the Ocarina of Time from my belt pouch. As she brought the instrument to her lips, Zelda softly told me to be at peace. As she played the Ocarina, I felt my spirit lift from the ground and I began to soar through time. I arrived back at the Temple of Time, a child once more.

I knew what I had to do. I walked to the Pedestal of Legend one final time, and plunged the Master Sword into the stone with all of my might. Numbed by the realization that this massive adventure was finally, truly over, I trudged through the empty temple, out the imposing entrance, and headed straight to Hyrule Castle.

That was six years ago. Six years of striving for a normal life. But try as I might...I could not. My body was almost fully grown now: I had the musculature of a warrior who had put in countless hours of combat training. I was clad in the attire that Hyrule had come to know: forest green clothing, leather and steel gauntlets, white cotton pants, and tough leather boots. I had never felt that I needed to change my style of clothing. The green Kokiri- spun tunic I wore, albeit modified for an adult's body, was simple, functional, and effective for adventuring through most terrain. The tough material rarely tore and was as sturdy as the trees of the Lost Woods. As I stood there, lost in thought in the garden, brooding over my fate, past deeds, and future life, Zelda, the young princess of Hyrule who was a year or two older than me, interrupted my reverie.

"What are you doing, Link?" she probed, "Did you need to see me?"

"Oh! Yes!" I jumped, "Sorry, I was daydreaming..."

She laughed, "That's fine. It's a common occurrence with you that I've come to adore."

I shifted around, a little embarrassed and unsure of what to say next. I felt my cheeks heat up a little after hearing about her "adorations". After all, she was a princess. And I was...well...a simple 16 year old who preferred adventure, solitude, and battle above all. Still, I could not deny that I was quite attracted to her, despite my self- imposed shortcomings.

"So, what is it that you needed to tell me?" she asked with an amused look.

I turned away from her gaze, back toward the Triforce.

"I, uhmm, I was going to tell you that I, well..." I paused.

"Tell me what?"

"That I was leaving Hyrule...I can't stay here. There are just too many painful memories..."

Silence stretched between us, heavy as iron. I looked back at her, guilt rising in my chest like a tide. Zelda’s gaze drifted downward, where she noticed the full weight of my gear—my polished Hylian shield and the finely forged sword strapped tight across my back. Her breath caught, and when our eyes met again, there was sadness there first, soft and shining. Then came the flicker of something sharper—hurt, maybe even betrayal—before she turned her face away. I thought I saw a tear glint in the corner of her left eye, catching the light like a fallen star. She sighed, voice catching slightly, then cleared her throat and lifted her chin with royal restraint, but her trembling lashes gave her away.

"You're leaving...but...why? I thought you were happy? I thought..." She tore her eyes away from mine. I definitely saw tears now, as one streamed down her face.

"I thought we were going to be together? And now you're abandoning Hyrule? Abandoning... me?" Her voice quivered.

I took her hand in mine. She hesitated. I could feel her almost try to tear it away.

"I thought I was going to be happy too... But I can't be. Not after everything I've been through here. All the creatures I've killed and obstacles I've overcome, the friendships created and destroyed. I need..." I sighed, "I need to get away from it, to get far from this place to mend the pain I've been through..."

After what seemed like an hour, Zelda finally spoke in a defeated tone.

"Well...it truly sounds as if your mind is made up. I cannot stop you, no matter how badly I want to. I know how stubborn you can be..." She peered at me through watery eyes, "You must do what you feel you have to...But please. Before you go, take this..."

She handed me the Ocarina of Time, the sacred royal family heirloom that allowed the user to manipulate time. The sapphire hue glowed faintly in the sunlight, as she placed it into my hand I felt the weight of the ocarina once again. Zelda took my face into her hands and told me to never forget her. To keep her most treasured artifact with me and to always remember who I was and how much I meant to her.

I nodded, and felt a tension in my throat as I spoke,"I will never forget you."

Suddenly the world shook. I was rocked from my slumber as Epona reared up at an unseen force. I grasped the reins, but they slipped through my fingers. I was launched off her back, and tossed to the ground. Darkness overcame me. When I came to, I heard voices.

"Great job you two! You scored a pretty decent catch this time!" A raspy and childlike voice rang out, "Let's see what he's got on him!"

I felt a swift kick as the creature rolled me onto my stomach. Hard, skeletal hands probed my belt pouches. I was still too dazed to get on my feet to confront the entity. All I could do was try to snap out of it.

"Hey Skull Kid! What did ya find?" Another voice chimed in, boyish, along with the faint twinkle that fairies are notorious for. "Lemme see! Lemme SEE!"

"Shut up, Tael! You'll wake him up!" The third voice, more feminine and light, aside from the abrasive tone anyway.

"He's got a sword, so who knows what he's capable of!"

"Awwww, but Sis I wanna know!" Tael whined.

The other fairy groaned in annoyance.

"Quiet you guys, look at this thing!"

The Skull Kid plucked something from my pouch and began to blow into what sounded like...

My ocarina! I thought, and shook myself awake!

While the thief giggled in childish delight, I mustered all the strength I could to stand up. I managed to get to my feet through sheer force of will, balancing precariously as my vision still wobbled. The thief playing my ocarina was a skull kid, just like the ones I'd seen from Kokiri Forest. The creature wore a large straw hat and ragged patchy clothing and his thin, fragile- looking limbs poked out from under the tattered rags. Figuring I was still in the Lost Woods, I prepared to draw my sword and attack the prankster. Yet before I could act, the two fairies, one white and the other purple, saw me and twinkled in alarm.

The skull child stopped playing, and slowly turned to look at me. The thing jumped in surprise and attempted to hide my ocarina behind his back. On his face, he wore a deep purple, heart -shaped mask with colorful spikes that formed the sides. But what stood out most to me were the eyes. Large, round, incredibly disturbing, orange and green eyes that bulged from the mask. I felt them pierce into my mind, until I remembered that he had taken my priceless instrument. A rush of anger flared up and I thought of Zelda. I lunged at the mischievous runt. The thief suddenly leapt high into the air with unprecedented agility, and landed straight onto Epona's saddle! Epona reared up in fright while the skull kid spurred her to move. Stunned only for a second, I threw myself at the now galloping horse, just barely catching hold of the stirrup.

I clung for dear life, desperately trying to pull myself closer to the insufferable imp! Poor Epona was scared out of her wits—her muscles bunched tight with panic, eyes wide and white-rimmed, every stride a desperate bolt away from the terror on her back. The way she whinnied, sharp and distressed, pierced through my anger and struck something deeper. She trusted me to protect her, and now she was being violated by this masked horror, twisted into a weapon against me. A pang of guilt cut through my fury—I had brought her here, and now she was caught in a nightmare neither of us understood. But even though my anger gave me the strength to hold on, I failed to stop the skull kid. I was being dragged along through sticks, rocks, and thorns that clawed at my skin like angry hands. A jagged stone tore a deep gash along my calf, and every bounce sent sharp shocks of pain up my spine. My tunic snagged and ripped, threads peeling away as the forest carved its punishment into my body. For a fleeting moment, a sliver of fear overtook the anger—a flash of helplessness, of being prey again, dragged through shadow and underbrush by forces I couldn’t yet understand. The two fairies were trying their hardest to keep up, but even they were struggling against Epona’s marvelous speed. The Skull Kid let out shrill peals of laughter, spinning and capering atop the saddle with impossible grace. He danced like a maniacal specter, every motion exaggerated and grotesque, as though the mask fed on chaos. Its surface pulsed faintly with each shriek of laughter, as if drunk on mayhem, growing brighter with every surge of panic and pain around it.

Moments later, Epona suddenly leapt over a fallen tree. I couldn't hold on any longer, and my hand went numb. I flew off the saddle, lucky to miss Epona's rear hooves, and I helplessly watched as they galloped away, disappearing into the gloom of the forest...

Chapter Two

A Terrible Fate

What seemed like an eternity passed as I painfully stumbled along after my stolen horse, heart pounding with a heady mix of desperation and rising panic. Every dragging step felt like a silent cry—one part anger, one part fear—that I might never see Epona or my ocarina again. Thankfully the sleepy forest received minimal foot traffic, and Epona's trail was fairly simple to follow. My legs, though battered and sliced beyond recognition, managed to carry me to a series of massive tree trunks. It was here where the clear trail ended, but I was not  going to give up on Epona, or my ocarina. They were beyond priceless to me now. I just had  to get them back!

Thinking I'd get a better view atop one of the tree trunks, I forced myself to clamber up the tallest one. Reaching the top and gasping for breath, with my entire body in agony, I observed my surroundings. Aside from the usual lethargy of the forested atmosphere, I managed to spot a cave where several horse tracks led to. The cave looked as if it was carved into a tree that stood a short distance away, it had  to be their hideout! Thankfully it was much easier to climb down...er...fall down… than it was to struggle up the imposing trunk, but I made it. I crawled my way to the entrance, totally exhausted at this point. I had no idea what I was going to do in this state, I could barely move my arm let alone swing my sword! But, being the stubborn lad I was, I made my way into the cavern despite my injuries. The darkness of the cave enveloped me like a wet shroud, the scent of damp earth and rotting wood clinging to my nose as I stepped into the void. I couldn't make out anything—the blackness pressed in on all sides, thick and suffocating, as if the air itself were holding its breath. I fumbled around the floor, forcing myself to plod forward, when suddenly I was falling!

Greeeaaaaat... I thought. So much effort and pain just to fall to my death. FANTASTIC!

I glanced down, trying to see the very bottom of the pit, but it was swallowed in darkness. A hollow wind howled past my ears as I dropped, accompanied by faint, ghostly echoes that bounced off unseen walls. The rush of air tore at my tunic and made my eyes water, adding a raw chill to the pit's growing dread. This must have been an incredibly deep hole, as I had been falling seemingly for a few seconds. But my thoughts of doom were interrupted by a pinpoint of light below me. As I prepared myself for the crushing blow of the floor below, the tiny dot multiplied into many dots, and then those dots became pictures. I was suddenly falling through faces! Faces upon faces stared me down—some familiar, others twisted into grotesque parodies of memory, their eyes wide and hollow, expressions frozen in masks of sorrow, fury, or vacant indifference. Either due to this new development, or from overwhelming pain, my vision darkened and I drifted into unconsciousness...

I had no notion of how much time had passed, but I was cast out of my comatose state by the feeling of a soft thud against a spongy substance. I opened my eyes slowly and saw that I was no longer falling through empty space. The padded flooring I had landed on was in fact a large, purple flower that had the faint scent of blueberries. All around me, the chamber glowed faintly with a surreal, bioluminescent sheen—the walls pulsing with veins of soft green and lavender light. Strange, twisted plants grew from every angle, some bearing softly humming bulbs, others blooming with hypnotic patterns that shifted like oil on water. The air was warm and slightly sweet, tinged with something earthy and ancient.

I gently pulled myself to my feet, bracing for the sharp sting of torn muscles and scraped skin—but nothing came. My breath caught as confusion swept in. Where I expected agony, there was only eerie ease. For a moment, I just stood there, stunned, warily flexing my fingers and shifting my weight, half-expecting the pain to lunge out belatedly like a hidden trap. To my surprise I felt fine! I looked down at my body to realize I had been completely healed! Not only that, but my green-colored Kokiri tunic and white pants had been fully restored as well. I was still disoriented from the fall, and could barely remember a thing.... Just when I began imagining that I was dead and in the afterlife, bright lights flooded the chamber, temporarily blinding me. I covered my eyes against the sudden brilliance and heard a voice. The same scratchy, childlike voice that I remember stealing...something... from me.

"Whew, what is with your stupid horse?! It wouldn't listen to a thing I said!" The voice taunted.

Suddenly, everything came flooding back to me—Epona! My Ocarina! The memory struck like a lightning bolt, sending a jolt of panic and grief surging through my chest. My breath caught as images of her wide, terrified eyes and the flash of the stolen ocarina tore through my mind. It was all real—and they were gone. The lights dimmed slightly and there, menacingly floating above the ground a few meters away, was the Skull Kid. The two fairies were with him, but where was Epona? I gazed around the grotto in desperation, but my mare was nowhere in sight. All that could be seen, aside from the thieves, was a tiny pond between us, and a few cave sketches carved into the walls. Other than that, it was an empty room.

"Where is she!" I growled.

"What? There's no need of a disobedient horse, so I did you a favor and got rid of her!"

I blinked in disbelief. Epona? Gone ? I clenched my armored fists in rage.

"NOOOO!" I shouted. "You're going to regret ever meeting me!"

I drew my sword and shield. This creature was going to pay for what he had done! I was at full health now... there was no way I would lose to him this time. He was cornered.

"Oooooo looks like we got a tough guy!" The Skull Kid proclaimed. "What do you fairies think?"

The fairies had no chance to respond, I darted forward, aiming to plunge my blade through the Skull Kid's mask. The child howled a malicious laugh, and suddenly my sword transformed into a large tulip and my shield shattered into a powdery cloud. Taken aback, I stumbled and tripped over myself, landing in the shallow water that separated me from the masked skull child.

"HA! You think you can take me as I am now? You think a big, strong man like you can stop me?" Skull Kid said in a threatening tone. "Well...we'll see about that!"

I quickly leapt to my feet, searching in the water for something I could use as a weapon. From the corner of my eye, I saw the strange, heart-shaped mask begin to emit a strange purple aura. I attempted to dodge aside, assuming he was about to throw some kind of magic bolt at me, but I couldn't move, my legs were paralyzed! The translucent purple aura had begun to surround me, and I feared that the worst was about to happen and I would be soon joining my ancestors.

The aura slowly closed in around me, encasing my body in its glow. Suddenly ice cold, ethereal tendrils surged from the aura and wrapped tightly around my body. The air thickened, tasting like syrupy rot, and I began to smell a pungently sweet odor as the ghostly tendrils writhed around my form. I felt an intense burning sensation, like something was boiling me from within, reshaping me from the soul outward! Tears of pain welled up inside my eyes as the fiery sensation swarmed over me, overtaking not just my body, but something deeper—my very essence. The ghostly strands pierced into my being, twisting and churning my spirit, dragging something foreign to the surface. I could feel things changing—my balance, my center of gravity, the very way my limbs responded, as if they no longer obeyed quite the same way. The pain became more than physical—it was existential, like I was being unmade. I cried out, the sound lost in the pulse of dark energy surrounding me. Just when I thought I would vanish entirely, the pain stopped. The purple aura withdrew, leaving me gasping on my knees. My lungs clawed at the air. I felt off...wrong...lighter, somehow—but wrong in a way I couldn't yet name.

"Heeheeheehee! Take that !" The imp cackled, laced with something deeper than cruelty...something ancient and wrong. "That'll teach you to threaten me!"

I once again began grasping around the shallow water looking for a stone, a fish, anything to throw at the Skull Kid while he laughed at me. My vision wobbled, but I managed to grasp a decent sized rock and got to my feet, throwing it straight for the heart-shaped mask. The rock smashed into the mask, which cracked faintly at the edge with a pulse of dark light, and the Skull Kid shrieked in pain. The mask seemed to absorb part of the blow, its surface momentarily rippling as if alive, and a low hum of energy thrummed through the air like a warning.

"Yeeaarrrghhh! You'll pay for that!"

The ground suddenly began to shake, and losing my balance I fell back into the shallow water. I felt weak, off balance, and I could hardly stand! The Skull Kid nervously looked around.

"Uughh. You're lucky, I have more important things to deal with right now. I'll finish you off later! You'll be much easier to get rid of by then!"

He began retreating toward the sketched-upon wall, and it opened upward like a door. I rose to my feet and began chasing after him, when the white fairy attacked me. Momentarily distracted, I managed to push the offending fairy away and get back to my pursuit, when the door suddenly slammed shut! This shocked the fairy, and it thankfully stopped attacking me as it rushed over to the door.

"H-hey! Skull Kid wait up!" The tiny white fairy shouted. "Don't leave me behind!"

There was no answer and the female fairy twinkled in despair. I felt a twinge of pity for her, but only for a split-second. She was an accomplice to an atrocious act on top of aiding the Skull Kid in robbing me. I ignored her pleas for the Skull Kid to come back, gathering my wits and trying to figure out why I felt so strange. I knelt down next to the pond to splash some water on my face when I saw my reflection. My eyes looked more of an aqua color now instead of the pale blue I remembered, but that was all I could see that was different about me. I shrugged it off, thinking that the water had discolored the appearance of my eyes. I stood back up and looked to the now crying fairy. A flood of emotions churned beneath the surface—was this justice? Pity? Some part of me wanted to hate her for what she'd done, yet another part saw only a lost creature, abandoned and afraid. I wasn't sure what I felt, only that the rage had started to cool—and something else, something quieter, was taking its place.

The pixie turned to face me and exclaimed that she was now separated from her brother, and how it was all my fault. I shot her an irritated glance and walked up to the door. I put my hands on it and began to push up. I had done this a million times before and it was no problem for me. At least, in the past it wasn't difficult. But now I was struggling to even lift it up a couple feet. My arms trembled, my muscles ached... and something felt off in how my limbs moved. My center of gravity seemed...wrong, slightly shifted. That aura the Skull Kid's mask generated must have sapped my strength! But despite this, I managed to get the door just high enough for me to slip through. The fairy, seeing an opportunity to escape the musty chamber, followed suit. Still, I ignored her, and continued down a long wooden corridor. It appeared as if I was walking through a tree...which made sense. I did fall through a hole in a tree, so why not? I was willing to believe anything at this point. The air smelled faintly of bark and decay—ancient, damp, and earthy. As I neared the end of the wooden hallway, the fairy came huffing and puffing after me.

"Wait! Are... whew... are you just going to leave me behind?" she panted, "You can't leave a poor, defenseless fairy like me to fend for myself!"

I looked at her and responded with a spiteful snicker.

"Defenseless, eh? What was all that with attacki- squeak "

My voice cracked, sharp and high-pitched like a child’s. The fairy gave me a strange look. I cleared my throat and began again.

"Attacking me? And why should I help you  at all? You've been nothing  but trou- crack "

Once again my voice squeaked, painfully so. What was wrong  with me?! There was a strange tightness in my throat now, like something foreign and unyielding had taken root.

The fairy kept giving me that odd look, but after a second she started begging again.

"Please please please  let me come with you! I promise to tell you all I know about the Skull Kid!"

I considered her offer, mulling it over in my head. On one hand, she could be a big help. On the other hand, I wasn't sure if I could trust her. But the pros outweighed the cons, and I nodded.

"Alright you can come. But if you try anything, you are throu- creak …?"

I coughed in frustration. It felt as if there was a tiny, smooth object lodged in my vocal cords. I kept coughing, trying to clear the obstruction. It would not budge. I pressed a gauntleted hand to my throat and leaned my forehead against the cool, wooden wall of the hallway. My whole body trembled—not from pain, but something more unsettling.

"Are you okay?" the fairy asked gently. "You seem a little distraught?"

Distraught? Seriously?  I thought bitterly. I had been robbed, dragged through the forest floor, plummeted to my supposed death, and who knew what else was wrong with me... and she says DISTRAUGHT!?

She must have seen the look on my face, because she started apologizing almost immediately.

"I'm sorry! I-I never meant for this to go so far!"

The fairy glanced away, and her demeanor shifted, lowering her voice almost to a whisper... as if she was trying to convince herself as well.

"The Skull Kid didn't use to be so cruel...i-it was all meant to be a simple prank, I swear..."

"A simple prank? Killing my horse— squeak —was a simple prank?"

The squeaking voice was grating on my nerves. The strange pressure in my throat grew tighter, like an invisible hand slowly wrapping around it. It was most likely due to all the trauma my body and mind had endured... but I wasn’t so sure anymore.

"You can't tell me it was a prank…" I said in a weary tone.

"Ok, ok, look. I will help you out with a whole bunch of things. You sound really tired, understandably…" the pixie reasoned out, attempting to bargain. "I know where a nearby fountain is. You can get help from the Great Fairy there. And if anyone can help you right now with the Skull Kid, it's the Great Fairy!"

"Fine. Show me where, and you can tag along." I finally gave in. A fairy fountain was exactly  what I needed.

"Awesome! You won't regret it, I promise! My name's Tatl. What's yours?"

"Link," I sighed.

"Ok great! Nice to meet you... and sorry again…"

I refused to respond as we crossed the threshold into the next room.

Chapter Three

Brand New World

As Tatl and I entered the next area, I cautiously took in my surroundings, preferring to avoid any more surprises. This room, or abyss I should say, was large and lit by only a few torches lining the walls. Great planks of trees rose up from unfathomable depths, and seemed to support the ceiling of the chamber. From the top of the chamber drooped many large root-like structures, so I assumed we were still beneath the forest. I cast my gaze back downward. From what I could gather from the sparse lighting, I noticed there was very little flooring here—a precarious lattice of wooden planks, some groaning softly beneath my weight as I advanced. I would really have to watch my step.

I began to plod forward with a determination to see the sky again. Tatl kept up with me, lighting the path with her faintly glowing form and we made it to the other side of the area with little difficulty. From this room expanded another hallway. I groaned in annoyance and asked Tatl how much further, being in no mood for games.

"Only a bit further! We're almost into town, that's where the fountain is!"

And so I started walking into the hall when I suddenly tripped over my loose boot. Wait…loose boot? The thing had fit perfectly an hour ago! My heart skipped—was it shock, confusion, or something deeper? The loose fit felt like a quiet betrayal by my own body, a creeping unease curling through my gut. Did that damned Skull Kid put an age-regression spell on me? That would explain the cracking voice I guess.

"Are you alright?" Tatl asked. "You seem to really be having a tough time moving around. You've been tripping all over the place since I first saw you!"

"No I'm not alright! Your friend put some -creak- kind of spell on me!" I shouted angrily. "What did he do?!"

She waved her hands in protest, "I had no idea his mask even had that aura ability. How should I know?" The tiny fairy shrugged.

She tried helping me up by tugging at my tunic. I got back to my feet and tightened the buckles on my boots. Hopefully this fairy knew what she was doing. I would hate to have to buy entirely new clothes, and it was doubtful I would find any Kokiri tailors anywhere near here. Yet at the rate I was going, it wouldn't be long before my tunic and white pants slipped right off.

I peered down the hallway, noticing how mechanical the surrounding walls appeared as gears turned slowly. The shift was jarring—a stark, metallic world of ticking gears and oiled steel replacing the organic hush of the forest. It was strangely comforting, but also alien, like stepping into the hollowed-out chest of some vast mechanical beast. The contrast unsettled me more than I expected, and yet, mechanical devices meant civilization. And civilization meant that Tatl was telling the truth.

As we passed through the clockwork hall, the gears began to turn faster. I noticed a heavy-looking metal door up ahead. I brushed the bangs that fell into my eyes away to get a better look. Wait…..bangs? I didn't have bangs? I usually kept my hair trimmed—always short and tidy to stay out of my eyes, especially during battle. Soft strands brushed my forehead, golden and unfamiliar, stirring a flicker of unease in my chest. Had we really been down here long enough for my bangs to grow out? As I was pondering the possibilities of the passage of time, the large door fully opened with a loud, metallic groan. As if it hadn't been opened in ages...but that wasn't right? The Skull Kid had just  come through here!

Maybe time really does get distorted in this place.  I thought.

I asked Tatl about the subject.

"No, he has a strange ability to move between realms. That's how he does most of his pranking actually." She explained.

"Oh, well that's just great. How am I supposed to even find him, then?" I signed dismay.

"The Great Fairy will know, she's very wise, and powerful! She'll know exactly what to do!" Tatl said in a hopeful tone.

I glanced back at her, and the pixie smirked. But the smile was short lived and twisted into a faint grimace.

"What's wrong?" I inquired, "Can the Great Fairy help me find him or not?"

Tatl tried to encourage me by grinning again.

"Oh totally! But we had better get there soon."

I grimly shook my head and let out a quiet huff of frustration, the mounting strangeness gnawing at my nerves. Every step, every change, every unanswered question—it was all becoming too much. And Tatl, for all her fluttering help, seemed to offer more riddles than relief. I shuffled through the entryway into a massive chamber of turning gears and pulleys. It looked as if we were in an enormous clock! A small stream ran through the center on the bottom floor where we stood, acting as the engine for the entire device as it turned a huge waterwheel. Sunlight streamed in through small windows on the upper floors, and I hoped that's where the exit would be. I noticed a flight of stairs to our left, so I headed that direction. Nearing the stairs, I noticed my tunic was starting to feel even more loose now, just like the boots.

I tightened my belt again, frowning as my fingers found far more slack than before. The leather resisted at first, then slid too easily—like it had been made for someone else entirely. It sagged lower on my hips than I remembered, the looseness stirring a quiet alarm beneath my skin. It wasn’t dramatic, but it was wrong. Subtle. Creeping. A growing mismatch between body and memory. I crouched to pick up my long, green hat, using the moment to adjust the boot straps again.

I peered nervously at Tatl, who was doing her best to look more interested in the waterwheel, avoiding making eye contact with me. I decided to see what her hesitation was all about, noticing that the stream seemed smooth enough to give a somewhat decent reflection. So I walked to the edge nervously, unsure of what I would see, and nudged ever closer. As I leaned down, a lock of blonde hair fell over my eye, feather-light against my cheek. I jolted upright, startled, and let out a sharp, high-pitched squeak—so soft and foreign it made my heart skip.

As the reflection formed in the slow-moving stream, I beheld my face—and a cold, crawling fear crept up my spine. For a heartbeat, I didn’t recognize the person staring back at me. There was something unfamiliar in the shape of my eyes, the softness of my jawline, as if my face were quietly shifting into someone else's. My breath caught, suspended between denial and dread, and I felt the world tilt ever so slightly. My eyes were undeniably a different color now—deeper, more vivid—and as I stared, the subtle softening of my features became impossible to ignore. My face looked younger, finer in structure, and unfamiliar in a way that made something tighten uncomfortably in my chest. The biggest difference, though, was my hair. Blond strands now reached the tip of my nose, drifting in front of my eyes like delicate silk. Without my cap to tame it, the change seemed even more dramatic.

And there’s nothing really wrong with me,  I told myself, clinging to the thought like a shield. Other than the longer hair, that is. I'm fine. If anything, I’m only under a reverse-aging spell! I can deal with that.... I've conquered gigantic monsters as a child—I’ll defeat the Skull Kid as well!

I smiled optimistically—perhaps too optimistically—and proceeded to tighten my boots, dusting off my cap as I stood. The grin felt a bit strained, more armor than emotion, but I clung to it anyway as I climbed up the stairway, trying to convince myself that everything would be alright. On the second floor, I was relieved to see a large set of wooden doors that gently moved in the outside breeze.

"Ok! Let's go already!"

I jumped in surprise, forgetting about Tatl, who was waiting impatiently beside the exit. I still wasn't quite used to having another fairy companion.

"Alright, alright. I'm -squeak- coming!" I replied, ignoring the cracking of my voice as I headed for the big doors.

I stepped outside, shielding my eyes from the bright midmorning sun, and sighed with relief. Finally!  It felt like an eternity ago when last I saw the sun. I took a deep breath of fresh air and looked around, letting the warm and comforting rays of light soak into my skin.

I stood in the middle of a bustling plaza, where the murmur of voices mingled with the rhythmic clatter of boots on cobblestones. The warm scent of baked bread and dry timber wafted from nearby stalls, grounding me in this strange but vibrant world beyond the forest's shadow. Townsfolk bustled back and forth, weaving around construction workers who were steadily building up a tower of wooden scaffolding. I turned back toward the building we had just exited—and felt my breath hitch.

The tower loomed above us, taller than I had imagined. A true clock tower, its brick and mortar body stretched toward the heavens like a monument to time itself....watchful, ancient, uncaring. Its great arms pointed skyward, massive hands marking the hour with solemn grace, as if trying to clutch the sun right out of the sky.

My neck began to ache from staring up at the tower for so long. I finally tore my gaze away and turned back toward the busy construction crew. For a moment, something about them struck me as strangely familiar—like I’d seen their faces before, though I couldn’t place where. But I shook the thought off. I had no time to gawk or daydream.

Tatl was already fluttering ahead, beckoning me with a sharp wave.

"Come on! Hurry up! The Great Fairy is just this way!" she called, her voice rising above the din of the bustling plaza.

I followed her into the crowd, weaving between people, trying not to lose sight of her. The mass of moving bodies made me feel small— too  small. I’d faced giant beasts without flinching, but now every elbow, every jostle made me feel oddly fragile. Maybe it was because I’d lost my weapons. Or maybe it was something deeper.

We left the chaotic plaza behind and entered a quieter part of town. The change was immediate—and welcome. The noise faded, replaced by the whisper of leaves and the chirping of birds. We were in a peaceful park, where bright flowers bloomed in clusters and soft green grass shimmered beneath the midday sun. Trees stood like guardians, their shade offering cool relief from the warmth above. I longed to sit down, just for a moment—to rest, to breathe—but Tatl was already zipping toward the hill at the far end of the grove.

The hill rose gently among the trees, and a stone path led to a cave mouth nestled in its side. Smooth steps guided us upward, and I followed, casting one last glance at the calm of the park before slipping into the cool dark of the grotto.

Almost immediately, Tatl gave a cry of alarm.

The cave opened into a glowing chamber centered around a fountain—a pool of pale, pulsing light. Fairies hovered above the water in a unified swirl, their wings shimmering with a soft pink hue. But something was off. These weren’t ordinary fairies. They moved in eerie unison, their colors uniform, as if they shared a single will. A hive-mind.

“ Great Fairy!” Tatl gasped, flying closer. “What happened to you?!”

In a hundred whispering voices, the swarm spoke as one:

“ The Skull Kid has cast a terrible spell upon me. He shattered my essence. He must be stopped… at all costs.”

Tatl gestured toward me with a hopeful flutter. “This one—he can help! He’s strong, I’ve seen what he can do!”

The pink fairies swarmed me suddenly, circling close. I froze as they examined me with silent intensity.

“ Poor dear,”  the voices murmured. “You too are touched by his corruption…”

I nodded faintly, already feeling the weight of hopelessness pressing down. If the Skull Kid had shattered this  creature of light… what chance did I really have?

“ Restore me,”  they said in perfect unison. “And I may be able to undo what’s been done. As I am now, I can only ease physical wounds. What afflicts you runs deeper than that.”

I opened my mouth to respond, but the world began to tilt. My stomach churned. I stumbled back from the glow and staggered outside, clutching my midsection as nausea overtook me. The moment I hit the grass, the fire returned.

It wasn’t heat like flame—it was something inside me , twisting and burning and reshaping. My spine arched with the pain as my muscles locked and convulsed. I curled into myself, the world blurring with tears as I bit down on my sleeve to keep from screaming.

My bones ground together. My chest tightened. My head pounded like a Goron drum being beaten by giants. And then—silence. The pain stopped as abruptly as it had begun, leaving behind only tremors and ragged breath.

I lay there, gasping for air, my vision swimming. Tatl hovered above me, her soft light flickering with worry. She drew close, and I caught the faint intake of breath as she stared at me.

A chill ran through me. Something in her expression said everything I needed to know—whatever had just happened… it was worse than I feared.

I didn’t move. Couldn’t move. I simply lay in the grass, limbs limp, staring up at the blue sky I longed to see earlier...trying to make sense of the impossible thing happening to my body, to my self .

Chapter Four

A Strange Ally

"It's ok, don't worry..." Tatl comforted, gently patting my head. Her voice wavered just slightly, like a bell pulled taut by invisible worry. "We can fix this, but you've gotta get up! You're the only one who can help the Great Fairy!"

I was still on the ground, lying in the sweet-smelling grass of the park, trying to recover from a painful episode I could only assume was a symptom of the curse. The grass felt soft, almost too soft, like it was trying to cradle me against the weight of my unraveling self. I glanced up at Tatl, who hovered in uncertainty overhead. Despite her attempt at encouragement, her glow seemed dimmer than before.

But she was right. I had to move. Gritting my teeth, I pushed myself up to my knees. My limbs trembled—not from exertion, but from the unfamiliar lightness that haunted my frame. I may have been weakened, humiliated by pain and mystery, but I wasn’t going to let this curse break me. I would end that wretched imp if it was the last thing I did. I was the Hero of Time, not some sniveling, childish weakling!

I braced myself in case the burning returned, then eased up onto my feet. My balance wobbled. I dusted myself off, wiped my eyes, and swatted the stubborn blonde strands of hair from my face. The motion felt unfamiliar somehow—delicate, instinctive. I bent down to tighten my boots again, their looseness now a persistent and mocking reminder that something was not right.

As I glanced down, something else caught my eye—two small bulges had formed beneath my tunic. I tried shaking it out, thinking it might be dirt or debris from all my falls. But nothing dislodged. Frowning, I reached up and prodded one gently.

Soft. Warm. Sensitive.

My heart leapt into my throat.

These... These were part of me.

A small, involuntary cry escaped my lips, childlike and raw. I slapped a hand over my mouth in horror. That sound hadn’t come from me. Not really. Not the me  I remembered. I tried speaking aloud to reassure myself, but the voice that emerged was higher, thinner—pitched like a young boy, on the edge of cracking. Or someone becoming something else entirely. The sound felt alien in my own throat, like a stranger had taken my place. A quiet dread crept in...what if it never returned to normal? What if this voice was mine now??

I stumbled backward, one hand clutching my throat, the other gripping air. The world felt too big around me, too heavy above me.

Why is this happening to me?

No. Not now. I couldn’t let myself fall apart. Not with the Great Fairy broken, not while the Skull Kid ran free. I had to press on. I had to fix this.

I turned toward Tatl, who was watching me with wide, sorrowful eyes.

"You're right. We need to get going," I said in that strange, strained voice, forcing calm into it. "We must restore the Great Fairy. Any ideas?"

"Uhh… I think we should ask around town if anyone has seen any wandering fairies," Tatl slowly replied, her tone cautious.

"Ok, that’s a good plan. I guess we’ll start in this park area. They couldn’t have gone too far from the fountain."

Tatl nodded and darted ahead, only pausing to glance back at me with something unreadable in her gaze. I exhaled slowly, grounding myself with each step as I followed. One foot in front of the other. Focus on the task, not the shifting terrain of my own body.

The sun had begun to dip lower, straying toward the horizon. Golden light spilled across the grass, making it harder to spot the shimmer of fairy wings. The park was nearly empty now—just a few children in matching blue outfits chasing one another through the trees, their laughter mingling with the sound of popping balloons.

Aside from a vigilant town guard watching over the scene, only one adult remained. A thin, sharply dressed man manned a small stall brimming with colorful masks. His face was hidden—crouched low, fussing with the bottom shelves. His movements were strange: stiff, erratic, like a marionette being jerked by a distracted puppeteer.

Despite the oddity, there was nothing overtly threatening about him. And if anyone had been lingering long enough to see a stray fairy, it would be him.

I started walking toward the mysterious man. We silently closed in, my steps light and Tatl's wings discreet, neither of us wanting to startle the man. He didn't seem to notice, and still worked his stall, his back to us.

"Hey, excuse me, sir, have you happened to see a pink fairy wandering all alone around here?" I nervously asked.

He slowly turned toward me. An oddly familiar man with short orange hair, his face gaunt and off-putting, grinned back at me—but something was wrong. His eyes sparkled with an unnatural glee, a little too wide, a little too knowing. The smile didn’t quite reach them, and the way he moved, fluid yet abrupt, sent a quiet chill skittering down my spine.

"You have met with a terrible fate."

"Wha...what did you say?" I whispered, genuinely disturbed. Tatl darted behind me to hide herself from the man's sight.

"A terrible, terrible fate." He continued. "A curse that forces you to change into something you are not. A curse brought on by a very dark and evil mask...yes?"

The man laughed, strangely enunciating his words as if he didn't quite know how to speak proper Hylian.

"I...umm...yeah that's right! How di—"

"Why, it was my mask that did these terrible things!" He interrupted, his face growing dark with anger. "It was stolen from me by a very impetuous creature. A Skullchild nonetheless, yes... And through my foolish inattentiveness, I have caused great suffering here...great suffering indeed!"

I flinched as he gesticulated his long, thin arms around with wild and sudden movements.

"You! I shall assist you...but only if you assist me in helping to restore this world. For it is in grave danger, oh yes it is!"

He raised his hands toward the sky, and a strange hush seemed to fall over the air between us. My gaze followed, hesitant, and I gasped. The sheer size of it—the monstrous moon—filled the sky with a suffocating presence. But it wasn’t just its unnatural closeness that struck me cold. It was the face. Furious, leering, twisted in a scowl of such raw hatred it made my stomach lurch. I felt as though it saw me specifically, as if that furious expression was aimed at my very soul.

That sharp chill creeping down my spine now shuddered through my whole body.

"Soon this world will be no more. Gone! And others are sure to follow. We must get my mask back, you see?!" The man begged in desperation.

Suddenly I remembered where I had seen this man before. He had once sold masks in the Hyrule Castle Marketplace—a harmless, eccentric merchant with a strange way of speaking and a knack for unsettling smiles. But now, standing here under that baleful moon, he seemed like a twisted echo of that memory. And not just him—so many of the people I'd seen in this town bore uncanny resemblances to those I’d known back in Hyrule. Familiar yet wrong, like reflections in warped glass. Was this all a dream? No... it felt more like I’d stepped into a nightmare shaped by memory—something that knew me better than I knew it.

"Ok, we will help you get your mask back! But you have to help us first!" Tatl chimed in. "We need to cure the Great Fairy!"

"The Great Fairy?" queried the Salesman. "What's wrong with the Great Fairy?"

"She's been shattered into pieces!" Tatl exclaimed. "If we don't help her soon, she could die!"

The mask salesman silently pondered, and his hand darted to his chin.

"So you need to find the missing pieces...hmmmm?" He smirked. "I believe I can lead you in the right direction. I have heard that there has been a mysterious light spotted around the southern end of town, yes!"

"Where did you hear that?" I asked, suspicious.

The mask salesman grinned at me. "Why...it is information that often supplies happiness! And happiness is what I distribute! Therefore information is like happiness in itself, indeed!"

"Uhhh...right. That's good enough for now, thank you, sir!" Tatl thanked, flying off along the dirt path. "Come on, Link! I know the way! Follow me!"

I stepped away from the creepy man, and dashed off after the fairy, trying not to trip over my ill-fitting leather boots.

The sun had just set when we neared the middle of town. The hustle and bustle of the city began to die down as people went back to their homes for the night. Bells rang out—some high and melodic, others low and sonorous—announcing the closing of shops with a mournful sort of finality, like the town itself was exhaling after a long day. I was happy to finally get some space; the streets had been tremendously busy. Through eavesdropping along the way, I learned there was an annual festival everyone was preparing for. Oddly enough, it seemed as if no one else had noticed that the moon appeared as if it were screaming in rage, and was looming as if to crush them.

I glanced around at the various shops we passed by, viewing the multitude of items being peddled behind windows. In a very rare instance of materialistic desire, I was envious of those who could afford the items from these expensive shops. I almost wished I could relax, buy some food, and new boots that fit. My (now too large) boots were killing my feet, and a pressure building within my chest was making it difficult to breathe. I was starving and parched with thirst—the aromas wafting from nearby diners sent pangs through my stomach, each scent a cruel reminder of how drained I truly was. My body felt like it was running on fumes, every step heavier than the last. Maybe that explained the gnawing panic in my chest. Maybe it wasn’t just the curse. Maybe the exhaustion, hunger, and creeping disorientation were warping my sense of reality.? Maybe this really was all a dream?

I shook myself out of my fantasizing. This was real. Everything was far too vivid and tangible for this not to be reality.

I focused on Tatl and willed my feet to follow as she led the way through the

winding roads. Eventually Tatl spoke, and I could only assume we made it to our destination.

"Be careful here, Link. Southside is kinda dangerous at night. A lot of thieves and their ilk roam around and do business in this part of town due to the lack of shops and wealthy homes. The guards rarely enter, aside from gate duty."

I flit my gaze around. The buildings were in shambles, their wooden frames warped and groaning in the wind. The air carried the acrid tang of soot and spoiled vegetables, mixing with the musty scent of damp wood and grime, and the roads poorly looked after. There were only a few people around. A shirtless, gaunt beggar miserably sat on an old crate, staring at the dirt, and low class citizens wearing patchwork clothing and worn shoes shuffled back to their hovels. I was thankfully ignored by the retiring denizens. I knew I couldn't handle being robbed right now. Several stars had finally begun to shimmer against the clear, indigo skies of twilight, peaceful and radiant...the exact opposite of how I felt.

"Link! Look!" Tatl suddenly pointed in excitement, bobbing up and down.

My eyes followed her gesture and locked onto a flicker of orange light just ahead—an ethereal flutter rather than the steady burn of a torch. My breath hitched. For a heartbeat, time felt suspended, and a thrill of hope surged through me. Was it truly one of the Great Fairy's fragments? Or was my mind playing tricks in the deepening dark? Tatl and I ran after it with renewed vigor.

As we drew near, I examined the area closely. Just below the rooftop of the decrepit wooden building was a tiny light. It fluttered: definitely not a torch...Yes! Yes, it looked just like the pink fairies in the Fountain! Tatl flew up to greet it, and I saw small flashes of color and heard a faint series of twinkling. Finally, the lost fairy happily flew down.

"Oh thank you! We were so lost until you found us! Please take us home?"

"Ok, let's hurry up and get you back!" Tatl declared. "Then Link and I can go find my brother, and Skull Kid!"

I followed sluggishly after the retreating fairies, hoping that I would get a chance to rest my aching feet when we got back. My body was put through so much today, from the violent dragging through the forest to the debilitating effects of the curse. I still hadn't been able to rest, and I felt the numbing exhaustion seep through my muscles.

It was after midnight by the time we returned to the north end of town. The trek was easy without having to constantly shove through the crowds. I was grateful the park was devoid of people, but the mask salesman had also disappeared.

During the walk through the darkened park, I was stopped by a chubby guard who sleepily asked what I was up to, and where I was going.

"That's none of your business you nosy tin can!" Tatl verbally assaulted the guard, slamming his visor shut. "Go bark up a different tree! Or better yet, go jump off the clock tower!"

The guard, pink fairy, and I were all equally taken aback at Tatl's unexpected outburst. The guard immediately retreated, visibly shaken, and smacked directly into a tree branch.

"Ooomph!"

The loud clanging of steel crashing to the ground muffled my quiet laughter. A reluctant grin tugged at my lips—maybe I was beginning to like this spunky fairy, despite everything. But I forced the thought away. Admiration had no place right now, not when every step forward still carried the weight of the unknown. There was no time for admiration. We still had a job to do, and we made our way to the entrance of the fountain, now lit by the welcoming glow of large torches.

We entered the cave, and the lost fairy excitedly twinkled and rushed into the mass of floating pixies. The multitude of glimmering fairies suddenly shone with a brilliant light that pulsed with rising intensity, casting wild, dancing shadows along the cave walls. The air vibrated with a humming resonance, like the chime of a hundred tiny bells, as each mote of light spiraled into the air. I squinted, shielding my eyes against the radiance as it coalesced into a single, dazzling shape...

Chapter Five

The Great Fairy


The intense light radiating from the figure began to dim, and I saw a large, imposing fairy gracefully emerge. Her presence was ethereal—otherworldly. The Great Fairy's hair cascaded like silken flame, pink and impossibly weightless, drifting as if underwater. She was clothed head to toe in garments woven from living flora: smooth green vines twined around her glittering arms and legs, while blossoms of every color shimmered across her body like living jewels. Atop her head sat a crown of roses, deep and dark as burgundy wine, twisted together like sacred twine. All around her, minuscule fairies danced in celebration, their twinkling wings forming halos of light around the return of their queen. I had seen Great Fairies before—but none with this elegance, this strange and solemn beauty.

"You have done it, young Hero, and you have my eternal thanks. Please, allow me to heal your wounds…"

She extended her hands toward me. I closed my eyes and felt a warm, golden sensation envelop me, flowing over my skin and deep into my spirit. The aches and fears that had clung to me like chains began to fall away. My hunger, my exhaustion, the tension in my limbs—gone. It felt like sinking into a childhood dream, some half-remembered place where I had once felt truly safe. I stood beneath her magic as if in the sun after days of rain.

A few moments later, the energy gently withdrew. I opened my eyes and met her gaze.

"Young Hero of Ages," she said softly, "as I tended to your wounds, I glimpsed far deeper—into the weave of your soul. There, I sensed greatness, and an immense power shining within. But I also felt a shadow: a very strong and dark magic entwining with your essence, warping it." A look of sorrow crossed her radiant face. "I’m afraid I cannot undo what the Skull Kid has done. His newfound power... it is greater than mine."

I turned slowly to Tatl, dismay tightening in my chest. Her glow was flickering red with alarm, and her expression crumpled with helpless terror. I didn’t need her to speak—I could see it in her trembling light. If even this majestic being could not stop what was happening to me, then what hope did we have?

The Great Fairy’s own brow furrowed. Around her, the small fairies flitted faster, chittering in unrest, winding through the plumes of her hair like scattered sparks.

"So... what, I’m helpless here?" I snapped, the words tumbling out harsher than I meant. "I can’t do anything but wait for this curse to finish with... well, whatever  it’s doing to me?"

"You are not helpless, young one," she replied, her voice a chord of calm conviction. "In truth, you are still the most  capable soul in this realm to face the darkness. The path forward will be yours to carve—but carve it you must, for if the Skull Child is not stopped, all life here will fall into shadow."

I lowered my gaze to my feet, but my eyes betrayed me—drawn instead to the delicate weight resting on my chest, and the strands of golden hair brushing softly against my collarbone. I closed my eyes, trying to quiet the chaos in my heart. It would not be her who saved me. If there was any hope of breaking this spell, of understanding what was being done to me, I would have to find it myself.

"Alright….I guess I have no choice. But if I must do this, I'm going to need help." I said as I looked at Tatl.

The white fairy made eye contact and jerked back in surprise, her wings faltering mid-hover as if she, too, hadn’t expected me to reach out. For a moment, hope and hesitation warred inside me—was I really asking her for help, or was I just too desperate to stand alone any longer?

"M-me?" She asked in astonishment. "Why would you want my  help? I'm one of the reasons that you're even in this predicament! That curse must be driving you crazy…"

I stepped closer to her. "I could be going crazy, or maybe this curse is in fact weakening my judgment, but either way...I desperately need help. And I think that you would be my best case support here...You know this place far better than I do."

Tatl just hovered in silence for a moment or two. Then she began quivering, sending tiny trails of glimmering fairy dust tumbling from her wings. A tiny grunt sounded and she nodded.

"Fine...but only  because my brother could be in grave danger….and I might feel a little  guilty about what's happening to you." Tatl's voice rang. "And don't think that we're going to be friends or anything, I just owe you! But ….thanks I guess. Thanks for giving me a chance." She muttered, then smiled at me.

I returned her smile and turned back to the Great Fairy.

"So..." I spoke in my strangely higher pitched voice, "I guess we are all set to go now, although I have no clue on where to start. I really hope you have some kind of idea of how I should proceed?"

The Great Fairy pondered for a second, then snapped her fingers. A troop of her fairy escorts flew up to her face and the Great Fairy nodded to them. The fairies chimed in unison and flew into the back of the cave. The large, opulent Fairy returned her attention to Tatl and I.

"I believe the first place you should investigate is the Star Chamber, just outside of town. There you will meet with an old astronomer named Reton. The moon has been looking very strange and... terrifying, recently. I'm sure that it's a clue to the Skull Kid's whereabouts."

"That old kook?" Tatl twinkled, "He's as crazy as a bombchu on magic dust! How could he possibly help?"

The Great Fairy shot Tatl a look of disapproval and continued.

"First try leaving the town through one of the city's various gates. The Star Chamber is just to the south of Clock Town. If that doesn't work, there's a small group of local boys, outcasts and orphans mostly, that have come to call this Star Chamber their secret hideout. They should know of a special way into the Chamber, but I've been told that only members of their little club are allowed to use it. So I'm afraid that you are going to have to somehow earn their respect...and it likely will not be easy due to how the skull kid's curse is affecting your appearance."

Wait, what? Affecting my appearance?

My breath caught, and I instinctively touched my face, then glanced down at my hands—smaller, thinner than I remembered. A chill crept up my spine. Was I really changing that much? I hadn’t checked my reflection since leaving the tower. The thought that my appearance might already be unrecognizable sent a flicker of panic through my chest.  What did I look like now? I didn't have a chance to ask as the small fairy squad returned, carrying a glistening item.

The Great Fairy took the item and thanked them. She then reached out with her arms once again, and the object drifted gently into my open hands. It was a bow—unlike any I had ever seen. I turned it over reverently. The wood shimmered with a deep sapphire luster, almost as if the night sky itself had been woven into its grain. Etched along its limbs were delicate carvings of roses in various stages of bloom, their thorny stems entwined like a protective bramble. Subtle streaks of iridescent green shimmered beneath the surface, shifting in the light like dragonfly wings. Its grip was wrapped in a soft, supple leather the color of dew-touched ivy, textured like a living vine. The bowstring, impossibly fine, glowed faintly with silvery filaments—like moonlight captured in silk thread. It felt impossibly light, balanced, and somehow... alive in my hands, like it had been waiting for me all along. I looked back up to the Great Fairy, awestruck.

"This bow is amazing !" I said incredulously. "I've never seen such fine craftsmanship!"

"That bow was given to me as a gift long ago, by an old and dying hag from another land." The Fairy responded. "I had helped to heal her soul from an evil that tormented her. She said it would prove to be invaluable when the world was in a diresome state. How correct in her prediction she was…. But I digress. I have a feeling you will be needing it, and that it will serve a more fulfilling purpose with you rather than sitting here, languishing away in this fountain."

I was almost speechless at the priceless gift, and I bowed deeply.

"I will definitely treasure this, and make sure that it is used to its full potential..." I vowed reverently.

I flourished in farewell, and prepared to leave with Tatl. The Great Fairy wished us luck, and prayed that I succeeded in my quest as we exited the fountain.

We departed from the cave entrance, and I noticed that dawn was quickly approaching. The sun, just barely peeking over the edge of the horizon, was blood red, signalling a stormy day. I looked toward the area where the mask salesman would be, half-expecting to see his crooked smile and erratic gestures still occupying the stall. A flicker of unease passed through me when I saw the space empty—just flattened grass where his stand had once been. Had he moved? Disappeared?

Odd…  I thought. He may have moved to a more profitable part of town .

I searched around the park for any signs of the salesman or troop of boys the Great Fairy mentioned, but it must have been too early as the park was silent and empty. I asked Tatl to go search one side of the area, while I looked around the other. A faint breeze was beginning to whisper through the trees, bringing a damp chill upon its breath. I walked around the area, looking for any sign of those kids or the mask salesman, but turned up with nothing. Ready to move the search on to another part of town, I called out to inform Tatl and started to walk towards the park exit.

"There's no one here! We need to move on to another area and find that mask salesman! Then we'll give him an upda—AAAARRGHH!" I screamed, my body seizing in sudden agony. An unbearable fire lanced through my spine like wildfire, sharp and twisting, as if my very bones were rebelling against me.

The awful burning sensation was back—stronger, sharper, more agonizing than ever! I doubled over and fell to the ground, clenching my stomach as a cry tore from my throat. Tatl must have heard, because she was at my side in seconds, darting frantically through the air like a panicked hummingbird.

My body began to jerk in violent spasms, twisting uncontrollably. That same aura from before, the one that had wrapped itself around my soul, writhed within my skin like a molten serpent. It felt like something inside me was dissolving—changing—becoming something it was never meant to be. My limbs buckled as if they were being crushed in a vice, and my face felt like it was being gnawed on by ravenous Wolfos. I could barely breathe. Streams of salty tears spilled from my clenched eyes, and black spots blossomed behind my lids as consciousness began to fade.

"Hold on!" I choked through gritted teeth. "Hold on!"

At last, the boiling agony began to ebb, the tearing faded, and my writhing stilled. I lay limp on the dew-soaked grass, every breath labored. I blinked open my eyes and tried to rise, but my muscles refused. I tried again, dragging my arms beneath me. Tatl tugged at my tunic's collar with surprising strength, helping me shift from sprawled on my belly to resting on my knees.

I pushed up shakily—and face planted directly into the grass. Thankfully, it was softer than stone.

"Ummm... maybe you should take it easy for a second," Tatl suggested, gently tapping my forehead. She pointed toward a tall oak tree behind me. "There's a tree right there you can lean against."

I groaned, a cough bubbling up from deep in my throat. Something dislodged—like a blockage coming loose—and I hacked repeatedly. I raised a hand to rub my neck and felt the gauntlet slide clean off. My breath caught.

My hand was... wrong. The fingers were slender, longer, more delicate. My nails were smooth, clean—nothing like the calloused, dirt-caked warrior’s hands I knew. I flexed them. They obeyed, but it felt foreign. Disconnected.

What was happening to me?

"Now now..." Tatl’s voice was soft. "It’s going to be okay. Stay calm… Let’s just get you to that tree."

I stared at her, speechless, then gave a reluctant nod. I began to crawl toward the oak, my limbs still shaking. Silken strands of strawberry-blonde hair kept falling into my eyes—long enough now to sweep past my shoulders. I angrily blew them away. Just get to the tree,  I told myself. Don’t look. Don’t think. Just move.

Tatl hovered at my side, pulling gently at my sleeve as I dragged myself the last few feet. I slumped against the rough bark, muscles trembling with exhaustion. I felt like I’d run a thousand miles through fire. Tatl was panting, wings fluttering erratically, but she managed to pat my head with a breathless, encouraging touch.

"There! -pant, pant -  We made it," she wheezed. "Just relax... for a second."

Supported by the tree, I finally dared to look at myself. I raised my right hand, turning it over, studying it. Reddish-blonde hair drifted into view again, and I caught a lock between my fingers. It was silky, smooth... too soft. Too real.

I yanked.

A high-pitched yelp burst from me. "Owww!" I gasped.

Tatl winced. "Yeah, you shouldn't do that. Pulling on long hair tends to hurt."

I shot her a scowl, but her expression softened with apology.

"Okay, okay… I’m sorry. That came out a little harsh," she muttered. "I just don’t know how to react. I’ve never seen this before." She hesitated, then added, "Buuut... as much as I’m sure you don’t want to hear this… I think you may need some new clothing."

I looked down. My Kokiri tunic now hung from my body like a bathrobe several sizes too large. And... the lumps I’d felt the day before had grown. Round. Full. Soft. Real.

I turned away, flushed with embarrassment, hiding my face behind my hair.

"Umm… look. It’s...uh... starting to get brighter," Tatl said hesitantly. "Soon people will be out and about. We really should find you something to wear. I think Clock Town has strict laws about human nudity in public… and... you’re just barely skirting those laws. Uhh… no offense."

I glared at her, too mortified to speak.

"Okay, how about this: I’ll go try to find something for you to wear while you return to the Great Fairy’s fountain and wait. That way you won’t attract any unwanted attention, and I can figure out our next move. What do you say?"

I rolled my eyes and used the tree for balance, Tatl once again tugging at my hand to help. I managed to rise, legs wobbly as pudding. My first step slipped—my foot slid right out of my boot—and I would have hit the ground again if not for Tatl and the tree catching me.

My white cloth pants nearly slipped down with it. I yanked them up with a furious tug and growled under my breath. Enough. I kicked off the remaining boot in frustration.

I really liked those boots. Sturdy, reliable, practically indestructible. Perfect for swordplay and travel. But... I couldn’t wear them anymore. Not like this.

Tatl fluttered down to gather the boots and fallen gauntlets. I took a steadying breath and tested my balance again. My legs felt slightly stronger—enough to walk.

And so, with nothing fitting, everything changing, and the sun rising behind us, we made our unsteady way back to the fountain…

I didn't know what awaited me there...but for now the next step was all I could take.

Chapter Six

Twisted Misfortune

I shambled into the Great Fairy's shelter with Tatl cautiously following behind, ready to lend a hand if I started to fall again. Dark, foreboding clouds had blotted out the rising sun, and the wind shifted, bringing the scent of rain with it. As the first droplets fell, a chill crept beneath my tunic, making me shiver—it wasn’t just the cold, but something deeper, like the world itself was holding its breath. Thankfully, we arrived at the cave opening just before the drizzle turned heavier. Tatl helped me along to a corner where I pressed my back to the wall and slid down the smooth stone to sit. Tatl dropped the boots and gauntlets she’d been carrying beside me, and quickly dashed outside once more. I weakly turned my head to glance at the fountain. The Great Fairy had disappeared and only a few small, pink fairies fluttered around the spring waters. A damp Tatl returned moments later, dragging the Great Fairy's luxurious gift behind her and releasing it a few feet away from me. The luminescent blue bow lightly thudded against the hard cave floor.

"Ok huff , I'm pretty sure the Great Fairy has gone to get some much needed rest...lucky..." Tatl twittered, out of breath from hefting my things around. "Just stay here pant  for the time being, and I'll be back with some clothes that will hopefully fit you whew  better."

She took a deep breath then circled around me, likely trying to figure out what size I needed. I just stared at my feet, trying to distract my panicking mind from having a meltdown. My emotions churned like a storm tide—anger crashing into despair, giving way to grim determination, only to drown again in suffocating hopelessness. My chest ached with each breath, and a faint tremor had taken hold of my limbs, as if my body could barely contain the turmoil within.

"Link, look at me!" Tatl shouted, breaking through my despairing thoughts. "It's going to be alright! We'll find the Skull Kid, you'll defeat him and reverse the spell on you, and then everything will be back to normal!"

The fairy's words filled me with a tiny bit of encouragement, but not like before. I hesitantly looked at her twinkling form. She looked just as scattered and uncertain as I felt, so I tried my best to crack a smile and answered.

"Ok…." was all I could mutter.

I sat there in stunned silence, my fears having been validated. The voice that escaped my lips was unmistakably feminine—light, fragile, and entirely foreign. I balled my fist and, rather unwisely, pounded the hard rock wall. Spurts of pain shot through my thin wrist and I clasped it with my other hand, gently massaging it.

Tatl cast a worried glance my way before turning to the exit, then fluttered off on her hunt. I didn't know how long I'd be waiting here, but I hoped that she wouldn't be gone for too long. Curse or not, I still had to stop the Skull Kid. What he had done...what he continued to do, was deplorable. I remembered Epona's fate and quietly mourned her loss. I hadn’t allowed myself to fully feel it until now—there had been too much chaos, too much pain. But in this quiet moment, the grief settled like a stone in my chest. I thought back to when I first saw her—a tiny filly, nervous and unsure, only trusting of Malon, the ranch owner's fiery daughter. I had rescued her from Ingo’s cruelty, and from that day on, we had been inseparable. She was more than a companion—she was a piece of home, a piece of me , from a time before the world began to unravel.

Now, with my very identity unraveling, her absence cut deeper. She represented a tether to the life I once knew, and now that tether had snapped. A single tear traced down my cheek, carrying with it the weight of everything I was losing.

Thunder rumbled outside the cave, shaking me out of my memories. The low growl of the storm felt like an echo of my own turmoil, reverberating through my ribs like distant thunder made flesh. The smell of fresh rain drifted in on a chilled breeze, brushing past my skin like ghostly fingers. I hugged my arms tightly around my uncomfortably protruding chest and curled my legs in close, trying to trap what little warmth lingered in my bones. My loose clothing clung to me, still damp from the dew-soaked grass, and my bare feet and hands tingled with cold. I reached up, half-hopeful, to take my cap and warm my hands inside it—only to find it gone. Who knew where I’d lost it? I didn’t really care anymore. All that mattered was that Tatl returned soon with something warm, something that fit.

The fairy fountain shimmered quietly before me, its waters rippling with rain droplets that echoed through the cave in a rhythmic lullaby. The pink fairies were gone, leaving behind only the whispers of the breeze and the soft gurgle of the spring. Time seemed to stretch endlessly. It felt like hours had passed since Tatl had left. My patience was wearing thin, and the chill was starting to bite deeper. I couldn’t just sit still any longer.

I rose unsteadily and walked toward the fountain, each step slow but more confident than before. My strength had partially returned during the wait, though my body still felt foreign. The stone floor was slick and cold under my bare feet, sending shivers up my legs. I wrapped the damp tunic tighter around my body, seeking warmth where there was none.

When I reached the fountain, I leaned over it slowly, apprehension knotting in my stomach. The surface revealed a stranger—dark green eyes wide with disbelief, pale fingers rising in sync with mine to touch a face I barely recognized. My once angular features had dissolved into gentle, unfamiliar curves. A dainty nose. Fuller lips. A rounded jaw. My hair was no longer the short blonde mop I remembered—it was now a thick, reddish-blonde curtain falling just past my shoulders. Even my ears had changed, now longer and sleeker, angled like delicate blades.

This wasn’t a disguise? This was...me?

I stumbled backward from the reflection, breath caught in my throat. Anger flared up through the fear, hot and righteous. I was not going to let this stop me. The Skull Kid wanted me weak—wanted me confused, lost in my own skin. But I was the Hero of Time. I had slain beasts twice my size and faced gods in shadow. I had stared down destiny before and carved my own path. I would return to Hyrule. I would marry Zelda, raise warriors, and pass down the strength that had brought me this far.

But then a terrible thought surfaced. I reached between my legs in a panicked reflex.

Relief washed over me.

Everything was still there. I silently thanked the gods and, bolstered by the reassurance, returned to my corner with a steadier step.

Tatl arrived just as I settled down, dripping wet and panting with effort.

"Ok! pant  I think I found something whew  that might fit you!" she gasped, her glow flickering with exertion.

She dropped the knapsack and collapsed beside it, wings twitching.

I rushed over, concerned, but she waved me off.

"Don't worry about me! huff huff  Just hurry and put those on before your tunic falls off and you blind me with your disgusting human body!" she barked. "Trust me, I won't look! huff  Just put the dumb clothes on already!"

Rolling my eyes, I knelt beside the bundle and opened it. To my surprise, Tatl had managed to piece together a decent outfit—and miraculously, everything was dry. There was a dark brown cotton tunic, long and loose around the neck, a pair of snug black pants, small brown fingerless gloves, a dark green cloak, and supple deerskin boots.

After checking that Tatl was still catching her breath and not peeking, I undressed quickly, avoiding my reflection in the stone. The tunic slipped over my head easily, soft and oddly comfortable. It hung to mid-thigh and clung to my new, slimmer frame. The leggings were more of a struggle—tight, itchy, and pulling unkindly at leg hair I still had—but they were warm. I adjusted them with a wince.

"You can look now, Tatl," I said, my voice painfully light.

Tatl took to the air again, circling me.

"Huh... not bad. I'd say I did a good job." She smirked. "Okay, now put the rest on and let's get going."

I slipped into the boots, their tops reaching just below my knees. They were snug but solid. The cloak, though damp on the outside, was lined with soft fur that instantly warmed me. I wrapped it around myself and re-fastened my old belt and pouches.

"How do I look?" I asked while sliding on the gloves.

Tatl tilted her head and shrugged. "It'll do. But hold still, you're a mess."

She zipped around my head, tugging and twisting until my hair was pulled into a tight ponytail, leaving a curtain of bangs to frame my face.

"Okay, done. Go check it out. But, uh... brace yourself. You've changed."

"Don’t worry… I already saw," I murmured, and walked to the fountain again, stumbling in the awkward weight of a new body.

The outfit wasn’t half bad. The cloak matched the tunic surprisingly well, and despite the snugness of the tights, the ensemble felt... wearable. My hair now sat neatly in a ponytail, though the bangs still fell annoyingly in front of my eyes. Still, I cracked a small smile. Zelda would probably have smiled at me—finally breaking out of the endless forest-green rut of my Kokiri tunic.

But the smile faltered. The thought of Zelda seeing me like this chilled me more than the storm ever could. I hated this—hated the idea of her witnessing what I had become. Would she pity me?
