Look away in horror? Or worse, not recognize me at all? That fear burrowed deep, colder than the cave air. And yet, wallowing wouldn't help. I gritted my teeth, forced a grin, and made a ridiculous face on the fountain’s surface, hoping humor could ward off the shame.

"Hey loverboy! Why don't you just marry yourself already?" Tatl teased, her voice laced with nervous humor.

I sighed and shook my head. It could’ve been worse. I could’ve been turned into a tree.

At least I wasn’t completely  female... not yet.

But there was no telling how far the curse would go.

Tatl buzzed impatiently, nudging me toward the exit.

I grabbed the Great Fairy’s bow and slung it across my back. With one final look at the empty fountain, I turned and followed Tatl out into the storm.

It was time to find the Skull Kid—and if I was to end this nightmare, I had to start now...before it consumed me completely.



Chapter Seven

Unexpected Complications

The sky was still dark with brooding clouds when we exited the fairy fountain, although the rain had ceased for the time being. I still couldn't see anyone around, but I heard the whooping of children playing in the distance. A chill breeze rustled through the rain-soaked trees, tussling my now tied-back lengths of hair. I heard Tatl's fluttering wings come up behind me.

"Oh thank the gods it stopped raining!" she twittered in glee. "I hate the rain. It may not be a big deal to you humans, but for fairies it's like flying through a rushing river!"

I looked up to the clouded skies, trying to spot the sun to get an idea of what time it was. My heart sank like a stone into a well. Looming between the parting storm clouds was the moon—closer than ever, its monstrous face twisted in rage. Its glare pressed down like a curse etched into the sky. The mask salesman hadn't been exaggerating. This world was truly doomed... and I was trapped inside its fate.

"Link!" Tatl shouted. "Look at the—"

"I know, I know! I saw it." I cut her off, the higher pitch of my voice still jarring in my ears. "We need to find a way to the Star Chamber, and fast!"

Tatl quivered and nodded. "Ok ok... ummm... I'm pretty sure it's located just outside of town."

"That's a good start. Let's hurry!"

We rushed away toward the park exit, off to find a town gate. The drenched dirt path through the park was slippery with wet mud. The mud sucked at my boots with each step, cold and thick like river sludge, clinging to my legs and slowing me to a crawl. I tried to keep up with Tatl as she led the way, but the slog dragged me back.

"Hey, slow down!" I called to the retreating fairy. "These boots weren't made for trekking through mud!"

Tatl reduced her speed. "Geez, do I need to drag you again?"

"Ughhh really? I do not need your sarcasm right now! I'm having a bad enough day as it is."

"Right... sorry." The fairy muttered and flew to my side. "Ok, how about this. You let me ride on your shoulder and I'll point you in the right direction. That way I'll be able to finally rest and you won't have to struggle to keep up?"

Right. I had forgotten that Tatl had lugged around my heavy gear all morning. The poor sprite must have been exhausted.

I bobbed my head in agreement and stopped to extend my shoulder toward the white fairy.

"Alright, I don't see why not if it makes it easier on both of us. Hop on."

Tatl plopped down on my shoulder and sighed with gratitude, happy to finally get a chance to rest her exhausted wings. Her tiny weight was barely noticeable, but the quiet companionship it offered grounded me more than I expected. For the first time in a while, I didn’t feel entirely alone in this shifting, unraveling body.

"Ok. So go towards that corridor over there," she began, pointing to one of the passageways we went through yesterday. "Then we're going to make a right and follow that road all the way down to the west side. That's the nearest gate that leads out of town."

I followed her instructions and began noticing something strange around the city. Instead of the hustle and bustle we dealt with the day before, the streets were nearly deserted. It could have been the rain, but I doubted that a little bad weather would prevent people from preparing for a huge, annual festival. The locals must have noticed the diresome moon in the sky as well. I sensed a general uneasiness while plodding through the wet streets... The few people I did see moved quickly, heads down, their voices hushed as if afraid to draw attention from the sky.

The stillness set me on edge. It felt like the whole town was holding its breath.

The town was ripe with fear.

As we entered a new district and neared one of the gates, I noticed it was protected by an ironclad, spear-wielding guard. A large visor covered the soldier's face, but his stance betrayed his state of mind. The gate guard was nervously clutching his weapon with a white-knuckle grip, staring up at the sky. The man's behavior confirmed my suspicions. If others had noticed the moon, then widespread panic wasn't far behind. I was running out of time, but if the Star Chamber was nearby, I could quickly find the Skull Kid and stop him before chaos ensued.

I approached the gate, preparing to leave the town, when the guard moved to block me.

"I'm sorry, er… young lady," the guard said, hesitating for just a beat too long before raising his hand to stop me. "It's far too dangerous for a kid like you to be journeying outside the town right now."

I opened my mouth in anger and scowled at the mocking soldier, momentarily forgetting my cursed appearance.

Young lady! Who was he calling young lady?!  I thought bitterly.

"Hey, what do you mean we can't leave? We've got a bow!" Tatl berated the guard. "We can defend ourselves just fine!"

"I'm sorry, orders from Captain Viscen. I can't allow anyone out of the city walls unless they have official business or are perceived to be capable of defending themselves." The gate guard turned his helmeted head upward. "The mayor sees the moon as a bad omen, and all sorts of monsters have been seen prowling the fields just outside the walls. He ordered the captain to cordon off all the town gates."

"I am  capable of protecting myself!" I retorted, exasperated. "And I do have business with the astronomer at the Star Chamber! So get out of my way!"

I was rapidly losing patience, and his snide "young lady" comment had made me more irritable. I felt my cheeks flush with anger and balled my fists, preparing for a fight. Tatl tugged roughly on my ponytail, making me wince from the sharp pain. Yet, the gesture reminded me that I really did look like a young lady. Tatl knew what I was thinking... I relaxed my fists and slowly eased my tense shoulders.

Was I really so changed that even a trained guard mistook me for someone else entirely?

"I'm not letting you pass, ma'am. Now back off before I'm forced to detain you for disrespecting the law!" the unfazed guard said firmly.

I glared and reluctantly pulled away from the gate. I couldn't believe my bad luck! Ever since I encountered that Skull Kid in the woods, my world had been completely turned upside down, and things were only growing steadily worse. I should have never left Hyrule… I should have just stayed and settled down to a normal, quiet life like Zelda advised me to do six years ago. Maybe this was the Goddesses' way of punishing me—not just for leaving the royal family, but for leaving her. For choosing the sword over her hand.

I reached up to massage my temples in frustration. I would just have to find another way to the astronomer. I had no other choice if I wanted to return to Hyrule, as well as back to my original form….

"Ok Tatl...do you have any other ideas?" I sighed, turning my head to glance at the little white fairy riding along my shoulder.

Tatl thought for a second, then replied, "Didn't the Great Fairy say something about a secret route to the Star Chamber? That a group of kids use for their hideout?"

I wearily shrugged. "I dunno... I guess I remember her saying something like that? There was a lot on my mind at the time. I suppose we'd better go look around and try to find this gang then."

Tatl twinkled in agreement, her glow pulsing softly as she settled once more on my shoulder. Her tiny form was encased in a delicate orb of white light, faintly tinged with lavender, her wings shimmering like dew-soaked glass. She looked like a fragment of starlight brought to life, flickering with restless energy even at rest.

We walked down the well-maintained street. This part of town was more refined than the other districts we passed through. The cobblestone streets were clear of debris and better maintained, with fewer potholes lying about. Neat rows of small, groomed trees and flowers filled the medians centered in the roads. Large decorative buildings lined the immaculate street, statues and fountains gleaming at every corner. The few people meandering around the lavish district wore fancy, expensive-looking clothing and carried themselves with reckless arrogance. There were far more armored soldiers patrolling this area as well. Quite a few of them guarded a red-bricked, slate-roofed building with several well-nurtured plants positioned beside the doors. A tin and copper sign hung above the door, reading "Mayor's Office." A few of the haughty passersby gave me curious looks. I tried to ignore them and started walking away from the irritating residents.

"Link! Look over there!" Tatl excitedly chimed. "Could that be one of the boys the Great Fairy mentioned?"

I glanced in the direction Tatl gestured. A boy, probably just entering his teen years, ducked inside one of the alleyways between buildings. I swiftly and silently followed behind, trying not to be obvious. The alleyway was cast in shadow, but there was still enough light to see clearly.

The kid wore a dark blue jacket and a round, matching blue cap, with grungy brown hair peeking beneath it. I couldn't quite see his face, but noticed he had a large number "twelve" stitched onto the back of his jacket. He had on grubby tan shorts and his shoes were badly worn. The boy was a short distance down the alley when he suddenly turned around a corner, and I rushed to pursue before I lost him.

The passage the young lad disappeared through was empty—somehow, he was nowhere in sight. I ran to catch up to him further down the way when I heard a voice ring out.

"Hey! Why are ya followin' me?"

I halted, startled by the voice, nearly causing Tatl to fall from my shoulder. I turned to see the kid pointing a loaded slingshot up at my face.

"Are ya crazy, girly? Or just askin' for trouble? I don't care much for being chased around!" the gang member threatened.

The kid was half my height, maybe a smidgeon taller than my waist. His face was covered in filth, and he looked to be missing a tooth in his mischievous grin.

"I'm not here to cause trouble, kid," I cautiously explained. "I'm just following you because I needed to ask you something."

The boy lowered his slingshot and tilted his head in curiosity.

"Yeah? Here to ask me handsome self on a date, eh?" the street urchin winked. "Sorry, not interested... you're far too fancible for my tastes, heh heh."

A flash of anger and revulsion crossed my face. If my face could melt off from secondhand embarrassment and fury, it probably would have right there in the alley.

"Urrghh...look you little twerp, I—"

"We need to get to the Star Chamber!" Tatl interrupted. "The Great Fairy sent us!"

Confusion showed on the kid's face. "The Great Fairy? Uhhh... well... I'm really not allowed to tell you about the secret hideout…" He motioned for us to come closer and whispered, "But if the Great Fairy told you, then you must have a good reason to know. But only club members are allowed in…"

I closed my eyes and shook my head. If I was going to find the Skull Kid, it looked like I’d have to play by their ridiculous little "club" rules.

"Alright alright, fine…" I sighed. "How do I join?"

The dirty scamp laughed, "Haha only boys can join, girls aren't allowed! Well…. normally anyway. But if the Great Fairy sent you, we could maybe make an exception. She's always taking care of us Bombers, so you must be somethin' special."

The words hit me like a slap. Only boys? My stomach twisted with bitter irony. Just a few days ago, I wouldn’t have thought twice about qualifying. Now, standing there in this unfamiliar body, hearing the word "girl" thrown at me again and again—even in jest—it stung worse than I expected. I clenched my jaw, swallowing the surge of heat behind my eyes.

"Okaaayyy? So can I join?" I asked once more, losing my patience.

"It ain't my place to say. I'm pretty new myself." The young punk shrugged. "You'll have to talk to our leader. That's pretty much the only way you can get in."

"Where do I find him?"

"Uhhh, he should be practicing his blowdart gun on the roof of the Stockpot Inn." He put a grimy finger against his lips. "But you didn't hear that from me!"

And with that, the disheveled rascal gave me one last wink and dashed away. I rolled my eyes and faintly smiled. The kid had spunk. I had to give him that.

Tatl called out to thank the receding figure, then faced me. "Ok, let's hurry to the Inn, Link! It's not far."

The tiny passenger tugged on my hair again, causing me to recoil.

"Owww! Would you stop that? I'm not a horse!" I shrieked as I walked back to the main street. "That does NOT feel good! How would you like it if I pulled on your wings?"

"Alright alright...fine, I'm sorry." Tatl chuckled, stroking the ponytail between her tiny fingers. "It's just that it feels so nice and soft! Like spun silk... it's kind of mesmerizing." Her voice held a snarky flicker of affection, a note of levity that made the moment feel strangely warm despite the chaos surrounding us.

"Yeah well, maybe you wouldn't find it so funny if I just tore your wings off…then we'll see who's laughing." I muttered under my breath.

We rejoined the cobbled street just as the drizzle returned, light and whispering. My boots splashed quietly through shallow puddles as we moved, trying to blend into the background. I stopped to watch the few townsfolk shuffle to their destinations, trying to retreat from the coming rain. A large, balding man dressed in farmer's overalls suddenly barged into me, knocking the breath out of my lungs.

"Watch yourself, you clumsy runt!" He shouted angrily and stalked off towards the gate.

Tatl had been flung off of her perch and I was kneeling on the ground, winded and gasping for air.

"You watch it, you donkey's anus!" Tatl bellowed out after him. "Link! Are you ok?"

She flew down to check on me as I tried to regain my composure. My eyes were welling with tears from the strength of the blow. I felt the fairy's tiny hand gently pat my back while I struggled to breathe.

"Urrghhh— gasp —what is WITH THESE PEOPLE?!" I wheezed, rage swelling alongside the ache in my ribs. "If one more idiot so much as looks  at me the wrong way, gasp  I swear I'll beat them senseless!"

It seemed like the entire town was full of jerks, I started to consider not saving them after all. But it was not in my nature to give up so easily. Whether I liked it or not, I had to help them.

"Hey hey, don't worry about them right now. They're all worthless cowards. Don't waste your anger on them. Just focus on finding Skull Kid. Then you can do whatever you want."

I righted myself and put a hand on my chest to steady my nerves. Feeling the soft, bulbous tissue that had developed there, I immediately removed it in disgust. I looked up at the sky, where the dim silhouette of the sun was nearing the horizon, casting long, cold shadows that seemed to stretch toward me like grasping fingers. The deepening dusk pressed against my senses, stirring a restless urgency in my chest—each passing moment another inch stolen by the encroaching night. Seeing that we were quickly running out of daylight, Tatl and I set off towards the inn...



Chapter Eight

The Stockpot Inn

Tatl hid beneath my heavy cloak, guiding me toward the Stockpot Inn as a rising sense of desperation twisted in my gut. My legs ached, my thoughts were fogged with exhaustion, and I clung to the thought of shelter like a lifeline. Just stepping inside—even if only for a moment—felt like the only thing keeping me upright. The billowing clouds had kept their promise—rain now poured in sheets, relentless and cold. Heavy winds howled through the streets, rocking the signs and shuttered windows that clung to the sides of shops and homes. Rivulets of water streamed down the mostly empty cobblestone roads, and the sun had already begun its descent behind the storm-darkened horizon. I was soaked to the bone, my recently grown hair plastered annoyingly to my cheeks and brow. The new deerskin boots squelched with each step, cold water trapped inside. It was getting colder by the minute, and I prayed we’d arrive at the inn soon. I doubted the leader of the so-called "Bombers" would still be there—if they were even real—but at this point, just being indoors felt like a victory. The added possibility of sleeping in a dry, comfortable bed stirred my aching legs to move faster. I hadn’t slept in a bed since I left Hyrule weeks ago.

"Left—now!" Tatl shouted, nearly drowned out by the wind.

I quickly turned down one of the narrower side streets. This neighborhood was packed with restaurants, small shops, and a couple of dimly lit game houses. A few determined customers milled about beneath umbrellas, their faces obscured by hoods and shadows.

"Which way next?!" I called, squinting through the downpour.

"It should be just up ahead! Right around that corner! I hope..." replied the soaked and slightly panicked fairy.

A jagged bolt of lightning split the sky, casting the alley in stark white light for a heartbeat. A bone-rattling crack of thunder followed, loud enough to make me flinch. The shock reverberated through my ribs like distant thunder made flesh, clashing against the cold tension already curled tight in my chest like a coiled spring. I quickened my pace, my breath steaming in the chilled air.

Slowing as I turned the corner, not wanting to slip, I finally spotted our destination through the downpour. The Stockpot Inn stood tall: a three-story structure of timber and stone. A large, weatherworn sign—"Welcome to the Stockpot Inn"—swayed slightly above the entryway.

Grateful for the shelter, I jogged the last few steps and reached for the handle. As I pushed the door open, a wave of warm, sweet-smelling air spilled out, thick with the scent of old wood and dried herbs. I huffed droplets of water off my nose, sighing in relief. Tatl zipped from beneath my cloak with a grumble, shaking off rain like a disgruntled cat.

Inside, the flickering light of wall sconces bathed the room in a welcoming glow that clashed tenderly with the storm still howling outside. The warmth seeped into my chilled limbs, softening the knots of tension in my shoulders, and for a fleeting moment, I felt like I had stepped into a dream—a fragile pocket of peace where the world couldn’t reach me. I trudged to the front desk, boots squishing and dripping with each step. A thin, auburn-haired woman with gentle blue eyes looked up and smiled warmly.

"Hello there, welcome to the Stockpot Inn... Oh my! You poor dear, you must be soaked to the bone! Are you by chance looking for a room? Normally we would be booked solid due to the Carnival, but with everything going on in Termina... well, not many have come to celebrate this year. Lucky for you, we have quite a few rooms available."

My face lit up. "Yeah, that would be great! Are there any fireplaces in the rooms?" I asked, already imagining my gear drying beside a crackling hearth.

Another rumble of thunder echoed in the distance.

"Oh, we have three rooms that come with a fireplace. But I’m afraid they’ve all been reserved... Hmm, let me double-check." The woman ducked beneath the counter and pulled out a large, leather-bound guestbook. Behind her, a decorative wall clock ticked steadily, the sound a soft anchor against the storm outside.

She flipped through the pages. "Hmm... yes, unfortunately, those rooms do appear to be taken... Mmm, wait just a moment. Oh! It looks like we do have one deluxe room available. The guest who reserved it never showed up—but they paid in advance."

She looked back at me with a hint of softness. "You poor dears look like you've had a terrible day. If you'd like, I'd be happy to give you the room—free of charge. It’s already paid for, and in these dark times, I think it’s the least I can do."

"Yes, oh thank you so much!" I exclaimed, my voice a mix of gratitude and disbelief. "You’re a lifesaver, ma’am!"

Maybe my luck was finally starting to turn around.

"Oh, you may call me Anju, dear. Allow me to grab your keys. I’ll be right back."

She disappeared into the back and returned moments later holding a ring of keys.

"Alright, if you’ll follow me, please? I’ll show you to your room."

I trailed after her, boots still squelching, leaving faint puddles behind on the polished wood floor. Tatl hovered beside me, her glow reflecting in little halos across the damp surface. I paused for a moment, instinctively searching for a towel or rug to wipe my feet, but Anju turned on the stairs and caught my hesitation.

"Oh, don’t worry about that, sweetie. I’ll clean it up after I show you to your room."

Candles flickered in lanterns lining the stairwell, their flames bobbing with each passing gust from the old drafty halls. The steps creaked under our weight, worn smooth by decades of use. Though aged, the inn was immaculately clean—its air tinged with the earthy scent of dried sage and cedar, and the faint, rhythmic creaking of wood beneath our steps gave the space a sense of living history, like the house itself breathed in time with the storm outside. Its bones weathered, but clearly cared for. Dust-free corners, fresh-swept floorboards, and serene paintings of forests and rivers gave it the quiet charm of a place loved by generations.

A loud crack of thunder shook the halls as we reached the top floor. Anju ignored the sudden burst of sound and turned left, down the small corridor, and stopped at the first door we came to.

"Your room is here..."

The innkeeper unlocked the door and gestured through to the room.

I walked through the doorway and examined the room. The chamber was cozy and inviting. A clean, welcoming bed with neatly folded blankets sat on the left side of the room. A lantern burned brightly on the bedside table, cheerfully illuminating the space. A small, unlit fireplace was built into the wall opposite the bed, its mantel finely crafted and smooth to the touch.

"Wow, this is pretty snazzy!" Tatl chimed. "I rarely ever get to stay in places like this!"

"Oh yes, we do try to accommodate our guests as much as we can," Anju replied, handing me the room key and sauntering over to the fireplace, striking a match to light it.

"Now then, checkout is usually at noon... but with all these bad omens plaguing the city, you may stay as long as you like. Something tells me you need the peace of mind. The gods only know that everyone needs a reprieve from hardship every once in a while..."

The pretty innkeeper suddenly expressed sadness in her eyes, and she seemed to grow distant, as though she stared across a salt-grey sea of silent burdens. Apparently I wasn't the only one having a bad day. I tried to smile to comfort her and show my immeasurable gratitude.

"Thank you so much, Miss Anju! I won't ever forget your incredible kindness. If there's anything I can do for you, let me know... and I will do all that is in my power to help," I vowed.

"Oh... no, don't worry about me... I must apologize, I've been a terrible hostess!" Anju blinked, snapping back to reality. She bowed courteously and backed out of the room. "Please let me know if there's anything else you need, Miss...? I'm so sorry, I don't believe I caught your name! How impossibly rude of me!"

"Ummm, it's... it's Link," I hesitantly answered and pointed to Tatl, who had already begun to warm herself by the fire. "And that's Tatl over there."

"Ah, those are good names," Anju nodded. "Well then, please excuse me. I truly hope you both have a relaxing and pleasant stay. Again, welcome to the Stockpot Inn."

The door gently closed behind the retreating hostess, and I listened to the faint tapping of her shoes fading into the distance. I looked down at my drenched outfit and unslung my bow, placing it beside the cleanly folded blankets. I was still freezing, the fabric clinging to me like a second skin, and I was quite anxious to be dry. I moved toward the warm, inviting glow of the fireplace. The fire crackled merrily, casting dancing shadows on the walls and sending out gentle waves of heat that clashed with the tension still curled deep in my muscles.

"Aren't you going to change out of those clothes? They're still drenched, you know? And you're dripping all over this nice floor!" Tatl voiced. "Go ahead and take them off. Don't worry, I won't look. I have absolutely no desire to see naked humans."

The white fairy turned her back to me and covered her eyes. I sighed and reluctantly began to strip down. My gloves and cloak plopped to the floor. The moisture had glued the wet shirt and pants to my skin, making them difficult to peel off. I tried my best to look away as I wrestled with the leggings and boots, not wanting to see my feminized figure. Every brush of fabric against my skin reminded me that this body wasn’t mine anymore. I had begun to feel sick to my stomach and didn't want to think about the curse. I just wanted warmth and a quiet night to recover. I could find the club leader in the morning, though I knew I was on a tight schedule. Since darkness had fallen, the kid had probably turned in for the evening anyway.

Pulling the soaked shirt over my head, I was finally free of the cloying garments. I moved to the bed to grab one of the blankets and unfolded the thick, wool comforter, draping it over my shoulders. Its scratchy warmth dug deep into my bones like the sun after a storm.

I huffed and plucked the dripping pile of clothing off the floor. I carried them over to the fireplace and positioned them so that they would effectively dry off. The fire hissed softly in greeting as the droplets sizzled away. Satisfied, I shifted over to the cushioned chair and sat down, wrapping the blanket tighter around myself.

"Ok Tatl, you can look now," I informed, and scooted the chair closer to the crackling fire. Finally feeling its warmth wash over me, I smiled with fragile relief. Aside from the lingering nausea and weariness, I was at ease—if only for a moment.

I relaxed, taking in the strange circumstances of the past few days. This was one of the most stressful series of events I had ever experienced. I had never once, in my wildest dreams, thought that I would be turned into a girl. And not just turned—becoming. Piece by piece, and hour by hour. The fact that this was really happening, and what the near future might bring, unnerved me. What if I never returned to normal? What if I changed even more?

Tatl interrupted my downward spiral into a helpless panic by breaking the silence.

"So, what about the leader of the Bomber Gang?" Tatl asked, "Did you already forget?"

"No, Tatl, I didn't forget... I just need to sit down for a bit. I'm still trying to get used to this body, and my insides are still churning from this morning."

"Aww come on, it can't be that bad," she replied, her wings twitching with amusement. "Besides, it could be worse. Skull Kid could have just turned you into a Deku stick! Or a cow... heheheh."

"Shut up. Just... just don't... not right now..." I muttered, a tired smile threatening to form. As much as I hated to admit it, her ridiculous jokes were starting to grow on me. Her teasing felt less like mockery and more like... comfort, in its own backwards way.

"Pfft... fine. Can't take a joke..."

I ignored her and shut my eyes. Tatl was definitely the first fairy I'd met that had so much... personality. I was a bit curious about why she was so abrasive, but I was mentally exhausted. My eyes closed, and the warmth of the crackling fireplace pulled me into its cocoon. The flickering glow clashed against the cold still clinging to my limbs, the tension coiled in my muscles refusing to melt. That comfort, faint as it was, lulled me into a deep, but restless sleep...

I dreamt of returning to Hyrule, of riding a horse through vast fields of wind-blown grass wavering underneath a clear, blue sky. I gallantly rode in triumph towards the glistening castle town in the distance. Flocks of birds passed by overhead as I spurred the horse beneath me to gallop faster, but no matter how fast it went, the castle seemed to recede ever further into the distance.

Suddenly, the wind slowed. The sky grew dark, and a huge shadow eclipsed Hyrule Castle. The birds scattered. A chill surged through me. I turned my gaze upward, and my heart froze. The moon—its monstrous, furious face leering—was plunging toward the castle. Its eyes wept silvery tears and its surface pulsed with molten cracks. Screaming erupted from behind the white ramparts as it plummeted faster and faster!

Time slowed. The land held its breath.

Then—it smashed into the earth with cataclysmic force. Waves of dust and fire rolled across the land like a storm of death. I was thrown from the horse, the shock wave hitting me like a giant’s fist. I hit the ground, gasping, and scrambled to my feet, trying to flee. But the wave caught me. I was swallowed in a maelstrom of debris.

I clenched my eyes against the clouds of ash. The air burned in my lungs. Then—

Suddenly it wasn’t ash anymore. I was choking on hair.

Massive tendrils of hair lashed all around me—silky, shining, and alive. They wrapped around my limbs with serpentine grace, tangled in my mouth, forced their way down my throat. I tried to scream, but the strands pressed deeper, muffling me, smothering me. The air smelled like lavender and rot. My arms were pinned. My legs tangled. Each movement only dragged me deeper into the silken prison.

No sword. No voice. No self. Just silk and silence.

Darkness overtook me. Somewhere, far away, someone called my name.

"Link!"

The voice was urgent, desperate, calling out again and again. But I was sinking, drowning in this fibrous sea. I reached one final time, my fingers stretching toward the light—

— and then, I was swallowed whole.



Chapter Nine

Dawn of the Final Day

My eyes snapped open and I screamed in panic. The contents of my stomach lurched up into my throat and I keeled over, vomiting a stream of clear fluid beside the chair. Tatl frantically twinkled over me, reaching down to try to hold my hair back while I dry heaved, then slumped back into the chair, weak.

My forehead was damp with cold sweat, and flecks of vomit dotted the wool blanket, still bundled around me. The fire in the fireplace had died to smoldering embers, but the room was still brightly illuminated by the bedside lantern.

"Link, are you alright?!" Tatl cried in shock, releasing my hair. "You were tossing and turning in your sleep, mumbling something about hair."

I wiped my mouth on the blanket and groaned, still nauseous, and feebly nodded in response to Tatl. "Uggghhhhh...yeah. I think I'll be fine. I just had a... terrible nightmare. No big deal. What time is it?"

"I dunno, probably not yet dawn...are you sure you're ok?"

I leaned up and looked at the fairy. I felt a little off balance, but I repeated myself.

"Yes, I'll be ok. Thank you for your concern though..."

"Pfft, I wasn't concerned! I just want you to be able to beat the Skull Kid is all," Tatl sneered.

I rolled my eyes and sighed. It was not easy to get a read on Tatl. It was as if she had a switch that flipped from prickly and sarcastic to nurturing and kind.

"Ok sheesh! Sorry I said anything..."

I muttered and attempted to stand, but fell back into the chair with an unexpected shift of balance. Was I suddenly changed even more?

"Uhhhh...Tatl? Did I go through more...changes?" I asked, not wanting to check myself.

Tatl drifted close to my face to study my features, then she quickly looked away.

"No, I don't think so... uhhh... If anything you look more rested. Still, maybe you should wait before you start moving around, just to calm your nerves." The pixie replied with a nervous glance, but quickly changed the subject. "Oh, but good news! Your clothes are all dry. I threw them onto the bed while you were passed out. They're ready to go, and now that you're up we should be too."

I glanced back to the clothes on the bed and smiled faintly. I knew there was more to Tatl than her abrasive personality and sarcasm—there was a soft spot hidden beneath that sassy exterior after all.

"Oh, how nice of you," I smirked, voice still hoarse. "You know... you've been a huge help to me these past couple days. If it weren't for you... well, I probably wouldn't have lasted this long, so... thank you."

"Now now, don't get all mushy on me. Remember, I'm only sticking around until I'm reunited with my brother!" Tatl lectured, though her light flickered with a quiet warmth. "It's getting late, and we still have to find that gang leader. First things first, you need to get dressed. Can you stand up now?"

"Yeah, I think so. Shouldn't be too much of a problem..." I answered.

I leaned forward and shakily stood, still bundled in the blanket. I managed to find my balance and tentatively walked to the bed. My body swayed after each step, my equilibrium becoming momentarily unstable. My gut was still squeamish, and I felt lightheaded, but I crossed the room to the bed with little consequence.

"Ok, I'm taking off the blanket, Tatl," I warned.

"Trust me, I'm not looking... blech! Do your thing already."

I steeled my nerves with a deep breath and slowly unwrapped the blanket, letting it drop to the floor. A chill wafted across my body and I shivered, wrapping my arms around myself. My palms met soft, unfamiliar curves. My breath hitched, and I recoiled instinctively, horror rising in my throat like bile.

Ample bosoms now rested on my chest—weighty and alien, large enough to disrupt my posture and balance. Even my arms had slimmed to match my delicate hands, their strength stripped away and replaced with elegance I didn’t recognize.

I gasped aloud, my throat tightening as I stepped back. The movement jostled my chest, triggering a disorienting bounce that sent a shiver through my spine.

"Oh gods... no... no no, please nooo..."

I trembled, unable to stop myself from looking. My eyes trailed downward past the unfamiliar mounds of flesh, following the unmistakable hourglass curve of my torso to the place I had been dreading. What had once defined my identity below the waist had vanished, replaced by a smoothness I couldn’t even bear to comprehend.

I slapped a hand over my mouth, stifling the cry that threatened to escape. My breathing turned shallow, panicked, each breath a sharp edge slicing through my ribs. My heart pounded like a war drum, and nausea rose in waves until the room tilted beneath me. I staggered back a step, barely catching myself on the nearby bedpost before collapsing.

The realization crashed through me with the weight of a landslide. This wasn’t just a curse anymore—it was a complete metamorphosis. I had become a woman.

Tears welled in my eyes, blurring the room, and I clutched my face in trembling hands.

"This... can't be happening... This can't be happening!" I rasped, rocking slightly as I tried to keep from falling apart.

Tatl’s voice broke through the fog. "H-Hey, is everything OK over there?" she called out, her voice taut with concern. "Is something wrong? Link?"

I couldn’t bring myself to answer. I was unraveling from the inside out.

"No, no, no, no! Don't! Don't look, Tatl... please... I'm... I'm ok!" I replied, my voice thick with emotion, trying to hold myself together by the thinnest of threads.

"You sure? You don’t sound—"

"I’m fine!" I cut her off too sharply, too fast. The silence that followed was heavy, but she didn’t press me further.

My fingers trembled as I reached for the clothes on the bed. Every motion was slow, like I was underwater—adrift in a body I didn’t recognize, aching to wake from a dream I couldn’t escape.

I managed to find the shirt and threw it over my head, thrusting my arms through the sleeves. Pulling it over my uncomfortable breasts, I let the garment fall to its length below my hips, covering my groin, then reopened my eyes. I reached for the tight black pants next with shaking hands and quickly pulled them on over my now smooth legs. The leggings were much more comfortable now, and far less constraining. My legs must have lost even more muscle mass...along with the hair that once covered them! The tight pants were snug and form fitting along my now dismally flat waist.

A few tears fell upon the bed, and a few strands of, noticeably more auburn, hair dangled before my eyes. I swept a hand over my face wiping the tears and hair away, and quickly snatched one of the light deerskin boots. I lifted my foot to slip it inside and managed to get it halfway through, when I suddenly lost balance. I couldn't catch myself and yelped as my rump painfully crashed to the hard wooden floor.

"Link! Are you alright!?" Tatl exclaimed. She gasped and sped over to me. "What hap ...?" The fairy inspected me closely, and surprise filled her face as she realized that the curse had fully run its course. "Ohhh...I see...I'm sorry. Are you...ok though?"

"N -no..." I sobbed uncontrollably, finally overcome by despair. "L -look at me! What do I do now? Why is this happening to me?!"

Tatl didn’t speak at first. She hovered close in gentle silence, her glow dimming to a soft shimmer. After a moment, she gently said, "Ummm... maybe you should lie down on the bed... just for a minute. Catch your breath."

I let out a bitter scoff between gasps, clutching at the boot I’d dropped. "Lie down? Are you joking? Right... because there's no way I'm going to save myself now, huh?"

"No, that's not what I meant..." she said quickly, fluttering closer. "Look, it’s not over yet! We can still change you back—and save my brother, OK? All we gotta do is find your instrument."

"Yeah... because that’s going to be so simple now," I muttered, swiping at my cheeks with the back of my glove. The tears had slowed, but the sting remained.

Tatl hesitated, her voice quieter. "Not really. Not unless you want to be that way forever. Are you... going to be okay? Do you need some time?"

"I'm fine. Or... I will be," I snapped, forcing the words through clenched teeth. My voice trembled despite my bravado. "As soon as I totally destroy that masked, impish idiot. This is only a temporary setback!"

There was a pause, then a cautious flutter from behind. "Umm... well. If you're sure you're okay... we should probably be on our way. I don’t think we have much time left. I was woken up by the earth quaking just before you started talking in your sleep."

Her concern wasn’t lost on me. She didn’t push further. Just floated there, giving me space. And strangely... that helped.

I gave a stiff nod, wiping the lingering tears on my sleeve. Sighing, I slid the boot fully on and rose to my feet, wincing at the dull ache still blooming in my tailbone. I sat back on the bed to finish dressing, slipping on the second boot and shrugging into my cloak. After tugging on my fingerless gloves, I glanced around the room, my eyes landing on the crumpled mess near the chair.

I scooped up the blanket I had used, tossing it over the puddle near the chair. Thankfully, there were no signs of vomit—just water and tears. I silently thanked the Great Fairy's magic for quelling my hunger. Anju didn’t deserve to clean up after me. She already carried too many burdens.

I flinched suddenly as a sharp tug jolted the back of my head.

"Owww! Tatl! What did I say about doing that?!"

"Hold... still, Link! Your hair's a disaster again!" the fairy chirped, her tiny hands working through my tangled locks. "Just let me... fix it... THERE! All done, you big baby."

I shot her a glare, rubbing the sore spot while she smugly tousled my bangs and floated back with a triumphant hum. I raised a gloved hand to my face and shook my head. She really could be a pain… but she stayed. And that meant something.

Despite everything, I gave her a faint smile.

"Let's just get going," I muttered, pulling my bow from the bed and slinging it across my back. "We have a long day ahead."

I turned down the lamp, wiped away what remained of the mess, and gave the room a final once-over. Satisfied, I locked the door behind us as Tatl hovered beside me, her glow steady and quiet.

We made our way back downstairs when we suddenly heard a loud crash coming from the first-floor hallway. I dashed downstairs and through the hall in the direction of the clatter. Upon hearing Anju's voice, I halted. It sounded like she was talking to someone.

"Jim! Why are you always causing trouble?! Don't you think we have enough going on right now? Put that ridiculous thing away and clean up your mess!" An exasperated Anju scolded.

"Hey, don't yell at me, I'm just trying to learn how to protect us! You never know when a weapon will come in handy. Especially after the moon falls and the survivors are fighting for food and water!" a prepubescent boy defended.

I inched closer to see if I could try to peek at whom Anju was speaking to.

"You need to stop with these awful fantasies of yours. It's going to get you into even more trouble with mother. And if the moon does fall, well... there likely won't be anyone left...so stop being a brat and just grow up, Jim!"

Had I been paying attention to the floor, I would have noticed the loose floorboard jutting up. But instead, I caught it with the toe of my boot and stumbled forward, trying to cover a surprised whoop. They noticed me anyway, and the conversation stopped.

"Hey, who's out there!" the boy challenged into the hall. "Show yourself before I give you a dart sandwich!"

"That's enough, Jim!" Anju chided. "It's ok, don't be frightened. Jim has more bark than he does bite..."

I reluctantly stepped from behind the corner. Anju was with a clearly related redheaded boy half her size, who pointed a long blowgun at me. They stood in what I presumed to be the inn's large kitchen. Pots, pans, and tiny ball-pointed darts littered the black-and-white tile floor. A fire blazed in the oven, with a kettle boiling on the stove that was full of...something. Various vegetables were strewn across a table opposite the room. Anju and the boy were beside a large island table that sat in the middle of the room, with knives stuck into the wood.

"Oh! Miss Link! I'm so sorry if we woke you!" Anju exclaimed.

"No, no, I was... already awake," I assured, trying to compose myself. "I was just coming down when I heard voices and..."

"And what? You always go snooping in other people’s business, lady?" Jim scowled, arms crossed defiantly.

Anju narrowed her eyes. "Mind your manners, you degenerate child! This is our guest and she will be treated as such."

She turned back to me with a sigh. "Please don’t mind him, Miss Link. This is my kid brother, Jim. He can be... difficult. I hope no offense was taken?"

"No, it’s alright, ma’am, really," I replied gently. "I just wanted to make sure everything was okay."

Anju softened. "Oh, everything’s fine, thank you. And how did you sleep, my dear? If I may say so, it looks like a full night’s rest did wonders! You almost look like an entirely new person."

I gave a weary smile, brushing a damp strand from my forehead. "Yeah… an entirely new person..."

The words tumbled out before I could catch them, soft and haunted. Something cold settled in my chest, like a secret only I could feel. Anju’s eyes flicked toward me, brows knitting with concern. I forced a shaky grin, trying to push away the weight curling in my gut.

"But uhh yes! The room was lovely. I passed out the moment I sat down. Thank you again for your kindness! It really means a lot."

"No trouble at all, Miss Link. I just wish I could say the same for my rude brother." Anju reached out and firmly gripped Jim’s red shirt, giving it a meaningful tug.

“ It's fine, really. I've dealt with much worse since coming to this town...trust me. But we had better be going. There's a lot to do, and we're running out of time. Thanks again!" I waved and turned to walk out.

"Oh hey, cool! You have a bow?" the young boy shouted with wide-eyed excitement, practically bouncing on his heels. "That's awesome! Can I see it?"

"Leave her alone, Jim, and clean up this mess! Now!" Anju snapped, casting him a sharp look from behind the counter.

I turned around, both Anju and I frowning at the boy, whose enthusiasm visibly deflated. "No, I'm very busy. I need to find a way to the Star Chamber as soon as possible. Playing games is only going to set me back even further."

Without waiting for a response, I turned and started toward the exit, Tatl zipping ahead like a streak of impatient light.

"Hey, wait!" Jim called, sprinting after me. "Did you say the Star Chamber? I can show you how to get in—I know a secret way!"

I halted mid-step, and he nearly crashed into me. I turned with narrowed eyes. "A secret way in? Riiight. Let me guess—you’re one of the 'Bombers,' too?"

He puffed out his chest proudly. "Ha! You're looking at their leader, lady."

I raised an eyebrow. "Seriously? I was kinda expecting someone a bit... older."

"Psshh, we don't let old grown-ups in the club. Or girls, either, usually... but you don’t seem like most girls. You’ve got that... vibe. So maybe I can cut you a deal—not club membership, but if you want into the Star Chamber, I can get you there."

His casual jab landed deeper than I expected, stinging like salt in a wound I hadn’t realized was open. I stiffened, forcing a sigh through clenched teeth and rolling my eyes in practiced deflection. "Fine. What's the catch?"

Jim grinned like a fox who’d just found a chicken coop. "You gotta prove you can use that bow. I’ve got some targets up on the roof. If you can hit them, I’ll show you the secret tunnel. Deal?"

I crossed my arms and gave him a flat, tired stare. "Why do you care if I can use it? If you want me to prove I’m tough, I could just throw you through a wall."

He barked a laugh. "I like your style! But nah, what would that prove—besides that you can toss a kid? If you hit my targets, that means you’ve got skill. And that means you’re cool enough to be shown the way."

I glanced at Tatl, still hovering at the end of the hall with her arms crossed and glow pulsing like an impatient lantern. She caught my eye and gave a lopsided grin, the kind that said "well, what’ve you got to lose?" I let out another sigh, this one laced with reluctant amusement, and reached out to shake Jim’s hand. "Alright, deal. But don't get cocky, kid. I'm still deciding whether you're annoying or charming."

"Cool! Follow me!"

Jim burst down the hall and bounded up the stairs with the energy of someone who’d just downed a whole jug of Lon Lon Milk. Tatl and I hurried after him, her wings trailing sparkles of light as we moved.

As I followed the enthusiastic boy, I noticed a large white number stitched boldly onto the back of his red shirt: a proud and defiant "1." It reminded me of the filthy street urchin we’d run into yesterday—his shirt had worn the number "12" in faded, crooked stitching. Jim's crisp, prominent digit made his position as the leader obvious. I didn’t understand these childish rankings and rituals—maybe it was all pretend. Or maybe, in a world constantly threatened by a falling moon, even pretend things needed structure.

We reached the top floor quickly. Jim skidded to a stop in front of the last door at the end of the hallway, practically vibrating with excitement.

"Okay, it's right here. I’ll have to set everything up first, so hang tight till I come get you. It’ll just be a minute!"

He disappeared inside, leaving the door swinging shut behind him. I caught a narrow glimpse of the eastern sky just beginning to pale. The sun hadn’t risen yet, but it wouldn’t be long. That gave me some hope—I still had daylight left to find the Skull Kid. But not much.

A few moments later, the door swung open again.

"Okay, everything’s all ready. C’mon, let’s go!"

Tatl and I stepped out onto the roof and were greeted by the scent of wet shingles and the sharp tang of morning air. Jim led us toward a large brass bell suspended in a weathered wooden frame. Around the rooftop, water-stained balloons were tied to small rocks, their colors dim in the gray-blue light. The inn rose higher than most buildings nearby, offering a broad view of the horizon—though it was a view quickly consumed by the ever-lowering moon.

Its grotesque face loomed above like a weight pressing down on the world. Even this high up, I felt smaller than ever beneath it.



"They say it's going to fall tonight," Jim said. "Is that why you want to go to the Star Chamber? To get front row seats?"

"No... I just... Look, what do you want me to shoot?" I replied, not really in the mood to explain myself to a kid.

"Whatever... just shoot those balloons and I'll show you the way in."

I nodded and unslung the bow from my back. My fingers curled instinctively around the polished grip, admiring the artistry in its elegant, swirling inlays. The grain of the wood shimmered faintly, catching the overcast light like it remembered battles of ages past. I gave the silver-flecked string a tentative tug.

"Wait a sec, where are your arrows, lady?" Jim asked, squinting up at me.

Arrows? Blast it! I had completely forgotten to look for arrows with all the chaos of the last few days. My heart sank, but I masked it with a confident bluff.

"Don't worry about them—I know what I'm doing. Just testing the tension."

I lifted the bow, drawing the string with a quiet breath. To my astonishment, as if summoned by will alone, a glowing shaft of light shimmered into existence, neatly nocked and ready to fire. The arrow pulsed faintly with a magic heartbeat, delicate and fierce.

"Whoa! No way!" Jim gasped. "You have a magic bow?!"

"I guess I do," I murmured, still stunned. I turned my gaze back to the balloons, steadying my grip. "Okay... let's see what this thing can really do."

I narrowed my focus, clearing my mind. The world stilled as I exhaled slowly and released the shot. The radiant arrow sliced through the air, trailing starlight, and struck the first balloon dead center, popping it with a satisfying bang that echoed like triumph.

"That was awesome! Do it again!" Jim cried, bouncing on his toes.

I smirked and took aim again. Another breath, another shimmer of light. Two more arrows sang through the sky, bursting the remaining targets in glowing explosions. The bow thrummed softly in my hand, as if whispering approval.

A deep wave of satisfaction rippled through me. It felt good — right —to fire a bow again. Like I had reconnected with something sacred. Like a piece of myself had returned after days of being lost, warped, twisted into something I am not.

"That was AWESOME! YOU'RE AWESOME!" Jim shouted, practically vibrating with excitement. "I gotta say, you have totally earned your passage through to our hideout!"

"Well, it's about time, kid!" Tatl sputtered impatiently, her wings buzzing with restless energy. "Let’s get a move on, then!"

"Well, it's about time, kid!" Tatl sputtered impatiently, her wings buzzing with restless energy. "Let’s get a move on, then!"

"Well aren’t you just full of cheer today. Calm down, fairy—it’s right this way!"

Jim backed away from the roof's edge with a few quick steps, then sprinted forward and vaulted across the gap to the next building. The jump was clean, his landing steady, and the streets below remained ghostly and still—darkened storefronts huddled beneath the pale hush of the pre-dawn sky.

"C’mon, let’s go!" he called, hands cupped to his mouth. "What’s the matter—scared?"

I rolled my eyes and re-slung the bow across my back. "Hardly," I muttered, stepping back. With a swift run-up, I leapt the distance and landed light on the balls of my feet. The impact jolted my chest, and I winced. Everything jiggled in a way I was still getting used to. I clutched at my tunic for a moment, then released it with a frustrated breath.

I took a moment to steady myself. I felt faster—more agile than I had the day before—but every motion now came with a heightened sense of self, an uncomfortable awareness that I was still learning to live in. The way my body moved wasn’t wrong exactly... just unfamiliar. Like wearing armor tailored for someone else.

Tatl fluttered across effortlessly, her glow pulsing in rhythm with the breeze.

"Awesome! Gosh, it sucks that you’re a girl—you’d make such a great Bomber!" Jim lamented.

A muscle twitched in my jaw. I forced a smirk. "Pfft... tell me about it," I said, my voice dry. "Every day’s a new adventure."

Tatl let out a sharp snort beside me, and I gave her a look that said, 'Not helping.'

Without answering, Jim pointed to a nearby drain and slid down it with practiced ease, vanishing into the shadows below.

I exchanged a glance with Tatl and shrugged. "Guess we're following the squirrel."

"Lead the way, Bombette," she quipped, and I narrowed my eyes at her before stepping forward.

I wrapped my gloved hands around the edge and slid down after him, the rough metal screeching faintly under my boots. I landed clean and crouched low, just in time to see Jim darting off again toward a narrow alleyway that terminated in a brick wall.

We chased after him, water puddles splashing underfoot—when suddenly, the ground quaked. I stumbled, catching myself against the damp wall as a low rumble rolled through the stone and air like a beast growling in its sleep. Tatl’s glow dimmed slightly as she hovered beside me, eyes lifted skyward in alarm.

"Link, the moon must be causing that! We have to stop the Skull Kid, now!"

"That's what I'm doing, Tatl—but we can't if we don't even know where he is." The ground finally ceased its trembling, and I resumed the chase, boots crunching over broken debris.

Jim stopped at the end of the alley near a junk pile. As we caught up, he gave a crooked smirk and began heaving a wooden crate to the side.

"Okay, it's just this way. You're skinny, so you should have no trouble fitting through here. But don’t tell anyone about this, got it?" Jim warned, glancing over his shoulder. "This is only for people like us to know. I can't make you a member, but I'd say you earned knowing about this secret... not that it really matters much now, huh?"

With the crate moved, I saw a small tunnel—probably an old sewer drain, just wide enough for someone of my new size. I approached Jim and gave him a nod of thanks before crouching to examine the tunnel’s mouth.

"Hmmm... hey wait! Before you go, I... I want to give you this." Jim reached beneath his shirt and pulled out a cloth badge. "This is proof of membership. It's kinda against the rules of the club to let you in... but I’ve thought it over. The rules don’t mean much when the sky’s falling."

He held it out, and I took it from his small hand. It was thick and circular, the image of a blue bomb stitched on white cloth. A little dirt smudged the edges, but it was whole. The weight of it in my palm surprised me. More than cloth—it felt like respect. Recognition. Inclusion. A gesture that, just days ago, would’ve felt ordinary—now struck a chord somewhere raw and hidden.

"Thank you, Jim. This... really means a lot," I said, my voice softening. I held his gaze a moment, then slipped the badge into my belt pouch with care.

"Hey hey, don’t go all emotional on me now!" Jim teased with a grin. "You’ve earned your spot... well, unofficially, anyway. Just don’t tell anyone. I’d get chewed out for letting a girl in the club."

"Look at you lowering your standards to our level! Honestly, you're going to make me blush, tough guy," Tatl said with a mock sigh, her wings flickering with mischief as she tugged on my cloak. Her tone was light, a small offering of humor to ease the heaviness of the moment. "Come on, Link. Let’s move before you start crying too."

I chuckled faintly, casting Jim one last grateful look. He gave a lopsided salute, all bravado and scrappy courage. Crouching low, I slipped into the tunnel. The crate scraped back into place behind me with a finality that echoed louder than the wind. Darkness embraced me, cool and damp, swallowing the light behind like a memory fading into shadow. Each step forward echoed in my chest—not fear, not courage… just resolve. The unknown waited—and so did my fate.



Chapter Ten

By the Moon and Stars

The dark passageway reeked of rot and runoff. The remnants of yesterday’s storm had left the tunnel drenched, water pooling in crevices and dribbling from the low ceiling in slow, cold droplets. A sharp, rank stench clung to the air—mold, stagnant water, something else decaying in the shadows. I could barely breathe without gagging.

Tatl flitted ahead, her glow faint and wavering, casting nervous shadows that danced across the dripping stone walls. The squeaking of rats echoed distantly, occasionally punctuated by a wet shuffle I tried not to identify. Her tiny form weaved through the narrow crawl space with ease while I slogged after her on hands and knees, gritting my teeth with every cold splash beneath my palms.

The tunnel was tight—so tight I doubted my original body would have even fit. That thought landed strangely in my chest. The only reason I could  squeeze through was because of what I'd lost… or gained. My new frame was narrower, more compact. Feminine. My long brown tunic was already soaked through, clinging to my curves beneath the forest-green cloak that trailed behind me like moss dragged through a stream. The brown fingerless gloves I wore were damp and gritty, and the black tights did little to protect my knees from the rough stone. My soft deerskin boots—once sleek and supple—were now caked in sludge and soaked to the seams, the tops flopping slightly around my thighs with every awkward shuffle forward. I had been crawling for what felt like hours, my breath shallow, the air thick and sour.

Suddenly, my fingers brushed something damp—and furry.

A high-pitched squeal erupted as the creature bolted, its slick body slapping across my hand before vanishing into the dark.

"AGHH—ugh—goddesses!" I recoiled violently, biting back a full-body shudder. The cold cling of fur still lingered on my skin.

"How are you doing back there?" Tatl called, her voice echoing faintly through the stone throat of the tunnel.

"I'm... urgh… fine," I grunted, though my voice cracked from the strain. My knees were bruised, my arms aching, and a headache was blooming behind my eyes from the foul air and the claustrophobic press of the tunnel.

"Ok... hang in there. I think I see a light just up ahead," she said, sounding unsure.

"Unngh, good… Hopefully that means more space," I muttered, dragging myself forward with a grimace. "I really need to stand up. And this place smells like something died, came back to life, and died again."

Tatl scoffed, but sure enough, I saw a torch flickering like a beacon in the darkness ahead. I felt the ground beneath me gently begin to slope into a shallow decline, and I slid down toward the light. The space around me finally expanded out into a large corridor. I stood up, shaking moisture and mud off my hands, and rested them briefly on my noticeably wider hips. My outfit clung damply to my frame—the long brown tunic darkened by the grime, its hem brushing just above my thighs. My green cloak hung sodden and heavy down my back, water dripping from its edges. The black tights beneath were soaked and streaked with filth, hugging the slim curves of my reshaped legs. My soft deerskin boots squelched with each step, the once supple leather now misshapen with water and muck. I stretched my cramping spine and sighed with relief, then bent down to massage my sore knees.

"Feel better?" Tatl teased with a sparkle in her voice. "That looked like a really  tight fit for you. Just think! You would've gotten stuck in there with your old bulky boy-body, haha!"

"Oh yes... just hilarious ," I deadpanned, rising to my feet and wringing moisture from my cloak. "Keep laughing and I’ll cram you in a bottle and trade you to a shop for a wooden shield. At least that way I’d get some  peace, and a more useful companion."

Tatl clutched her chest as if mortally wounded. "Oof! Low blow! And here I thought we were bonding. Come on, admit it—this sleek new bod's getting you into places old you never could!"

"I’d trade every 'advantage' for my real body back," I muttered, adjusting my damp tunic. I crossed my arms over my chest, fingers unintentionally pressing into the soft curves I still hadn’t gotten used to. The sensation made my stomach twist. "I’d rather not have these , thank you very much. Besides..."

I sighed and dropped my hands. "If I still had my original form, I could've just walked through the damn front gate."

"Ughhh, fine, whatever..." Tatl huffed, flipping in midair. "You're such  a buzzkill sometimes. Just trying to lighten the mood! This place could be worse."

"And you’re  welcome to stay down here in this...ugh...smelly sewer if you love it so much," I snapped back, trudging after her. My voice echoed off the tunnel walls—high-pitched, strained, unfamiliar. It mocked me like some other version of myself had stolen my place.

Without warning, the earth shuddered beneath my feet. I staggered, catching myself against the slick stone as another tremor groaned through the ground. The walls moaned around me, the vibrations crawling through my bones.

As the rumbling faded, I let out a shaky breath I hadn’t realized I’d been holding.

"Link! This isn’t a spa day! Save the beauty rest for after we stop the moon!" Tatl barked from ahead, her glow flickering like an impatient candle.

I swear I'm going to pull her wings off...  I thought darkly, scowling as I resumed my squelching march down the sewer path.

I plodded on for a few more meters, stopping at the edge of a waterway. The narrow canal spilled over into a deeper basin, its surface reflecting the flickering light of a torch perched atop a cubic stone island rising from the center of the fetid pool. The air was thick with the stench of stagnant water and mildew. Though the torch looked deceptively close, the jump required to reach it seemed longer than any I’d attempted before. Tatl hovered above the stone platform, her wings casting tiny ripples of light on the surrounding walls.

"C'mon! Just hop across, it's not that far!" Tatl called, her glow dancing in encouragement.

Well, I've come all this way,  I told myself. I can't turn back now!

I backed up a few paces, took a deep breath, and broke into a run. I leapt from the edge, feeling an unexpected surge of grace and lightness in my stride—perhaps a strange benefit of my newly changed form. I soared further than I’d ever thought possible, landing on the stone block with a jarring thump. The impact made my chest bounce painfully, drawing a startled grunt from my lips, but I managed to stay upright. I turned and looked back in awe. That had definitely been the furthest leap I’d ever made.

"Nice job! For once you're actually light on your feet!" Tatl praised with a chuckle. "Think you can make it to the other side?"

She gestured toward the far end of the waterway. Beyond the dark ripples, the tunnel resumed—grey stone walls and a low ceiling funneling toward a sharp turn. Another torch flickered at the bend, its dim glow casting spidery shadows across the floor. I nodded, shaking out my shoulders.

"Yeah, I think I’ve got one more in me."

"OK, I’ll go on ahead and wait for you," Tatl chimed, zipping through the dank air and disappearing toward the next landing.

Tatl paused beside the flickering torchlight, hovering just above the ledge to ensure I'd landed safely. I took a deep breath, wanting to show off a bit, and sprinted toward the gap. Launching from the island ledge with a burst of energy, I tucked into a forward flip midair—twisting through the gloom like a ribbon on the wind. My soft deer hide boots struck the stone floor with a muted thud near the water’s edge, and I let out a breathless laugh of triumph.

"Pfft... show off," Tatl muttered, though I caught the amused twinkle in her glow. "Let’s move on before you sprain something."

I rolled my eyes and waved her off with a half-smile, striding confidently down the corridor. The dark stone walls curved ahead, and faint glimmers of light began to flicker against them. The ambient torchlight caught on the subtle green folds of my traveling cloak, its soaked hem brushing the backs of my knees with each step. Beneath the cloak, my long brown tunic clung damply to my frame, its edge falling just past my thighs. My black tights were still damp and snug against my legs, their fabric streaked with a few smudges from the crawlspace. My soft deerskin boots, supple and silent, squelched faintly with every footfall. Damp air whispered through the tunnel and toyed with the cloying strands of my ponytail as I extended my gloved hands for balance, each step placed with cautious resolve.

We crept closer until another chamber emerged from the shadows. A large, rough-hewn square had been carved into the wall—clearly shaped by hand tools rather than magic. The warm light beyond spilled invitingly through the passage.

I eased forward and peered through the stone threshold.

Inside, the room glowed with a cozy, unexpected charm. Several large wooden crates lined the left wall, worn from age but still sturdy. Piles of old carpets and raggedy rugs lay scattered around, forming a lumpy nest of color in the center. Wooden toys, half-broken but lovingly repaired, sat beside a handful of dog-eared books. A cluster of torches bathed the chamber in golden light, their flames casting playful shadows across the walls—each one covered in vibrant finger-paint drawings. Suns, stars, and strange animals danced across the stone in swirls of blue, red, and green. At the far end, a wooden ladder rose toward another hallway, its rungs polished by many small hands climbing again and again.

I moved into the room some paces, but stopped when I heard a burst of loud snoring. I quickly signaled for Tatl to do the same, and began looking side to side in order to locate the source. I noticed four boys, of various ages, sleeping among the rug and blanket piles. The snoring was coming from a plump kid wearing a blue outfit. He was rolled over on his belly, and had the number "five" stitched to the back of his shirt. This must have been the Bomber's hideout!

Carefully, I stepped between scattered piles of blankets and half-eaten snacks, my every movement deliberate. I doubted the Bombers would appreciate a so-called girl discovering their sacred sanctuary, and waking them up might have led to chaos. Thankfully, the soft, supple leather of my new deerskin boots muted my steps. They hugged just beneath my knees, the flexible hide offering both warmth and silence—far better than the clunky pair I’d worn before. Those would've given me away in an instant.

Each footfall was painstakingly measured, the dim lantern light flickering across the sleeping forms like a warning. My brown tunic brushed quietly against my black tights with every step, and my green cloak swayed gently behind me. Fingerless gloves gripped the bow slung across my shoulder, and for a brief moment, I almost felt like myself again—except for the telltale shift in my center of balance and the weight now subtly distributed across my frame.

At last, I reached the ladder nestled in the far wall. Tatl was already hovering above it, her soft glow casting faint shadows on the rungs. I climbed steadily upward, the ladder's wood cool and slightly damp beneath my fingers. The hush behind me remained unbroken—only the soft, rhythmic snoring of the sleeping Bombers whispered up from below. At the top, I allowed myself a quiet breath of relief and stole one last glance downward. The boys were still deeply asleep, untouched by our quiet intrusion.

We pressed forward.

The passage opened into a chamber that felt like a forgotten observatory dreamt into stone. Warm golden light from flickering sconces pooled in the corners, glinting off burnished brass instruments and dust-flecked glass. Tables brimmed with beakers of glittering, colored solutions and thin-necked flasks that pulsed with internal light. Delicate copper wires curled between vials and glass orbs, while intricate metal tools lay scattered like alchemical relics awaiting their forgotten purpose. It smelled faintly of old ink, lavender, and something bright and metallic—like the memory of starlight caught in glass.

Books were stacked not only on shelves, but also in organized towers on the floor, their leather spines creased with age. One bookshelf sagged under the weight of ancient tomes and coiled scrolls tied with twine, their paper yellowed and curling. Nearby, a well-worn recliner rested by a brass reading lamp, a folded quilt draped over one arm as if awaiting the return of a scholar long in retreat.

To the right, a spiral staircase emerged from the stone floor—made of sun-faded wood dyed a mottled blue, its railings carved with swirling constellations and crescents. It curled upward into shadow, a beckoning ribbon that shimmered with mystery.

"Uhhh... hey Link," Tatl murmured, slowing in the air. "You should go on without me. I think I'm gonna stay down here..."

"What?... Why?" I paused, foot hovering over the first step. Tatl's glow dimmed, her wings twitching with unease as a look of guilt twisted across her tiny features.

"Umm... Well, back when I was with the Skull Kid, we... might  have gotten into some trouble with the astronomer. Messed with his gear a little. And he might  have tried to set us on fire. Look, it's complicated, and I'd really rather not talk about it. Just... go. I’ll wait here."

I blinked in disbelief. "He tried to set you on fire ?"

Tatl shrugged, trying to act casual but failing miserably. "It was more of a... strategic use of a blowtorch. Anyway, bygones!"

Despite myself, I let out a short huff of laughter. It cut through the anxiety, just a little. I looked at her more kindly, the corner of my mouth twitching up. "You'll be okay. Just don’t touch anything this time, pyromancer."

Tatl flickered nervously again, wings buzzing. "Right! Just stay calm, don't break anything, and you’ll be fine! Probably. And hey—if he tries to roast you, remember: duck and cover."

I groaned, but the banter soothed something knotted inside me. I placed a hand on the railing, a reluctant smile tugging at my lips. The thought of dealing with an eccentric old man wasn’t appealing—especially one who may or may not have weaponized a blowtorch—but I’d come too far to hesitate now. One step at a time, I ascended the staircase, my boots echoing softly against the worn wood, each step lit with scattered hues of refracted starlight.

At the top, I stepped into a vast circular chamber that felt like crossing a threshold into myth. The Star Chamber. Above me, images of stars and moons swirled across the curved indigo ceiling—projected from a massive, cylindrical scope mounted on a raised platform in the center of the room. The scope stretched upward, disappearing through the open roof like a pipe organ of the cosmos, reaching for the stars it sought to understand.

The walls were lined with diagrams and sketches of constellations, planetary cycles, and celestial mechanics, all scribbled over in a spidery, near-illegible scrawl. Charts fluttered slightly from the drafts in the room, catching the soft light with every movement.

I let out a breath. There, just to the side, was a door leading out to fresh air. My shoulders relaxed just a touch. No more tunnels, not today. Thank the goddesses.

I shook the exhaustion from my limbs and stepped further into the room. I was too close now to back down. Somewhere in here, I’d find the help I desperately needed.

In the center of the raised platform, directly beneath the towering telescope, stood an old man draped in flowing blue robes that shimmered faintly like starlight. His white beard cascaded down to his chest in wisps, and a pair of round spectacles perched precariously on his nose. Behind him, scrolls and parchment were scattered across a side table, as though he lived entirely among the stars.

That must be the astronomer,  I thought, and approached with caution, noting the way his long fingers nimbly adjusted a dial on the telescope.

The elderly man remained hunched over the scope, brow furrowed in intense concentration. I stepped carefully onto the platform, trying not to startle him. Still, the wooden floor gave a faint creak under my weight. He turned with a soft grunt, eyes twinkling beneath his lenses as he finally noticed me.

"Oh! Hello there, young lady!" he greeted with theatrical flair, his voice echoing slightly beneath the domed ceiling. "Such a rare delight to receive visitors in these days of uneasy stars. My name is Reton, humble observer of the heavens and caretaker of this observatory. And who might you be, starborn wanderer? The Bombers rarely send strangers through their secret way... are you one of their trusted allies?"

"Uhhhh...hi…"

I replied awkwardly, my stomach twisting at the greeting. 'Young lady' again. No matter how many times I heard it, it still hit like a slap—like an echo of something I wasn’t ready to accept. I tried to swallow the discomfort, plastering on a faint smile. Best not to raise any red flags.

"Um... the Great Fairy sent me. She said the moon would guide the way?"

"Mmm... the Great Fairy, you say?" Reton stroked his beard, his eyes gleaming with a flicker of curiosity. "Then surely this is no ordinary errand. Very well, let us see what the heavens reveal."

He turned back to the towering mechanism with a fond reverence, adjusting the intricate array of brass knobs and ivory-inlaid dials. Each click echoed like the ticking of a cosmic clock in the hushed observatory.

"There we go," he murmured with satisfaction. "Come, child, look through this telescope and see what the skies would have you know."

I stepped up to the massive lens... or  telescope  as he called it, and leaned forward, one hand steadying myself against the polished wood casing. The metal eyepiece was cool against my skin. The surface of the moon loomed close in the frame, cratered and brooding, its furious face looming like a cosmic horror. No sign of the Skull Kid—yet.

"How do I move it?" I asked, trying to keep my voice even, though the sheer craftsmanship of the instrument made me nervous to touch it.

"Ah yes, yes—of course," Reton said, gesturing with a knobby hand that trembled slightly with age. "This dial will guide you left and right, and those smaller ones—zoom. Treat her gently, as you would a skittish steed or a cherished harp. She's a bit cranky, but she can dance if you know how to lead her."

I nodded and began to adjust the view. The image shifted as I panned outward, revealing more of the town and the rolling horizon beyond. The sun now blazed high and golden, casting stark shadows that stretched like fingers across the cobbled streets. I realized with a jolt that it must be nearing noon—the crawl through the tunnels had stolen more time than I’d thought.

Clock Town sparkled below me like a freshly polished gem. Wet rooftops glinted as if lacquered in gold, and puddles in the alleys gleamed like shattered bits of glass. Banners snapped crisply in the breeze, their colors bright against freshly scrubbed stone. Flower boxes brimmed with renewed life, their petals unfurling as if the storm had kissed them awake. Chimneys puffed lazy curls of smoke, and the rooftops shimmered with the rain’s last sighs. The town looked reborn, yet beneath the sparkle was a tension I could feel in my bones—a peace too delicate to last.

I adjusted the telescope and swept it slowly over the town’s perimeter, tracing the walls before shifting to the wild world beyond. Towering snow-draped mountains loomed behind the town, rising like frozen sentinels. Their jagged peaks kissed the clouds, stark against the blue-washed horizon. To the west, a great sea shimmered like molten silver, its waves lapping endlessly against some distant unseen shore. To the east, ochre-colored desert canyons sprawled across the land like cracks in a sun-scorched map. Below the telescope’s reach, thick trees stood like silent sentinels, ringing a barren stretch of deforested flatlands that encircled the town like a forbidden wall of green, veiling whatever moved beneath their canopy.

Despite the clarity, I found no sign of the masked Skull Kid. Nothing but the endless world and the impossible weight of uncertainty. I thought back to what Tatl had said—the Skull Kid could travel between realms. If that was true... was he even in this world anymore? The question hung in my chest like stone. I sighed and stepped back from the lens.

The astronomer must have heard me and turned, concern etched in his wrinkled features.

"My dear, what's the matter? Did you not find what you were looking for?"

"No," I said softly, feeling the weight of failure settle on my shoulders. "I couldn't find anything."

"Well, what might you be looking for? Perhaps I could be of some assistance?"

I hesitated, uncertain. But the Great Fairy trusted this man. If she believed in him, maybe I could too. I swallowed and decided to take the risk.

"I'm looking for a masked skull kid. He stole something very precious from me, and I have to get it back."

Reton stiffened. "Wait... Skull Kid? You mean the  Skull Kid—the one who's been wreaking havoc across Termina? The one who nearly destroyed my laboratory?!" His voice bristled with sudden outrage, his hands clenched at his sides.

"Yeah, I think so," I replied cautiously. "Do you think you know where he is?"

Reton stroked his long, wiry beard and hummed, a deep furrow forming between his brows. Then, suddenly, his eyes brightened with inspiration.

"No, but I might have a theory. Have you noticed how the moon seems to be glaring down at a specific point?" The elder shuffled toward the telescope.

I stepped aside, allowing him access to the lens. "No, not really. I hadn’t even considered it."

"Neither had I—until recently," he said, adjusting the telescope with quick, practiced movements. "That dreadful imp has stumbled across something of immense power. He’s been using it to sow chaos across the realm. What if he’s also using it to control the moon? And if that’s true... then maybe the moon’s gaze itself is a clue."

He rotated the dials and adjusted the zoom, the soft clicks of the apparatus punctuating the tension in the room. Suddenly, Reton let out a sharp, triumphant bark of laughter and stepped back.

"Ah-ha! I believe I’ve found his hiding place!"

I darted forward and pressed my eye to the lens. The red glow of the moon’s furious gaze filled my view, and as Reton nudged the telescope to follow its line of sight, the lens came to rest squarely on the top of the town’s ancient clock tower.

"There he is!" I gasped, breath catching with a strange mixture of excitement and dread. "The Skull Kid—he’s on top of the clock tower!"
