"Indeed he is, child." Reton's bushy eyebrows rose in concern. "But what are you going to do? You should be fleeing! That moon will likely fall tomorrow morning, and you must escape to a place far from here!"

"I can't run from this. I… I need to stop him." I stepped back from the telescope, my hands clenched at my sides. "It's the only chance I have to get my life back to normal. Why don't you  run?"

The old man gave a soft, wistful smile. "My life is almost at an end anyway, my dear girl. I'd rather die watching a beautiful, cosmic show of destruction than gasping for a last breath of air on my deathbed."

I stared at him for a moment, surprised by the serenity in his voice. Then I nodded. I understood. If I was going to die, I, too, would rather go out in a blaze of glory.

But unlike him, I wasn’t ready to give up yet.

I turned away, making for the edge of the platform. Behind me, Reton’s voice rang out with a sudden urgency.

"If that wretched imp has the power to bring down the moon, what hope do you have of beating him, my dear?" he pleaded. "You wouldn’t stand a chance—even with that magnificent bow slung on your back!"

I paused, one foot already lifted to leap from the platform, and glanced back over my shoulder. I gripped the bow on my back instinctively, as if drawing strength from its presence.

"Even if I don’t succeed," I said quietly, my voice low but steady, "I have to at least try. Because if I do nothing, I’ll lose everything . And I’ve already lost too much."

A flicker of heat tightened in my throat—half grief, half defiance. For days now, I'd been changing, unraveling, and fighting to hold onto something that still felt like me . But now, for the first time, the path forward didn’t feel like surrender. It felt like a battle worth fighting.

The elderly man chuckled, a warm sound tinged with admiration. "Well... I must admit. You have far more courage within you  than most of the denizens of Termina combined . I wish you the best of luck, child."

I offered him a faint, grateful smile, then turned and descended the winding stairs—now armed with the most important thing of all: not just resolve, but a burning need to reclaim my fate, to right the wrongs Skull Kid has brought on this world before it was too late.



Chapter Eleven

Countdown

I reached the bottom of the stairwell to see Tatl entertaining herself by flipping through some open picture books. Relief shone through her features when she saw I was unharmed.

"See? You're ok! Although... honestly I admit that I didn't know if the astronomer had been affected by Skull Kid's magic, but there was nothing to worry about after all!" Tatl twinkled. "Soooo... did you find where the Skull Kid is hiding?"

"Oh, well thanks for that!" I sarcastically replied. "And yeah I did. He's controlling the moon from the top of the Clock Tower in town."

Tatl huffed in frustration and kicked the book she had been studying shut, a soft thud echoing throughout the small room. "Of course he is! Why didn't I think of that?"

I looked at the pixie in confusion. "What do you mean? Are you saying that we could have skipped this whole mess of a journey? I crawled through a sewer to get here!"

"Look, I wasn't thinking straight, I'm sorry! I don't like to ruminate about stuff like that, ok!?" Tatl snapped back, but there was a flicker of pain behind her words, like a flame shrinking inward.

"What do you mean? Stuff like what?"

"I just...!" Tatl paused and softened her voice. "I just don't like to think about the past. That junk simply distracts from the present..."

We stood in silence. The flickering torchlight painted long shadows across the walls, and for a moment, it felt like the room was holding its breath with us. I understood her hesitation. The past was a wound I carried too—one that had never quite closed. Horrific struggles, torn friendships, betrayals that still echoed in my chest. A different world. A different me.

"I know what you mean," I said, voice quieter now. "The past is also hard for me to talk about… It hasn't been an easy life for me, even before all of this nonsense."

I knelt beside her, folding my legs underneath me, and looked up into her glowing form, haloed in the soft, golden light from the bookshelves nearby. "But if you ever do  want to talk about it, I'm here. You don’t have to carry all that alone. Not anymore."

Tatl hovered there for a long moment, her wings beating slowly, the quiet hum sounding almost like a heartbeat in the stillness. Then, with hesitant grace, she drifted forward and gently rested herself against my shoulder. Her glow softened, no longer sharp and flickering, but calm—like a firelight remembering how to be warm.

"Same goes for you, dummy," she murmured. Her voice was quieter than I'd ever heard it. "You don’t have to keep pretending you're made of stone. I see you. You know... even when you try to hide it."

Something in her words broke through the last of my armor. I let out a small breath, one I hadn’t realized I was holding, and closed my eyes for a moment. A fragile understanding passed between us—not made of grand declarations, but of quiet, mutual scars that hummed in the spaces we dared not speak aloud.

The world outside was ending. The sky was falling. But in that moment, a thread was woven between two broken souls. Not because I was stronger. But because, for once, I wasn’t entirely alone.

"I guess... you deserve to know about it. In a way, a small part pertains to you as well..." Tatl whispered, still resting lightly on my shoulder. She took a breath that shimmered with the weight of memory, and began:

"Before all the bad stuff happened, Tael, Skull Kid, and I were kind of a family. We stuck together because no one else would take us in. We were outcasts, and orphans." Tatl sighed. "On clear evenings, Tael and I would carry Skull Kid up the Clock Tower and watch the sunset over the ocean. We would all laugh, tell jokes, talk about our desires, and just have fun. When night fell, we gazed at the blanket of stars shining with the moon. I'd recite old legends and ghost stories, and we'd be up all night, too terrified or excited to sleep." Tatl paused, her glow dimming slightly with the ache of remembrance. "Those were during the good times..."

"Sounds to me like you were really attached to Skull Kid... what happened?"

Tatl fell quiet, her wings twitching faintly. When she finally spoke, her voice was tinged with bitterness and grief. "That stupid mask happened. As soon as Skull Kid put it on... he changed."

She fiddled with her tiny hands, the motion a shield against the storm she was reliving.

"Skull Kid, well, he was always kinda mischievous. He loved to play pranks on others, but his jokes rarely ever hurt people. One day, we were playing hide and seek in the forest and we were having a great time! Skull Kid was the seeker, Tael and I hid in the bushes a ways away. We'd been waiting for him for a while, when suddenly Skull Kid started calling out to us, saying that he wanted to show us something. When we reached him, we saw a man with a large pack lying unconscious in the grass. There were masks of all shapes and sizes everywhere, and there was Skull Kid, standing over the man's body... and wearing that awful horned, purple mask."

Tatl turned to face the wall, her small body trembling. Her voice had grown thinner, and something in her shimmered like the last leaf on a tree.

"His pranks quickly became more and more violent, and he forced us to participate. Innocent bystanders suffered. We trashed towns and homes. People started to hate us. But despite all that, Tael and I stayed with him, really hoping that he would see the pain he caused and would stop. But he only grew worse the longer he wore the mask."

Tatl sniffled, and faced me again. Her tiny eyes were still glazed over in memory, and in them I saw something raw and unhealed—the heartbreak of watching someone you love disappear inside themselves.

"It wasn't much longer before the guardian deities of this land banded together, and kicked us out of Termina. That's when he changed for the worst," she said softly, her voice laced with a sorrowful kind of reverence. "Skull Kid was filled with a terrible wrath, screaming about revenge, and how everyone would pay. His dark mask began to give him strange abilities, at the cost of his good spirit. He went through the forest we were sent to, and focused his anger and rage on every living being he came across. In his eyes, they were all his own personal playthings..."

Her words hung between us like a bitter mist. The torchlight shimmered faintly in the corners of her glow, and for once, there was no sarcasm, no mockery. Only grief.

Tatl broke her focus and turned to meet my gaze. Her wings gave the faintest flick, not out of impatience, but to keep herself grounded in the moment.

"And that's when we met you. The Skull Kid saw you and your horse moving through the woods and thought it would be fun to mess with a swordsman. We followed, and... well, you know the rest..."

She floated closer, so close I could feel the warmth of her light on my cheek. "Link... I'm sorry for my part. I truly didn't think it would ever go so far..."

Her voice cracked just slightly. Not from guilt, but from the quiet ache of someone finally laying down a burden they'd carried too long. It was the first time I had ever heard such sincerity come from her. I was speechless, a tightness blooming in my chest, but I nodded.

"It's ok, Tatl. Thank you. Thank you for telling me all of that. It couldn't have been easy."

"But you understand, right?" she pleaded, drifting back an inch. "The Skull Kid isn't really evil. I'm positive that it's the mask that's causing him to be this way! We have to help him!"

I looked away. The room suddenly felt colder.

"I don't know... All I can be certain of is that he's going to destroy the world, and I have to stop him. It might not even be possible to help him. I'm sorry."

Tatl nodded, but there was something hollow in the gesture. Like part of her had braced for those words, and still hoped she wouldn’t hear them. She hovered silently for a moment longer, then turned abruptly and zipped toward the passageway leading back through the sewer.

"Well... either way. We can't do anything while we stand around here. We have to get back to town, and to the top of that tower!"

"Wait, why can't we just go the normal way back into town?" I asked, tilting my head. "There's a door leading right outside, up there!" I pointed up the stairs.

"Well yeah... but... I don't want to be spotted by that crazy old man. He could snap at the first sight of me, and then incinerate us with his horrible fire spitting blowtorch!"

I waved her off with a sigh. "He's not crazy. You guys broke his stuff. I'd be angry too! And besides, the Bomber kids down there are probably awake by now. I really don't feel like explaining myself to them. Now, let's hurry outside and head back to town!"

I turned and started up the stairs, the conversation still clinging to my thoughts like morning mist. Behind me, I heard Tatl grumble under her breath.

"Urghh... fine, Miss Prissy. I'll just hide under your cloak until we're back in town."

She zipped underneath the folds of my green cloak, her deep vulnerability shuttered behind sarcasm once more. But I felt the warmth of her light settle at my shoulder, quieter than usual. And I understood.

Some things are too raw to hold in the open air for long.

I slowed as we neared the top of the stairwell and peeked around the corner to the rising platform. Reton was completely focused on his telescope, muttering quietly to himself as his robes gently rustled in the breeze from the open hatch above. I tiptoed toward the door, the wooden floorboards creaking faintly beneath my soft boots. With careful fingers, I eased the latch open and slipped outside.

I squinted against the brilliant afternoon light, my eyes watering as they adjusted after so long in the subterranean gloom. The Star Chamber crowned the peak of a low hill, encircled by tall trees whose canopies murmured with the wind. Gusts tousled my hair and swirled around my green cloak, which still shielded Tatl, grumbling, beneath its fur-lined interior. The breeze smelled of pine and damp earth, tinged faintly with the scent of something floral just beginning to bloom. Below me, the white limestone walls of Clock Town stood tall and quiet, their rough-hewn faces gleaming under the early summer sun. From here, the town looked peaceful—a gem set against the backdrop of an approaching doom.

The Clock Tower loomed in the distance, its long shadow casting a solemn swath over the town’s rooftops. Its four-sided clock face glinted quietly in the sun, unmoving, as if holding its breath. I could almost hear the echo of a bell that hadn’t yet rung. It was now one o'clock.

After taking a moment to breathe in the eerie calm, I gauged the hill's slope. It wasn't too steep, and the grassy incline beckoned like an open invitation. With a running start, I vaulted forward, cloak streaming behind me. The hill was soft beneath my boots, each step muffled by thick blades of grass as I picked up speed. Tatl let out an indignant squeak as she was jostled about in the folds of my cloak.

"Oof! Could you not  treat me like a sack of beans?!"

I laughed, my hair whipping around me as the wind rushed past. The air tasted clean and wild, and for a brief moment, I felt free.

With a final leap, I landed at the base of the hill among a cluster of maple and birch trees. Shadows clung to their trunks in broad, broken shapes. The rustle of leaves was joined by the chirp of unseen birds, and the distant hum of insects waking from the storm's aftermath. I took a few steadying breaths, then noticed the dirt path curving gently upward—a trail I had entirely missed.

"What were you thinking? I'm stuck in your hot, stinky cloak, having a bad time, and you go jumping off cliffs when we have a perfectly good trail to walk down?" Tatl's muffled voice shot from the folds of fabric, furious and faintly wheezy.

"Oh stop whining, that way was faster." I smirked. "Besides, with all your little jokes about me lately, you had it coming. Why are you still in there anyway?"

"Well... I... but..." Tatl sputtered, clearly struggling to defend her cowardice. "Pshh! Whatever... I don't want that dumb old man to see me, who knows what else he has in his arsenal."

I chuckled and stepped onto the dirt path, brushing my hands along the wild grass lining its edge. The trees thinned out as we walked, the ground beneath my boots shifting between packed soil and slick patches of mud. Overhead, the leafy canopy became dense again, blotting out the sun and casting the grove into a cool twilight hush. Mottled pools of light danced between the leaves, catching on dewdrops and spiderwebs stretched between the branches.

The quagmire made the hike back to town a sluggish plod. My deerskin boots were great for stealth and acrobatics, but terrible for trudging through rough terrain. My feet were sucked into the clinging mud with each step, and the dirt path blended in with the bog. The slop forced me to fight to stay balanced and upright, and each pull flung the thick muck every which way. I must have looked like a street urchin, crawling through untold filth from the sewer and now this thick mud. Maybe I could get cleaned up at the Stock Pot Inn if there was time.

I reached the edge of the shaded grove, winded. Finally, on sundried dirt and fields, I decided to rest. I felt Tatl bat my cloak away, and free herself from the no doubt, foul-smelling garment. The pixie gulped deep breaths of fresh air.

"Do you gasp  have any idea how bad it stinks in there!?" Tatl wheezed dramatically, fanning her face.

"There's nothing I can do about it. That's just what happens when you crawl through a sewer," I muttered, flicking splatters of mud off my leather gloves. The sunlight felt like a blessing, warming the chill from my bones as I kicked clumps of muck from my boots.

"Link! Watch out!"

Something deep green flashed in the corner of my eye, and I twisted aside on instinct. A wet, slapping plop  struck the ground where I had just been. I turned, unslinging my bow in one smooth motion, and aimed at the threat.

What stood before me was a man-sized glob of animate slime. Its translucent emerald form rippled with inner motion, like thick syrup barely holding shape. Two bulbous eyes jiggled at the top of its dripping mass, and inside its gelatinous body, I glimpsed the half-digested remains of some unfortunate forest rabbit. The creature pulsed forward in a twitching lurch, shaped like a grotesque teardrop made of toxic jelly.

I blinked in disbelief. "What is  that thing?!"

Tatl zipped up beside me, her wings buzzing in alarm. "That's a Chuchu! Normally they're small and harmless, but lately? Everything’s going wild. These things have multiplied and grown to absurd sizes. This one’s probably been feeding off magical runoff near town."

The Chuchu quivered and lurched again, its body wobbling like a drum of acid-filled pudding.

"Great," I muttered, drawing my bowstring tight. "So what, do I just shoot it?"

"If you want to survive, yes!" Tatl snapped. "Don’t let it touch you! That slime is super acidic while it's alive. You'll roast faster than a Deku nut in a bonfire. Wait until it's down, then back off—it turns inert when it dies."

I narrowed my eyes. "Perfect. Just the relaxing stroll I needed."

The Chuchu wobbled and leapt towards me once more, making sloppy splat sounds that echoed through the clearing like wet applause. I took aim with the magic bow, drew the string back—still amazed at the radiant shaft of white light that shimmered into existence—and let the bolt fly.

FWAAASPLOOSH!

The creature let out a grotesque gurgle as the bolt pierced through its center, erupting into a spray of fluorescent goop. It collapsed into a glistening puddle of green sludge, twitching once before going still.

"Wow... I love  this thing!" I held up the bow with a grin, turning to Tatl.

She bobbed approvingly. "I'd say the Great Fairy knew exactly what she was doing. I mean, sure, Chuchus and balloons are hardly intimidating, but you’ve got real form. That shot was clean. Like you’ve been doing it for years."

I re-slung the weapon with a sense of practiced comfort. "Yeah, back in Hyrule I had a bow from a temple. It was elegant, powerful... one of my favorite weapons. I used it so much, it became instinct....like breathing or swinging a sword. Before I left, I gave it to my sworn brother Darunia and the Gorons as a parting gift."

"Gorons? You mean you have those rock-eating dummies where you're from too?"

I raised an eyebrow at her tone. "They're not dummies. Just... incredibly stubborn. But yeah, we had them too. I didn’t know there were Gorons in Termina."

"Sure are," Tatl replied. "They live up north in the Snowhead mountains. I haven't been up there in a long time though, they're such a pain to traverse if you aren't made of stone."

As we neared the outskirts of town, I let that revelation roll around in my head. Could it be that Termina was some kind of mirror world? Had refugees from Hyrule crossed into this realm ages ago?

My thoughts were interrupted as the rattle of wheels and hooves clattered toward me from the dirt road. A rickety, horse-drawn cart came barreling down the path, its wheels squeaking in protest. The driver pulled hard on the reins with a shout, and the horses whinnied to a stop, kicking up a cloud of dust.

"Hooo, easy now!" the man bellowed, his deep voice like gravel tumbling in a barrel. "Hey! Young lady! Over here!"

I tensed slightly and walked the short distance to the cart, hand near my belt in case things turned sideways. The man who hopped down had tallow-colored hair slicked back with oil, a grin missing a few teeth, and a smell that suggested he hadn't bathed since the last lunar cycle. His patchy tan shirt had seen better decades, and his khaki trousers were more hole than fabric.

"Where are you headed? You can't really be going back to town... right? Why, haven't you seen that the moon is falling right on top of it?" he asked, his voice cracking with the strain of fear. His eyes were wide, rimmed red with exhaustion and desperation.

Behind him, the wagon bed was crowded with terrified families. A woman clutched a crying infant swaddled in a patchwork blanket. A boy, no older than ten, stared blankly at the sky while holding a wooden sword in trembling hands. Another man rocked back and forth, whispering a prayer under his breath. The smell of smoke drifted from the town beyond, sharp and acrid.

Tatl whispered to me, "What are you doing! We don't have time for this dummy."

"Yeah, I... ummm... I have family there," I said quickly, eyes fixed on the cart.

The man didn't seem to believe me, but panic overrode his skepticism. He frantically beckoned for me to climb in. "Maybe so, but you should come with us! It's dangerous to go alone! Especially for a skinny little thing such as yourself. There's monsters and bad people running around EVERYWHERE! The guards abandoned the gates! The mayor's mansion is burning!"

"No thank you," I said softly but firmly. "I really have to get back to town."

I turned back toward the looming walls of Clock Town. Over them, thick clouds of smoke billowed into the air like black flags. I could hear faint cries carried on the wind—calls for help, for mercy, for someone to stop the sky from falling.

"Hey, wait! Are you sure you don't want to come with us?" the man shouted after me, voice tinged with helplessness.

"Yeah, I'm positive! I'm sorry, but I have to get going!" I called back, already breaking into a jog.

"Ok... I wish you and your family luck! Farewell! Be safe!"

I heard the poor man scramble back onto the cart. The driver cracked the reins, and the wagon groaned forward, disappearing down the muddy path like a funeral procession fleeing from the grave.

"I guess people in town are panicking. We'd better hurry and get back!" I told Tatl, and without another word, broke into a sprint.

We made it to the southern town gates just as the sun bled into the horizon, painting the sky with streaks of crimson and gold. The massive limestone entrance loomed before us like a monument to a dying world. Time felt warped, disjointed—as though every tick of the clock hastened the moon's descent.

We entered the southern district, the slums where I'd first found the lost fairy that fateful night. Now, that same place had turned into a vision of the apocalypse. No guards patrolled the entrance. Their posts were abandoned, shields discarded like broken promises. In the distance, screams tore through the smoke-choked air—anguished, terrified, desperate. The clang of stolen swords, the crackle of burning homes, and the panicked braying of overburdened livestock filled every breath with chaos.

Townsfolk of every class scrambled through the streets, brandishing weapons or fists, clawing over wagons, doors, even each other to find some escape. A pair of noblemen fought tooth and nail over a crumbling rickshaw, their fine coats stained with soot and blood. Children wailed from alleyways as flames devoured the wooden skeletons of their homes. Horses lay shattered and screaming in the streets, many already rotting, their flanks torn by panic or worse.

And then, impossibly, Gorons. Enraged about something , they rampaged down the boulevards, smashing buildings with massive stone hammers, their roars shaking window panes. I saw one tear the awning from a bakery and hurl it into a nearby fountain with a guttural cry.

"Hurry! Let's get to that Clock Tower!" Tatl cried, her voice almost lost in the din, zipping down the debris-strewn street like a trailing spark.

I sprinted after her, dodging overturned carts and sidestepping throngs of frantic citizens. I drew my bow, heart pounding, prepared for anything. My boots splashed through puddles that glistened with firelight, slick with ash and blood.

Above it all, the Clock Tower loomed like a final sentinel—monolithic, unmoved. The terrible, leering moon now filled nearly the entire sky, its cratered face swollen with fury, leering down at us like a cruel god.

I pushed myself harder, lungs burning, until we reached the great base of the tower.

There, at the massive wooden doors, stood the mask salesman. He waved us toward him with urgency, his limbs swaying like a puppet cut free of its strings. His eyes were far too calm.

"You, my young hero, have certainly waited too long to return my mask!" he said, looking me over.

"It's not my fault, I've run into a few difficulties as you can clearly see!" I snapped, gesturing bitterly to my altered form.

"Yes... I can see." His voice was quieter now. "I can help return you to your true self, but you must regain that which was stolen. Only then can I help."

"Right, you need your mask," Tatl said sharply.

"Not only my mask, but that sacred instrument."

"You mean my Ocarina?" I frowned. "How do you know about that? It's supposed to be a Royal Family secret."

"Why, I make it my business to know, yes. As I stated before, information buys happiness, and happiness is what I sell, hohoho!"

There was something terribly wrong about him—a flicker in his movements, like reality couldn't fully decide where he belonged. Power rolled off him like perfume, sweet and poisonous. But I had no choice. He was the only thread I had left.

"Now, hurry young hero! The longer you wait, the more these people will suffer." He pointed to the exit with unnerving enthusiasm. "Be quick, and have faith! You shall succeed!"

I turned to the door, Tatl trailing behind me with nervous sparks crackling off her wings.

"I really don't like that guy, he gives me the creeps!"

"I agree," I muttered, brushing my muddy bangs from my eyes. "But we may not like him, and we may not trust him, but he's the only one who seems to know what’s really happening."

"Yeah... I guess so," Tatl said, glancing back toward the tower. "I just hope we're not making a huge mistake."

I tilted my head up toward the peak of the Clock Tower, where time itself seemed to freeze. There was no path, no staircase. Just stone, shadow, and the promise of collapse. The scaffolding left by the fleeing construction crew barely scraped a fraction of the height.

"So... how the hell am I supposed to get up there?"

We searched frantically, weaving through a landscape of chaos as screams and thunderclaps echoed around the plaza. A sickening pressure twisted through my gut and mind—like the dark tendrils from before were slithering inside me, coiling tighter with each heartbeat. There were no visible stairs up the brick tower, no open doors, no ropes, no hope.

I circled the base of the Clock Tower, my boots splashing through puddles and crunching shattered glass. At the far end, I spotted a narrow ramp leading to a crumbling ledge, barely clinging to the wall about thirteen meters off the ground. I ran a trembling hand across my temple, caked in grime and sweat, my vision flickering with panic.

"Ok... how do I even get to the top?" I muttered.

"Umm... Well, I certainly can't carry you like I did with Skull Kid! You may be lighter than you were before, but I can't possibly take you all the way up without killing myself!" Tatl snapped, though even her sarcasm trembled.

I let out a groan, half-laughing in despair. "Great. I'm going to die looking like this ."

"Why don't you ask around? I've seen  people up there during festivals. There has to be a way!"

I glanced around. The plaza, once alive with laughter and music, was now a silent grave. Ash drifted through the air like snow. Cracked stalls and abandoned confetti told the story of a celebration that would never come. Tatl must have seen the flicker of hopelessness in my eyes.

"Maybe we should return to the Stock Pot Inn? Anju might know something. Besides..." She flitted close to my tunic and wrinkled her nose. "You really  need a bath. Badly."

"We don't have time for that, Tatl!" I barked, swatting her away. The twisting in my head was getting worse—not just nausea, but something deeper, like my thoughts were warping, reshaping themselves. "The moon is falling by the minute, and I’m starting to feel sick...."

"But look around! That ledge is the only way! Even if you could  reach it, you’d never get up there fast enough!"

I clenched my jaw. "Fine... I guess you're right. Let's just go."

We reached the inn long after twilight gave way to night. The earth groaned beneath our feet in violent tremors, like the world itself was trying to shake us off. The air was thick with ash and panic, every breath laced with smoke and dread.

Clock Town had become a waking nightmare.

Fires danced along rooftops, their orange tongues licking at the heavens, casting flickering shadows over the cobbled streets. Market stalls lay in splinters, fruits and trinkets crushed underfoot. A child wailed from beneath a toppled cart, his cries barely audible over the cacophony. A stray dog limped past us, trailing blood and looking back over its shoulder as if begging someone to explain why the sky was falling.

Shadows of looters darted through alleyways, some clutching sacks of stolen bread or jewelry, others just running with nowhere left to go. Fistfights broke out in front of shuttered doors as families clawed for space in already overflowing wagons. Desperate townsfolk clung to shattered homes, shouting the names of loved ones lost in the smoke. From the direction of the mayor’s hall, thick black smoke rose in columns. Somewhere nearby, a woman screamed, her voice breaking into sobs before vanishing beneath the roar of collapsing stone.

And above it all, the moon had descended so far it now scraped the clouds—massive, luminous, a swollen leering god of stone. Its hateful gaze burned down upon the Tower, casting the world in a deepening crimson glow

We threw open the inn's doors to find it transformed into a ruin. Shelves splintered, chandeliers shattered, paintings torn from the walls. The faint scent of smoke filtered from upstairs. In the wrecked kitchen, we found Anju collapsed on the floor, cradling a photograph to her chest, her sobs muffled by the cacophony outside. Shards of broken dishes glittered like teeth around her.

She was startled at our approach. "Oh! Miss Link! W-what happened to you? Why are you still in town!?"

"I have unfinished business at the top of the Clock Tower," I said breathlessly. "Do you know how to get up there?"

"The Tower opens at midnight for the Festival of Time," Anju whispered, her voice cracking. "It was supposed to begin tonight. But now... now it may all vanish before it begins."

Tatl spun around me in a panic. "Midnight?! Link, it's almost midnight now!"

I turned to run, but Anju's cry stopped me.

"Wait! Please! If you see this man— my  Kafei—tell him I’m waiting! Please!" She ran toward me, holding out the photograph with trembling hands.

I took the picture. A young man with striking blue hair, red eyes, and a sapphire pendant stared back. He looked regal, gentle, full of promise.

"He was supposed to marry me tonight... and he vanished three days ago. I... I can’t go on without him."

Tears spilled through her fingers. Without thinking, I dropped to my knees and held her. "I’ll find him. I swear. Now stay safe!"

Just then, the building shook with an ear-splitting roar. The walls cracked, a wooden beam splintered above us.

"We have to go!" I grabbed Anju’s hand and bolted for the exit. We exploded through the doors just as the inn collapsed behind us in a storm of dust and flame.

"C’mon! We can't stay here!" Tatl cried as buildings crumbled and fire rained from splintering rooftops.

Anju tore her hand away. "GO! I have to stay! For Kafei!"

I hesitated. Just long enough to nod.

Then I ran.

We raced toward the Tower, dodging falling beams, splitting earth, and gouts of flame as the heavens howled. Time had run out.

The end of the world had begun.


Chapter Twelve

End of the Beginning

The fearsome wind screamed through the skies, shredding banners and sending debris flying like shrapnel. The earth convulsed with escalating fury, rupturing stone and shattering roads as the terrible lunar ceiling lowered by the minute. The crumbling city around me was a ghost of its former self—barren, broken, forsaken. All who could flee had already vanished, and those who remained were swallowed by the void. Gravity itself seemed unhinged, torn in a cosmic tug of war between the dying world and the monstrous moon, which now loomed so close its craters were visible in terrifying clarity. Chasms cracked open beneath abandoned homes, devouring entire sections of the town like a beast gnashing its teeth.

I stood with Tatl at the base of the massive Clock Tower, the very ground beneath us trembling like a dying heartbeat. From above, the bellowing tones of midnight thundered across the city, each chime sounding more like a funeral bell than a celebration. Somehow, impossibly, the monolithic clock stood unbroken—its ancient face staring defiantly into the eye of the apocalypse. Fireworks launched from its heights, desperate and bright, as if their flaring brilliance could push back the doom that crept ever closer.

I heard the grinding of great gears behind the cacophony and bolted toward the sound. On the ledge Tatl and I had found earlier, a gaping entrance yawned open where once there was only stone. I sprinted up the ramp, wind clawing at my cloak, and threw myself through the doorway. Inside was a dust-caked elevator shaft, dimly lit and swaying with each quake. A single iron lever jutted from the left wall like a relic. I yanked it hard as a distant building groaned and collapsed in a plume of fire.

The doors creaked shut behind us, sealing out the chaos, and the elevator began to rise with a lurch. A wave of vertigo swept through me, amplified by the swirling sensation tightening in my skull. My breath came in ragged pulses. I felt dizzy, unstable, as if the world outside and the world inside me were both unraveling at once. My limbs felt too long, too light, as if I were being remade again mid-ascent.

Tatl hovered beside me, wings fluttering erratically. "Here we go, Link. This is it! All we have to do is get your instrument back, and it will all be over!" she said, but her voice trembled under the weight of uncertainty.

I nodded, rolling my shoulders and bending my legs, trying to center myself. My outfit was still smeared with grime from the morning's crawl through the sewers, but that didn’t matter now. All that mattered was reclaiming the Ocarina. Returning to normal. Escaping this strange, unfamiliar body. But a quiet dread gnawed at the back of my mind—what if there was no going back? What if this body, these curves, this voice, this frame... had already become part of me?

I didn’t know how I would survive the apocalypse, but I knew one thing for sure:

I didn’t want to die like this. And I sure as hell didn’t want to stay this way in the afterlife, if there even was one.

The elevator slowed, shuddering to a groaning halt. The doors yawned open, and I stepped out warily onto the wide, bowl-like platform. Wind whipped around me, screaming like the voices of the dead, but here at the tower’s peak, there was an eerie stillness—a hush before the end. Far above, the moon leered like a flaming god, pulsing with violent crimson light. Below, the world buckled and burned.

Skull Kid hovered several meters off the platform, his small body limp in the air like a puppet held aloft by strings of shadow. Darkness bled from the mask that clung to his face, oozing and writhing in waves that shimmered with malice. And there beside him—trembling, wings flickering weakly—was Tael.

"Tael!" Tatl cried out, her voice cracking. "Get away from him!"

"Sis! You came back!" The purple fairy turned to us, relief bursting through his trembling glow. "You gotta help me! Skull Kid's not listening to reason! He's lost!"

Slowly, Skull Kid turned to face us. The movement was unnatural—slow, deliberate, like a marionette yanked against its will. In one hand, he twirled my Ocarina, rolling it across his fingers with a cruel carelessness, as if it were no more than a polished pebble.

"Well, well, well… Look who decided to show up! I figured you'd still be stuck in that cave I left you in. But no matter... I'm thrilled to see the spell worked! That’s a great  look for you, Mr. Big Shot. Or should I say… Miss  Big Shot! Heeheeheehee! Not so threatening now, are you, little girl?"

His laughter rang out across the basin like a blade drawn across glass—sharp, awful, triumphant. The platform beneath me trembled with every cackle, and sparks of energy hissed from the mask like venomous snakes. Rage surged through me, hot and steady. I wouldn’t let him humiliate me again. I reached for my bow...but Tatl darted in front of me.

"Skull Kid! LOOK at what you’re doing! Look around you! Everything’s falling apart! You need to STOP!"

"Who's gonna stop me, traitor?! You and your pretty new friend? Ha!" Skull Kid cracked into a fit of laughter again, but it was strained now—like something else was laughing through him, stretching his voice beyond what it was meant to carry.

Tael darted forward, wings quivering. He turned to the fractured horizon and cried out with all he had:

"Swamp, Mountain, Ocean, Canyon! Those who are there, come here, to our hour of need! Please!"

His voice echoed across the burning sky. For a split second, it seemed like the wind itself paused to listen.

In a blur of dark light, Skull Kid lashed out, smacking Tael to the platform. The fairy bounced off the stone with a cry and lay still, wings dimmed and twitching faintly.

"Shut UP, stupid fairy!" he shrieked, eyes glowing too brightly.

"Tael!" Tatl wailed, flying to her brother's side. "Don’t you dare  hurt my brother, Skull Kid! That’s it. We are DONE being your friends!"

Skull Kid paused. The mask pulsed once—deep, throbbing, like a heartbeat from within a grave—and then he gave a careless shrug. "Whatever. Like I care. You’ll all pay either way. Nothing  can stop me now!"

He turned his face skyward and raised his arms. The mask’s jagged heart-horns flared with purple light, and a shriek—inhuman, ancient, and impossibly loud—tore through the sky like the cry of a god in agony. From the mask erupted tendrils of writhing violet energy, screaming into the clouds. They struck the moon like a whip, and the moon responded.

A deafening roar cracked the heavens. Flames burst across the moon’s surface like bleeding wounds. It started to accelerate.

Faster.

Closer.

Downward.

"Link! What do we do?!" Tatl shouted to be heard over the deafening howl of wind and collapsing stone.

I reached behind me, heart hammering, and grabbed the Great Fairy's bow slung across my back. Drawing a glowing arrow, I took aim while Skull Kid cackled in triumph, his guard momentarily lowered. I loosed the magic bolt. It sliced through the air with a high-pitched hum and struck the back of his head.

The arrow of light didn’t pierce him—the dark aura enveloping him rippled like a living thing and absorbed most of the force—but the impact was enough. He reeled, staggering in midair like a puppet with cut strings. With a startled grunt, he dropped my Ocarina.

The sacred instrument struck the stone platform with a ringing thud that echoed like a chime through the sky.

"Good shot, Link!" Tatl cried. "He dropped your thingy! I'll distract him—go!"

She zipped toward Skull Kid in a blur of defiant light, weaving around his slashing arms and tugging at his tattered cloak. He snarled and swiped, eyes blazing, utterly focused on the annoying glimmer in his face.

I locked onto the Ocarina lying beneath him. My heart surged. That small, gleaming artifact held everything—my identity, my power, my path home.

I broke into a sprint, boots pounding the trembling stone. Just before reaching it, I dropped into a slide and scooped the Ocarina from the ground in one smooth motion. The second my fingers touched its sacred curves, a searing warmth shot up my arms—and the world shattered.

Time froze.

Light and memory surged around me, and suddenly I was no longer atop the Clock Tower. I stood in the Temple of Time. Moonlight filtered through high stained glass windows, and the air smelled of old stone and divinity. My body… was my old body. Stronger. Broader. Familiar.

Zelda stood beside me, serene and radiant, her golden hair cascading in soft waves. She held the Ocarina in both hands, her eyes solemn.

"You must do what you feel you have to... but please, take this," she said gently.

I took the Ocarina from her. The moment it touched my hands, the temple pulsed with magic.

"Link, always remember this. As long as you hold this Ocarina, you hold Time itself within your hands."

She raised it to her lips. The first notes of the Song of Time filled the chamber—soft, mournful, eternal. The melody swelled and echoed through the sacred space, wrapping around me like a blessing, or a farewell.

As the last note faded, Zelda lowered the instrument and looked at me one final time. Her expression was bittersweet—hopeful and heartbroken.

"Always hold this song within your heart," she whispered, "and the goddesses will keep you safe from the ravages of Time."

The vision dimmed.

And then the whiteness took me.

I was back at the top of the Clock Tower, the lunar inferno still blazing through the sky like a comet of wrath, tearing the very air apart. The heavens were aflame, stained with crimson and orange as though the gods themselves had bled across the firmament. Thunderous cyclones of fire swept over the land, setting entire fields ablaze. Massive earthquakes cracked the crust of the earth, toppling towers and swallowing screaming souls. Somewhere beneath all of it, Tatl still danced desperately through the smoke, distracting Skull Kid.

"What are you doing?! This is no time for daydreaming, Link!" Tatl cried as she dodged a blast of dark energy. "Surely there must be something  you can do?!"

"Oh Goddess of Time, save us!" I heard Tael gasp, his tiny voice raw and trembling. He clung to his sister in one final, fragile embrace.

My heart surged. The moment crystallized. I knew  what to do.

I raised Zelda's Ocarina to my lips, my hands trembling but sure. I closed my eyes. My breath steadied. The world raged around me, but I shut it out. My fingers moved on their own, gliding across the sacred instrument’s familiar surface. The Song of Time spilled from me like a river long dammed, its notes cutting through the thunder and flame like bells tolling from another world.

With the final note, the Ocarina pulsed with blue light—gentle and defiant. The air bent. Time shuddered.

The world fizzled, unmade at the edges. Everything stretched into streaks of golden light, drawn upward and inward. I felt myself dissolving into the current of time, my soul launched backward through memory.

Images blurred past: the hollow forest where I'd first met Skull Kid, the plunge through the gaping tree trunk, faces swirling like reflections on water. I saw the curse envelop me, the twisted laughter, the metal door beneath the tower—

Then silence.

Then light.

I opened my eyes.

Sunlight poured down upon me.

I stood again at the base of the Clock Tower. The Ocarina of Time dimmed in my hand, still warm from the song. Tatl hovered beside me, her glow bright but uneven, flickering with disbelief.

"Wha…? What just happened?" she breathed. Her eyes darted to the familiar stonework around us. "Are we... back to that first day?"

She zipped skyward and gasped at the blue dome above. The moon was high and distant again, no longer tearing through the sky like a blade.

"D-did you... just turn back time?"

I was just as stunned. The world was whole . The cracked scaffolding was reduced to its earlier frame. The scent of smoke and blood was gone, replaced with fresh-cut wood and morning dew. Construction workers hammered rhythmically at half-finished platforms. Merchants chatted. Townspeople bustled. Guards patrolled, unaware of the apocalypse they narrowly escaped.

"I guess I did..." I murmured, then touched my throat.

My voice was still high, unmistakably feminine. A flash of irritation passed through me.

I looked down at myself. Still the same soft, rounded form. Still the same clothes Tatl had found. At least they were clean now, and the enchanted bow remained strapped to my back. But inside, nothing had reset.

Tatl floated closer, inspecting me.

"But... you're still a girl?" she whispered. "You were only just  beginning to change when we were here last... Were we not affected by the song like everything else?"

"I guess not," I said through clenched teeth, heat creeping into my cheeks. "Let's just find the mask salesman again. He said he could cure me if I got my stolen item back."

As if on cue, the heavy Clock Tower doors groaned open, their wooden frames creaking like ancient bones. The Happy Mask Salesman emerged, his wide, unsettling grin stretching across his face. He motioned with a frantic hand, his shadow long and twitching under the light.

"Come, come! Quickly now!" he urged, his voice sharp with urgency.

I startled, heart still pounding from the temporal plunge. Swallowing my suspicion, I followed Tatl close behind. Inside, the din of Clock Town vanished like a dream fading at dawn. All that remained was the slow, rhythmic churn of gears overhead and the eerie hush of something ancient waiting.

The salesman stopped in the middle of the circular chamber. His hands folded together with unsettling grace.

"Well done, young hero! I'm so  very pleased. Now—did you manage to reacquaint yourself with your sacred item?"

"Yes, but it was no easy task," I replied, still winded. I lifted the Ocarina with care, the blue sheen of its surface catching the dim light. "Here it is."

"Ahh, marvelous! Just as I hoped!" the man exclaimed, clapping once with a sound too sharp to feel real. "With this, yes, I can help restore what was broken. I can teach you to mend your spirit... and return you to your true form."

He gave a bow and twirled toward the far wall, his steps jerky and uncomfortably gleeful. Then, as if summoned by thought alone, a colossal pipe organ faded into view—its twisted brass pipes blooming from the wall like metallic vines.

"Now, listen carefully," he said, sliding onto the bench with twitchy reverence. "This melody holds magic older than the mask. If played by one who believes , it heals not only the flesh... but the soul. The Song of Healing, it is called."

He pressed the keys. The first notes were low and hollow—then swelled into something haunting, aching, whole. The song rang out into the chamber, folding itself around me like memory. Each phrase seemed to reach through the bones of the tower and brush the edges of the world itself.

When the final chord faded, the salesman turned to me, eyes wide and waiting.

I raised the Ocarina. My breath shook.

With a steadying inhale, I played. The tune felt like it had always been within me, waiting to be remembered. The song poured out in smooth spirals, wrapping me in peace, as if the instrument and I were becoming one. The chamber pulsed. The shadows leaned in.

Then came the pain.

At first, it was no more than pressure behind my sternum. But it bloomed, rapidly—sharp, blooming fire. My limbs locked. My skin crawled. I gasped and crumpled, every nerve alight. It felt like I was being peeled away from myself, like layers were sloughing off beneath invisible hands. The Ocarina tumbled from my grip, ringing against the stone floor.

I screamed.

My bones shifted with wet, muffled pops.

I gasped... a sound caught somewhere between a moan and a sob. My spine compressed with a crackling pulse, hips wrenching outward with a jarring tug, as though I were being sculpted by some cruel artisan. I could feel  the flesh at my waist drawing inward, tightening around a frame that was no longer mine. Breasts swelled again—round, aching, undeniable—and this time there was no ambiguity. The sensation wasn’t just change; it was confirmation.  A terrifying solidifying of a direction I hadn’t chosen, carved into my very marrow.

My hands, still gloved, grasped blindly at the floor. They were too small, too light—fingers delicate and trembling like those of a porcelain doll. Every nerve pulsed with raw electricity. My tunic clung differently now—tight across my chest, snug around my hips. The shifting undergarments offered no comfort, their unfamiliar tug a constant reminder that the change had not merely returned—it had progressed .  Feminine in a way that felt impossibly complete.

I whimpered. My voice broke high, bright, unmistakably sweet...

Then the light deepened. I arched against the pull of it, crying out again as something inside me— deep  inside—was drawn upward like thread through a needle. I felt it stretch, burn, and snap, replaced by an aching hollowness... or perhaps something new. A sharp, hard clatter struck the floor beside me.

When the radiance finally receded, I was curled on the Clock Tower floor, every breath a shallow flutter in my chest. The Song of Healing had done something —yes—but not what I had pleaded for. Not a restoration.

The hush that followed rang louder than the scream.

Tatl hovered nearby, her wings twitching. "L-Link... are you okay?" Her voice was barely audible.

I opened my mouth. The words faltered in a voice that didn’t belong to me.

Then came the Salesman. His hands folded in delight. His voice too pleased.

"Oh my... this is most unexpected. Most unexpected indeed."

His smile did not reach his eyes.

And in that moment, I realized: whatever I had become... it was no longer reversible by song alone.

Tatl fluttered around me in slow, hesitant arcs, as if unsure whether she should speak or even touch  me. Her glow was dimmer than usual, flickering with uncertainty, like she too had been affected by the song's backlash.

"You... you're not better," she whispered. "You're... worse."

I turned to look at her, but the motion sent a curtain of hair swinging against my cheek—a sensation so alien, so intimate , it made me flinch. My hair. It was longer now. Thicker. A deep, rich scarlet that shimmered in the tower’s low light, cascading down my back like a velvet banner.

My throat clenched. I tried to speak again.

"Tatl, I—" The voice that came out wasn’t mine. It was soft, lush, unmistakably shaped by a different biology. A voice meant for songs, not shouts. Even the act  of speaking felt unfamiliar—like my new body demanded grace, whether I gave it or not.

Tatl recoiled slightly, wings pausing mid-beat. "That... doesn't sound like you're better..."

"I know." I touched my throat and winced. My fingers were slimmer, my nails subtly glossed. Even that— that tiny, pointless flourish —felt like a betrayal. A detail I would never have chosen.

The Mask Salesman clapped his hands, humming like a man at a garden party. "Ahhh! Such a transformation! A blossom in full bloom! Yes, yes, very good. Quite elegant."

"Shut up," I snapped. But the fury didn’t land—it floated out of me like a panicked melody. No edge. No weight.

I needed to see.  I staggered toward the great gear’s polished hub. The metal was scratched and weathered, but there in its center was a clear, silver circle—reflective enough to show the truth.

I climbed onto the rim, heart pounding. Then I looked.

The girl in the reflection was beautiful. Painfully  so.

Delicate. Ethereal. A vision sculpted from someone else’s dream.

Her eyes were impossibly bright—emerald green like sunlit forest leaves after rain—wide and shimmering with unspeakable confusion. Thick, dark lashes framed them like delicate shutters. Her face was narrow and heart-shaped, kissed with the faintest blush, and her pouty lips parted in breathless disbelief.

Scarlet hair, deep and dark like fresh-spilled wine, cascaded over her shoulders in glossy waves, some strands clinging damply to the line of her jaw. Her cloak, slightly askew, slipped down from one sculpted shoulder, revealing the delicate slope of her collarbone and the gentle swell of a too-soft form that hadn’t been mine a day ago.

Even her posture betrayed me—hips cocked subtly, legs angled with an accidental grace I hadn’t earned. She looked like someone meant to be protected, not someone who had spent years fighting to protect others.

And when I raised my hand to my mouth in stunned horror... she did the same.

I hated her.

"I'm not... me," I whispered, voice trembling with a grief too sharp to cry.

Behind us, the Salesman shuffled forward, hands folded like a prayer. "A miscalculation, perhaps. But one with potential! Oh yes, oh yes, tremendous potential! You still have  your old self, yes yes—it's all right there in the mask."

He pointed behind me.

And there it was.

A wooden mask, carved with haunting precision to match my old face. Lifelike. Vacant. A cruel parody of memory.

It stared up at me from the floor like a severed head.

"What did you do to me?!" I screamed. The words tore out in a high, keening wail...not a roar, not a command....

A cry.

And he only smiled.

"I am, to be quite fairly honest, unsure what happened. This is most unexpected…" he repeated, placing a long, pale hand against his chin in mock contemplation. His eyes twitched—too bright, too calm.

I’d had enough.

I drew my bow in one fluid motion and trained it on the trickster. The silvery string thrummed as it stretched, the light arrow blooming to life with a hiss of power. His smile faltered. He raised both hands in a flutter of alarm.

"My, my, my! I do indeed understand your anger! But—please—I do believe I’ve deduced what went wrong, yes I have!"

He turned and gingerly plucked the mask from the floor— my  face, still carved in haunting detail—and held it up with a kind of reverence.

"The song I taught you restores spirits broken by fate," he explained, his tone delicate, almost giddy. "But the magic that cursed  you—it did more than remold your flesh. It reshaped your soul.  Yes, yes! So when the melody did its work, it did not restore what you once were—it sealed  it. It purified what remained and placed it into this mask."

I stared at him, horror rising like bile. "So what? I'm stuck like this forever?"

I yanked the bowstring tighter. The glowing bolt flared, casting trembling light on his face. "I cannot  be like this forever!"

"No! Heavens no!" the Salesman sputtered, eyes wide and wild. He sank to one knee, holding the mask out like a holy offering. "If you place this mask upon your face, you will return to your original body. I promise you, young hero! Just please, lower your weapon."

Slowly, I eased the string back. The arrow fizzled, and my shoulders fell with the weight of doubt. I lowered the bow—but not my guard.

I stepped forward and took the mask. It was warm. Too warm. Tatl zipped in front of me, placing herself between the mask and my face.

"Link, wait! We can't trust him. What if it’s another trick? You saw what that song did to you. What if this just makes it worse?"

I looked past her, straight into the Salesman's pleading gaze. "You have got  to be kidding me," I said, my voice trembling on the edge of disbelief. "You expect me to trust you? Look  at me."

The Salesman clasped his hands, eyes shining with desperation. "Please, young hero. You must believe me! You are the only hope this world has. If your body disturbs you so deeply, then yes—place the mask upon your face. And you will be you  again. Yes, yes. I swear it."

The mask in my hand pulsed faintly. It almost... called to me.

But so did the ache in my chest.

So did the fear in my bones.



Tatl tried to discourage me, her voice sharp with fear, but I stepped forward anyway. Something in the Salesman’s pleading tone—frantic and too eager—gripped me with a sick sort of hope. I took the eerily familiar mask from his trembling hands, and he rose to his feet, bowing low with theatrical reverence.

"That mask contains your former spirit, yes yes," he murmured. "Merely putting it on will restore your original shape—it will, it will!"

Tatl hovered near the reflective gear, her glow dimmed and uncertain. I turned the mask over slowly in my hands, my stomach knotting. The wood pulsed—warm and strangely alive, like it still remembered the rhythm of my breath. My old face stared up at me. Familiar, yes... but hollow. Lifeless. A fossil of identity.

"You really think this will work?" I asked, cringing at the softness still threading my voice. Tatl said nothing. The Salesman nodded with that same unblinking smile.

I hesitated only a moment longer.

Then I pressed the mask to my face.

It moved .

Not like something worn—but something claiming. The back writhed and latched , a vine of bone and memory curling into my skin. My breath caught. My chest seized.

A muffled scream escaped me as my spine cracked , folding inward with unnatural force. My shoulders wrenched wide, arms stretching, muscle re-forming along their lengths. My hips cinched in sharply, ribs groaning as they collapsed into a narrower frame. My chest flattened with a fiery compression that stole the air from my lungs.

Tatl screamed something—but I couldn’t hear it. Not over the tearing .

My arms bulked up, joints popping as strength returned like thunder beneath my skin. My legs extended, knees locking, feet reforming with painful cracks as they filled out heavy, mud-caked boots I hadn’t seen in what felt like years.

With a sickening jolt, weight surged back into my body. I was heavy  again—solid, masculine, grounded. The gentle, swaying grace of my former form vanished beneath returning muscle and grit.

And still... the mask clung to me.

It squeezed tighter. It loved  me. My jaw stretched, grinding into its old shape. My voice box cinched like a fist closing inside my throat. I gasped, and the sound that came out was deep, ragged— real.... me .

The shifting finally eased, and I collapsed forward, heaving. I could feel the sword and shield heavy on my back, replacing the slender arc of the Great Fairy’s bow. My Kokiri tunic—green, battered, mine —hugged my muscular torso like a returning memory.

I stumbled toward the reflective gear. Tatl exhaled, her wings trembling with cautious relief.

My boots thudded against the wood as I stepped up. I stared.

Pale blue eyes. Short blond hair. Gauntlets. Warrior’s jaw. The weight of countless battles written across my frame.

The Hero of Time.

"Thank the gods," I breathed, stunned by the baritone thrum of my own voice. "You were telling the truth."

"Indeed, young hero, I was!" the Salesman chirped, folding his hands. "But do remember—it is only temporary. Your spirit  is changed, yes yes. Until you retrieve my  mask... I’m afraid it will remain so.""



"But how are we supposed to get it back?" Tatl interjected, her voice sharp with frustration. "Skull Kid is just too powerful now! We could barely even faze him—how are we supposed to defeat  him?"

I stomped toward the mask salesman, armored boots clanking against the floor, my gauntleted fist clenched with renewed determination.

"I can beat him now. I’m back to normal. He’s not going to be a problem."

"No, no," the Salesman said gravely, shaking his head with a grimace. "Your little friend is quite right. The dark magic within that mask has twisted him, granted him strength beyond comprehension. You would not triumph. You would perish."

"But you just  said I was the only hope!" I snapped. "What, have you changed your mind already?"

"Heavens, no! You are  the world’s only chance, yes yes!" he said, wringing his hands. "But you cannot defeat this evil with strength alone. No, no, you must heal the wounded hearts and tormented spirits of this land. You must bring them to your side for the final confrontation. Only united, only then, can the mask’s power be truly overcome."

Tatl hovered beside me, wings flickering in disbelief. "Heal the souls  of the land? What does that even mean ? How does that stop Skull Kid from obliterating everything?"

"The mask feeds  on suffering, thrives on hatred and despair!" he declared. "If you undo the pain it has caused, its strength will weaken. That lovely little tune you’ve learned—it will be crucial, yes! Have faith in the melody, have faith in each other!"

I crossed my arms, still unsure. "Right... faith. That’s easier said than done. Where exactly do I start? Healing hearts isn’t exactly a sword-swinging sort of quest."

"No, no, it isn’t," the Salesman admitted, his voice now hushed and reverent. "But you have gifts, hero. Gifts you once used to bring joy, long ago. You must wield them again. Just as you did before. I believe in you! You’ve saved a world once—you can save this one, too. It is your destiny , yes indeed!"

I stared. My chest tightened. I knew  him.

He really was  the same mask peddler from Hyrule.

I remembered helping him back then, giving away masks across the land. But how did he know about my journey? I’d never told anyone—not even the knights or my friends. Only Princess Zelda knew. How could he  know?

There was more to this man. Far more.

"Okay... I get it." I muttered. "You’re not just some merchant. You’ve seen more than you let on. But if the only way to truly change back is to stop Skull Kid and return your mask... then that’s what I’ll do."

"Most excellent! How encouraging indeed!" he exclaimed, practically skipping with joy. "You will  succeed, I know it!"

Tatl awkwardly fluttered beside me, glancing at the salesman like he might sprout another head.

"Uhhh... we should probably get going now, right, Link?" she muttered, nudging my arm. She leaned close and whispered, "This guy really creeps me out. Let’s leave before he does something even  weirder."

"Ohoho yes! No time for idle chatter, no no! Off you go! The fate of the world waits!" the Salesman laughed, eyes twinkling far too brightly.

Tatl zipped behind me in surprise, clearly not expecting to be overheard. I chuckled and shook my head. There was no fear in me now.

I was back .

"Yeah... thanks. For turning me back. I’ll let you know how it goes."

I turned to leave, hand on the wooden doors.

"Ah! Wait, young hero! One last thing!" the Salesman called, his voice echoing oddly in the chamber.

I paused, groaning softly. There’s always  a catch.

"You mustn’t wear the mask for long periods," he warned, suddenly grave. "Its magic draws from your spirit. Wear it too long... and you will become a husk. Dust. And with you, hope itself will fade."

I clenched my jaw. Of course. Of course  there was a cost.

"Great. So how do I take it off? It’s attached to my face."

"Why, like any other mask, of course! Just pull—and off it comes! Hoho!"

I rolled my eyes. "Right. Just rip off my face. Got it."

With that, I shook my head, muttering under my breath, and opened the doors. The light poured in—bright and blinding. Tatl hovered at my side, and I stepped forward, leaving the strange chamber behind.

The next chapter of my quest had begun.



Chapter Thirteen

Ancient Deadlands

The destroyed ruins of the archaic temple were filled with a sense of terror and foreboding. Wispy trails of ghostly blue clouds loomed amidst a cold, sunless sky of grey. A lonesome wind howled through the barren wastes of what was once a beautiful woodland full of life. Fossilized trees, and fields of destroyed foundations marked the ancient graveyard of a glorious kingdom, destroyed in some terrible calamity that had been forgotten in the passing of eons. Piles of dusty bones littered the landscape, and not a single living creature roamed the bleak deadlands. Save for one.

A peculiar traveler, tall, lanky, and garbed in elegant clothing, navigated the treacherous ruins. The figure seemed to be hunting for something, stopping every few meters to peer under debris and rummage through charred bone piles. The mysterious stranger continued on like this for hours, patient in his search and methodical in movement. The bitter chill of the howling wind didn't faze the smiling man as it billowed around his clothing.

The man's grin widened as he walked closer to the crumbling remains of the temple ruins. He knew in his heart that this was the right place; there could be no mistake. He had searched far and wide, through time and space, and even within the Void of Death itself to behold this doomed land once again. The man knew the domain very well, better than most other worlds, and he skittered with a graceful madness through the sharp, icy rubble and broken buildings. Then the man halted within the shattered walls of what was once a great tower within the demolished temple.

The aberrant fellow moved towards a corner where a huge piece of debris lay, and shifted the impossibly large boulder away with astonishing ease for a man of such a thin stature, revealing a set of stairs underneath. He hopped into the air with glee and giggled in delight, knowing his long, grueling journey was coming to an end. His painstakingly elaborate schemes and eternal dedication would soon be rewarded, and he would finally, after two long centuries of seeking, have...it.

The man plodded down the pitch black stairwell, and into a deep passageway without a care in the world. Dusty candles hanging along the walls of the wide passage mysteriously lit around him with icy blue flames, piercing through the lifeless dark ahead. The stone tunnels were remarkably intact and free of blockage as the man excitedly plunged onward. The wind's eerie moaning filled the passageways, and skeletons littered the halls. Any ordinary person would have fled long before venturing into this evil place, but the ageless man was no ordinary being. He sneered at the haunting noise and continued his mission down the seemingly endless corridors. The gentleman knew he was very close now. So close that he could almost taste victory on the tip of his tongue. Nothing would stop him! Nothing would satiate his burning desire! Nothing in all of creation would prevent him from finding his long lost possession! The crazed man chuckled into the blackness ahead. He almost dared something to impede his hunt now.

After hours of silent travelling down the dry, freezing tunnels, the man crowed in triumph.

"Here! It must be here!"

Before him stood a large stone slab that obstructed the way ahead. It was marked with an all too familiar design. The image displayed a large, solitary eye crying a single drop below the pupil's center. Three sharp points extended evenly above the eye. A large ring, broken into sections by smaller rings with interspersed circles lying over the lines surrounded the oculus. The Eye of the True Sheikah, a symbol that he had known from birth.

The Eye began to glow faintly with cyan light as the fearless man approached. He produced a razor sharp dagger from the folds within his clothing, and drew the blade along his open palm. The strange fellow uttered not a single sound, and placed the bloody palm upon the pupil of the eye. Recognizing the purity of the man's blood, the symbol flashed, and the slab began to rumble and move upward into the ceiling. The wound in his hand healed immediately, and he giggled with an insane happiness.

The slab revealed a final passage into a massive, sinister- looking chamber, dimly lit by eternally burning torches of purple flame. In the center of the room was a raised platform. Upon it rested a huge, perfectly rounded orb of what appeared to be pure amethyst. As the fanatical man approached, the orb began to hum and vibrate, surrounding itself with a shadowy aura.

"At long, long last! I have finally found you. Yes!" The man cried in pure joy.

He moved close to the ominous sphere, placing a pale hand upon it. The orb suddenly hissed and a loud crack resounded through the chamber! The amethyst sphere had disappeared, replaced by a churning, two -dimensional circle of light and darkness that roared with energy. Deep black, red, and gold colors shifted and swirled within the magic window, creating dancing shadows throughout the chamber. A scent of burning steel permeated the area, and magical energy electrified the air. The deranged man clapped his hands gleefully and entered through the portal, vanishing into the tenebrous ring of roiling twilight.

Chapter Fourteen

Dawn of the First Day


I pushed open the wooden doors of the Clock Tower after finishing with the Happy Mask Salesman, and took a step into the warm sunlight, breathing deeply the fresh morning air.

It smelled right, crisp with dew, faintly sweet from baking bread, and tinged with the earthy scent of damp stone warmed by the sun... but it felt wrong . My body still braced for chaos—muscles taut, eyes flicking to the rooftops as if expecting fire to rain down again. The stillness was unnatural after everything we’d just survived. Even the birdsong felt out of place, like an instrument playing too soon after a funeral.

I swallowed the tension and forced my shoulders to relax. The square had returned to its ordinary rhythm as if the world hadn’t nearly ended hours ago. Birds warbled overhead, flitting between rooftops gilded by golden sunlight. The plaza, so recently wrapped in fire and despair, now shimmered with color and warmth. Children laughed somewhere down a nearby alley, and the hammering of carpenters echoed across the square as the construction crew—now completely unbothered—dutifully repaired the scaffolding they had abandoned in panic.

I watched a woman sweep the front step of a bakery, unaware her world had been destroyed and rewoven around her. A musician tuned his instrument on the corner. The sky was spotless... perfect even.

It was unsettling at first... but I felt unshakable. Alive. My boots gripped the cobblestones with purpose. My shoulders squared, tunic shifting with every step like it knew how I moved. For the first time in what felt like years, I wasn't afraid. The world could burn again and I’d be ready. The bright ball of fairydust beside me, however, looked anything but assured...

"Wait a second... what are they still doing here?" Tatl asked, flicking anxiously in the air beside me. "Don’t these people even know what happened?"

"Hrmmm... I think the only ones who notice time travel are the ones who make  it happen," I said with a confident smirk and a shrug. My voice felt right in my chest. Solid. Grounded. "Or something like that. Someone explained it to me once. I couldn't follow it. The whole thing sounded more like philosophy than magic."

Tatl, the ever-sarcastic little wisp who once hovered around me like a thorn in my side—sharp, jumpy, and never short on complaints—floated beside me now with a strange stillness. Her usual stingers of wit were gone, replaced by a thoughtful hum, as if she finally understood the weight I carried. We weren’t just allies anymore. We were partners. She wouldn’t say it, not yet—but I could feel the shift.

We had spoken to the Mask Salesman, and as strange and theatrical as he was, he knew things. Deep things. Dangerous things. He told us the truth about Skull Kid’s mask—how it didn’t just manipulate despair, it fed  on it. Every broken heart in Termina was fuel for that cursed thing, and Skull Kid had become more shadow than child.

We couldn’t fight that with swords or bravado. We had to heal the wounds of the world itself.

That’s when he taught us the song.

A strange, haunting melody meant to soothe cursed spirits. And it had worked—though not in the way I expected. When I played it, something inside me shifted. My soul was split—sealed into a mask shaped like the person I used to be. The man. The warrior. The legend.

Now, I wear him like armor. The Hero of Time.

And truthfully? It felt good . My stride was sure, my voice steady, my instincts sharp. I didn’t flinch from shadows anymore—I welcomed  them. If this mask was a lie, it was one I could live with. Because when I looked ahead, I saw a road that would demand blood and resolve, not softness.

So here we were, back at the start—Clock Town bathed in gold, its cobblestone streets echoing with the casual clamor of a world reset. The towering Clock Tower loomed above, elegant and ageless, as if daring time to challenge it again. Sunlight spilled over the plaza, washing away the chill left by the Salesman's haunting smile and cryptic warnings.

"Okay, Link," Tatl buzzed at my side, her wings catching the light. "What do we do now?"

I tilted my head up toward the clear sky, where the moon once hung like a blade. Now it was distant again—innocuous, expressionless...just a hunk of space rock. The people below had no idea how close they'd come.

"Not sure," I answered, my baritone confident and amused. The Hero’s Mask felt perfect, like an old uniform fitting better than ever. "Your turf, not mine. You’re the expert here."

Tatl twirled thoughtfully in the air, tapping her tiny fingers to her chin. "Anju, maybe? She always seemed to know stuff."

I winced at the name. I remembered her kindness... and I remembered leaving her behind.

"No," I said flatly. "She wouldn’t recognize us anyway. We're the only ones carrying the memory of what happened. Let's not add to any more confusion than is already in this town."

Tatl rolled her eyes, mimicking the Salesman's singsong tone. "Well then, where do we go, young hero ?"

I chuckled and nodded toward a group of guards up the street. Sunlight glinted off their armor as they marched lazily across the plaza, clearly more bark than bite. Perfect.

"Time to introduce myself," I muttered with a cocky grin. I signaled Tatl and strode forward with purpose. My boots struck the stones with a reassuring rhythm. Sword at my side, shield at my back—I looked every bit the part.

"Gentlemen!" I boomed, loud enough to command their attention. "I hear there’s trouble in this land. I’m new here, sure—but I’m no tourist. I’m a warrior, and I came to help. So—where’s the fire?"

The portliest of them raised an eyebrow before letting out a snort. "Ooooh, look out lads! We’ve got ourselves a hero! Wahahaha!"

The others burst into laughter, loud and stupid.

"Just because you’ve got some shiny gear and a talking glowbug doesn’t make you anything special!" the ringleader jeered, wiping a tear from his eye. "Go home, kid. We’ve got real soldiers on this side of the wall."

My hand angrily reached toward my sword. I barely reached the man's shoulder, but I didn’t need height to carve through arrogance. He wasn’t a soldier—he was a clown dressed in hand-me-down armor. I could end this entire conversation with a single swing. Tatl, quick as ever, darted in front of me and grabbed the steel brace of my gauntlet.

"What are you doing?!" she hissed, wings buzzing with tension. "I thought you wanted to help people, not get tossed in a dungeon! There's more of them than us, genius!"

"Hahaha! Better listen to your tiny friend, kid! Now get out of our sight before we actually throw you in jail for threatening us... and mocking the law!"

I met their laughter with a slow, controlled glare. I could’ve humiliated all of them in five seconds flat. But Tatl was right. I was here to save this world, not beat up its idiots. I stomped away, letting the stomp of my boots echo with restrained fury.

"So, all the town guards here are about as useful as a wet paper knife," I muttered, brushing bits of hay that had drifted from one of the carts off my tunic.

Tatl zipped around to my side. "Seriously, what was that ? You just marched up to them like a cocky sword boy looking for a duel. Who even are you right now?"

"I dunno," I shrugged, flashing a lopsided grin. "Just... feels good to be me again."

"Well, tone it down, hero. You're starting to sound like one of them . Maybe that mask’s making you act all puffed up."

"Nah, it’s fine," I replied, waving her off. "I just gotta get used to feeling this strong again."

Tatl narrowed her eyes but let it go. "Alright then, what now? The guards are clearly useless."

"Yeah. Time to think."

"The Great Fairy maybe?"

"Not unless she’s relocated from that park. That place and I aren’t exactly on good terms," I grumbled.

I shifted off toward a quiet corner near a crooked mailbox by a crumbling stairway. A flicker of yellow and blue flashed from the alley nearby—something darting away. I ignored it. The world could wait a second.

I leaned on the mailbox, the sun glinting off its worn red exterior. "Healing the hearts and souls of the land"—what the hell was that supposed to mean? I needed direction, not riddles.

A small kid wearing a yellow Keaton mask brushed past me. He had sky-blue hair and carried himself like someone with a mission. He paused, stood on tiptoe, and slipped a pristine letter into the mailbox slot. I barely glanced at him. Just another piece in this strange, ticking town.

Back during my previous adventure in Hyrule, it seemed the path had always been lit ahead of me. All I had to do was listen to Navi—my, at the time, very annoying fairy companion—who thankfully had returned to the Kokiri Forest once her work was done. As shrill and irksome as she was, the blue pixie had always known exactly where to go next.

Tatl, on the other hand, seemed just as lost as I was. Still, if given the choice, I’d take her over Navi any day. Abrasive sarcasm was easier to stomach than the constant barrage of "Hey! Look! Listen!"

With no other leads to chase, I finally gave in to Tatl’s earlier suggestion.

"I've got nothing... I guess we can go talk to Anju," I muttered.

The boy in the yellow Keaton mask gasped and bolted into the alley at the mention of her name. Something about him prickled at the edge of my memory—but it slipped away before I could grab it.

"See??" Tatl huffed, floating just above my shoulder. "You should've just listened to me from the start."

"Whatever. Let's move. I'd rather get to where we’re needed before it’s too late."

"Pffft. Too late? You can bend time now, remember? We’ve got all the time in the world."

"That’s exactly why we shouldn’t waste it," I said. "Time is dangerous. You can’t just rewind the world forever without consequences. If you mess with it too much, it breaks ."

"Wait... seriously?" Tatl’s tone shifted from teasing to curious. "How do you even know that? You don’t look old enough to know how to shave, let alone time travel."

I smiled wryly. "I’ve got stories. Just not ones I feel like reliving. I came here to forget that part of my life... but I guess trouble follows me like a shadow."

"I’ve noticed," Tatl said, more gently this time. "So let me get this straight. You ran from all of it—war, destiny, trauma—and wound up back in the thick of it anyway? Transformed and everything?" She buzzed closer, her glow dimmer, more reflective. "That’s... rough. Hero work sounds like a curse."

I didn’t answer right away. The rising sun painted long shadows behind the rooftops and fences, and the scent of fresh bread mixed with smoke drifted through the cobbled street. Bells chimed faintly in the distance as stalls opened for the day.

"It is a curse sometimes," I said. "But it’s also a duty. I didn’t choose this life. But maybe it chose me. And if it did, then I have to carry it, whether I like it or not."

Tatl hovered beside me, quiet.

"For what it's worth," she finally said, her voice softer than I’d ever heard it, "I think you’re one of the strongest people I’ve ever met. And I don’t mean because of your sword. I mean... just you . The way you keep going."

I nodded, not trusting myself to speak.
