And as the two of us continued on through the awakening streets—through the noise and color and clamor—I realized something. Tatl wasn’t just a guide, she was a companion...one who saw more than she let on.

And for now... that was enough.

By the time we fought our way through the jostling crowds to the Stock Pot Inn, the sun blazed directly overhead, casting stark, golden light across the cobblestones. The moon still looked deceptively normal—its silver face soft and full above the rooftops—but a wrongness clung to it, subtle at first. As we walked, the expression seemed to shift ever so slightly, like a trick of the eye. The curve of a frown. The suggestion of eyes too deep, too knowing. It loomed a bit larger now, and a smoky haze began to gather at its edges like breath on glass. But no one looked up. Laughter and music filled the air as merchants hawked glittering wares and children darted beneath the legs of distracted shoppers. The festival clung to the town like a fevered dream, blinding everyone to the end creeping ever closer.

Each person I nudged past felt heavier than the last. My boots dragged, thudding dully against the uneven stone as if the weight of the world were pulling me down. My breath grew shorter, and the smell of roasted meat, perfume, and sweat churned my stomach. By the time we reached the inn’s battered oak door, I was stumbling, half-draped over it for support. I pressed my forehead against the sun-warmed wood, blinking hard to stop the street from spinning. My fingers fumbled at the doorknob, and then the dizziness won. I doubled over, knees nearly buckling.

"Link! What's wrong? Are you ok?!" Tatl’s voice pierced the noise, her glow flaring with urgency. "Wait...wait—your mask! You have to take it off, remember? The salesman warned you not to wear it for too long!"

Her words hit like a bucket of ice. In the rush of familiarity—of feeling whole again—I’d completely forgotten. The mask. My supposed return to self. But this body was a lie, one that fed on my spirit. My breath came in ragged bursts as I staggered sideways to brace against the cool stone wall, my gauntleted hand leaving a smear of sweat on the surface.

I could feel the tremor in my limbs, the way my heart raced too fast, too shallow. My strength was ebbing—siphoned away, moment by moment—just to keep the mask’s illusion alive.

"Come on! You have to remove the mask!"

I looked around, I couldn't change here. There were too many witnesses, and with my luck I would be burned at the stake for shape shifting if I was seen. "I...I can't...take it off here in..the open, Tatl!" I gasped.

"Well..umm...ok..." Tatl glanced around for a hiding place, then pointed, "There! Through that alley!"

She gestured to the narrow gap we had leapt over the previous morning, and I nodded wearily, slowly shambling towards the corridor. The few citizens who saw me laughed, thinking I was probably drunk. Tatl and I ignored them as I entered the shaded alley and I collapsed to the dirty, stone ground. I fought to move my armored gauntlets to my face. I managed to roll onto my back, and began to tug on my cheeks, hoping that the magical mask would pull free.

As I tugged at the mask’s edge, I felt my skin resist—like it didn’t want to let go. My vision doubled and then fractured like shattered glass, each shard humming with memories not entirely mine. My fingers felt like they were digging into warm wax, peeling back something alive and reluctant. Then—snap!—the mask came free, and with it, a breathless rush of cold air and physical collapse.

A pulse of searing heat surged through my chest, and I doubled over with a strangled gasp. My bones crunched inward, not breaking, but rearranging—like an invisible sculptor was molding clay with impatient hands. My armor clanked loosely against shrinking shoulders. My lungs seized for air, my breath hitching as my ribcage narrowed and my voice broke into something higher, softer, laced with panic and shame.

The change rippled outward... hair spilling like spilled ink down my neck, fingers tapering, hips flaring, a sickening swirl of motion in my gut that wasn’t pain so much as displacement. I could feel the curve of my breasts swell again beneath my tunic, the fabric stretching taut over the form I hadn’t yet accepted. A wave of helplessness clung to my skin like sweat. Then it was over. I was smaller, fragile, trembling—and unmistakably her again. My clothes even began to shimmer and transform right along with me! A few seconds later the transformation was over, and I heaved in deep breaths of air, feeling the unfortunate weight of breasts upon my chest again. I sat against the wall, chest rising and falling rapidly. My hands trembled as I brushed tangled bangs from my eyes...eyes that felt wider now, more vulnerable. I swallowed down the ache in my throat and stared at the mask lying on the ground beside me. It glinted in the light like a cruel joke, silent and inert. I didn’t know whether to be grateful for it… or afraid.

"Ughhh... gasp ...if it's going to be like this every time... huff ...then I'm really going to consider keeping the mask on," I groaned, my voice now unmistakably soft—gently pitched, with that haunting lilt I still wasn’t used to.

I pushed myself up with trembling arms, feeling the familiar tightness of my body return—feminine, compact, curved. I looked down and adjusted my tangled forest green cloak, pulling it behind me with a frustrated tug. My form-fitting dark brown tunic hugged close to my now-supple frame, cinched at the waist by the leather belt I had almost forgotten I wore. The tight black pants stretched snugly over my hips and thighs, now smaller but unmistakably shaped. The chill of the stone beneath my deerskin boots had crept through me—how long had I been lying there?

I grumbled, brushing a clump of dried alley grit from my thigh and leaning down to pluck the Hero’s Mask from the dirt. It felt heavier now. Not in weight, but in meaning. I held it for a beat too long before sighing and tucking it behind my belt on my right hip, as far from my heart as I could manage.

"I can't say I blame you. That looked like it really hurt," Tatl said gently, her voice quieter than usual. "I don't envy your position one bit. Umm... no offense."

"Gee, thanks..." I muttered, brushing my crimson bangs from my eyes. The strands were longer again—thick and soft, clinging to my cheeks. Everything about me was soft now, inside and out. I hated how easy it had become to move in this form. Hated that my body knew what to do before I did.

"Let's just go," I mumbled, voice edged with weariness. "Listening to me whine won't get us anywhere."

I shuffled out of the shaded alleyway and into the midday glow. Warm air hit my skin like silk. A breeze fluttered the hem of my cloak and cooled the sweat at my neck. Just ahead, the Stock Pot Inn's familiar wooden door rose into view like the promise of rest.

But before I could reach it, a troupe of circus performers and street dancers turned the corner in a lively swarm of silk and tambourines. They flooded the square in a kaleidoscope of color and laughter, blocking the entrance as they queued in a snaking line, chattering excitedly about their performances.

I stopped, letting out a sigh through my nose.

"Oh come on!" Tatl yelled. "That's just rude!"

"Oh! My apologies, ladies!" One of the colorful performers turned and bowed with exaggerated grace, his voice dripping with theatrical charm.

"Please do excuse our frightful rudeness. The others are a bit grumpy, you see!" An almost exact replica of the first performer offered a mirrored bow, his tone equally flamboyant. "You may surely go ahead of us, if you like?"

The performers were identical twins, unmistakable not just in appearance but in spirit. Each had a thick, bushy brown mustache that curled at the ends like the flourishes of a calligrapher’s pen. They wore extravagant jester costumes adorned with diamond patterns, puffy sleeves, and layered collars that wobbled with every movement. Their pointy cloth shoes curled upward at the toes, ending in golden bells that jingled with every exaggerated gesture.

One brother was clad primarily in crimson with sapphire trim, the other in deep azure with crimson accents. Their silk hats sagged under the weight of more bells, swaying with each bounce of their heads. Shocks of flat brown hair jutted out from beneath their caps like awkward feathers, and both had the same twinkling blue eyes—eyes that held mischief, but also a surprising depth of warmth.

Slung from their belts were pouches of juggling balls in every color imaginable. With a practiced flourish, they each pulled two balls into their palms and began juggling in synchronized rhythm, tossing and catching in perfect unison. The bright orbs glittered as they spun through the air, catching sunlight like jewels. Onlookers cheered from behind them, clapping in time with the acrobatic display.

"Umm...sure? Why not." I nodded. "Are you guys here for the carnival?" I had almost forgotten about the annual festival.

"Yes, as a matter of fact we are!" One twin declared with a flourish, spinning a juggling ball on his fingertip.

"Although I doubt we'll be staying long..." The other twin stuck a thumb up, gesturing to the sky. The moon high above had begun to shift again—its once calm, silvery surface slowly warping into grotesque animation. Cracks formed along its surface like splitting porcelain, revealing the cursed face beneath: wide, sunken eyes full of menace and a snarling, lipless grin that seemed to stretch across the sky. Its gaze bore down on the town like a wrathful god's judgment. "That little man in the moon seems to be a bit cranky today! Hohoho!"

"You could almost say this only happens once in a blue moon! Ohohoho!" The juggler dressed in blue chuckled, juggling three brightly-colored orbs that sparkled in the light.

Tatl and I shrugged at each other, neither one of us finding the joke funny.

"Oh, but did you hear about the swamp?" The red juggler asked, leaning in with mock secrecy.

"Uhhh no?" I braced myself for another horrible joke. "What about the swamp?"

"They say there was a kidnapping!"

"Oh my, a kidnapping? Did they catch the culprit?!" The blue juggler gasped dramatically, hands thrown to his cheeks.

"No, because the kid woke up! Aaaahahahaha!"

The twins erupted into hysterical laughter, clutching their sides and nearly dropping their juggling balls. I rolled my eyes and groaned, while Tatl planted a tiny glowing palm against her face in absolute disgust.

"Ahaha! I slay myself! Ohohoho!" the red juggler wheezed, kicking his curled shoe in glee.

"With jokes like that, you could also slay the horrifying monster that's haunting the swamp! Haha!" the blue juggler cackled, spinning on his heel.

Tatl perked up, her wings flickering with sudden interest. "Wait...are you guys still joking? Or is there seriously trouble in the swamp?"

"By my stubble, I'd say there was double trouble poison bubbles! Hohoho!" Red sang, throwing a juggling ball skyward.

Both Tatl and I groaned in unison, loud and exasperated, turning away to spare ourselves from further auditory punishment. The line into the inn had finally begun to move, and I silently prayed we'd be inside before another pun found its way into the air.

"Wait wait! We're sorry, truly we are!" the twins confessed in perfect chorus. They somersaulted in unison and landed with hands pressed together in apology. "It's just that we're entertainers, you see—bringing laughter is our solemn vow!"

"Except no one really finds us funny..." Red admitted, his shoulders sagging as one of his juggling balls slipped and rolled away.

"Tis truth," Blue nodded, managing to catch his before it hit the ground. His voice turned more serious as his eyes darted toward the eastern horizon. "But despite our buffoonery, there really is danger in the swamplands."

"Danger indeed," Red added gravely. "The waters are sick, the creatures twisted. People vanish without a trace. Even the wind feels heavier there."

The blue juggler's face darkened as he leaned forward. "Something ancient stirs in the murk. The locals whisper of shadows with teeth, of spirits gone mad. It’s not just superstition anymore."
The two of them shivered in unison, I couldn't tell if it was genuine or just to add to their theatrics.

"Wait a tic!" Blue suddenly exclaimed, snapping the moment. "That’s a fine-looking bow on your back! Are you a hunter? Or an adventurer perhaps?"

I reached instinctively for the bow, the polished blue wood cool beneath my fingers. I had nearly forgotten it was there—so light and perfectly balanced, the Great Fairy's gift felt like an extension of my will.

"Ooo, maybe she can slay the monster!" Blue quipped, resuming a gentle juggling pattern as he circled with glee.

"Oh yes! Then perhaps we could travel to the Deku Kingdom like we were supposed to do in the first place!" Red rejoiced, spinning dramatically. "No one seems to care how hard we work when we're in Clock Town... always laughing at us, never with  us."

Tatl hovered close to my ear. "They’re strange… but I think they’re being honest now. Maybe the swamp is where we need to go next."

I nodded quietly, casting one last glance at the twins, who now juggled with practiced sorrow. Their painted smiles didn’t quite reach their eyes anymore.

Tatl drifted close, her glow dim and purposeful, nudging my left arm with the back of her wings. "I think that's what we needed, Link. Now let’s get a move on before they notice we’re gone!" she whispered, not wanting to risk another pun assault.

But we weren’t fast enough.

"Ah, Link!" Blue suddenly called, locking eyes with me and giving a theatrical bow. "What an... interesting  name for a pretty little ranger such as yourself!"

Tatl audibly groaned and slapped a glowing palm over her face. "You’ve got  to be kidding me..."

"Umm... thanks? I guess?" I replied, my voice flat and cautious. I began inching away, throwing on the politest smile I could muster. "Look, guys, we really need to get going. But thanks for the tip. Seriously—that was helpful."

"Oh sure, no problem!" they chimed in perfect chorus. “Though you know, a tip might be—"

I didn’t wait to find out what their tip might be. I took off mid-sentence, sprinting through the bustling crowd before they could weaponize another punchline. Tatl zipped after me with a grateful sigh, weaving through the air like an arrow.

Once we rounded the corner and put a few buildings between us and the jugglers, I stopped to catch my breath and leaned against the side of a flower shop.

"Okay… whew ... at least we know where we’re going now. Where’s the nearest gate to the swamp?" I asked, still panting slightly.

Tatl huffed, hovering with her arms crossed in mock indignation. "Oh sure , just dash off and leave me to suffer with the court jesters! If I had to hear one more awful joke, I’d have chucked myself into a well."

I smirked and brushed a crimson strand of hair behind my ear. "Hey, I figured you’d be right behind me. No need to get all grumpy!"

"You’re lucky I like you," she muttered, but there was no heat in her words—only relief. "But yes, the gate to the swamp should be over on the south end of town. It was that gate nearest to the Star Chamber. You know where to go from here, right?"

"I'm still not entirely familiar with this city." I shrugged. "I think it'd be best if you led the way again."

"Okay, but you're gonna pay for leaving me behind like that, hehe!"

Tatl zipped ahead like a mischievous spark, darting between vendor stalls and colorful awnings with the giddy vengeance of a fairy who knew how to make me chase. I took off after her, weaving through the bustling crowd of townsfolk and ducking under clotheslines and banners strung across the street. The morning sun gleamed off the cobblestones, the scent of roasted nuts and fresh linen swirling in the air. A group of musicians played a jaunty tune in the plaza nearby, and a child ran past me with a bright ribbon trailing in her hand.

I was just getting my rhythm when Tatl suddenly stopped midair at a sharp turn near a flower stall, her wings frozen mid-flutter. I skidded to a halt, nearly bumping into her.

Her glow had dimmed, pulsing softly in a rhythm that suggested unease. "Did you hear that?"

"Hear what?" I asked, glancing around at the morning bustle.

She tilted her head. "I swear I thought I heard someone call for help... it was faint, but it came from that alley up ahead."

The joy of the festival melted from my thoughts as I followed her gaze. The alley beyond the archway lay in shadow, quiet and oddly still. A hush lingered there that didn’t match the rest of the street’s energy.

"C'mon, let’s go see! Maybe you’ll get to be a hero here after all!" Tatl teased, but her voice carried a thread of urgency.

Without another word, she shot forward, disappearing into the gloom.

And with a quiet sigh and the echo of bootsteps at my back, I dashed after her yet again...



Chapter Fifteen

Troublesome Town

The hum of Clock Town's South District swallowed us whole. I just barely managed to keep up with Tatl as the darting fairy zigzagged through the crowded backstreets. The buildings here leaned closer, casting long shadows that never quite lifted even under the noontime sun. Faded paint peeled from old signs, and warped awnings sagged with grime. Stalls clustered in tight rows, their vendors more sullen than cheerful, hawking wares with weary calls that sounded more like warnings. The scent wasn’t grilled meat and sweets anymore—it was smoke, oil, old bread, and something slightly metallic that lingered too long in the nostrils.

Without my mask, I wasn’t particularly intimidating. I had to practically dance through the cluster of townsfolk, dodging elbows and stepping over crates, sleeping dogs, and half-rotted fruit spilling from busted carts. My smaller frame got jostled constantly, and I was tossed to and fro as the crowd surged around me. Tatl must have seen me lagging behind, because I caught sight of her hovering just above a quieter alleyway a few meters ahead, her glow dimming with a rare stillness.

I finally burst free from the knot of bodies, chest heaving slightly, and found Tatl hovering in place above a narrow, dim corridor choked with shadow. Her glow pulsed in sharp, cautious flickers, her eyes locked on something ahead. I started to ask why she’d stopped so abruptly, but she raised a tiny, pale hand to shush me.

"There it is again! Listen..." she whispered, wings barely fluttering.

I stilled beside her, letting the city's din simmer into background noise. Distant shouting. A drunken laugh. The rattle of a cart wheel catching a stone. But under it all, barely audible—like a breath beneath a storm—I heard it.

"Help... someone help me..."

Tatl turned sharply toward one of the cement walkways branching off the main road. It was narrow, shaded, the kind of place no one paid attention to unless they were already lost.

"It sounds like it’s coming from over there," I said, gesturing. "But... don’t we have somewhere to be? There’s bigger fish to fry in the swamp."

Tatl whirled around to face me, arms crossed. "Was that supposed to be a joke? Way to poke fun at someone else’s misfortune."

Her glare faltered as I raised an eyebrow, amused.

"Hey, don't give me that look! You know what I meant. Come on. If someone’s in trouble, we check it out. That’s what heroes do, right?"

"Hey! There are more important things, Tatl! This is a city—there's always going to be trouble somewhere." I crossed my arms. "And besides, when did you start caring? You usually just mock people’s pain—mine included. What's with the sudden conscience, huh?"

Tatl zipped up to my face, wings buzzing in irritation. Her mouth opened, ready to snap back—then closed again.

"Maybe it's because I'm trying to save my brother." Her voice cracked as her anger dimmed into something quieter. "And... maybe... I'm trying to save myself."

I blinked, caught off guard by the honesty.

"What do you mean? As long as you stick with me, the moon won’t fall on you—if that’s what you’re afraid of."

"No, that’s not it!" she snapped, exasperated. "You don’t get it, Link. I've done terrible things. I helped Skull Kid—I laughed at his pranks, I encouraged him! And now... after everything we saw, after what he became... I can’t just pretend I wasn’t part of it."

She hovered uncertainly, then added in a hushed tone, "I need to do something right. Even if it’s small. Even if it’s just helping one person."

Before I could respond, another pained cry rang out, sharper this time. A gruff voice followed: "Shut up, wimp!"

Tatl flinched, wings quivering.

I exhaled slowly and gave a reluctant nod. "You’re right. I haven’t exactly been thinking clearly either. Heroes don’t get to pick who’s worth saving. Everyone matters. And… if you’re trying to make things right—then I respect that, Tatl."

Her glow softened. Together, we crept to the corner of the walkway. I leaned against the wall of a crumbling stone house and peeked around.

The person calling for help, a boy around my age it looked like, was cornered several meters down an alleyway, surrounded by three older men who looked more like castoffs from a rotting pirate ship than citizens of a peaceful town. One of them shoved the boy against a wall, laughter thick with menace. I couldn’t see the kid’s face yet, just his tangled black hair and thin limbs curled protectively.

Tatl's light strobed in anger, casting a flickering glow across the shadowed alley walls. I reached instinctively for the mask at my belt. Time to be a hero again—or so I thought.

No one else bothered to help the boy, it seemed. The few shameful cowards that strolled along the walkway outside the alley pretended not to see, skirting the confrontation with their eyes fixed on the ground. I glared at them, disgusted by their indifference, by the way they made themselves ghosts in the presence of violence.

"You have to go help that kid, Link!" Tatl shouted, her voice sharp in my ear like a cracked bell.

"Owww! Geez! Not so loud!" I flinched and covered my ear. "I can hear you just fine without the audio assault."

"Sorry, but look! We gotta help! Those creeps are twice his size! Who knows what they're gonna do to him!"

"Yeah, yeah, I'm on it... hang on."

I reached for my mask, fingers brushing the smooth wood where it hung at my belt. I braced myself for the usual pull—the searing heat, the painful twist of bone and flesh that marked my transformation. I pressed the mask to my face... and nothing happened. Cold wood. Dead weight.

My heart thudded once in confusion. I lowered the mask, turned it in my hands. It looked fine. I tried again. Still nothing.

"What's wrong? Why isn't it working?" Tatl asked, panic creeping into her voice.

"I don't know... Do you think the salesman tricked us? Maybe it was only supposed to work once?" I muttered, shaking the mask as if that might jolt some forgotten magic back into it. "Feels useless now."

"But why would he lie? He needs you to get his mask back. What would he gain by screwing you over?"

"Good point," I muttered. "Maybe it needs time to recharge."

Tatl hovered closer, wings twitching anxiously. "You did  wear it for a long time. The Salesman said it draws from your spirit. If you used too much of yourself... maybe you need to recover before you can transform again."

The boy cried out again, his voice ragged and desperate—a raw, unfiltered panic that sliced through the chaos of the alleyway. It hit me like a gut-punch, bypassing reason, bypassing fear. I placed the useless Hero’s Mask back on my belt, my hands trembling with frustration. My soul—my self —was still too hollow to summon its power.

I wasn’t just powerless.

I was trapped in the wrong skin again, and someone needed saving.

I froze for a heartbeat, listening to the pitiful cries echo from deeper in the alley. My body—slight and lithe, foreign and fragile—offered no reassurance. These weren’t just schoolyard bullies. These were grown men. Monsters, really. Hardened criminals with blood on their hands and no fear of consequence. I couldn’t fight them head-on. Not like this.

But I did have the bow.

“ Hey, we can’t just stand here and do nothing!” Tatl zipped in front of me, her wings flickering with urgency. “You’ve gotta stop them!”

"Ugh... fine. But if I get pummeled, I’m blaming you ."

She didn’t argue.

I sprinted toward the alleyway, my pulse thundering in my ears. The scene slammed into me like a blow to the chest. The group of brutish men—grimy, mean-eyed, and thick with cruelty—had already worked the boy over. He was crumpled on the ground, one arm twisted awkwardly beneath him, the other draped over his head in a feeble attempt at defense. Blood smeared the cobblestones near his mouth, and his breath came in short, panicked gasps. The men loomed above him like vultures, laughing, kicking at his sides with sick delight, savoring every flinch. I couldn’t yet see his face clearly, but he was scrawny—fragile in a way that made their assault feel monstrous.

I skidded to a stop just outside the mouth of the alley. Their stench hit me even from the entrance, a vile blend of body odor, sour ale, and the metallic tang of blood. Every instinct screamed at me to run—but I squared my stance, drew a shaky breath, and stepped into view.

"Hey!" I shouted, voice wavering. "Leave that kid alone!"

The words left my mouth brittle and too high-pitched, barely cutting through the suffocating silence of the alley. They bounced off the bricks like glass shattering—delicate, ineffective. I winced at the echo, hating how weak I sounded, how far I'd fallen from the commanding presence I once took for granted.

The degenerates turned toward me, halting their assault on the collapsed boy. He lay in a crumpled heap near the alley wall, blood streaking from his mouth, his limbs limp and unmoving. Upon seeing me, the attackers erupted into derisive laughter, clearly mistaking my smaller frame for weakness.

Leading them was a greasy, unsavory man with matted, orangish hair slicked to one side and pustules peppering his unwashed face. His yellow chaps were stained and frayed, and his boots were so worn the soles flapped. Two rust-pocked cutlasses hung at his waist from a scarred leather belt. His torso, glistening with sweat, was only half-covered by a black vest emblazoned with a faded skull insignia, parted to expose his hairy, grime-caked chest.

"Wahaha! Lookie here, boys! Fresh meat!" he bellowed in a grating accent, clearly amused. "The cute mouse thinks she’s gonna tangle with alley cats, huh? Let’s show ‘er how we play, Zip."

A towering brute stepped forward, easily twice my size. A jagged scar tore through his left brow, and crude ink covered his thick arms in twisted designs. His eyes, bloodshot and sunken, traveled over me with vile hunger. He licked his cracked lips as he drew a curved knife from the folds of his grimy coat, stepping over the injured boy like he was a pile of garbage.

"Heheheh… You’re right, Faz," he sneered. "C’mere, sweet thing. I like my meat rare."



He advanced slowly, savoring the moment with a sick grin that promised more than just violence. The way his eyes lingered on me wasn’t just predatory—it was possessive, calculating. Behind him, the rest of the gang snickered, their amusement cruel and cold, emboldened by the thought of what Zip might do once he got his hands on me. My breath hitched; terror had me by the throat, curling cold fingers down my spine. But even as panic tried to root me to the ground, instinct surged up and overrode it. I yanked the Great Fairy’s bow from my back, my fingers trembling, slick with sweat, my pulse thudding in my ears. The leather grip pressed into my palm, grounding me. The polished wood thrummed beneath my fingers like it recognized me, like it was waiting. I held my ground, heart pounding, breath shallow. Even afraid, even trembling, I wouldn't let them see me break.

“ If you come one step closer to me, I swear you'll regret it!" I shakily warned, terrified to find out exactly which images played through the gangsters' sick minds. The men laughed at my threat, hearing the fearful quaver in my voice.

Faz threw his head back and roared with laughter. "Shoot what, darlin’? You ain’t got any arrows! That’s just a pretty stick!"

As Zip took another step forward, menace radiating from his hulking frame, I instinctively drew the string. Once again, a brilliant shaft of light flared to life—startling, radiant, alien. I gasped, still unfamiliar with the magic of the bow, but I didn’t lower it. I let the bolt loose with practiced release of the drawstring.

FWAAAAHHHSSSSSsss !

Zip halted mid-step, his eyes bulging wide in pained surprise. He looked down to find that the searing beam of light had punched straight through his chest like a lance of molten glass. A smoking, cauterized tunnel cut clean through flesh and bone, the air instantly thick with the choking stench of scorched leather and charred meat. My stomach lurched as the acrid heat clawed its way into my lungs. The edges of the wound hissed and spat, tiny sparks arcing from the seared hole like embers dancing off a forge.

The man gasped, a wet, rattling sound, and spat a splatter of dark blood onto the cobblestones. His sword clanged to the ground. For a heartbeat, he stood—then his knees buckled. His hulking frame toppled forward with a deafening THUD , kicking up a puff of dirt and ash. One last twitch... then silence.

The other thugs froze. All their cruel bravado drained in an instant. They stared at me—not with anger, but with true, visceral horror. And for the first time... they looked afraid.

"Wha... you... you fracking killed 'im! My goddess-damned BEST MAN!" Faz cried, voice shrill and cracking with disbelief.

I stood there stunned, the bow still humming softly in my grip. That wasn’t my intention. I hadn’t even known  the weapon could do that. The power of it... the raw, merciless power had taken even me by surprise.

I exhaled slowly, shaking, finally releasing the breath that had locked in my chest. My fingers still quivered around the grip. Swallowing hard, I lifted my chin and met the thugs’ horrified gazes with steel in my eyes.

"I warned you," I said, voice low and cold, the fear now buried beneath something sharper. I pulled the bowstring again, another bolt of light flaring to life between my fingers, humming with deadly promise. "Let the boy go. Or you're next."

The renegades scrambled over each other as they tried to flee down the alley, leaving Zip's still warm corpse behind. Tatl hovered silently over my shoulder, wings humming low, her usual sharp commentary replaced with stunned silence. The boy they had cornered—the one I had thought barely conscious—dragged himself upright with a sharp wince. He limped over to the body, fists clenched, and with a cry somewhere between pain and triumph, kicked Zip’s corpse with all the strength he could muster. The dull thud echoed in the alley. Thick, red blood poured from the gaping wound, snaking between cobblestones before vanishing into a nearby gutter.

"Take that, you sick bastard!" the youth spat, his voice raw. "You deserved every bit of pain you got!"

Up close, I could see the damage the gang had done to him. His blue cotton shirt was torn at the seams, clinging to a frame that was wiry and bruised. The white vest he wore—frayed at the edges—had the number "three" stitched in red thread on the back, identifying him as one of the Bombers. His baggy dark blue trousers hung awkwardly on his slim frame, the waistband cinched with a rope instead of a belt. He looked about my age—seventeen, maybe eighteen—but carried the hardness of someone older. His black hair stuck out in scraggly tufts, tangled and damp with sweat. Grey-green eyes, sharp and intelligent despite the swelling, scanned the alley as if still expecting more danger. A bruise blossomed along his cheek, and a darkening black eye turned his gaze into a lopsided scowl. His jaw was squared with stubborn pride, and despite the limp and the bruises, he stood like someone who refused to stay down.

After he was finished kicking and stomping on Zip's lifeless body, the boy turned toward me, breath ragged and chest heaving, his sea green eyes burning bright with disbelief and awe.

"You... you saved my life," he said, voice hoarse, cracking not from weakness but from the weight of it all. Tears spilled freely now, tracking down bloodied cheeks. "You have no idea what they were going to do to me... what this sick bastard was going to do to me!"

He lashed out again at Zip’s body, his foot striking the limp corpse with a vengeance that echoed like a punctuation mark. Tatl flinched, her light flickering as she hovered back a few inches—not out of fear of the boy, but from the sudden return of brutality after such a surreal stillness. "Okay, whoa... I don't know what he was about to do, but kicking a dead body won't help you feel better," Tatl said, hovering cautiously, her usual snark blunted by the weight of what had just happened. Her glow remained dimmer than usual, as if reflecting the lingering shock in the air.

"Uhhh... you’re welcome," I murmured, uncertain, eyes still locked on the smoking remains of my enemy. "I didn’t mean to kill him though. I just wanted to scare him off..."

"Don’t you dare regret it," the boy growled, voice suddenly hard and steady, though his hands trembled. "This guy was... not human. He was a monster. They all were."

His fists clenched, knuckles white with rage and memory. He shook from the weight of it, then exhaled long and slow—as if purging poison from his lungs. And then, as if drawn by some instinctual pull, his eyes landed on the glimmering blue bow slung over my shoulder. For a moment, all the pain slipped from his face, replaced by something raw and reverent. A flicker of awe, like he'd just seen magic for the first time—and couldn't quite believe it saved him.

"So... I haven't really seen you around? We usually catch wind pretty quick of strangers with magical weapons." The boy stepped forward, wiping the corner of his mouth with the back of his hand. His lank black hair fell across his brow. He was maybe a few inches taller than me in my current form, with a wiry, restless energy behind his dark eyes. He extended a scraped, calloused hand, muscles thin but coiled like a street cat ready to bolt or pounce. "Name's Ratt."

"Umm... Link," I replied, giving his hand a light shake. His palm was rough with dirt and old scars.

"Huh? Really? Weird name for a girl—but kinda awesome. Like, 'stick-it-to-em' awesome."

"Why does everyone say that? What's wrong with my name?" I sighed, sharper than I meant to.

"Oh! I didn't mean it like that! Just... sounds bold, y'know? Like something you'd shout from a rooftop." Ratt rubbed the back of his neck awkwardly. "So, uh... where are you two headed?"

Tatl finally piped up, snapping out of her stunned silence. "We're going to the swamp. And we're outta time to talk about it—it's already three thirty, according to the Clock Tower!"

The sunlight had thinned into amber veins across the alley walls, casting long, slanted shadows through the grime. A breeze pushed the stench of mildew and fried oil past us, and the murmur of distant bells reminded me how little time we had.

"The swamp? Seriously? You know there's a monster out there poisoning everything, right? People go in and they don’t come out."

"Yeah, we heard something like that. But we’ve got our reasons." I turned on my heel, cloak whipping behind me. "Thanks again... and stay out of trouble."

As I turned, my cloak shifted and revealed the Hero’s Mask at my hip.

"Whoa! That mask is awesome! Looks all brave and fierce and stuff! Where’d you get it? I've never seen anything like that. Bet if I had one, even the worst creeps around here wouldn’t mess with me anymore."

"It's... special," I muttered, tucking the fabric back into place over my mask. "One of a kind. I seriously doubt there's another like it."

He stared at me a beat longer, something unreadable in his eyes. Not envy—more like yearning

"Well, I gotta say, you'd look way more intimidating with it on. I would’ve never guessed you were that tough, just from looking. You’re so small, kinda frail-looking... and well, really pretty. Like, goddess-tier pretty."

His words stumbled out like loose pebbles—awkward, too loud, clearly unrehearsed. He blushed the moment they left his mouth.

I shot him a glare, then turned away and kept walking, jaw tight.

"Hey, wait—that was a compliment! You don’t like compliments or something?"

"Look, kid. I'm busy. You're welcome and all for me saving you, but I've got a lot to do. You can't follow me where I’m going. And no, I’m not much for being called pretty. So just... go away, okay?"

"Sheesh, you’re one weird chick, you know that?" he called after me, trying to laugh it off. "And who are you calling kid? You don’t look any older than me!"

I tried to ignore him and picked up my pace, weaving through the dusty side street. But the persistent idiot kept stride with me, undeterred

"So..uhh... look, I'm part of this group, right? We call ourselves the Bombers, and we go around trying to help people, too." Ratt awkwardly massaged his neck as he prattled on. "Maybe I can pull some strings and, you know, get you a membership?"

I sighed, putting a hand on my face while Tatl chuckled. "Looks like you have an admirer, hehe!"

I took a swat at the precocious fairy, who dodged by increasing her altitude and continued giggling.

"We don’t have time for this," I growled. "You can’t follow me, Ratt. It’s too dangerous, and you’ll just get in the way. I don’t need help, and I’m not joining your club. Got it?"

"Ya know what? I like your style, Link. Tough, relentless, stone-cold. Hah! I dig that."

I stopped in my tracks, exasperated, and turned to face him fully, hands planted firmly on my hips.

"Leave me alone! Just because I saved your life doesn't mean you're invited to tag along. Don't you have somewhere to be right now? Like your secret sewer club hideout?"

Ratt froze mid-step. "Wait... how’d you know about our hideout?" He leaned in, wide-eyed, lowering his voice like he was sharing a royal secret. "No one's supposed to know but us Bombers. That’s, like, rule number one."

That did it. I snapped.

"You mean the place under the Star Chamber with the old ladder, the smell of moldy laundry, and rats the size of Cuccos guarding your stash of candy bars?"

Ratt's jaw dropped. His expression flickered from horror to amazement, then landed squarely on adoration.

"Whoa! You're like one of those legendary garo scouts from Ikana!! Jim’s gonna lose his mind when I tell him about you!"

I groaned and rubbed my temples, already regretting engaging.

"I mean, you just—you show up, save my life, humiliate the Blood Wolves, shoot magic arrows, and now you know our hideout? Who are  you? Like, were you trained by secret royal warriors or something??"

Before I could protest or escape, Ratt zipped forward like a blushing hurricane and planted a quick, awkward kiss on my cheek.

I blinked, stunned. The world tilted. Heat surged up my face.

My fingers curled instinctively around my bow as he bolted, laughing like a boy who'd outrun fate. In one smooth, furious motion, I yanked it free, drew, and let a bolt of radiant magic shriek past his heels. The flash popped against the cobblestones, and Ratt yelped like a kicked Cucco, vaulting into the air.

"Oooh, feisty ! I love  that!" he crowed, already disappearing around the corner, laughter trailing behind him. Somewhere in the distance, I could just make out, " I'm totally in love with you! "

"Hahaha! He got you so  good!" Tatl cackled, spinning in place. "You should’ve seen your face!"

"Seriously, Tatl?" I snarled, still fuming. "Can we not  do this right now?"

"Aww, come on !" she wheezed. "That was hilarious. Admit it. Just a little bit."

"No. It wasn't. I'm still a guy, remember? I just—" I faltered, voice tight. "I just killed someone, Tatl. And you're out here laughing like it was some kind of carnival stunt."

Tatl’s laughter faded, her wings drooping a little as she floated nearer. "Hey... I know. I just—Ratt caught us off guard, and I guess I needed the tension break. But you did good, Link. You helped that kid. That’s what the Mask Salesman meant, right? Healing the hurt in this world. You did that today."

I let out a bitter huff. "Whether I helped or not, we’re wasting time. You wanna crack jokes, go join the jugglers. Otherwise, point the way."

"Okay, okay! You big sourpuss!" she said, offering a half-smile as she zipped ahead. "Southside’s just this way. Try not to melt before we get there."

She flitted down the walkway, back toward the main road. I stared after her a beat, then sighed and followed. The air felt heavier now— from everything that had happened. The swamp still lay ahead, probably a day’s journey at least. And we were already behind. There was too much to do… and not enough time to do it.

Suddenly an idea popped into my mind.

"Wait, that's it! If the Ocarina can control Time, then maybe I could use it to keep time from moving too quickly!" I quietly reasoned, eyes widening with sudden inspiration.

"Tatl! Hang on, I just thought of something!" I called out to the pixie flying just up ahead.

"But, I thought we were in a hurry? Make up your mind!" Tatl scolded, her wings fluttering with irritation.

"Look." I produced the shimmering blue instrument from my belt pouch, the metal accents cool against my fingertips. "If we could turn it back with this, maybe we could slow time down as well?"

"How? Is there another special song you know that can do that?"

"Hmmm... no. Not really anything specific to stopping time, unless..."

I gently raised the Ocarina to my lips, the sun catching its curves with a soft gleam. As I blew the first notes of the Song of Time, the air around us shifted. The melody drifted through the streets like wind through chimes, ethereal and slow, curling through the bustle of the plaza. A hush seemed to fall—briefly—as if the world leaned in to listen.

A few of the common townsfolk stopped in their tracks, gazes drawn toward me with mild curiosity, some swaying unconsciously to the haunting cadence. Each note shimmered in the space between seconds, stretching them out, warping the edges of time itself. I focused all my will on the intention: not to reverse time, but to stretch it—to slow its river to a crawl.

As the final note faded, I held my breath. The onlookers blinked and slowly returned to their business. The moment passed.

Tatl hovered beside me, watching the scene with narrowed eyes. After a beat, she shrugged. "Well... did it work?"

I looked around, scanning for anything out of place. The crowd still bustled, voices rose and fell, merchants hawked their wares with the same fervor as before. The same elderly man leaned over his rickety cart, still bartering over...questionable apples. Nothing had changed.

"Well, it was worth a shot," Tatl said with a halfhearted flap of her wings. "If anything, it's a pretty neat song. But c'mon, let's go. It shouldn't be too much longer to the southern gate."

"Alright," I murmured, sliding the Ocarina back into my pouch. Yet something tugged at the edge of my senses.

The air felt just a little heavier, like the hush before a storm—or a moment caught in amber. But with the town still moving, it must have been my imagination. A single leaf detached from a nearby branch and hovered for an impossibly long moment before drifting slowly downward...maybe too slowly. But I didn't have time to think about it too long as Tatl was already on the move. I stepped after Tatl, trailing just behind her. With every footfall, the bustle of Clock Town seemed to peel away like a dream I was waking from. I was more eager than ever to leave it behind—to get away from the asinine guards, the aggravatingly flirtatious boys, the snide stares and suffocating streets.

Out there was the unknown—untamed, perilous, and free. A world of awe and danger and wild, uncharted possibilities. And for the first time in what felt like forever, my heart beat with something close to joy.

Adventure. The exhilaration of the unknown.

Limitless possibilities awaited, and for once in a long time, I was truly in my element.

Chapter Sixteen

Termina Field

The blazing mid afternoon sun still shone high in the blue skies when we reached the old, eroded southern gate. The guard had discarded his visor, his sweat-slicked face weary beneath the sunlit blaze. He slouched against the chalky white limestone wall, brow furrowed as he wiped at the heat with little urgency. Around him, the southern commons simmered in slow decay...unkempt locals sprawled in the patchwork shade cast by leaning shanty roofs, waving scraps of paper or warped tin lids to stir the still air. Barefoot children darted between crumbling alleyways, their laughter sharp against the dusty silence, vanishing like mirages among weed-choked cracks in the pavement.

The heat clawed at my skin like invisible fingers, dragging sweat from every pore until my tunic clung to me like a soaked rag. It was hotter than it had been on that first day...oppressively so, like the sun itself was bearing down with the intent to set the world ablaze. My breath came shallow, fogging the air for just a heartbeat before the heat swallowed it whole. Behind me, Tatl fluttered low, her glow dulled to a wan shimmer. Even her voice...usually sharp and relentless, sounded slurred by the intense warmth.
“ Ughhh… why is it so hot?” she groaned, wings flitting uselessly. “This isn’t normal, Link. The sun… it hasn’t moved in hours.”

“ Whew… I don’t know…”

I panted, brushing damp strands of hair from my forehead with the back of my hand. The heat pressed down like a weight, sticky and relentless.

“ What time is it, anyway?”

Tatl hovered toward the towering spires of the Clock Tower, squinting through the shimmering heat haze that danced like water over the rooftops. Her glow pulsed faintly, flickering with uncertainty.
“ It’s… still only three-forty? That can’t be right. It feels like it’s been at least an hour since you rescued that kid!”

 “Really?” I murmured, my voice low as I brushed damp bangs from my eyes. “You don’t think playing the Ocarina… did  something to time, do you?”

"Well...I dunno, you've got more experience with that thing. So you tell me?"

I observed the people around us. They all moved, talked, and played at a fairly normal pace. If the magical instrument had stopped time, I would only assume that the rest of the world would stop with it.

"Hmm...these people are all moving around, so I don't think time froze. Maybe you just saw the clock wrong earlier?" I deduced.

"Well, we were pretty distracted, especially you haha." Tatl winked at me as I glowered in response. "Oh come on, lighten up! The gate’s right there. We’ll figure it out soon enough."

I nodded to Tatl, her laughter picking up my spirits a bit, and looked to the gate. The guard was still bumbling around, now lazily playing catch with his helmet. He seemed oblivious of us. Still...without my mask, I doubted that I'd be allowed through. I gripped the wooden surface with clammy fingers from the belt, inspecting it closely to see if anything had changed. Something about it felt different now. As I lifted it in my hands, its surface shimmered faintly with vitality, almost alive.

"I'm going to try changing back," I told her, stepping toward an old crate beside a decaying home. "I've got a good feeling about the mask this time."

Tatl hovered closer. "Good idea. I don’t feel like dealing with another idiot guard in this weather. I’m right behind you."

I searched around the crate and house for any possible witnesses. Finding no one and satisfied we were alone, I took a deep breath and braced myself, bringing the mask to my face. I held back a muffled shriek as pain once more enveloped my body, and fought to stay on my feet. It wasn't as excruciating as before, but the heat of transformation still stole the breath from my lungs. Bones cracked and lengthened, my limbs shifting back into their taller, broader shape. I grunted, barely keeping on my feet. The familiar weight of gauntlets and boots returned.

"Are you ok? Not going to pass out or anything, right?" Tatl voiced in concern.

"Agh, no. I think..." I cleared my throat, startled by the suddenly deeper timbre. "I think I’ll be fine. That wasn’t so bad."

"Yeah well, could've fooled me, but I'd rather not try the experience myself."

"Can’t blame you there." I stretched my arms and tested my balance, adjusting the chain-mail armor beneath the familiar green tunic. "But I’ll take transforming back into my  body over being a weak girl any day."

After a similar assessment with my boots, I was satisfied that everything was in order. I made my way back to the limestone gates. The temperature seemed to rise with every passing minute, and the sun beat down fiercely upon me during the short walk. However, I wasn't worried about a little summer weather, and confidently strode up the aloof guard. The perspiring soldier appeared to be mildly dehydrated, but nodded to me as I closed in, waving us by with a dazed look in his eyes.

"Yuh, you can go through. Be careful though...monsters...n' stuff..." He sighed.

"Uhhh, right. Thanks, I guess."

I returned his nod and plodded through the gate, heading beneath the thick wall. The shade did little to ease the heat, and my face was already beading with sweat. The weather was still manageable, though, and I'd been through much greater heat before. If the fires of Hyrule's great volcano Death Mountain couldn't conquer me, then a meager heatwave like this would be a cakewalk

"So what's the plan, Mighty Hero?" Tatl flopped onto my shoulder with a groan.

"We get to the swamp, find whatever monster is plaguing the area, slice it to pieces, and dice any other beasts into slimy pulps. Then afterwards the locals say hooray and thank us, we move on to whatever else we need to do. Easy, simple, cut and dry." I wiped away a drop of sweat hanging down from my brow.

"Oh, yes. Totally simple there, monster hunter...What a smart tactic... 'RAAUUGGHR LINK SMASH!'” Tatl sprawled onto my shoulder like a wet towel, “...we're gonna die..."

I ignored her snark and continued out into the wide expanse of the flatlands before us. All the trees and foliage had been cut down and beaten back for almost a kilometer around the walls of Clock Town, leaving only fields of dry grass. The blue sky was bright and clear, with no clouds to block the harsh sun, nor wind to ease the soaring temperatures. The heat was finally starting to get to me, and I turned to Tatl in frustration.

"Alright, Miss Critic, if you're finished roasting me, how about you stop using my shoulder as a free ride and tell me where we need to go?"

"Oh come on! I'm just joking, and your shoulder is comfy! But fine... just go past that hill with the Star Chamber. If I remember right, there should be a fork in the trail." The fairy thought for a moment. "I think the left path leads to a ranch, or farm... or something. Taking the right path takes you to the swamp, maybe..."

"Your confidence is almost overwhelming..." I scoffed, then rolled my eyes with a sigh. "Ughf...whatever. Let's just get there..."

Aware that my mask's power wouldn't last long, I decided to run toward the copse of trees near the hill to save time. Tatl was caught off guard and tumbled off my shoulder as I lurched forward without warning. The parched grass crunched beneath my boots as I sprinted along. The disgruntled fairy fluttered after me, grumbling about being knocked off her comfy perch.

Halfway to the trees, the earth suddenly shimmered, and two red, slimy Chuchus erupted from the ground in front of me. With a grin, I drew my sword and shield and waited for the monsters to make a move. They both wiggled in anticipation before leaping at me, the gelatinous bodies undulating as they moved. They lunged. I sidestepped and brought my sword down in one clean arc, bisecting them. Their jellied remains hit the dirt with a wet slap. Red goop splattered everywhere and bled out onto the thirsty earth, along with the liquefied remains of some poor fool's hand and torso.

"Ewwww that was...gross." Tatl retched as the ooze evaporated. "But uh...good job. Best not to end up like...ugh...that guy."

"That was nothing. If you want to see gross, you should go to Hyrule's graveyard."

I chuckled as I wiped red globules from my blade into the dry grass, watching the goopy remains quickly evaporate.

"Reanimated corpses, blood and gore, disembodied rotting skulls...you'd love it!"

"Oh gee, sounds like such a treat. Thanks but no thanks...blech!"

I sheathed my sword behind me, and returned the Hylian shield to my back. Mirages danced along the horizon in the sweltering heat, and my face dripped with sweat onto my damp tunic. The air was deathly still, without even a gasp of wind to alleviate the scorched earth. I looked to the skies, where the sun remained in the same position when we l town.

"Well, the sun still hasn't moved. I think the Ocarina actually stopped time!" I marveled to Tatl.

"Greeeaaaat...can you play it again? If it gets any hotter, and I think I'll literally combust." Tatl groaned as she fanned herself.

"Yeah, I might as well. Hang on..." I nodded and went for my Ocarina.

I reached into the respective belt pouch, but came up empty handed. Figuring that I had unconsciously moved to a different one, I shrugged and felt around the other pouches. Still unable to find the Ocarina, I frantically searched along the ground to see if I somehow dropped it! The blue instrument was nowhere to be seen!

"What's wrong?" Tatl noticed the panic in my eyes. "You didn't lose it did you? Oh gods, please tell me you didn't!"

"No! I always put it right back in this pouch here!" I pointed to the rear pouch. "But it's not there!"

"Well...we're doomed. Between the sun broiling everything alive, and the moon falling. Yeah, this world is toast! Or jelly, depending on what happens first."

"This is no time for your jokes!" I bellowed, the fairy flinched at my booming voice. "If we don't find that Ocarina, we're all doomed!"

"Ok ok, GEEZ!" Tatl muttered defensively. "Just calm down, take a breath, and think. Surely no one stole it from you. What could have possibly happened to it?"

I took a deep breath and roughly massaged my temples. I winced as I felt the second skin almost tear away and I pushed my palms against it, keeping it in place.

"I hate this thing. I can't even think properly without it falling off!"

"Wait... Link, that's it! The mask!" Tatl chimed. "It's a complete magical change, so maybe it totally alters your gear, as well as your clothes and weapons!"

"So... What you're saying is that I can only play my Ocarina without my mask? Only as a blasted idiot girl?!" I growled, the heat of the sun making my anger worse.

"Apparently! Now calm down! It's not such a bad thing, and it could always be worse!" Tatl chided, wagging her tiny fingers at me. "I've seen the Skull Kid tear things apart with his mind, and explode people from the inside out. It's a wonder you're even alive after both failed encounters. Now take off the mask and play your flute thing! This heat is making me crazy!"

I scowled at the pixie, seething that she was probably right, and hissed a response through my teeth.

Fine...stupid fairy."

I hesitated for a moment, then reached for the mask, bracing myself.

The transformation back hit fast, a torrent of twisting, tightening, shrinking . I clenched my teeth as my limbs reformed, my clothes shifting around a suddenly unfamiliar body. When it passed, I gasped for breath...lighter, smaller, back to this stupid form.

"There...*huff*... happy now?" I gasped at the fairy as the shifting finished.

"Yes...sort of. Now can you hurry?" Tatl replied.

I rolled my eyes at the fairy, watching my crimson locks sway as I reached into the pouch behind the restored cloak. Sure enough, the Ocarina was resting within. I gripped the instrument and pulled it to my face, pursing my lips. The Ocarina once more echoed throughout the area as I played the Song of Time. I focused my thoughts towards time flowing normally. The final notes echoed across the fields. A breeze stirred. And the world shivered around us as the cool air seemed to refresh the lands again.

"Well...you were right after all, Tatl.” I sighed, “I can only use the Ocarina in this body. Wonderful...."

As I returned the instrument to my belt, the sun began to quickly retreat down to the horizon. As if it were attempting to restore itself within the present. The cool breeze suddenly became freezing gusts, and then mighty gales which knocked me to the ground. Tatl gripped onto my bow for dear life as I desperately tried to keep from blowing away as a frozen icicle. As quick as it started, the tempest suddenly ceased and the world once again became silent.

"Umm...what just happened?" Tatl hovered, flabbergasted at the now-dark sky.

"I think that was time catching up to itself. So much for trying to get ahead... I hope we bought ourselves a little more at least." I gasped and stood up, brushing away frozen sweat and dust room my face and clothing.

"I dunno, but I'm sure everyone is freaking out right now. Between the moon, the sun, and crazy wind, I think I'd have gone bonkers if I didn't already know what was going on!"

"Me, too. Maybe we shouldn't stop time again. It might be worse than just heat and wind next time. Oh, and umm...sorry for snapping at you earlier...I didn't mean it. The sun was probably affecting my mood."

"Yeah, you better be sorry!" Tatl smirked. "If it happens again, I'll have to tear you to pieces, wahaha!"

"Oh I don't doubt it, Mighty Tatl, great fairy warrior!" I stated in mock reverence. "May great destruction reign down upon those tiny flies that dare to challenge you!"

"Ok, ok... let's get moving before you break a nail or something."

"Ha! You know you really do belong on a stage, entertaining everyone with such hilarious jokes."

I shook my head as Tatl giggled with soft chimes, and resumed the trek toward the copse of trees near the Star Chamber ahead. We moved quickly as the sun set, and soon reached the first few trees. I slowed, and listened carefully for monsters lying in wait. I lightly stepped underneath the canopy, and into the shadows. Thankfully, the going was easy since the ground was solid now, not the sludgy muck it was last time we came through the area. Flitting my gaze around as I walked with my bow at the ready, I asked the glimmering fairy flying over my shoulder where the path was.

"You just have to keep going further in, it should be to the right of that slope up ahead." She whispered, hovering next to my ear.

I nodded and adjusted course. I heard leaves rustling above and aimed up at the sound. Two pairs of glowing red eyes swooped down, coming straight for us.

The black bats' leathery wings were huge, ending in ferocious claws. They came at us, screeching loudly with large fangs protruding from their open maws. My nimble fingers, now more familiar with the bow, expertly loosed two magic bolts at the Bad Bats. The arrows hit their targets dead on, and the winged monsters flopped clumsily to the ground, their heads replaced by sizzling holes. I swiveled my head, ensuring that no others had joined in the assault.

"Do you see any more?" I asked the anxious pixie.

Tatl looked all around. "I think we're safe for now. I don't hear anything else."

I hastened my steps onward. We quickly moved around the slope ahead, and sure enough discovered a well- beaten path of gravel and dirt. I paused on the road, trying to figure out which way to go. One direction curved east, leading out of the forest and likely toward town. The other way went south, around the hill. Tatl tugged on my cloak, pulling me in the southern direction.

"C'mon, keep moving before more monsters find us!"

"Hey, I can move on my own, you know?" I berated. "Ease up on the pulling!"

The rushed fairy released the fabric and flew to my ear.

"Ok, well the swamp isn't far from here. If we hurry we can get there before sunrise...-"

Tatl was cut off when we both heard a loud rumbling up ahead. We both turned to see a white cart coming into view as it rounded the hill, drawn by strongly built horses. I say that the driver was a lanky, shirtless man with a straw hat and tanned leather chaps. Not wanting to draw extra attention, we dashed to the side of the road and hid behind one of the tree trunks. I didn't want to be delayed any longer, especially by yet another violent encounter should the driver prove to be hostile. Tatl ducked underneath my cloak to hide her luminous form standing out in the twilight.

The horses slowed as they passed on by, but the cart stopped right next to our tree with the driver pulling on the reins with a shout.

"Ya'll out there hiding in the woods better come out now, 'afore I blow ya to kingdom come!" The driver shouted in a country twang, not unlike Talon from Lon Lon Ranch.

I slowly peeked around the trunk, while silently preparing another magic arrow.

"Yeah, I sees ya! This ain't my first rodeo now, git on out in the open!" The rough man produced a bomb, and readied a match to light it.

"Ok ok!" I reslung my bow and stepped away from the tree. "Just put that away before you kill all of us!"

"Where's yer friend? The shiny one?"

Tatl reluctantly flew out of cover, grumbling, sharing my irritation at the delay.

"Now, ya'll tell me if there are any more of you, or we all go kablooey! I ain't lettin' no bandits steal our milk this time!"

The man inched the lit match toward the fuse. Determination shone in his eyes, as the fire danced shadows along his features.

"No, wait, there are only two of us! We're just trying to make our way to the swamp, now relax and put that thing away!" I snapped. The man paused, then relented, puffing out the tiny flame.

"Hoo wee...this day's just a'goin all kinds of cracked! You tellin me tiny things like ya'll headed for the swamp? Must be crazier than a croc... but between that moon, the sun, and all around weather, I' bound to believe anythin' at this point." The wiry driver scratched his chin.

"Ummm right. Well, we must be off now. Farewell!" I waved as we scooted past the cart and the still confused man.

"Now now, Missy, you can't be serious about going there! The swamp'll eat you alive, I tell ya! And the deku scrubs are like to capture you two for trespassing! They been actin' real strange. Everything's been goin' kooky since that moon grew a face. These are the end times I tell ya!"

"Exactly, so we have to go before it's too late!" Tatl flew up to the man's tanned, scraggly face. "There's no time for us to chit chat! Especially with your poor grasp of language."

"Shooty dawg if you ain't a cranky one....Yipes!” The man waved Tatl away with a surprised yelp, “Fine fine! I gotta get these supplies to town anyways a'fore I run into any more trouble. Good luck to ya'll! Oh, and I reckon if ya'll change your mind, my ranch is right up th' road if ya need a place to stay the night!"

The man shucked his reins and the horse-drawn cart creaked along as bottles clanged together in the back of the wagon. I heard him distantly mumble something about 'crazy fillies' and 'everything running amuck' as the cart vanished from view behind the trees. Tatl and I shrugged to each other and took off running around the bend where the cart came from.

A few thin trees rested beside the path as we passed the hill, but the sky was clearly visible and stars twinkled peacefully in the night sky above. The moon was larger now, with its gravely visage piercing down upon the world in silent malice. I shivered; the face of the cursed satellite gave me chills. It served as an ever-looming reminder of why I was here, what inevitable doom was coming if I failed. But I pressed onward, intent on saving this world. That was what I was made for, even if I lost my old body.

An hour passed by as we followed the trail, and I fought to keep my eyes open. I hadn't had any sleep yet, and the constant action of these past few days had worn away the Great Fairy's vigor that was given to me. I wasn't the only one struggling though.

"I'm getting tired, Link... we should stop somewhere and make camp." Tatl loudly yawned and plopped onto my shoulder.

"No, we need to..." I yawned after the fairy, releasing a sleepy squeak. I cleared my throat and continued, shaking myself awake. "Aherm, we need to keep moving... "

"Aww, see? You're just as exhausted as me." Tatl expressed, rubbing her eyes. "Can we at least stop for a small nap?"

"No..." I huffed. "Look, we're almost there. The road splits up ahead!"

The path diverged right and left. A broken signpost sat between the road, the split pieces on the ground had the letters "Swa " and "Ranch" painted on them, but gave no clear direction.

"Umm...you said go right, yeah?" I questioned Tatl, who was quickly falling asleep.

"Yeah...right..." The drowsy pixie repeated.

I plodded to the right, shuffling my feet through the dirt. A nap did sound nice, and I seriously considered it while my feet ambled further down the road. As I debated with myself, a bright ball of light flashed by in the night sky, moving far too erratically to be a shooting star or comet, making an infernal screeching noise. I turned to the sleeping fairy on my shoulder and nudged her awake with my bare finger.

"Hey, wake up." I whispered. "Is that type of thing normal out here?"

The bright orb darted down the road away from us, and Tatl squinted after it and opened her eyes wide.

"Uhhh no. Not at all! What is that thing?"

"I'm not sure, but I've got a bad feeling about it. I've never seen anything like it before. Maybe we should umm...go the other way. Sleeping until dawn at that ranch, or whatever you said it was, doesn't seem like such a bad idea!"

I felt goosebumps rise along my arms, and quivered from the chilling sound the thing produced as it followed the trail. Tatl, fully awake now, nodded and drifted off of my shoulder.

"I think that you might be right. I'm super creeped out...so...let's go before it comes back!" Tatl twinkled in fright, fairy dust falling to the ground as she shivered as well.

Tatl and I turned around, and fled to follow the other road opposite the ranch. Only after I was certain that the thing wasn't coming for us, did I slow down, taking deep breaths to calm my nerves. Tatl looked worriedly behind us, but was relieved to learn that the thing had ignored us. I took in the surroundings, checking for any other new threats. Trees were plentiful down this way, and the air was thick with moisture, carrying with it a foul stench.

"So, this path looks, and smells, more...swampy than the other. I think we're headed in the right direction." I said to Tatl.

"It's been awhile since I've been down this way. The swamp is not the most pleasant of places so I try to avoid it. Before we go any further though...I think we should sleep. It only gets worse from here.”

"Yeah...you're probably right. We can find somewhere safe to take a short nap I guess." I mumbled while rubbing my eyes. "I doubt I'd be able to save anything if I collapse from exhaustion..."

Tatl nodded, and I sluggishly glanced around the trail for a nook or cranny to tuck into. The damp ground surrounding us was a definite no, but the thick branches high on the trees above looked promising. A short climb should be easy, so I veered toward the next trunk and began shimmying up the bark.

"Come on, ugh... we'll be relatively safe up here." I grunted as I scrambled up to the largest branch, and wedged myself between it and the trunk.

"Whatever you say, as long as I can snooze in peace." The fairy yawned.

Tatl nestled herself in my warm cloak, chiming in comfort as she got settled. I was too sleepy to mind, and it wasn't long at all before we both drifted to sleep. The crickets chirped and all manner of nocturnal animals yipped and squawked, serving as a natural lullaby. I quickly forgot about the ball of fire, and allowed my eyes to relax shut, falling almost immediately into a dreamless sleep.

Chapter Seventeen

The Southern Swamp

I awoke with a start as something small and solid pelted my knee. Almost tumbling from the high branch, I caught myself just in time to see two odd, hairy creatures fleeing down the road on all fours. A grumpy Tatl protested my sudden movements and flopped out of the green cloak in a tangled mess.

"What's the big idea?" the fairy whined. "Why are we waking up so early? The sun's only just beginning to rise! And I was having such a great dream too…"

"Calm down, I was woken by some hairy beasts throwing stuff at me…" I shushed, staring after the creatures.

A red sun was peeking just over the hills to the east, indicating a storm like before. Looming grey clouds moved in from the north, and damp wind lightly brushed my hair.

"Great. More rain…" I stood and stretched my arms and legs. "Ok, I guess that's as good a wake-up call as anything. Better get moving before the storm washes us away, Tatl."

I knelt down, grabbing hold of the gnarled branch beneath me, and gracefully swung away from the branch. Rolling mid-air, I landed squarely on the path with an agile twist. I was suddenly very grateful for the new supporting undergarments—the jolt of the landing would’ve been brutal on my chest without them.

"Nice...maybe you belong in the circus, too." Tatl flew down beside me. "I almost guarantee that you couldn't do that in your old body!"

"Hmm, probably not. Maybe this form isn't so useless after all." I cracked a small grin and peered down the path. "Wait... look over there! Those are the things that attacked me!"

The furry white beasts stood still and faced us, almost like they were waiting. Their large eyes glimmered curiously, and flared upturned, wide nostrils on their leathery, grey faces.

"Oh, monkeys? They don't really attack people, they're mostly just annoying." Tatl replied nonchalantly.

"Wha? What's a monkey? We don't have any of those in Hyrule."

"Those animals right there, like I said! Monkeys live in a giant tree within the swamp and are friendly enough, but can be pretty mischievous. I've never heard of them coming out this far though… it's odd for them to wander from their home tree."

"Well, they seem to be waiting for me. If they are friendly, do you think we should follow them?"

"They are heading in the direction of the swamp, so I don't see any reason not to." The pixie shrugged. "But be on your guard, who knows what waits ahead."

I nodded and stepped toward the monkeys, who immediately burst into motion—jumping excitedly, clapping their hands with rapid, rhythmic slaps, then dashing down the dirt road in a flurry of scampering limbs. Their shrill chattering and the soft thump of padded feet against the muddy path echoed through the morning hush, beckoning us to follow with an almost gleeful urgency.

A fine drizzle began to fall from the bruised sky, each droplet ticking softly against leaves and soil as we neared the trail’s end. The sound mingled with the rustle of wind in the branches above, whispering a quiet warning of the storm to come. The monkeys scrambled up some trees that lined the edge of a foul, murky bog, as if marking the threshold between the familiar trail and the swamp’s shadowy heart. A powerful stench permeated the humid air, and a thin mist swirled along the damp, mossy ground. Croaks and growls from swamp creatures resounded all around us, including what sounded like wolfos calls. Large tree trunks supported a wide canopy over the tepid, algae-crusted waters, with vines hanging down various branches. The monkeys took hold of the vines and swung away into the fog.

"Umm...ok? Now what? They can't expect us to follow them like that!" I looked to Tatl.

"I dunno...monkeys are weird. But there's a boat rental shop not far from here, according to that sign. It looks like it's pointing down the shoreline that way." She pointed a tiny arm to a signpost nailed to a tree.

"Good, a boat would be helpful. I'd rather not have to swim through this stuff. The smell alone might kill me!" I reeled away from the squalid bog.

Tatl fluttered down a somewhat obscure pathway through the mire, her glow muted beneath the thick canopy and the ever-churning mists. I chased after her, hair clinging to my cheeks in the warm humidity, my boots sinking into the spongy moss and muck. The air was pungent with rot, the distant croak of frogs and whisper of unseen things all around us.

I caught up just as she froze midair, wings humming with tension. She stared ahead, and I followed her gaze—only to find three grey wolfos hunched over a fallen monkey, their blood-slick muzzles tearing at limp limbs. The sound of crunching bone was too loud.

I motioned quietly to Tatl to back away, my heart thudding in my throat—but it was too late. One of the wolves, its snout matted with gore, snapped its head up. Its green eyes glowed like twin curses. With a savage snarl, it howled—a battle cry that sent the others whipping around, their mouths dripping thick threads of saliva.

I fumbled for my bow and fired a trio of radiant arrows. They struck with sharp flashes—but bounced off, fizzing out harmlessly into mist.

"Damn it!"

The alpha lowered its head and charged.

I shoved the bow aside and reached for the Hero's Mask beneath my cloak. My fingers trembled—just for a moment—as they closed around its smooth, too-familiar shape. It pulsed faintly, like it had been waiting. Like it remembered.

I slammed it onto my face.

The shift was violent.

Muscle coiled and hardened through my limbs. My ribs compressed as a deeper breath filled new lungs. My bones ached, grinding into place as the mask fused with me. Confidence bloomed—hot and overwhelming—as my senses sharpened and something primal took the wheel.

By the time the wolfos reached me, I was already moving.

My shield rose instinctively, steel ringing against claw. I shoved the beast back hard, feeling its weight give beneath my strength. My sword slid free, eager in my hand.

"Come on then," I growled, a crooked smirk tugging at the corners of my mouth. My voice sounded deeper now—rougher, edged with something hungry.

Tatl retreated to the treetops with a worried trill, her glow flickering with unease.

The other two wolves circled, hackles raised, low snarls vibrating the air between us. The alpha lunged again, a blur of grey muscle and fury.

I spun into its charge, steel flashing. My blade met its claws in a spray of sparks, and I twisted, dancing just out of reach as the beast stumbled past. The movement felt effortless—almost playful. I laughed, a low, taunting sound that didn’t quite feel like mine.

"Too slow," I hissed, savoring the moment.

The wolfos staggered, its flank wide open. The scent of blood was thick in the air.

With a single, brutal thrust, I drove my sword into the soft flesh beneath its ribs. The creature howled—a short, sharp cry—before collapsing into the mud, its limbs spasming in death.

I yanked the blade free, flicking blood into the black water.

"One down," I murmured, letting the words hang like a challenge. "Who's next?"

The others lunged at once—claws slicing the air—and I backflipped, landing light on my feet in the mire with a muddy splash. My blood roared. Every heartbeat thudded like war drums in my chest. A plan burned in my mind: bait them into a tree and strike when they were stuck.

I slammed my shield with the hilt of my sword, the clang echoing through the swamp like a bell of war. I grinned—savage, wild—as I backed toward the largest trunk I could find. The wolves took the bait.

Three snarling beasts surged at me, eyes alight with bloodlust. My back struck bark. They thought I was cornered.

Perfect.

I dropped low, rolled, and their claws raked empty air inches above my head. Bark splintered behind me as their talons buried into the trunk.

I didn’t even rise—I spun from the crouch, blade extended, a perfect arc of wrath.

Steel sang. Bodies buckled.

My sword carved through ribs and muscle with a wet, sickening cleave, the howl of one wolf cut short in a bubbling gasp. A geyser of black blood burst from its throat, drenching my tunic and hissing where it hit the magic-etched steel. Gods I loved this sword!

Another wolf twisted, impaled mid-leap, its momentum carrying it down the length of my blade until I shoved it off with a boot to its chest. Bone cracked beneath my heel.

The last one barely had time to flinch. I pivoted, snarling, and split it from jaw to sternum in one downward stroke. The flesh parted like overripe fruit, spraying gore across the roots.

Their lifeless corpses hung grotesquely from the bark, claws still buried deep, as if frozen mid-hunt. The air reeked of iron and rot.

I stood slowly, chest heaving, the thrill still burning hot in my lungs—and laughed. It wasn't relief. It wasn't joy. It was wild and sharp, a sound that didn’t belong in the throat of a child. Loud, long, unrepentant. It echoed through the swamp like a dare—like I was begging the world to send me more.

This... this was what I was made for.

The blood, the precision, the raw satisfaction of dominance. It had been too long.

Too long since I felt alive  like this.

I wiped the ichor from my blade with the sole of my boot, watching the thick smear slide across the steel. Something deep inside me thrilled at the mess, at the power. And for a moment... I didn’t care who I had to become to keep feeling this way.

"That was incredible! How'd you do that?" Tatl praised, flitting down to eye level, her light flickering with hesitant awe.

"Experience," I said, my voice husky with adrenaline. "I’ve fought worse. Wolfos are nothing compared to what I’ve survived."

I stalked past the corpses without looking back, like they were already fading into memory.

"Well, I bet if Skull Kid saw you do that, he'd think twice before messing with you again, haha!"

"He caught me off guard," I muttered. My hands twitched at my sides. "But I wasn’t expecting such power from a simple skull child. Next time, the imp won’t be so lucky."

Tatl hovered awkwardly. "Uhhh, right. We should keep moving though, it's creepy around here…"

"What? Did I say something wrong?" I snapped, quicker than I meant to, the fight still sizzling under my skin.

"No, we just uhh... need to hurry…" she said, shrinking from me, her glow dimming.

"Ok...fine. Be that way," I muttered, forcing my breathing to slow.

Tatl stopped suddenly, wings still.

"It’s just... you get so worked up about killing Skull Kid. He used to be your friend, remember? And... I dunno. Sometimes it sounds like you enjoy  it. The violence. Like you want  it, when you wear your mask…"

Her voice was soft, but it cut deep. And for a second, I couldn’t tell if I was angry because she was wrong—or because she wasn’t.

I stared ahead into the mist, her words echoing longer than they should’ve. Was I really that bloodthirsty now? That wasn’t me. That wasn’t supposed  to be me. I only fought when I had to—only when there was no other choice. But the heat in my blood… it hadn't felt like necessity. It had felt like hunger.

I turned to her, slowly. “Does it really look that way to you?”
