“Yeah, it does. It’s kinda scary, to be honest,” Tatl replied, her voice quiet but steady. “And you only act that way when you wear the mask. Without it, you’re calmer. Softer. Like yourself again. I dunno…”

“Huh…” I looked down at the gauntlet on my hand, at how the metal gleamed like it belonged there. “Maybe this form is getting to my head.” I flexed my fingers, half expecting to feel claws instead of skin. “Or maybe… maybe I’m getting too comfortable in someone else’s skin.”

“We can ask the salesman,” she offered. “When this is over. He might know more about it.”

I hesitated. The power still coursed through me. I didn’t want  to let it go. But her eyes held no fear—just concern. Real concern. And that pierced deeper than her words had.

“Yeah… better save the magic anyway,” I mumbled, forcing a half-smile. “No sense burning it all now. As much as I… want to stay like this.”

I paused, glancing down at my hands again. “Tatl… what if I’m changing? Not just the body—me. What if the mask is starting to rewrite who I am?”

She hovered closer. “I don’t think it’s rewriting you. But maybe… it’s amplifying something. Drawing out parts of you that you try to keep buried.”

I swallowed. “But what if those parts take over?”

“They won’t,” she said gently. “Because you’re scared of that. And the fact that you’re scared means you’re still in control.”

With a slow breath, I reached up and peeled the mask away. It came off reluctantly, like it had grown roots in my skin. As it separated, I felt a strange tug in my chest—like something tearing loose from inside. Then the shift began.

It was never graceful.

My shoulders cracked inward, collarbones narrowing. Muscle retreated down my limbs like the tide, leaving me smaller, lighter, softer. My hands trembled as calluses vanished, replaced by thinner fingers that no longer fit the gauntlets quite right. The armor sagged on me—suffocating and oversized, pressing down on shrinking bones with the weight of someone I no longer was. I staggered under it, each step an effort, until the enchantment caught up and the fabric of my clothes adjusted with a faint shimmer. The mail tightened, resizing, reshaping—but not before I felt that moment of utter helplessness, like drowning in the remains of someone else’s body. I stumbled, breath hitching as my center of gravity shifted, hips subtly widening, my chest compressing and rising in uneven spasms as it adjusted to a new rhythm.

My voice, when it finally escaped in a ragged breath, was higher again. Familiar. Unfamiliar.

The worst part was... I was starting to get used to it.

Not just the pain, but the shape. The lightness. The way the world looked from here.

And that terrified me.

Tatl floated close and rested a tiny hand against my shoulder. “We’ll figure it out, okay? You’re just… adjusting. Swapping bodies like that—no one could do it perfectly. Not even you.”

Her glow pressed gently into my shoulder—not heat, not light, but something else. Like the memory of a hand I hadn’t held in years.. It surprised me—how gentle she was being, how much she cared . Tatl had always been sharp-tongued and fast to criticize, but there was something softer in her now, something she rarely let anyone see.

And I felt it. I needed  it. That tiny hand on my shoulder was the only thing keeping the fear from swallowing me whole.

“I don’t know who I’m becoming,” I whispered, feeling my hands tremble as they gripped the wood of my old self.

“Maybe you don’t have to know yet,” she said. “Maybe it’s enough that you’re still trying  to be you.”

I nodded, not trusting my voice, and tucked the mask away inside my cloak. Its weight felt heavier than before.

And we kept walking. Quietly. Just two souls in the mist, trying not to lose sight of who we were…trying not to think about who I was becoming.

Putting any further bleak thoughts aside, I concentrated on our surroundings. The stillness gnawed at me. The swamp had become deathly silent—no croaks, no wingbeats, not even the buzz of insects. The air grew colder, heavy like wet wool against my skin. Each step felt like it stirred ghosts beneath the mire.

Then I saw it. A thick wall of fog rolling in across the lagoon, not drifting but hunting . It pulsed with slow, unnatural rhythm, as if it were breathing.

A chill lanced down my spine.

"Tatl! TATL!" I hissed, trying to keep my voice low but urgent. "Get off the path! Something's coming from the swamp!"

She turned, and the moment her eyes locked onto the approaching haze, her glow dimmed to a nervous flicker. We scrambled off the trail and ducked behind a clutch of enormous, slime-slick ferns. My heart thundered in my ears as we crouched low.

The fog roiled like boiling tar, and then began to congeal —not fade, not part, but thicken , pulling itself together as if it had a mind and malice of its own.

Then we heard it.

A moan—not human, not beast. Long, hollow, and soaked in agony. It pierced the silence like a blade, sending ripples through the swampwater. Every instinct in me screamed to run.

The fog convulsed one final time before vomiting out a shape.

It stumbled forward on two legs—barely. A towering, hunched figure cloaked in rotting swampmoss and tattered black fabric, parts of its flesh blistered and seamed like melted wax. Its face was hidden behind a cracked mask painted in crimson spirals, warped by moisture and time. Veins of shadow throbbed through its limbs, pulsing like worms beneath paper-thin skin.

In one hand, it clutched a diamond-shaped shield crusted with dried blood and mold. In the other—a rusty, jagged sword, its edge curved like a butcher’s hook, pitted with decay. It dragged the blade along the muck as it moved, and the sound it made—metal on stone, on bone—rattled in my teeth.

It didn’t speak. It didn’t need to. Its presence alone suffocated the air, like a memory of death come walking.

Tatl pressed against my shoulder, trembling. "What... what is  that?"

I didn't answer. I couldn't. My mouth had gone dry, my fingers twitching toward my mask.

Because whatever this thing was, I knew in my gut—we weren’t supposed to see it.

And it wasn’t supposed to be awake.

Tatl muffled a sharp cry at the ghastly creature's appearance. The brackish skin dangled in tattered shreds from rotting muscle tissue and bone, and a horrendous stench of death emitted from the body.

The mask worn by the monster looked ancient—less like it had been crafted and more like it had grown  out of time itself. Its wooden surface was splintered with rot and age, warped by moisture, and painted with flaking white tribal patterns that writhed faintly in the shifting fog as though still alive. Three long, moss-streaked green pinions jutted from the crown of its head like the plumage of a diseased bird. The mask's gnarled eyes and mouth were hollow, bottomless voids that seemed to drink  the light around them.

From those gaping orifices dribbled a thick, purple-black ichor, syrupy and reeking of decay. It oozed down the warped mask and spattered onto the bog, hissing softly as it poisoned everything it touched.

The creature’s torso was a massacre of torn flesh. Great wounds split it open from sternum to navel, revealing necrotic organs sloshing wetly with each shambling step. Its intestines dangled like rotten vines, swinging against the remnants of shredded, ceremonial robes that clung to its form in tatters. Each moan that echoed from its throat was guttural—like something being dragged from the bottom of a grave.

Behind it, a slick trail of that noxious ichor bled into the swampwater, curling through it like ink in milk—clouding, poisoning, killing .

The creature staggered deeper into the bog, dragging its sword like a reaper's scythe behind it. Only once it vanished into the veil of mist did the air begin to shift again. The fog clung like breath from a grave, curling around roots and stones with the hunger of something that remembered the living. The stench remained, but the pressure in my chest lifted, and I realized I’d been holding my breath.

Tatl and I exhaled in unison.

"Ughhh... I guess we found our monster," I murmured, stepping slowly out of cover, every muscle still tight with dread. My voice sounded thin, stretched taut across the fear still clinging to my ribs.

"Yeah... let’s umm... not  go after it though," Tatl said, trying to sound flippant but failing. "That thing was terrifying! How could anything live  here with nightmares like that  lurking around!?" She gagged behind me, wings flickering erratically.

"We have to go after it," I said flatly, eyes still scanning the fading mist. "That’s the whole reason we’re here."

"But... did you see  it? That thing was HUGE!  It’s not just some common wolfos or chu-chu—its weapons were, like, twice your size! You’d be paste  before you even touched it! And it was already dead! How do you kill something that’s already  dead?!"

"Trust me, I’ve fought bigger," I replied, more calm than I felt. "And undead aren’t the hardest to put down. They don’t think. They just follow pain. But that fog it seems to travel with... that’s the real problem. If we don’t track it to its lair, it could vanish again."

Tatl buzzed beside me, fidgeting midair. "Seriously? You’re not even the tiniest  bit scared? That thing  will be starring in my nightmares for years!"

I let out a breath, glancing back the way the monster had gone. "I’ve seen worse. Once, I had to descend into the Shadow Temple—an ancient burial vault beneath a graveyard. It wasn’t just ruins... it was a place of ritual torment. The walls were painted in dried blood, iron masks still nailed to the stone where the skeletal remains of prisoners had been bound. There were pits lined with spikes, corridors that whispered.... The dead didn’t just lie still down there—they waited . And don't even get me started about something called the Dead Hand..."

Tatl’s glow pulsed nervously. "W-wait, what?! If that wasn’t  a blatant lie... how are you even still alive ?!"

I shrugged, a bitter smile tugging at the edge of my mouth. "Courage. Luck. Or maybe just a magical sword that cut through evil monster souls like nothing."

She hovered closer. "Let me guess... you conveniently  don’t have it anymore?"

"Returned it to its resting place," I said. "When my mission ended, there was no need to keep it."

"No need ?!" she squeaked. "Did you see  that thing? We could’ve used  a soul-cleaving sword of destiny right about now!"

"Yeah, well... life’s full of bad timing," I muttered, my hand drifting toward the mask hidden beneath my cloak. "We make do with what we have. I left Hyrule with a sword and shield that a temple priest had blessed to burn with divine light whenever it touched something truly evil but...well, it's probably gone forever."

The sword I carried now—when masked, anyway—wasn't quite the same. It had the right weight, and it sang a familiar note when I swung it, but there was something missing in the resonance. It felt hollow, like an echo of what it pretended to be. Not a legacy blade, not a weapon of destiny—just a shadow made steel. It moved like it remembered greatness but couldn’t quite reclaim it. As if it knew it was only wearing a hero… not living with one.

The thought made my lips curl downward in anger at my fate. The memory of what I once carried—what I once was —sank like a stone in my chest. The world I left behind had crowned me a hero, but here I was, crawling through a haunted swamp with a false sword and a body that barely felt like mine. Every step forward felt like penance. Every breath was like a reminder that no prophecy had saved me from this. My destiny had turned to ash, and I was choking on the embers.

Tatl was quiet for a beat, then mumbled, "I still think you’re insane. But I guess that’s the only kind of person who’d walk into a swamp like this."

"That makes two of us," I said, finally cracking a small smile.

She huffed. "Don’t remind me."

I started down the trail again, anxious to leave the area.

"Wait, you said you completed a mission. What mission?" Tatl pressed, her wings flicking with renewed energy. "You can't just leave it there, you've piqued  my interest!"

"It was a long time ago… I don't really want to talk about it," I muttered, already regretting letting anything slip.

"Oh come on ! You said that before, but I told you a little about my past. Why don't you return the favor?" she begged, drifting close with an expectant tilt.

"Ugh… fine. I guess that's fair." I sighed, rubbing the bridge of my nose. "Okay, here's the short version. A thief named Ganondorf stole a sacred relic that granted his wish to rule the world. He declared himself King of Evil, enslaved the races of Hyrule, and I was chosen to stop him. So I did—with help from... people I trusted."

"That's all …? That's the best you can do? You can't just drop  something like that and not deliver. Gimme more!" she pushed.

I groaned. "Alright. I cleansed evil from seven temples—each one crawling with monsters, traps, curses. Fought through endless hordes, rescued the sages who’d been imprisoned, sealed Ganondorf in a void of darkness... and then got shoved back in time to relive my childhood. Like it all never happened."

"Well... it’s better than nothing," Tatl said, though her voice had softened. "One day I’ll break through that guarded little hero heart, but for now I guess I’ll let you be mysterious."

"Yup. Legendary hero. Or... I was." My voice came out quieter than I meant. "Before I was sent back. I had night terrors for months after. Waking up thinking the world had ended. Zelda… she was there for me. Helped me adjust. Helped me... let go."

"Who's Zelda? She sounds nice."

"She was the Princess of Hyrule. Now the Queen, probably." I tried to sound casual, but even her name stirred something old and aching in my chest.

"Wow. I gotta say, I wouldn’t have guessed you were the ‘falling-for-royalty’ type," Tatl whistled. "All noble and tragic."

"I never said I was in love," I snapped, a little too quickly.

"It was totally in your voice when you said her name, you cannot  deny it," she teased. "And it sounds like she cared about you too. No wonder you're all moody and evasive—you feel guilty for leaving her behind."

"No! That's not...it…" I sighed, Tatl was right. "Look...I just don't belong with a princess. I'm a battle-hardened warrior, and Hyrule is in a time of peace. I can't live like that, not after everything I'd been put through. How could Zelda possibly be happy with someone like me?"

"I dunno, love isn't my strong suit. But I doubt that Zelda cares. I think when all this is over, you should go back and tell her how you feel."

"I don't even know how to get back, let alone survive this place! Besides, look  at me!"

I gestured to my feminine form and kicked a rock in frustration. Pain rippled through my foot and I stumbled, hopping on one leg as I massaged my stubbed toe.

"Owww! Arrgh! I'm done talking about this!" I screamed.

My shrill voice echoed through the swamp, startling birds from the branches above in a flurry of wings. The sting faded, but the embarrassment lingered. Not from the pain—real as it was—but from the rawness of being seen while my emotions were falling apart.

"Alright, alright! Sheesh ! Calm down before you summon that bloodcurdling monster again!" Tatl waved frantically, scanning the shadows. "I'm sorry... forget I mentioned anything."

I glared at the ground, blinking away the rain that had fallen into my eyes.

Only... it wasn’t raining.

Tatl hovered closer, her glow dimming into something gentler—but she didn’t speak. Not right away.

Instead, she lingered beside me in silence. And for once, it wasn’t filled with quips or questions. Just quiet understanding. I could feel her watching me—not with pity, but with a dawning clarity. Like she was seeing past the mask for the first time, seeing the shape of someone scarred beneath all the silence.

I didn’t want her to see it.

I did  want her to see it.

I looked down at my hands—smaller now, softer, uncertain—and sighed heavily.

"Maybe," I muttered, eyes fixed on the shifting mist ahead. "Maybe I was in love. Maybe... it’s complicated."

The words felt too small for the weight they carried. Like naming a wound didn’t make it bleed any less.

"Love didn’t stop her from turning back the clock. It didn’t hold back… fate. And it sure didn’t stop me from getting torn out of one life and thrown into another." I paused. "She…ugh…she did what she thought was right. Maybe she was  right. I just... I don’t know where I’m supposed to put any of it now."

Tatl’s voice came at last, quiet and low. “Maybe… you don’t have to. Not yet. Maybe it’s okay if it doesn’t make sense for a while.”

I glanced at her.

She didn’t look away. “You’ve been carrying all that without a break, haven’t you? Always trying to be the hero, even when no one’s looking. Even when it’s tearing you apart.”

I said nothing. I didn’t have to.

“You know… um… you’re not alone now,” she said, more gently than I’d ever heard her. “You don’t have to carry it all by yourself. Not with me here.”

Her glow warmed slightly, a soft pulse of light in the gray. Not bright, not bold—just enough to be felt, like a hand quietly reaching out in the dark.

And I found myself—just for a moment—believing her. Wanting to believe her. That someone could stand beside me and see  the ruin without flinching.

"Let's... just keep moving," I said, my voice rough with emotion. Not dismissive—just worn. Like the words were walking on blistered feet.

She didn’t argue. Just stayed close, her glow surreal against the fog. Her silence said more than comfort ever could. She was with  me. No expectations. No judgment. Just presence.

And we kept walking, the mist curling around our legs like memories too stubborn to fade—but now, for the first time in a long time, not entirely alone in them.

I chose to remain quiet until we reached the boathouse. Thankfully, Tatl followed my lead—but her words kept echoing through my mind like ripples over a wound that refused to close. She had seen more than I meant to show. And worse—she’d been right. But admitting that to her? To myself? That was still too much.

I knew how Zelda had looked at me. I knew what we shared, unspoken as it often was. But my happiness... that had been forfeit long ago. Offered up to the gods the moment I drew the Master Sword and stepped into the timestream. Zelda belonged to Hyrule, to peace, to golden rooms and measured words. She deserved the warmth of sunlit courtyards, the laughter of children, soft hands and safer futures. I was none of that. I was the shadow that lingered after the fire. A sword with no sheath. A name whispered in temples and forgotten at home.

I was built for battle and adventure.

Despite the curses that clung to every branch, and the unease that coiled like fog at my ankles, part of me—some twisted part—almost enjoyed  the trek through the bog. There was a rawness here. A thrill beneath the dread. Like walking a knife’s edge with bare feet. The uncertainty hummed through my bones like the prelude to battle. It gave me purpose . Purpose I hadn’t felt since the last seal closed the Demon King in the abyss and silence fell over the kingdom.

Peace had starved me. Six years of it had eroded me in ways no war ever could. Without a threat, I was just... leftover. Rusting.

So I came here. To a place that still bled. Where monsters still hunted and evil still whispered in the dark. Here, I wasn’t obsolete. Here, I mattered .

The trail ended at a long, weathered boardwalk. Planks groaned beneath my boots as I stepped onto it, damp with moss and slick with age. Mist curled like breath around my ankles, coiling up from the dark water below. The air smelled brackish—part algae, part rot, tinged faintly with woodsmoke and something faintly sickly sweet, like an old corpse.

The world fell quiet, as if holding its breath. Lanterns glowed faintly at the head of the pier, casting amber halos into the fog like tired eyes that refused to close. Further down the dock, nestled into the mist, stood an owl statue—weathered, half-covered in lichen, but unmistakable. Its eyes were shut, wings folded, like it was waiting for something.

Across the water, a two-story shack floated gently, tethered by thick ropes to half-submerged pylons. The building creaked softly with each ripple of the swamp, like it was murmuring in its sleep. Smoke curled from its chimney in a lazy spiral, tracing a slow path upward into the gray.

"Alright, here we are. Are you OK, Link?" Tatl chimed, her voice careful—not too light, not too prying.

"Yeah, I'm fine… I just had to work through some things," I said, forcing a breath past the tightness in my chest. "I just want to say… that you were right. I'm not good at talking about this stuff. And I'm sorry. For being such an idiot."

Tatl hovered a little closer, her glow warmer than the lanterns. "Hey... thanks for saying that. You’re not an idiot. Just... damaged goods like the rest of us."

I snorted softly. "Thanks.... I think."

"You're welcome," she said, and for once, we both laughed. Just a little.

And for a heartbeat, the fog didn’t feel so heavy.

The boardwalk swayed gently beneath our steps, the wood groaning with age and damp. Ripples fanned out through the stagnant water with each footfall, disturbing floating debris and clumps of green algae. Gnats and flies buzzed persistently around our heads, drawn to the sweat and lantern glow. I swatted at them half-heartedly, my mind still half-lost in memory. The smell of mildew, river mud, and faint smoke drifted in the air, thick as the mist.

We reached the weather-beaten door of the boathouse, its surface warped with years of exposure. I knocked with my knuckles—three sharp raps—and heard the shuffle of movement inside. A small peephole snapped open, and a gruff voice echoed from within.

"Eh? What do ye want!"

"We would like to rent a boat. Do you have any available?" Tatl answered politely.

"A boat? Nah, this is the photography club. The boat rental’s up the ladder to the left! But ahhh... the owner, Koume, hasn’t been by in a few days!"

The man’s voice boomed with a thick, unplaceable accent, every syllable dragged out like rope soaked in molasses.

"Oh, okay then... do you know any other boat shops around here?" I asked, leaning closer to the opening. "We're kind of in a hurry."

"Nope, 'fraid this is the only place 'round here with boats! Tell ye what though, you two look straight bushed! Why don’t ya both come inside for a nice cuppa 'n warm yer spirits. I’m sure ye can spare a tic after hoofin’ it over 'ere!"

The heavy door creaked inward on rusted hinges, revealing a formidable man with a closely-shaved black beard and mirror-tinted glasses that flashed in the lantern light. A brown leather flight cap was pulled tight over his head, and his massive arm gestured us in with the ease of someone used to taking up space. His vest, worn and sun-faded, clung to a thick, hairy torso and a bulging gut, and beneath it, a pair of comically small white-and-red pinstriped trousers barely clung to his frame.

I cast Tatl a sideways glance and shrugged.

She gave a small nod, and we stepped into the warm, flickering light of the cabin.

"Awright, make yerselves at home. I got the tea goin' on the mantle," the mountainous man bellowed, his voice booming with that unmistakable swamptung lilt.

The cabin chamber was cozy and worn-in, smelling faintly of cedar smoke and damp wool. Dim lanterns hung from exposed beams, casting soft golden pools of light over the mismatched furniture. The walls were cluttered with curling photographs—sepia-toned snapshots of travelers, misty lagoons, and half-submerged ruins. A few taxidermied fish, preserved mid-thrash, hung above a display of homemade bows and rusted tools.

A large couch sagged against the far wall, draped in an old knitted throw. Several leafy potted plants clustered beside a squat little table, their fronds reaching like curious hands toward the heat of the fire. The man waved us toward it, and we obliged, sinking into the creaking cushions.

He thumped over to the fireplace, where a small kettle hissed quietly over glowing coals. He stirred them with a blackened iron poker, sending a puff of embers into the air.

"So, what brings you two birds to this armpit of Termina? We don't get too many fair folk such as yerselves down 'ere," he asked with a broad grin, revealing a missing tooth.

Before we could answer, the man clapped a massive hand over his face.

" Strewth!  How could I be so crass to not make proper acquaintances! I'm called Frank, if it so pleases ye both." He executed a flourishing bow with surprising grace for someone of his size. "How might I call you?"

"Well, my name is Link… and this is Tatl."

"Well, 'tis a pleasure to meet ya!" Frank said, ambling behind a cluttered counter at the other end of the room. He rummaged briefly through a drawer full of mismatched mugs. "So, a boat… are ye here to see th' sights? I'm a tour guide of sorts, and I know me way 'round the swamp like the back o' me clamp!"

"Ummm, kind of, I think?" I replied, still working to decipher his colorful dialect. "We're hunting the monster that's causing havoc here."

Frank paused, mug halfway to the counter. His jovial expression stiffened. Slowly, he leaned forward, elbows bracing against the bar’s edge.

The smile never quite left his face—but it no longer reached his eyes.

"Blimey! Yer serious!" The man scratched his exposed, hairy chest with thick fingers. "You best stay away from that beast, sheila! Matter o’ fact, ye best flee this bloody swamp altogether!"

"It's Link," I said sharply, straightening. "And we can't leave. I can handle myself, and we were sent to deal with the monster." Tatl hovered beside me, nodding in solidarity.

"I apologize for me swamptung... 'Sheila' is just a word we use down 'ere for spunky young lasses such as yerself," he said with a sheepish grin. "But I’m bloody serious—ye gotta get out while ya still can. Odalwa ain’t an ordinary monster."

"Odalwa?" Tatl echoed, brow furrowing. "That thing has a name ?"

"Yeh. Used to be just a ghost story we told the wee ones to keep 'em from wanderin'. ‘Bog in to yer rat stew, Bill and Sally, or Ol’ Odalwa’ll tear yer tongue out!’ That sort o’ thing. But they ain’t just tales no more. Somethin’ woke it up. It’s real now, and it's been snatchin' folk."

"So… what you're saying is a storybook monster came to life. And now it's hunting people," I said, flatly.

"Right-o! And from what I seen and heard, it favors little sheilas like you.  So I’m beggin’ ya—get outta dodge before it’s too late."

I rose from the couch, jaw tight. "No. Look, if you can’t or won’t help us, we’re going either way."

Frank raised his hands defensively. "Wait jist a tic, mate! Hear me out, yeh? If yer gonna be trouncin’ about the swamp, you’ll need a boat, at the very least. That fancy bow o’ yours won’t do much against Odalwa, if you’re serious about huntin’ it."

"Then what do you suggest?" I muttered.

"Koume’s sister, Kotake, runs a magic shop east of here. Strange old bird, but wise as the tide. She might know where Koume’s gotten off to. And chances are, she’s got some thingummy or charm that might help ye survive out there."

He scratched behind his ear, his tone softening. "I'd be heaps grateful if ya found Koume. Business has been dryer than a dead Deku without my boat captain."

I exchanged a glance with Tatl, who nodded.

"Sounds like we’d be killing two birds with one stone. Where’s the shop, exactly?"

"Coupla clicks east. Stick to the shoreline and you’ll see the path clear as day. Big crooked trees and some glowy fungus’ll light yer way."

"Right. Thank you for your... kind... hospitality, Frank," I said, heading toward the exit. "But I think we’ll have to take a rain check on that tea."

Frank gave a knowing chuckle and tipped an imaginary hat. "Fair winds, then. And may yer feet stay dry and yer bow stay true."

I waved once, and stepped back into the fog with Tatl at my side, the door creaking shut behind us.

"Swamp dwellers… so weird." Tatl shook her head, her tiny voice tinged with amusement and mild exasperation. "I can barely ever understand them—and they're all pretty crazy. But... I guess you'd have to be, living in a place like this."

I laughed softly, the sound a little hoarse in the heavy air, and started down the boardwalk toward solid ground.

"Alright. We should hurry. I can't imagine we have much time left before the moon falls."

Tatl floated upward, scanning the thick clouds overhead for a glimpse of the doomed sky.

"I can't tell either, but you're probably right. He said the shop was east of here, shouldn’t be too far a walk. I’m more worried about what he said about Odalwa…" She glanced around, her glow dimming slightly.

"If we see any fog drifting our way, we’ll hide—same as before. Don’t worry. We’ve made it this far." I tried to sound calm, steady. My boots squished into the mossy earth, the wet ground sucking at each step.

"Okay, you’re the hero," Tatl said, not quite reassured, but choosing to trust me anyway.

She drifted in closer, her light brushing against my shoulder—not a nudge, not an accident. A quiet signal. A promise.

Whatever came next, we’d face it together.

I smiled faintly and gave her a thumbs-up, the gesture small but sincere. She chuckled, a fragile sound that stirred the air around us like wind through reeds.

The shallow mud squelched beneath our feet as we moved eastward into the pale haze of the swamp. Ferns and vine-choked trunks loomed in the fog like the silhouettes of forgotten sentinels. Crickets whispered. Distant birds shrieked once and fell silent.

With each step, the quiet thickened. The squelch of my boots faded beneath the hush, swallowed by the stillness.

And I couldn’t shake the feeling—that every step forward was drawing us nearer to something nameless. Not just a beast or a shadow or a trap, but something older. Something watching.

The mist curled at our heels like ghosts, and even with Tatl’s gentle glow beside me, the weight of the sky pressed down harder with each breath.

Whatever lay ahead—monster, memory, or madness—it wasn’t just a threat to overcome.

It was a reckoning.

And I had to face it—not just for Termina, but for every fractured piece of myself scattered through this dying world. My name, my purpose, my fate… they all waited in that dark. So I stepped forward—into the dread, into the waiting dark—toward the reckoning that bore my name.

Chapter Eighteen

Ambush

The swamplands grew darker and more oppressive as the day died slowly, suffocated beneath a sky of muddy orange and bruised violet clouds. The sunset was smothered completely, hidden by thick stormbanks that loomed in the distance. The deluge promised that morning had never come, but its absence felt like a curse rather than a mercy. Distant thunder rumbled low across the horizon, a constant growl that never ceased, as if some vast beast circled just beyond the horizon, patiently stalking us, waiting for nightfall. Still, the air hung heavy and soured—dense with the stench of algae, molded rot, and something deeper that filled my lungs with dread. Breathing it in made my throat itch. It felt like the swamp was trying to get inside me.

Tatl and I picked our way along the marshy shoreline, boots sucking into damp earth that squelched and gurgled with every step. The buzzing of insects that had plagued us earlier began to fade, replaced by a sinister hush. Birds, too, had gone silent. It wasn’t peaceful. It was the kind of silence that animals used to warn each other that a predator was near. I tried not to dwell on it.

Frank, the strange but hospitable tour guide of the boathouse, had told us of a Magic Shop somewhere further down the bank. According to him, the shop owner’s sister was likely still there and might have the key to the locked boat. We followed that hope. Tatl drifted close to my shoulder, veering away from the more toxic patches of marsh, her gaze darting restlessly into the mist-choked trees as if expecting them to move.

"What if we run into Odalwa on the way to the magic shop? It was bad enough to look at in broad daylight, and I certainly don't want to be grabbed by the monster!" Tatl flitted about nervously, startling at every movement within the mists.

"Don't worry about it, we'll just hide like last time. If it can't see us, then we'll be just fine." I offered a weak grin. "Worst case, I throw you at it and run."

"Excuse me?! I am not bait! I am a dazzling orb of wisdom and guidance! You throw me at a monster and I will personally haunt you in every temple from here to Termina Field."

"See? You’d make a great distraction. Loud and  glowy."

I joked lightly, but a brief pang of guilt twisted in my chest at her glare. Truthfully, I’d sooner fling myself into danger than risk her.

Tatl huffed and glared, but the glow around her pulsed a little warmer, less frantic.

"Frank said the shop isn’t far," I added more gently. "We’ll be there soon."

"He also said people like you were Odalwa's favorite victims. You know—small, brave, tragically stab-happy types. And it’s getting dark… what if it sneaks up on us and kidnaps you like the others?"

"I highly doubt that a big monster could sneak around so easily. Plus, I’ve noticed my hearing’s a lot better since... well, you know." I tapped my temple. "New ears and all..."

"Oh perfect. So we’ll hear  it coming before it eats you. Great comfort."

I tried to keep my tone light for her sake, but truthfully, her fear was starting to creep into my own bones. The longer we walked, the more the shadows seemed to shift and breathe around us. My gut was twisting with unease, a wordless signal screaming from the same primal place that made the animals flee before a storm.

"Hrrmm ok...if you say so. You're the warrior here, not me. I suppose you'd know the situation best." Tatl took a deep breath and blew it out slowly, as if trying to physically push her nerves down. "So... I wonder what happened to the boat lady. Do you think she got taken, like the others?"

"I hope not," I muttered. "We don't even know where they're being kept. Plus we really need a boat here. I wouldn't dare  swim in that stuff!"

Even thinking about it made my skin crawl—murky water thick with algae, debris, and who-knew-what corpses bloating under the surface.

"If she was kidnapped, then there's apparently no way we can get a boat, and we'd be stuck. So please, don't jinx it for us."

"I'm just saying... we should have a backup plan or something…" Tatl grumbled.

"Ugh... fine. I guess you're right." I sighed. "Keep an eye out for anything we can possibly use as a raft. There's gotta be driftwood along the banks we can lash together. But stay away from the treeline—if I were a monster, that's where I'd be lurking."

We scanned the banks as we walked, our eyes flicking between patches of reeds and half-sunken logs, the last slivers of daylight fading fast. The air was still thick and warm, reeking of mold and death. When we rounded a bend in the lagoon, a sickly-sweet stench slammed into me like a blunt weapon. I gagged and glanced around frantically, something was wrong here.

The water ahead had turned a curdled shade of purplish-brown, its oily surface slicked with bloated fish and bits of unidentifiable gore. The banks were mottled with black silt and flies, buzzing in lazy, grotesque swirls.

"Uh, Link? I have a bad feeling about this area," Tatl whispered, barely audible against the dense silence. "Look at the water. Do you think... that thing could be nearby?"

"It's a good chance," I said, scanning the treeline. My eyes caught a fallen log near the shore. "Quick, let’s take cover over there."

We moved fast but low, instinctively hunched, every squelch of our boots in the muck sounding like a gunshot in the hush. I ducked behind the log while Tatl slipped inside my cloak like a trembling ember.

For long moments we held our breath. Nothing moved.

I slowly lifted my head to peek. The lagoon had gone still, deathly still, as if even the wind had stopped breathing. Purple-grey clouds loomed overhead, reflected in the mirrored slime of the water. Algae clumped like floating bruises on the surface. Across the way, a thick copse of moss-draped trees hung in silence, their vines swaying just barely—as if something had brushed past them.

I peered into the trees across the stagnant water, straining my eyes for movement among the gnarled trunks and weeping vines. The air was still, sticky, and so thick it felt like it could be sliced. A sudden explosion of motion snapped my gaze upward—birds erupted from the canopy in a flurry of panicked wings, screeching as they fled from something unseen. The sound faded quickly, swallowed by the thick fog.

The swamp held its breath. Everything stilled to unnatural silence. Then came the footfalls—heavy, distant, rhythmic… Each one sent subtle tremors through the earth, vibrating up through my boots and into my bones. The lagoon's mirrored surface rippled with each impact, breaking apart reflections like shattered glass. My stomach knotted.

I didn’t breathe. Didn’t blink. Just waited.

With a splintering crash, Odalwa burst through the trees—its enormous form exploding into view like a nightmare made real. Its sword, jagged and grotesque, cleaved through low-hanging branches as if they were paper. Its body was painted in crude war markings, masked by a twisted wooden faceplate riddled with nails and carvings. It stomped to the water’s edge, its movements oddly stiff, like a puppet being jerked forward by invisible strings.

Then it sniffed.

Sharp, wet gasps sucked in through the slits of the mask, each one sounding like the gurgle of drowning lungs. It tilted its head left, then right, twitching with each breath. My blood turned to ice as its hollow eye-holes swiveled in our direction.

I ducked behind the log, heart pounding in my ears like a war drum. The wood was trembling against my spine with each of the thing’s steps. Tatl let out a tiny whimper inside the cloak, her glow dimming almost to nothing. I slipped a hand back to my belt, fingers closing around the mask. If it came closer—

A shriek split the stillness.

From across the lagoon, dozens of furious howls echoed, followed by a clatter of thrown stones. The monkeys. A chaotic barrage of screeching erupted from the canopy as rocks pelted the monster’s face and shoulders. I could hear them thunking against its wooden mask—sharp cracks and splinters flying.

Odalwa let out a guttural roar and spun on its heel, the sheer vibration of its voice rippling the water. It charged across the swamp in a furious, thudding sprint, crashing after the monkeys as they scattered into the trees like startled leaves.

I dared to raise my head. The log creaked as I shifted.

Dozens of monkeys—mud-caked, shaggy, and wildly different in shape and size—were perched in the treetops, flinging anything they could get their hands on: rocks, fruit, even bones. The scene was primal and chaotic, but to my amazement, they were holding their ground. The liquid rot from its body spewed into the waters as the monster moved, and the monkeys retreated back into the safety of the woods.

My hand trembled around the mask. That had been too close. One more second... one single misplaced breath...

Tatl stirred faintly in my cloak. "That was way  too close."

"Yeah," I whispered. "I noticed."

When everything was quiet and calm once more, we both breathed a huge sigh of relief.

"See? Whew  Not a problem," I said with a shaky laugh. "We could see it from a mile away! Totally under control."

Tatl zipped out from under my cloak with a scowl. "You were about ten seconds from getting pancaked! If it hadn’t been for those monkeys, we’d be monster chow."

"Well… maybe," I admitted, rubbing the back of my neck. "I could’ve transformed and taken a swing at it. Might be smart to put the mask on ahead of time next time."

"Oh, perfect. Loud thumping and dramatic transformation sparkles in the middle of a stealth mission—great plan." Tatl zipped between me and the mask, glowing brighter in frustration. "Seriously, you’re not exactly Mister Subtle with that thing on."

"Okay, okay! Point taken. But if we bump into Odalwa again, don’t expect a well-timed costume change."

She sighed, drifting back beside me. "Let’s just not  bump into him again. Deal?"

"Deal."

We trudged back toward the shore, following the murky lagoon, the last echoes of monkey screeches fading behind us like distant war cries. Whether they meant to save us or not, I owed them a debt.

Twilight settled over the swamp like a burial shroud. The light drained from the sky, replaced by a hazy gray-blue gloom that seeped into everything—water, bark, skin. The whole world felt damp and grave-cold. Trickling streams bled into the main body of water—sickly green and black, oozing like veins across the mire, carrying with them strange slicks of iridescent oil that shimmered with unnatural colors.

We passed bloated animal corpses half-submerged in the muck, their skin blistered and peeling, limbs stiff in death. Some had sunken eyes filled with maggots, others had mouths frozen open in silent screams. Flies buzzed in maddened spirals, thick enough to form clouds that dispersed only when we neared. Gnats bit at my face and neck, leaving itchy welts that throbbed with each heartbeat.

Bones, long picked clean, jutted from the silt like broken fingers reaching for mercy—or perhaps warning us back. A stench of rot and chemical decay clung to the air, thicker than fog, crawling into my nose and mouth until I nearly gagged. Each breath felt like inhaling poison.

The ground squelched beneath our feet, soft and treacherous. My boot slipped once on a patch of black slime and I caught myself on a twisted root that oozed decayed matter the color of dried blood.

I pulled my cloak tighter, but it didn’t help. Nothing could. The swamp was death—slow, sticky, and inescapable. And it was watching us.

"Ughh.. I'm thinking we should just walk through the trees and forget following the shore! These flies are driving me nuts !" I hissed to Tatl, flailing at the relentless swarm buzzing around my face. They were in my ears, up my nose—one even tried to crawl into  my mouth.

"What about the shop? Frank said to follow the shore—" Tatl ducked as I swatted at a particularly aggressive gnat. "Hey! Watch it! I do not  want to get knocked out by your flailing."

I turned to apologize—and nearly stepped on a decomposing goose. The burst of stench that hit me was immediate and vile.

"Urghh—gross!" I gagged, leaping awkwardly over it. My foot landed ankle-deep in a patch of squelching, sour mud. "Oh COME on!"

Tatl winced as I yanked my boot free with a wet slurp. "That poor bird. How did it even get  here?"

"No idea," I muttered. "But I'm done with this. Let's move over there—before I end up face-first in a pile of swamp meat."

I stomped toward the tangled treeline, boots squishing, cloak dragging muck. Tatl zipped after me, trying to escape the thickest cloud of biting insects.

"And what if we run into monsters back there?"

"Honestly? I’d rather deal with a monster than trip over one more dead goose."

"That’s a bold strategy. 'Death by bog beast' versus 'death by bird blunder.' Truly heroic."

"We’re probably near the shop by now anyway. Monsters don’t usually hang around where there’s signs of people... right?"

Tatl glanced around the gloom. "This place hasn’t looked 'people-friendly' in a decade. But hey, if you say so, Hero."

"Relax. We’ve got this. Just stay close."

"Pfft...sometimes I wish I had your confidence," she muttered, landing delicately on my shoulder. Her wings drooped just a little. "But I guess after all the crap you’ve faced, a little murder-mud and monster-stench is nothing."

"Well, once you've been sucked inside a giant whale, travelled through time, defeated the literal King of Evil, or changed into the opposite gender, I think you'd be surprised at what you can accomplish. At that point there's really nothing that can surprise you."

Tatl let out a genuine laugh. "Okay, fair. You’ve earned your swamp swagger. Maybe I’ll borrow some."

"Just don’t borrow my boots. They’ve officially died."

"Duly noted. I'm glad I can fly."

She flexed with a tiny hum, mimicking a bodybuilder pose. I snorted.

"Alright, tough girl. Let’s tone it down—I think I see something up ahead. Building-shaped. Maybe we’re finally close."

I ran to the carved wooden structure ahead, heart pounding with each step, trying to stay silent as the trees loomed like sentinels around me. The encroaching darkness made everything seem warped and surreal. The gateway before me was a strange burst of color in the gloom—etched with painted owls, foxes, and glowing symbols in vibrant reds and blues. Beneath it, a worn sign read: "This way to Kotake's Magic Shop, for all your mystical needs!" The arrow beneath the cheerful script felt almost mocking.

"Well, I'm glad we're almost there. It's getting really hard to see out here, plus these flies are getting on my last nerves!" I slapped at my arm again, feeling the wet crunch of a crushed bug against my skin.

"I couldn't agree more, I was about to say that myself… I'm being attacked from all sides!" Tatl flailed her tiny arms like she was drowning in a storm of gnats.

We passed through the archway, and the air instantly grew heavier, wetter. The dirt path narrowed and twisted through choking underbrush, while moss hung like streamers from crooked limbs above. Somewhere to our right, an animal let out a guttural cry—abrupt, short, then silence. I paused. Tatl hovered close, glancing around with wide eyes.

"Probably just a wolfos," I whispered. "They hunt at dusk."

The light dropped sharply. What little sun remained was swallowed by the canopy above, casting long shadows that shifted as though breathing. Tatl nudged my arm, pointing at something ahead—a flickering orange glow weaving through the dark trees.

"Hey, what's that? You think it could be someone who needs help?"

"Umm, maybe... but we need to get to that shop."

"Yeah but... what if they're in trouble?" She fluttered anxiously toward the treeline. "C'mon, let’s go see!"

A flash of silver blurred past us.

With a deafening crack, a tree exploded in front of Tatl, showering her in bark and splinters. She screamed. My instincts kicked in—just as a massive, gnarled hand lunged from the shadows toward me. The skin was stretched taut over blackened bone, riddled with fungus and oozing pustules. I barely twisted away in time, rolling into the wet leaves and dirt, heart stuttering.

Odalwa. Again.

I bolted behind a tree as the ground shook beneath the thing’s steps. Tatl zipped upward, her glow panicked.

"Link! Watch out!"

The monster’s massive blade carved through the air, slashing through vines and trees as if they were tissue. It moved with terrifying purpose—this wasn’t a wild swing. It was hunting.

I dove behind a bush as the sword cleaved my previous hiding place clean in two. Wood detonated in splinters. Leaves shot upward in a burst of green and brown. The very air seemed to recoil, buzzing with static and the scent of burning rot. A guttural wail—inhuman and primal—rattled my bones, deep and resonant, like the cry of something ancient and wrong.

Then I saw its face.

The mask’s eyes turned toward me—twin voids of pitch black, bottomless and lightless, pulling in every flicker of the world around them. They weren’t just empty—they were devouring. Shadows bent toward them. My heart seized.

Black ichor oozed from the corners of the mask like tar-slick tears, dripping steadily onto the moss and hissing where it landed. Thin veins of fungus pulsed along its surface, glowing faintly like embers under skin.

It didn’t see me.

It sensed  me.

No time to transform.

I wrapped trembling fingers around my bow, notched a magic arrow, and aimed through the foliage. The faint glow lit up the brush—too late.

The creature's head snapped in my direction. It roared, louder than thunder. A wall of sound and fury.

And it charged.

I tried diving away back into cover as Odalwa charged toward me, flinging broken trees every which way like a tantrum of nature itself. One of the soaring trunks clipped me in the left shoulder, and the impact exploded in white-hot agony. I screamed, a raw and guttural sound, as my body twisted midair and slammed into the ground. I hit hard, my lungs seizing up, my vision clouding. Pain exploded through my shoulder in searing white-hot waves, each breath agony. My vision blurred with tears, limbs unresponsive, useless. Terror surged, bitter and choking. I had never felt this vulnerable—this powerless.. Every heartbeat sent another lance of torment down my side.

The ground shook as Odalwa’s massive footfalls closed the distance. My heart thundered. I blinked away tears, mud clinging to my face. And then—

It loomed.

The mask hovered inches from my face, steaming breath washing over me like a swamp fog from a rotting beast. The stench made me gag—sour, fungal, and metallic. Black ichor dribbled from its jaw, sizzling where it hit the earth. The hollow eye sockets stared into me—those unnatural voids that swallowed all light, all hope.

My limbs refused to move. My shattered shoulder sent waves of paralysis through me. My good hand scrabbled weakly at the dirt, reaching for a branch, a weapon, anything . But I couldn’t escape.

"Get away from me!" I shrieked, voice breaking with terror. I tried to slide back, but my body wouldn’t obey. My arm collapsed beneath me and I fell sideways into the muck.

The mask tilted.

The monster reached for me—its twisted hands gnarled like dead wood, dripping with ooze, its fingers twitching like it could already feel my throat.

And then—

Tatl.

She hurled herself in front of the mask, clutching a jagged splinter of wood. With a sharp cry, she drove it straight into the thing’s eye.

The sound was unbearable. A screech tore through the swamp like a siren, rattling the trees and my skull alike. Purple liquid jetted from the mask’s eye socket, spraying in thick arcs that hissed when it hit the dirt and plants. Odalwa stumbled back, claws clutching at the embedded shard, convulsing in rage.

Tatl dropped.

She fell limp, tumbling end over end until her tiny body hit the ground like a fallen ember. Her glow flickered erratically, fading.

"Tatl! Tatl, are you— gasp —okay!?"

I dragged myself toward her with my good arm, each movement a scream inside my nerves. Twigs tore my skin. Vines tangled my legs. But I didn’t care.

She was lying in a nest of debris, her little limbs trembling, her face smeared with that same grotesque purple ooze. Her breaths came in short, shallow bursts—barely there.

"Tatl! No, no no no—stay with me! Come on! Please!"

I reached out and cradled her tiny body in my palm, feeling her weak pulse through my dirty fingers. She didn’t respond.

I sobbed, helpless. The swamp pressed in from all sides.

“Tatl! Tatl, please—”

My voice broke, raw with panic and grief. I cradled her tiny, trembling form gently, fear squeezing my heart like a vise. I could lose anyone, anything—but not her. Never her.

Then—

The ground thundered.

Odalwa had recovered. It stood tall and furious, blade raised in a high arc. I couldn’t move. Couldn’t run. I had nothing left.

It let out a roar—a bellow of hate and hunger—and charged.

I closed my eyes, clutching Tatl to my chest.

And waited for the end.

An icy blast of freezing air suddenly whizzed past my face, so sharp and dry it sliced the breath from my lungs. A thunderous thwomp  followed, shaking the ground like a boulder had fallen from the sky. I dared to crack one eye open.

Odalwa’s massive, decaying form lay toppled, now encased in a thick, crystalline coffin of ice. Frozen mid-lunge, its blade still half-raised, the monster let out muted, muffled groans from behind the frost, its limbs twitching just slightly beneath the surface. Steam hissed from the seams of the block as the swamp’s heat began to eat away at the edges, but for the moment—blessedly—it was trapped.

Then she appeared.

The hag swooped in from the trees like a phantom wind, hunched low upon a crooked broomstick that left a curling trail of shimmering frost in the air behind her. Her robes were tattered and layered, adorned with glowing runes and stitched charms that jingled faintly as she moved. Frost clung to the hems of her sleeves. Her skin was pale green and wrinkled like dry leather, and a massive sapphire glittered from the center of her towering violet turban.

I blinked, dazed, something was familiar about her. Her presence buzzed through me like static, familiar yet distant—like a name on the tip of my tongue. Where had I seen her before?

With a guttural rasp, she raised her gnarled hands—decked in silver rings and bright lacquered nails—and chanted something low and ancient. The ground beneath the frozen monster rippled with crimson light, then split apart like paper. A swirling vortex of red magic yawned open, its edges crackling with raw power.

Odalwa groaned again, its massive body trembling within the melting ice. With a sharp gesture and a hissed word, the hag completed her spell.

The frozen brute sank into the portal without a sound. One moment it was there—the next, it was swallowed by the red void. The portal snapped shut with a hiss, leaving behind only curling steam and scorched moss. A surge of relief and awe washed over me as Odalwa vanished into the swirling portal, replaced by stunned silence. We had escaped death—barely, impossibly.

The witch exhaled through her nose, satisfied, and gave a brisk nod. The sapphire on her turban flashed. She turned toward us, muttering something unintelligible—something about reckless girls and unfinished errands —as she glided closer.

My body went limp.

With the danger gone, all the adrenaline drained from me at once. The world swam before my eyes. The pain in my shoulder roared louder than ever. I tried to hold onto consciousness, but it slipped through my fingers like mist.

The last thing I saw was her boots touching the ground beside me, and a gloved hand reaching down, glowing softly with pale blue light. As darkness claimed me, I clung to a fragile hope that this witch—this savior—had arrived in time. Tatl’s small body still nestled in my palm was the last thing I felt as everything slipped away.

Chapter Nineteen

Toil and Trouble

A dull ache radiated from my shoulder as I slowly regained consciousness, the throb of pain pulsing in time with my heartbeat. My body felt heavy, wrapped in fatigue, and the air around me was thick with a strange and spicy smell that clung to the warmth like smoke in an enclosed room. My limbs felt like they were submerged in warm honey, sluggish and uncooperative. I was lying on a soft mat, and heard the faint sound of bubbling liquid nearby—a rhythmic, soothing noise like a distant cauldron simmering with secrets.

Footsteps approached—soft, deliberate. Something warm and wet gently plopped onto my shoulder, followed by a tug as it was wrapped and secured. A spike of pain lanced through me, sharp and sudden, and I sucked in a gasp through clenched teeth.

My eyes flew open at the sting. The moss poultice pressed against my skin was warm and damp, its earthy, astringent scent blooming in the air like crushed herbs beneath a midsummer sun. I turned my head and tried to sit up, but a wrinkly, olive-toned hand pressed firmly against my chest, holding me down with surprising strength.

"Stay there, you foolish child!" a voice croaked. "Your body’s still healing. No need to go flopping about like a fish out of water."

I stared up at her—the same ancient hag who had frozen Odalwa in a block of ice. Her skin was cracked and weathered like bark, eyes bugged and sharp as beetles. She leaned over me, peering at my shoulder like it was a misbehaving experiment.

"My potions work fast, yes, but not that  fast. Hmph! You’ll be up and charging into danger again soon enough. You’re lucky I found you when I did, you know. Not every day I scoop a screaming girl and her twitching glowbug off my front lawn."

I opened my mouth to speak, but my throat was scorched and dry, like I’d been chewing Gerudo desert sand for hours.

"T-Tatl..." I rasped, barely a whisper.

The witch blinked. "Tattle? Tattle on who ?" she asked, squinting in suspicion.

I shook my head weakly. "My... my friend. Is she—cough, cough—is she okay?"

Understanding dawned in her expression. She gave a grunt and waddled over to a cluttered table, rummaging among jars and flasks. "Ah, the fairy. Tough little puff of light, that one. Took a direct hit of Odalwa’s blood. Nasty, toxic stuff, that. But you’re lucky, you see— I’m  the greatest alchemist in all Termina! If anyone could save her, it’s me."

A knot of fear in my chest loosened just slightly.

"She’s not out of the woods yet," the witch added, grabbing a clear flask filled with milky white liquid. "But she’s stable. Breathing. Needs lots of rest. So do you, by the looks of it."

I watched her closely as she turned, the light catching on the rings decorating her gnarled fingers. My gut twisted with doubt. After everything, could I trust her? Was this kindness... real? Or something worse hidden behind her craggy smile?

And yet, there was no real malice to her movements. Only practiced care. Purpose.

She returned to my side, holding the flask like a chalice.

"Here, drink this. It'll help to free  your parched tongue." The witch clucked softly, her tone lilting—but her grip on the flask was firm, insistent. She tilted the pungent substance to my lips without waiting for agreement.

The liquid was oddly sweet, thick with a flowery, perfumed essence that clung to my tongue. It tasted like violets crushed with honey and something faintly coppery beneath, like blood hidden beneath blossoms. As it slid down my throat, I felt the fire in my throat dim, the cracked dryness replaced with a soothing coolness. It relaxed me almost instantly. Too instantly.

I closed my lips around the edge and pulled more of the tonic into my mouth—until she jerked the flask away.

"Alright, alright, that's enough. I don't need you drinking too much and becoming all giddy on me." She set the flask back onto the nearby table, with a more stern gleam in her eye. "Now then, would you tell me what you're doing with that enchanted bow?"

There was a weight behind the question. Not anger. Not threat. But something colder—expectation. Like a teacher who already knew the answer, and was just waiting to see how honest I’d be.

The ancient woman gestured to a shadowed corner, and my eyes followed her crooked finger. The dim flicker of a candle revealed my clothing and blue bow, neatly draped over a wall-mounted hook like museum artifacts. Dust motes drifted lazily through the beam of light, catching on the fine hairs of hanging herbs and glittering jars that lined the stone walls. The room was steeped in an overwhelming earthy scent—moss, dried roots, sharp tangs of preserved bark and bitter oil. It felt old, dense with secrets.

Seeing my belongings—laid out, handled, distant—sent a shiver through me. I felt exposed, small. Like something picked clean and set aside for study. My eyes dropped reflexively to myself.

Bandages were tightly wrapped across the curves of my breasts, and a scratchy brown blanket clung to my hips and thighs. That was it. My legs, bare and cold beneath the thin wool, curled in instinctively. My cheeks flushed with heat.

The old crone caught my mortified glance and cackled like wind through brittle branches.

"Oh come now, hehehe, don't look so embarrassed. There isn't anything there I haven't seen before—not that you’ve got much to show, runt. Hardly any muscle at all. Now. About that bow."

Her sudden shift in tone—low and expectant—hit me like a jolt. I swallowed.

"It was given to me by the Great Fairy," I said quickly, the words slipping out faster than I meant. I couldn’t stop myself.

"Is that so... huh." Her eyes narrowed like a snake in tall grass. "I would've hoped that such a wise fairy queen had better judgment. Why would she give a stupid young girl like you  something so powerful?"

My stomach clenched. "Hey! I may have gotten ambushed by that creature out there, but I'm not stupid! The Great Fairy gave me that bow because she said I was the only hope for this world!" I pushed myself upright with trembling effort, only for her hand to slam me back into the bedding again. She was smiling. But there was nothing soft behind it.

"The only hope? Ha! If I hadn't been picking mushrooms out there you'd be lizalfos stew meat by now—or strung up with the others, wherever that beast takes them!" she barked, her grin sharp and wolfish. "So you better tell Ol' Kotake the real  story... before I turn you into a Deku toad."

My breath caught.

Upon hearing her say that name, a jolt of recognition stabbed through me—cold and immediate. The dark-skinned hag’s face blurred with a memory from deep within the Spirit Temple: fire, mirrors, laughter like shattered glass. Kotake and Koume—Ganondorf’s surrogate mothers. My breath caught as I recalled the way their magic had twisted minds, corrupted the Gerudo, and nearly destroyed me. No wonder her voice unsettled me the moment I heard it. She was one of Ganondorf's surrogate mothers! Kotake and Koume! Years ago, I had to fight the powerful witches in the Spirit Temple, back in Hyrule! Their magic had twisted the minds of the Gerudo, built the backbone of Ganondorf’s army, and nearly destroyed me

"Wait! You're one of Ganondorf's minions!" I shouted, recoiling with raw panic. I tried to scoot back toward the wall—toward my bow—but the blanket tangled around my legs and I slipped in the rush. My heart hammered.

Kotake’s eyes narrowed as she caught my ankle in her grip, surprisingly firm for someone so ancient. "What? How could you possibly…!"

She froze, inspecting me more closely now—my ears, my face.

"Are you from Hyrule? Tch, I should’ve guessed... But no. I'm not one of his sycophants, girl. Koume and I may have been of Ganondorf's tribe, but we fled before his evil spread thanks to a prophetic vision we saw of the Hero of Time bringing about our destruction.”

She stepped closer. "But how do you  even know about us? Our names were erased. Hidden by the Gerudo. You should not know. So—speak. SPIT IT OUT!"

I glared up at her, defiant even as pain sang in my bones.

"Because I  was the one who defeated you. Both of you. And him . I’m the Hero of Time."

I slapped her bony hand away from my ankle.

Her jaw dropped, then snapped shut like a steel trap. She barked a laugh—wild, shrill, and humorless.

"Scat and swamp fumes! You're a petulant little girl with a head full of stories. Or maybe that potion knocked what few wits you had loose."

"I’m not a girl, you decrepit vine-witch! I was cursed  into this body by the Skull Kid! I infiltrated  your Spirit Temple, freed Nabooru, and killed you both using your own magic! I watched you fuse , and I burned  you down with the mirror shield!"

The laughter died. Kotake’s face went still.

And then, slow as shadow, she drew a small, silvered dagger from beneath her robes.

The blade glinted—thin, curved, and wickedly sharp. She moved so close I could smell the acrid tingle of her alchemical robes, feel the stale heat of her breath on my cheek.

She placed the tip to my throat. The edge kissed skin. Then pressed.

"Who... are... you?" she hissed. Each word etched deeper. "You know far  too much. You're no lost little damsel."

Her eyes burned—not with anger, but with calculation. Fear.

"You have five seconds to explain yourself, before I slit your pretty... little... throat."

I didn’t flinch.

"I told you. I’m the Hero of Time," I said, voice hoarse but unwavering. "So either end it, or believe me. I don’t care anymore."

The blade trembled.

And for a heartbeat... so did she.

Kotake grunted, muttered something under her breath, and slid the dagger back into the folds of her robe. Her bulbous yellowed eyes remained fixed on me, silent, calculating. Then, like a dam cracking all at once, she threw her head back and burst into laughter—loud, shrill, and deeply amused.

"Hahaha! Oh, by the sands, I was starting to think the potion had soured, but it's true! Truly  true! The great Link, Hero of Time, terror of witches and monsters alike, reduced to a scrawny slip of a flower petal! Oh, the irony! The symmetry! The sheer poetry !"

She cackled until her breath wheezed. "You and your mirror-shining bravery gave Koume and I nightmares for years, you know. But now? Hah! Look at you. Stripped bare, bandaged, whimpering in my hut like a half-drowned cucco. Heeheehee!"

She wiped a tear from one eye, still shaking with mirth. I turned away, flushed with shame and fury, biting the inside of my cheek to keep from screaming.

"Oh yes, hardee har har !" I snapped, voice tight. "Why not just kill me already? Take your revenge for your son, or your pride, or whatever’s left of your ego. I’m right here. Go on."

I tried to cross my arms, but pain spiked through my shoulder and I hissed through gritted teeth.

"Kill you?" Kotake scoffed, waving a gnarled hand. "Child, you're managing that feat just fine on your own. No, I don’t want you dead. Not yet. If anything, I ought to thank  you."

Her voice dropped lower.

"You helped open our eyes. Ganondorf—he was going to use us. Just as he used the rest of the tribe. We saw it too late to stop him, but early enough to flee. Koume and I, we’re not evil , girl. We protected our people. We kept them alive when your Hylian kings tried to erase  us."

She stepped away, voice calmer now but no less firm.

"History forgets that, doesn’t it? Your royal family tried to wipe out the Gerudo after the Great Wars. Burned our temples. Buried our daughters. But of course, to the hero, we’re just wicked witches in the dark."

She chuckled bitterly, then waved a hand dismissively. "But enough of that. Political ramblings are wasted on ears still soft from fairy songs."

My jaw clenched. The shame burned hotter now—not just at her laughter, but at the truth I didn’t know how to face. No one ever talked about the other side of the fence… but her words made a kind of uncomfortable sense.

"Umm, okay? So if you aren't evil, why did you flee to Termina?" I asked, trying to keep the edge in my voice. "Surely you could’ve stayed and helped the Guard capture Ganondorf. Running only makes you look guilty."

Kotake scoffed, her mouth twisting into something that might’ve once been a smile. "You may be the former Hero of Time, but you’re still a daft, clueless child. Had we stayed, the King's Guard would’ve done to us what they did to the rest of our sisters—imprisoned us, tortured us, and strung us up like warnings."

My lips parted in protest. "No. That can’t be right. The king wouldn’t allow something like that. He would’ve shown mercy. Unlike your people, who nearly destroyed the kingdom! We restored Hyrule. We—"

"—You restored  nothing," Kotake snapped, eyes flaring. "You buried what made it honest . The Royal Family enslaved the races to serve their glory—Gorons in the mines, Zora in the reservoirs, Gerudo in the margins. That’s what started the Great Wars, girl. Your noble line  forced loyalty through blood and blade. If not for your precious ‘goddess’ shielding your people, the Hylians would have crumbled under the weight of their own greed."

She leaned close, voice low and sharp. "The only reason your race still exists is because you're the so-called 'Blessed of Hylia.' Keep that in mind the next time you think yourself a savior."

And with that, she rapped her jeweled knuckle sharply against my forehead.

"Ow—hey!" I winced, recoiling.

"Now hush," she muttered, shuffling back toward her table.

I sat in sullen silence, rubbing the sore spot. Her words throbbed louder than the sting on my head. And disturbingly... they didn’t feel entirely wrong. The stories I was raised on never mentioned chains in the mines or drowned songs in the Zora halls.

I turned to apologize—but then my eyes caught on the half-empty flask on the table.

The potion.

A shiver of suspicion curled through me. What if it hadn’t just made me speak the truth? What if it was twisting my thoughts? Making me question the truths I knew ?

I stiffened. "Ugh, you can’t brainwash me with that weird potion. I’m not so easily corrupted!"

I jabbed a finger at her. "And my people have always been good to the land and its subjects. It’s you  and your ilk who spread poison, who summon monsters, who cause all the trouble—"

Kotake slowly turned back, one brow raised. Her grin returned—but it had no warmth.

"Oh, child. If I had intended to corrupt you, you wouldn’t be arguing  with me right now. You’d be agreeing. You’d be smiling."

Her gaze flicked to the flask.

"That potion didn’t change your mind, dear girl. It just quieted your fear long enough to hear the truth."

I looked away, heat blooming in my cheeks again.

Because the worst part was… some stubborn part of me feared she might be right.

I let out a long breath and sank into the mat, the tension in my muscles giving way to exhaustion. Whatever her past, whatever she said about Hylians or the wars, one truth remained: she had saved me. She had saved us . And for that, I owed her at least a sliver of gratitude.

"Look... despite all that, you still went out of your way to rescue us. And I guess... whether you're trying to brainwash me or not, I need to thank you. For saving our lives."

Kotake waved a hand as if brushing off a speck of dust. "Well, it’s what I do . People come from all over Termina to seek my skills and potions. And for the record, I merely gave you a truth tonic. I have no use for a weak twit like you to be a slave anyway."

My eyes snapped toward her. "Wait— truth  tonic?"

"Of course," she said breezily, already turning toward her shelves. "You never know what kind of snake slithers in from the swamplands. And you —carrying the Bow of Light of all things—I needed to be sure."

I narrowed my eyes. "So you drugged  me. That’s what you’re saying."

"I protected  myself. You’re lucky that’s all I did."

I huffed and slumped back, flicking my crimson bangs from my eyes with a sharp motion. "Well, now you know who I am. I’m just the great Hero of Time, defeated and cursed into this stupid form by a bratty Skull Kid. Congratulations."

Kotake hummed, her grin fading into something more thoughtful. "Masked Skull Kid, you say? Ah yes, Koume’s been complaining about strange energies rising in the swamp. But I didn’t imagine that  was the cause. That runt’s been meddling in everyone's business for years, but something this vast..."

She trailed off, muttering to herself as she shuffled through a curtain of beaded vines.

When she returned, she held a glass vial filled with a shimmering red liquid. The light caught it like a flame, casting soft ruby flickers along the walls.

"Alright, Missy. Drink this—it’ll mend the damage to your body and restore your strength. I already gave a drop to your fairy friend, so she should be fluttering awake soon."

She caught my hesitation immediately and raised a bushy brow.

"No, it’s not poisoned. No, it won’t make you sprout a third eye or worship frogs. Just drink it. I wouldn’t waste good ingredients on a corpse. And besides..."

Her eyes glinted.

"I have a favor  to ask of you."

She handed me the vial, and I took it reluctantly, the glass warm from her palm. Popping the tiny cork free, I brought it to my nose and recoiled instantly—the scent was like fermented mushrooms and singed wood. Grimacing, I shut my eyes and tilted the red potion back.

The liquid hit my tongue like fire-drenched syrup—sickly sweet, then bitter, then sour. I gagged and forced it down, shuddering with each thick gulp until the last drop slid down my throat. I sat there a moment, quivering in disgust.

"There you go," Kotake said, watching with something close to amusement. "Now just lay back down and don't move while I tend to your friend."

I set the empty vial beside me, then slowly reclined against the mat, letting my body sink into the faint warmth spreading through my chest and side. My fingers tingled. The sharp ache in my shoulder began to dull, replaced by a soothing hum that flowed down my arm.

Kotake shuffled to a blackened fireplace at the far end of the room. A squat cauldron bubbled over orange flames, filling the space with the thick scent of earth and iron. Tatl lay nearby, still unconscious, curled in a shallow wooden box lined with moss and silk.

The witch ladled some of the cauldron’s dark brew into a stone bowl. As she stirred it with a gnarled stick, I watched her closely, uncertain if this was more magic or medicine—or both. A flicker of blue light pulsed faintly along the rim of the bowl.

The healing potion surged through me again, and I gasped softly as I felt my muscles knit, the raw pull of my shoulder easing further. Fingers I hadn’t realized were numb slowly curled again.

Kotake walked over to Tatl and, with unexpected gentleness, sprinkled a black, shimmering powder over her delicate form. Her voice dipped into a low murmur, words in a language I didn’t understand curling through the air like smoke.

When she returned, she looked almost… tired.

"Alrighty then, your arm should be healed for the most part. Why don’t you stand up and dress yourself. Then we can discuss my payment for saving your life."

"Hmph… I guess that’s fair," I muttered, pushing myself upright with a wince. My legs were stiff, my balance unsteady, but the pain had mostly ebbed.

I glanced back toward Tatl, her glow now faint but steady.

"What did you just sprinkle onto her?"

Kotake grinned, not unkindly. "Still don’t trust me, eh? Hehe, well I suppose that’s wise. I dusted her with something to draw the poison out and nullify its effects. Nothing dangerous. Just a little shadowroot and moon ash. Ancient remedies."

She winked, and I wasn’t sure if it was meant to reassure me—or unsettle me more.

As I trudged toward my hanging garments, still clutching the scratchy blanket around me, Kotake clucked and snorted, amusement glittering in her bugged-out eyes. She leaned on her stick like it was a throne, watching me with a predator’s patience.

"Tsk tsk. You needn't be so modest," she said with theatrical exasperation. "There’s nothing to hide. I had to undress you, you know?" She chuckled, the sound dry as sand scraping stone. "As a former Gerudo matron, I’ve seen more naked women than you’ll ever meet , hehehe. You should be proud of your form if nothing else—most of them would, and have, killed to own such a lovely body!"

I scowled as I reached for my tunic. "This is a cursed body, remember? Why would I enjoy it? The whole reason I’m stuck in this world is to undo  this ridiculous spell."

"Oh, I’m sure," Kotake said with maddening cheer, her voice rising in sing-song mockery. A knowing gleam danced in her eyes like firelight flickering over oil.

I hesitated, glancing at my reflection faintly mirrored in a polished copper cauldron. My feminine face—rounder, softer, still unfamiliar—stared back at me with a confused mix of strength and fragility. There were smudges of ash on my cheek, a lock of red hair stuck to my damp temple. I sighed and grumpily pulled the dark brown tunic over my breasts. The neckline was lower than I remembered without the cloak covering it, and still showed off more than I would've liked.

"Look... my situation’s none of your business. Not to sound ungrateful," I muttered, fumbling with the cloth wrapping around my chest. "But every time I catch a glimpse of myself like this , I’m reminded I can never go back. I’m supposed to be a warrior. Not some damsel in distress."

The words tumbled out before I could stop them—ripped from the tight place in my chest. That truth tonic still clung to my tongue like oil, loosening truths I hadn’t meant to share.

Then I realized— goddesses , I was still naked below the waist. And Kotake was watching. Her grin widened, toothy and unrepentant.

Heat rushed to my ears. I lunged for my clothing, pulling on new underwear with frenzied urgency, followed by my dark green cloak and fingerless gloves. The bra still lay on the ground like an abandoned challenge. I scowled at it.

"And then there's this stupid thing... how the hell do you get used to wearing this stuff??"

Kotake clucked like an annoyed hen and shuffled over to me, picking up the tan bra with exaggerated disdain.

"Honestly, you are worse than a child..."

With surprising strength, the hag spun me around, stripped off my cloak and tunic in a swift motion, and expertly wrapped the bra around my chest, adjusting the cups so my breasts settled into them properly. Her hands were quick and precise, like someone who had done this a thousand times.

"You're gonna have to get used to it eventually, girly! Heheheh..."

I groaned as she stepped back. I bent down to pull on my deerskin boots and grabbed my sturdy gear belt from its peg. The leather was worn smooth in familiar places—finger-hollows, notches, the faint scent of wind and sweat and battle.

The weight of it grounded me. I strapped it around my waist and pulled on my boots with trembling fingers.

Last, I reached for the blue bow.

Its weight in my hands stilled the storm. I tested the silver drawstring, felt the tension vibrate through my fingertips like a quiet song. It was solid. Real. Mine.

"I'll never get used to this. I was the goddess-damned Hero of Time. And now—"

"Oh posh!" Kotake interrupted. "You sound more like a spoiled little princess than a fallen hero. Your curse —pah! I’ve seen men turned inside-out, children hexed to live as shadows. You’ve got skin, breath, will. Be thankful, you foolish girl."

She thumped me on the head with her stick again—more gently this time, though it still stung.

"Now, if you're quite finished bellyaching, I need you to fetch my sister."

"Ouch! Would you please  stop hitting me?!" I snapped, batting the stick aside and rubbing the sore spot. My ears burned hotter than ever.

The crone only snickered.

"I'm simply trying to instill some sense into that addled brain of yours, you pansy. But are you going to sit there and moan or be on your way to find Koume?"

"Urrghhh… that was actually the only reason we came this way," I admitted, rubbing the back of my neck. "Frank, the Tour Guide, said she was missing. And we need a boat to go deeper into the swamp."

"Eh? Deeper ?" The witch croaked in disbelief. "Why on earth would you wish to go further in? You barely survived here on the outskirts!"

"Ha, I'm not as helpless as you think—watch this..."

I reached behind my belt for the familiar weight of my mask.

My fingers grasped at air.

Panic gripped my chest like a vice. I patted my belt, checked my cloak, searched every pouch. Nothing. My breathing quickened as I dropped to the floor, shoving aside furs and satchels in frantic desperation.

"Watch what? If I wanted to see hysterical floundering, I'd throw a fish onto dry land!" Kotake scoffed. "What in the realms are you looking for now?"

"My mask! Where is my mask?!" I cried, voice cracking. "I just had it! No, no, no—this can’t be happening!"

"Mask? I didn’t see anything like that on you, or anywhere near when I found you," she said, squinting. "Why are you so agitated over a silly trinket?"

"It’s not silly! That mask contains the last of my spirit! If I can’t find it, I’ll never turn back—never be myself again!"
