My eyes darted wildly around the hut, scanning corners, nooks, under rugs and behind baskets.

Kotake rubbed her chin, expression souring. "Hmm… a very interesting way of preserving spirits. Primitive, but clever. Still, stop flitting your eyes around like a startled cucco. I told you—I don’t have it. You most likely dropped it when Odalwa attacked you."

I stumbled onto a nearby stool, holding my head in my gloved hands.

"Gods... I'm going to be a girl forever…" I moaned, my voice muffled by my palms.

"Oh, stop your incessant moping! You're worse than a newborn babe! If your precious mask is missing, go find it ! It's likely still in the area where the monster ambushed you, you soft-brained twit!"

She stormed over, her stick tapping sharply on the floor.

"Get up. Find your mask. And find my sister. Your fairy stays here with me as collateral until you return."

I blinked up at her. "But what about Odalwa? I doubt I’d get very far before it found me again."

"Hmph… I already considered that," Kotake grumbled, fishing in the folds of her robe. She produced a smooth, flat stone no larger than a coin, etched with faded runes.

"This is a charm I crafted while you were unconscious. It will keep the monster from sensing your presence. With it, you won't be hunted—unless you’re foolish enough to draw attention again."

I took the charm from her wrinkled hand, turning it over in my palm. The grey stone was cool, faintly humming. A tiny, blood-red ruby gleamed at its center, surrounded by flecks of deep purple that shimmered like ink in water. A looped piece of thread was securely wrapped around the charm, effectively creating a necklace.

I exhaled slowly, steadying my nerves. One step at a time.

"Thanks... I guess."

Kotake gave me a sideways grin. "You're welcome. Now get going before I change my mind and keep your bow too."

I pulled the amulet over my head, flipping my hair out of the way, and stood. The charm settled against my chest with a gentle thud, its pulse faint but steady—like a quiet heartbeat.

"Okay, this is good… umm... do you think you know where Koume might be?"

"Last I heard, she said she needed to find yantam bark for boat repair. That particular tree only grows in the Shrouded Fens." Kotake waved her hands with exaggerated mystery, her fingers leaving faint trails in the air.

"Great, but how do I get there?"

"Phah! So many questions! It’s right down the path behind my hut. There’s a fallen, hollowed-out tree stump that serves as the entrance. Now run along, your fairy friend still needs careful attention. If she wakes before you get back, I’ll let her know you’ve become my errand girl, hehehehe!"

I rolled my eyes and turned away, stomping out the door. Her laughter followed me like a swarm of buzzing insects. As much as her teasing grated on my nerves, I couldn’t shake the feeling that Kotake—however irritating—meant well.

The hut was perched high on a wooden platform built into the thick trunk of an ancient tree. As I stepped outside, the cool air of early dawn greeted me, carrying the scent of dew and distant wildflowers. I stumbled slightly, catching myself before I toppled off the edge. Below, the swamp glistened with a sheen of early light.

A steep ladder rested against the platform’s rim. I scanned the canopy, ensuring no monsters lurked nearby, then descended cautiously. My boots hit the lower platform with a dull thud.

Below, a purified spring wound gently around the base of the tree. The water shimmered silver-blue in the light—pure, untarnished, and sweet-smelling. A welcome contrast to the miasma that clung to most of the Southern Swamp.

I circled the trunk, the amulet pressing cool and comforting against my skin. Just as the witch said, a stone path nestled behind the roots, partially concealed by overgrowth. A series of stepping stones crossed the spring. I leapt to the nearest one, water splashing softly beneath me, then bounded across to the other side.

I sauntered onto the path, the misty morning air clinging to my skin. The calls of waking birds echoed through the trees, and the faint gurgle of the spring followed me like a song.

But without Tatl beside me, the silence felt deeper. Heavier.

"Don’t worry, Tatl," I muttered, glancing back toward the tree-bound hut. "I’ll be back soon."

I turned away, squaring my shoulders. Sunlight streamed in golden shafts through the leaves ahead, slicing through the morning fog.

"Okay, Link, just keep moving and everything will be fine... You’ve been through far worse before. This is nothing."

I nodded to myself, gripped the amulet tightly, and stepped into the waiting trees—where shadow and silence were already beginning to rise.



Chapter Twenty

Monkey Business


The stone pathway was fairly simple to follow, compared to the rest of the swamp's trails. I felt a nervous urgency pulse through me with each step, allowing me to make excellent headway. Rays of morning light danced through the pale mists as the sun slowly rose over the treetops, but despite the calm morning I knew there was little time to waste. The northern skies were almost completely blocked by the moon, its face glaring pure hatred at the world below.

A faint tremor rumbled in the distance, warning of the doom and destruction soon to come. Worse still, my mask was missing, and if I didn't find it soon I feared that all hope of ever returning to normal would be lost. Should my mask be destroyed, my spirit would go with it, and I'd be trapped like this forever.

Choosing to focus on the task at hand, I jogged down the path. The soft footfalls of my light boots pattered on the hard rock surface, each step echoing like a heartbeat in the quiet forest. The air was thick with moisture and the tang of loam, and pale beams of light lanced through gaps in the mist-shrouded canopy. Though birds chirped softly in the distance, I couldn’t shake the feeling that something was off—like the entire forest was holding its breath.

I scanned the woods around me for movement, my grip tightening on the bow at my side. I had an unsettling sense that something was watching me from beyond the veil of trees, unseen eyes tracking every step. Still, I pressed on, alert and silent, each motion measured. The gem-studded medallion swinging from my neck—Kotake’s charm—glinted dully in the filtered sunlight. It was supposed to keep Odalwa from hunting me. I prayed the witch had been truthful. I couldn’t fight that thing again—not in my current state.

Eventually, the path ended at the foot of a steep cliff wall. A massive, hollowed-out trunk of a fallen tree lay embedded in the stone, serving as a natural tunnel through the rock barrier. Dense fog rolled from within its dark maw, thick and pale, spilling over gnarled roots like spectral breath. I couldn’t see the far side—it was swallowed by haze.

That same prickle of being watched crept back along my spine. My fingers curled instinctively around the grip of my bow, but I forced myself to move casually. If something was waiting for me, I didn’t want to give it the satisfaction of fear.

With a deep breath, I stepped inside.

The tunnel was silent—eerily so. My boots thudded dully on damp wood as I crept forward, every sense on edge. The air smelled like moss and wet bark, and the fog curled around my legs like a living thing.

I emerged on the far side into a world blanketed in silver mist. The Shrouded Fens stretched before me, a swamp cloaked in secrecy. The trees here were taller, darker, and seemed to lean in toward one another like conspirators. I could barely see more than a few paces ahead.

I understood now why it was called the Shrouded Fens.

Everything here was hidden. And something, I knew, was still watching.

I shuffled forward, taking care to watch my step, the wet ground muffling my footsteps beneath the thick fog. I squinted into the white haze, trying to make out shapes beyond the immediate blur. A vague rounded silhouette began to take form, dim and uncertain at first, but gradually sharpening into the outline of another hollowed-out tree trunk. The damp wood loomed like a mouth in the mist.

I stepped through it, waving the fog away with one arm as I passed into the gloom—and froze.

I was back at the entrance.

"Oh great! Another Lost Woods…" I groaned aloud, throwing my hands up. My voice echoed dully, swallowed quickly by the wet air.

I looked up at the sheer cliff face nearby, hoping to spot a path upward where I could get a better view of the surroundings. But before I could move, a soft thud landed just behind me.

I spun around, heart lurching.

A white monkey stood there, its fur ghostlike against the haze, large black eyes fixed curiously on me. Its little chest heaved with gentle breaths, and for a heartbeat we simply stared at one another.

Then it hopped forward, motioning with its paw toward the trunk.

"Mmm… This way... follow!" the monkey grunted in a strange, halting voice.

I blinked. "W-wait! You guys can talk?"

"Yes. Follow... mmm," it repeated, then turned and bounded into the tunnel without looking back.

Still stunned, I hesitated—then shook off the surprise and broke into a jog. My boots made soft clops along the old wood as I ran. I didn’t want to lose sight of the small creature—not in this swirling white maze.

The monkey led me through a series of identical tunnels, each one swallowing us into another fog-drenched passage. The air grew damper, thicker, and the wooden walls echoed with my breath and the faint patter of the monkey’s nimble feet. Between the fog and the twisting corridors, it was a miracle the creature didn’t lose its way.

After what felt like an endless chase through fog and twisting trunks, we passed through the last tunnel—and suddenly, the miasma lifted.

Before us stretched a grove unlike anything I'd seen before. Odd, brightly colored trees burst from the swamp floor, their trunks painted in reds and deep blues that shimmered in the misty light. Their bark looked smooth and velvety, like brushed suede, and large, juicy-looking orange fruit hung from low, swooping branches like lanterns on a festival night. The scent here shifted too—faintly sweet and oddly floral, as if the air itself were laced with nectar.

The monkey scuttled ahead without pause, disappearing behind one of the larger trees. I followed, half-wary, half-curious, until we stopped abruptly before a bizarre, humanoid-shaped shrub.

It looked almost sculpted—too symmetrical to be natural—with leafy arms curved like hips and a knotted, angular face formed from bark and foliage. As I stepped closer, something glittered at the top of the figure: a shiny red gem, embedded like a crown.

And then, the plant moved.

"Are you going to stand there all day gawking at me, you twit? Or are you going to help me out here?" the shrub bellowed in a voice both shrill and imperious, its leafy limbs flailing like offended arms.

I staggered back with a yelp. "I… ummm… I’m sorry? What, uh, what do you need? Water?"

"No, you dolt! I’m not a plant!" the creature snapped, rattling with indignation. "Why don’t you do something useful and fetch my sister, Kotake? She’ll know what to do."

My brain scrambled to keep up. "Wait. You’re Koume? I guess I should’ve seen that one coming... What happened to you?"

The foliage shifted as the shrub seemed to deflate with a tired huff. "How did you know my name? I’ve never seen you before!"

"You mentioned Kotake," I muttered, still staring in disbelief.

"Bah, no matter! Some impetuous Skull Kid wearing a mask ambushed me while I was gathering supplies. Caught me off guard. The little devil turned me into a plant! A plant, of all things! Do I look like a geranium to you?!"

"Hmph, I know how you feel. I've had my fill of Skull Kid and his curses myself... Oh wait!" I blinked, realization striking like lightning, and reached for my ocarina, plucking it from my pouch with trembling hands. "I think I know just what to do."

Koume's leafy brow furrowed. "Hey… That instrument right there, somehow it looks... very familiar. Like something I've only dreamed about in—"

I didn’t give her a chance to finish. I brought the ocarina to my lips and began to play the Song of Healing.

The first few notes drifted into the grove like wind through reeds—soft, sacred, and strange. The melody shimmered in the heavy air, and the trees themselves seemed to lean in to listen. Koume began to glow, her leafy form pulsing with a pale, ethereal light.

The monkey that had guided me screeched in sudden terror, leaping up a tree and vanishing into the canopy with a rustle of leaves. Light burst from Koume’s chest, flaring bright white as the song reached its crescendo.

"Whaa?! What's going on here?!" Koume shouted, her voice rising in pitch as her body dissolved into golden particles.

The brightness swallowed her, consuming the foliage until it collapsed in on itself like mist in sunlight. Her cries were lost beneath the swelling chords, the grove bathed in a soothing, mystical hum.

As the last note rang out and the light dimmed, Koume reappeared—whole, human, and utterly flabbergasted. Her tiny, wrinkled form stood dazed in the sunlight, mouth agape and robes slightly askew.

I lowered the ocarina and slipped it back into my pouch, exhaling with relief.

"Phew... I’m glad that actually worked. Hah!"

Koume glanced down at herself, inspecting her hands, her feet, even tugging at a strand of her hair as if confirming it wasn’t made of moss. At her feet lay a Deku-shaped mask—wooden, gnarled, and now lifeless. She kicked it aside with a huff of disdain.

Then she whirled on me, hobbling forward on her stubby legs with surprising speed.

"Who... are you?? Where did you get that instrument?!"

"Look… It's a long story. I'm sure if you get back to your sister she'll tell you all about it. But everyone seems to be worried about you… it would probably be best if you let them know you're OK."

"Oh my! You're right, Kotake must be worried sick!" Koume snapped her fingers and a rickety broom appeared in a puff of smoke. "Thank you most graciously, child! Shall I give you a ride back to my sister's shop?"

"Umm… no thanks. I've still got something I really need to look for." I politely declined, still aiming to locate my mask before the moon fell.

"Meh, suit yourself. Come by the boathouse sometime, I'll give you a free ride on one of my fancier ships." The fiery witch hopped on her broom with a surprisingly agile flip and sped off into the sky, sparks and embers trailing behind her. "Hehehe! Koume is revived!"

I stood alone again in the strange grove, quiet now except for the rustling leaves and the faint whistle of wind through the red-and-blue trees. I walked toward the mask Koume had kicked aside. A flicker of hesitation tugged at my gut—part awe, part dread. What power still clung to it? What might it do to me if I dared to wear it?

Its features were eerily lifelike: a protruding hollow snout, beady red eyes, and stiff green leaf-like fronds for hair. It looked like a warped Deku face carved out of living wood, expression frozen in wide-eyed surprise. The edges were rough, almost alive, and the whole thing seemed to hum faintly with leftover magic.

I didn’t dare put it on. Not after everything. I’d had my fill of cursed masks.

"Hmm...maybe I could ask Kotake to look at this for me," I murmured, slipping the strange mask behind my belt.

I turned and made my way back the way I’d come, stepping through the large tunnel, its interior swallowed in a dense, curling mist that clung to my boots and crept along the ground like a living thing. My footsteps echoed faintly within the hollowed trunk, swallowed up almost immediately by the enchanted quiet. As I emerged from the other side at the Fens’ entrance, I let out a sigh and rolled my eyes at the trickery of the woods. The place pulsed with strange magic—it felt like stepping out of a dream that had forgotten its ending.

But before I could take another step forward, a sudden rustle above made me freeze. Three monkeys sprang down from the trees with acrobatic grace, landing in my path in a tight semicircle. Their fur was damp with dew, and their sharp eyes glittered with recognition. I stumbled back slightly, startled, and instinctively drew my bow, pulling the string taut with a whisper of tension.

"No no swordsman! We friends, we friends!" the middle monkey hooted, waving its arms wildly in alarm. Its voice was scratchy but urgent, thick with a jungle dialect that turned vowels into squeaks and consonants into chirps. "No shoot!"

My eyes widened. I hesitated a moment, then lowered the bow, letting out a slow breath as I returned the weapon to my back.

"Hey… you called me 'swordsman'! How did you know I’m a swordsman?"

The monkey bounced on its feet, pointing animatedly. "We see you fight wolves! With mask! You brave. You avenge brother—bold! Eek eek! But you… you be under curse. Swamp curse too… very bad. You here to help us, eh? Yes?"

Its speech was garbled, riddled with strange cadence and half-formed grammar, but the meaning came through clearly enough. They’d seen me. They knew more than I’d expected—and perhaps more than they should.

"Uhhh... yeah, that's right. But... I lost my mask, and I can't defeat that monster without it."

"Oh!" The spokesmonkey turned toward the trees and hooted, waving for something to join the group. "We see you drop while you attacked by ancient curse terror! Mmm... We protect!"

A large gray monkey, bulkier than the others and nearly as tall as me, lumbered out of the dense underbrush. Cradled carefully in its thick-fingered hands was my mask—its

carved features bold and resolute, even beneath a layer of grime. My heart leapt into my throat.

"You guys... found it?" I gasped, running up to the larger monkey and nearly snatching it from his hands in relief. I let out a cry of joy, clutching the familiar artifact to my chest. "You protected it—for me? Thank you!"

I bowed low in gratitude, a deep swell of amazement—and a twinge of guilt—tightening in my chest. They hadn’t owed me anything. Yet they’d watched over one of my most precious possessions.

"How can I repay your kindness?" I asked, still clutching the mask to my chest.

"No pay," the spokesmonkey declared with a shake of his head. "We help you defeat terror! We want home tree back! We want prince back! Deku take prince—blame him for missing Deku princess! Help!"

The monkey suddenly burst into frantic chatter, the others joining in a synchronized explosion of screeches and tail-thrashing. They leapt and bounded around me in chaotic arcs of fur and sound.

"Whoa, whoa, hold it! I’ll help you guys, just quiet down before something hears you!" I shouted over the din, waving my hands above my head to calm them.

At the command of a sharp caw from the leader, the others froze mid-bounce and settled, twitching with barely restrained energy. The lead monkey stepped forward again, his large eyes now filled with quiet sorrow.

"Prince being held in Deku Palace... south edge of swamp," he said solemnly. "Must hurry now. They punishing prince... very bad."

With that final word, they dashed off, vanishing into the shifting curtain of trees and mist. Though peculiar, the monkeys clearly understood the swamp's dangers far better than most—and they had returned something precious to me. At the very least, I owed them. If their prince was being punished unjustly, I would see him freed. But first, I needed to return to Tatl and check in at Kotake’s shop.

I glanced up at the sky, the sun now rising higher above the treeline, spilling golden light over the dense canopy. Judging by the angle of its ascent, it was already mid-morning. The brilliant azure sky was a painful contrast to the looming black moon still dominating the northern horizon, a grotesque reminder of the ticking clock above. There wasn’t much time left, and I doubted I could find Odolwa’s lair on foot before the world was crushed beneath that leering celestial face. There had to be a faster way to get around. Some shortcut. Some trick.

Sighing, I secured my recovered mask to my belt alongside the strange Deku one, and took off at a steady jog down the stone trail. A quiet sense of triumph bubbled up inside me. I had completed my tasks without losing my life, and I owed that to the strange tribe of monkeys who had protected what I had lost. Without them, I’d have been just another victim swallowed by the swamp’s creeping decay. And if they needed help, well... saving a prince sounded simple enough. The Deku had never posed much of a threat before—not to someone with a shield and decent reflexes. With my mask restored, the odds were finally tilting in my favor.

The twisted silhouette of Kotake’s crooked-roof shop came into view as I rounded the final bend. Colorful smoke curled from its chimney like incense from a cauldron, swirling in purples and sickly greens above the treetops. I paused, a mischievous grin curling my lips as I recalled Kotake’s endless jabs and jeers.

Oh, she was going to love  this.

I plucked the Hero’s Mask from my belt and pressed it to my face. The transformation struck like a thunderclap through water—searing heat and icy tension wrapping around my frame as my muscles writhed, bones grinding into new shapes, sinew pulling tight across a form not wholly mine. I gasped, my vision flashing white for a breathless moment as the magic scalded through every nerve.

It was painful—always—but familiar now. Almost comforting. Like slipping into a battle-worn coat that still bore the scent of home.

As the shift settled, I blinked against the sharp clarity of my restored senses. Colors seemed deeper. Edges more defined. Strength returned to my limbs like a tide rolling in.

I stepped up onto the platform, boots thudding softly against the planks, and climbed the creaking ladder two rungs at a time. The scent of moss, smoke, and potion oil drifted from the crooked little house ahead, curling through the morning air like old secrets.

Still smirking—half from triumph, half from the mischief I planned—I reached for the handle and pushed the door open.

"I'm back!" I gruffly called into the hut. "Where's Tatl?"

Koume and Kotake were in the middle of a conversation when I thudded through the door, and both shrieked at the sight of me.

"It's him... the Hero, Kotake! He found us, what now?!" Koume panicked, backing up against the back wall.

"No wait! It's an illusion, or a spirit!" Kotake snapped, eyes narrowing with suspicion. "The hero was transformed into some petulant girl! Should we banish this ghost into oblivion?"

"Yes, let's finish it quickly! The mere sight of it will haunt my dreams tonight!"

Koume burst into flame, heat rippling off her form in waves of shimmering distortion, while Kotake became encased in mobile frost, jagged shards skating over her arms as she raised them. I quickly raised my hands, waving them frantically.

"Hey hey! Wait, it's me! Do you want to destroy your hom—"

Too late. Their twin spells collided midair, forming a cyclone of elemental force that slammed into my chest like a battering ram. The impact knocked the wind from my lungs and flung me backward into the closed door, which rattled against its hinges.

A searing pain spread through my ribs as I crumpled, the Hero's mask dislodging from my face mid-fall.

And then—

The change hit me like an explosion inward. My limbs shrank, bones twisting and reshaping with sickening cracks. Muscles contorted, pulled taut like strings, then released in shuddering relief. My torso cinched inward; hips flared with a sharp crack. My voice cracked into a short, strangled gasp as the last remnants of my former shape rebounded into something smaller, rounder—feminine yet again.

I lay face-down, fingers trembling against the cool wooden flooring, gasping as the storm inside my body quieted. The mask rolled across the floor, coming to rest beside me, its surface glinting dully in the firelight. My tunic had ridden up in the blast, and my now-smaller frame left me swimming in its folds. A draft crept up my thighs as I weakly tried to tug it back down.

"Wait, Koume! Look, it's not a ghost. Hold your fire, you twit!" Kotake yelled out.

"It was only… gasp ... a joke!"

I wheezed, trying to sit up as my voice cracked into a familiar feminine tone again. I paused, blinking. The pain wasn't nearly as bad from the transformation this time—just a flicker of heat in my chest, a soft pop of pressure in my hips. That flicker of unease returned. Was I... getting used to this? I looked to the mask that had fallen beside me.

"And how… pant ... did you knock my mask off?"

Koume extinguished herself with a dramatic puff of steam, peering at me like I was a curiosity pinned in a display case.

"What in all the sacred springs... Kotake, did we hit him so hard he changed species?!" Koume squawked. "He’s a girl now! A girl ! Spirits and shadows, that’s a first even for me!"

"I told you that wasn’t a spirit, you daft cucumber," Kotake snapped, thumping Koume on the head with her mixing stick.

"Ow! Don’t smack me with that thing! The real Hero couldn’t possibly be here, so how was I supposed to know it wasn’t some ghostly projection?!" Koume snapped back.

"S-stop it, you two!" I barked, my voice breaking as I dragged myself upright with trembling arms. My limbs felt like soaked parchment—fragile and weak. My breath hitched, and my chest heaved as I fought to steady it. My face burned with a mix of shame and disbelief—flustered from being caught off guard, from transforming so helplessly, from realizing that the very witches I'd once defeated at full strength had nearly flattened me with a single blast. "It’s... just me."

"Phah, you daft child! Why would you pull such an awful trick? And how did you cast that illusion?" Kotake demanded, arms crossed and eyebrow twitching.

"No, look." I picked up the mask from the floor, brushing soot from its carved surface. "It’s the mask. It restores my real self—not an illusion, not a spell. Just... whatever this curse is."

Sarcasm dripped from Kotake's words as she answered. "Why my dear sister, this is the 'great and noble' Warrior of Time who tortured our slumber for nearly a decade. Only he's been cursed into this adorable little flower, hehe."

"Truly?" Koume chortled only momentarily before becoming serious. "I'm sorry, I shouldn't laugh. This one saved me from sharing a similar fate, so I must show my gratitude."

"Similar fate? You're already a woman, you senile toad!" the icy witch mocked.

"Shut your gums, you vulture. A few days ago, a scrawny masked skull child came out of nowhere and ambushed me! Then the kid turned me into a plant, of all things!"

"So... that's why you went missing? You couldn't defend yourself even against a weak Skull Kid? I think you may have been more useful as a plant, hehehe. I—"

"Good gods, do both of you always quarrel like this?!" I snapped, throwing my arms up. My patience was already fraying at the seams. "Look, all I want is Tatl and a boat. Then I'll be out of your hair and you won’t have to deal with me ever again."

"Oh, right. Your impertinent little fairy friend…" Kotake muttered, rifling through her robes. Her fingers emerged holding a glass bottle with a glint of smug satisfaction. "She was getting uppity about you being gone and tried to escape the moment her strength returned. I had to… restrain her."

She casually tossed the bottle to me. I caught it with a startled grunt, the glass cool and solid in my palm. Inside, Tatl whirled like a trapped star, her glow flaring with indignant fury. Tiny fists hammered against the transparent walls, lighting up the bottle like a lantern about to burst.

Without hesitation, I popped the cork. The moment the seal broke, Tatl erupted into the air like an angry comet, circling my head in a rapid blur of wings and righteous fury. Her voice—sharp, high, and relentless—unleashed a furious tirade in every direction.

"You maniacs bottled me?! Do you have any  idea how humiliating that was?! I swear, if I were five times bigger—"

I raised a hand slowly, gently pressing a finger to her tiny face mid-flight.

"Shhh… it’s okay. We're alright now."

She hovered there, wings buzzing like a nervous heartbeat. Her glow flickered—hot, then hesitant. Her mouth still opened in protest, but when her eyes met mine, something in them softened. The fury dimmed, and her whole frame gave a subtle shiver. She stayed close, breathing heavily, and slowly lowered herself. I nodded and offered the bottle back to the witches.

Kotake waved one gnarled hand dismissively. "No no, you keep it," she croaked. "You might be needing it for that one later on. I’ve no use for more bottles. Consider it a bonus for... uh, saving Koume in such a timely manner."

Her dry, crow-like cackle scratched the air, and Koume rolled her eyes with a tired groan.

Tatl floated down to my shoulder and settled there with a reluctant sigh. Her glow pulsed a little softer now—dimmed, yes, but warmer. Grounded. We were together again. And that was enough for her.

"Uh...thanks I guess. Oh, before I forget, I found this after I cured you." I produced the mask Koume had kicked aside earlier. "Could you by chance tell me anything about it?"

Kotake snatched the Deku mask from my hands with surprising speed. "Hmmmm, this smells strongly of magic…"

The hag turned it over in her gnarled fingers, squinting at the carved visage. She brought it to her face and inhaled sharply through her oversized nose—the kind of exaggerated sniff one might expect from someone judging a rare wine at a banquet.

"I'll need to run some tests," she muttered, still eyeing it carefully. "But judging by the smell—rich with loamy moss, sap, and something else... something spicy—I’d wager this gives the wearer some botanical traits. Maybe even allows them to interact with plantlife in strange ways."

"You figured that out from a sniff?" I asked, incredulous.

Kotake tapped her enormous nose with pride. "This old thing could out-smell a swine and out-sniff a bloodhound. It's why my potions are so famously potent—I find only the finest, most fragrant ingredients."

"Ha! You just think  you can smell as well as you used to," Koume snorted. "Might I remind you that you're over four hundred years old? Your nose probably thinks soap is poison."

"I'm still younger than you, crag-face!" Kotake snapped back, brandishing the mask like a weapon.

"As if! I was born after you, snag-tooth!"

"Spear-nose!"

"Hog-back!"

"Sheesh, do you two ever stop fighting?!" I finally burst out, rubbing my temples. "And here you call me  a stupid child when you’re both worse than toddlers! Gods help the swamp if I ever turn out like you two."

The bickering hags paused just long enough to glance at each other—and then cackled in unison.

"There you see, Kotake? From the mouths of babes, wisdom seeps. Now then, I'll be the adult here and cease this ridiculous bickering," Koume snarked to Kotake before turning to face me. "I'll be at the boathouse—should you require a boat, come see me there."

Without another word, she summoned her broom with a snap of her fingers, opened the door with a lazy wave, and flew off in a swirl of herbal smoke.

"Hmph... that nerve of Koume… Sometimes I swear she'll be the death of me," Kotake grumbled, more to herself than anyone. Then she turned her jaundiced gaze on me. "Anyhow, don’t you have somewhere to be right about now, little hero?"

"Yes, actually. Now that I’ve got everything I need—at least for now—do you know where this Odalwa creature is hiding? I don’t have time to search blindly, not with the moon falling faster every second."

"This old bag doesn't know, Link," Tatl interjected flatly. "She doesn’t even know where it came from!"

"You know, for someone I just saved, you’re a rather ungrateful little maggot!" Kotake shot back, her voice rising with indignation. She turned to me with a sniff. "But no, I don’t know where the monster lives. I’d wager the Deku or Ape clans know more. Speaking of which... do you want this back?"

She held out the Deku Mask toward me, its carved features catching the dim light. I reached for it, hesitating just a heartbeat.

"So... you don’t think this will do more harm than good?" I asked, unease prickling my fingers. "I’m sick of cursed masks. Just holding this thing makes my skin crawl. I don’t trust it—not after what the last one did."

"How should I know? I’ve never dealt with this sort of thing before," Kotake scoffed, shrugging her robed shoulders. "Why don’t you just see for yourself?"

"Umm… maybe later. One transformation is enough for now." I glanced down at the mask, then tucked it away beside my own. "I dunno... Every time I change back to this, it’s like... something inside me gets pulled a little looser-"

"Link, we really need to go," Tatl cut in, tugging on the edge of my cloak. "As much as I love watching you chitchat with Granny over here, we still need to defeat that monster before the moon crushes everything."

"Yeah, yeah… I’m coming." I turned toward Kotake. "Thanks again for saving us. And... sorry for Tatl’s manners. We’ll get out of your hair now."

"Yes yes, just go," Kotake muttered. "And keep that medallion—I don’t want to hear about another fool getting dragged off by Odalwa!"

She waved her bony fingers toward the door. I nodded with a shallow bow and turned to leave, the medallion thudding gently against my chest like a second heartbeat.

As soon as we were outside, Tatl zipped around my head in a puff of indignant light.

"Geez. Took you long enough! I can’t believe that witch actually put me in a bottle!"

I gave a faint smirk, tucking the bottle she’d escaped into my pouch.

"Well, now you know how fairies feel."

She huffed again, but I caught the glint of a reluctant grin beneath her scowl.

"Knowing your attitude I don't blame her. You owe her your life, you know?" I scolded as I lightly stepped down the ladder. "You really should be thankful!"

"Well maybe I would  be if she didn't imprison  me!" Tatl snapped. "Anyway, what do we do next? And where were you this whole time?"

As we descended, I recounted the events—how the monkeys found me, how Koume had been turned into a shrub, and the strange power of the Song of Healing. Tatl listened in brooding silence until I mentioned the Deku Palace.

"There's no time for that, didn't you see the moon? We've only got a few hours, and you want to save this dungheap within that short span? No way. Play your ocarina and let’s go back to the first day!"

"That wouldn't help. It took a whole day just to get here, remember?" I murmured, sliding down the final rungs of the ladder.

"It's better than nothing. I don't think we'll get much further at this rate."

"Okay, fine. I’ll think about it. If we don’t find something by nightfall, we’ll go back."

Tatl hovered close, wings twitching. "I'd rather not be here at night… with that  devil... but you're the boss, I guess."

The midday sun filtered through the spanning canopy of wide, pronged leaves and long tangles of vines. The humid, motionless air weighed heavy on my shoulders, every breath thick with the scent of earth and decay. Still, we pressed on.

The midday sun filtered through the spanning canopy of wide, pronged leaves and long tangles of vines. The humid, motionless air weighed down my steps, but we traveled on quickly despite it. There was silence all around us and the atmosphere was tense, the kind of thick, oppressive quiet that made the hairs on my arms stand on end and my instincts twitch like a drawn bowstring. It's as if the entire swamp was on edge, preparing for the end of all things, and we hurried on our way back to the boathouse.


Chapter Twenty One

Into the Corruption



We made our way through the humid wall within the tepid swamp. My muscles ached with fatigue, each step dragging with quiet resistance, and my breath came shallow and thin, tasting faintly of mildew and decay. A dull weight pressed behind my eyes—exhaustion mingling with a growing sense of urgency. Still, I pressed on, each step driven by the memory of what I had seen and what I had yet to face., both of us intent onA listening for any strange movement. The pools of water around us were still, and the dying foliage just as motionless. I carefully navigated around fallen logs, dead fauna, and pools of putrid liquid as we journeyed back to the boathouse.

"So what happened back there? Those witches seemed to... know you somehow?" Tatl chirped, breaking the sullen silence. "And where did you disappear off to, leaving me behind to deal with that ugly old hag? You know we hate being stuffed into bottles like that!"

"I went to find Koume, the one with the boats. And they were just… hmm… ghosts from my past and uh...future, I guess."

Well, they did say they would come back to haunt me… I silently mused.

"Ah… soooo you knew them back where you came from?"

"No, not really. But I did sort of... kill them during my last adventure. Somehow they remembered, or saw their deaths through visions, and I guess it scared them enough into changing their ways."

I had a brief flashback with a firestorm of magic, of ice and flame spiraling together like twin comets smashing into the mirror-finished shield I found in that temple. I could still feel the chill and heat on my skin, the sound of Koume's voice twisted with rage, mixed with Kotake’s laughter echoing even as they fell. It was...a powerful memory.

Tatl paused mid-flight, confusion apparent on her tiny features as she analyzed my expression.

"Uhh... yeah nevermind, I don't wanna know anymore." She fluttered ahead, her confusion shifting to apprehension. "Why is everything so quiet around here? Yesterday the animals wouldn't shut up!"

"It could be the moon, or Odalwa. This amulet Kotake gave me should protect us, though."

"Uh huh. You said 'I should hear it coming' and 'don't worry'." Tatl whined, mimicking my voice in a high-pitched mockery. "Pfft, you should have just listened to me in the first place!"

"Shhhhh ok ok...enough, Tatl! Bickering will only attract unwanted attention." I scolded the snarky fairy. "Let's just focus on getting back to the boathouse."

"...fine… In any case, I hope that thing works. By the way, what's the story on that new mask on your belt?"

"Oh right, that. Skull Kid apparently turned Koume into some kind of plant, and I removed the curse by playing that song the mask salesman taught me. Then Koume was cured, and it just...appeared… just like my mask when I played the song for me." I produced the Deku mask and studied its features.

"Why don't you try it on and see if it does anything?" Tatl pressed, tapping the tough wood with a tiny finger. "I'm sure you'll be fine."

"No no, I'd rather not. I've had nothing but bad luck with these stupid masks, and I think it'd be in my best interest to leave this thing alone."

Something huge suddenly rustled the branches above, and rotted leaves drifted down from the canopy. Tatl and I froze. I slowly reached down to my mask. I was not going to be taken down so easily this time. Grabbing the mask, I pushed it to my face while leaping aside as the transformation took hold.

Tatl zipped to my side as I rose to my feet, sword and shield drawn. When nothing else happened, I scanned the tree limbs above.

"Do you think it was just a large bird?" I muttered.

"That didn’t sound like any bird I’ve ever seen… or heard. What if it’s another huge monster?" Tatl whispered anxiously.

"Then I’ll take care of it. But it’s most likely one of those monkeys playing a joke. Still... let’s stay on guard."

We cautiously pressed forward along the obscure trail, and my boots splashed through puddles of algae-ridden mush as I kept one eye on the thick canopy. My hand never left the hilt of my blade.

Tatl and I eventually reached our goal an hour or two later without further incident. Our tense pace had lengthened the journey, but the fairy’s sigh of relief at the lagoon’s edge was palpable.

"I thought we were never going to make it back alive! But… you know... only for a second."

I smirked at her bravado as I stepped onto the floating dock leading to the boathouse. My limbs felt heavy, my steps dragging with growing fatigue. Tatl noticed and held out a tiny hand to stop me.

"Okay okay, you’re not invincible. You should probably take off that mask now. No need for it anymore, right?"

I frowned, reluctant to part with the feeling of confident power—but nodded. I reached up and removed the mask. The shift hit like a crashing wave; heat surged through my veins, my limbs buckled as bone and sinew shrank. My hips flared sharply, my chest tightened, and a breath caught in my throat as it pitched higher. The weight of sword and shield vanished, and the eerie lightness that followed left me reeling. The wooden planks beneath my boots rocked with the sudden change, and I stumbled, catching myself on one knee as my long hair brushed against my cheek.

I exhaled shakily, heart pounding. No matter how many times it happened, the transformation never got easier. It wasn’t just the body that shifted—it was the reminder, the loss of what once felt like myself.

"Okay—cough cough—I'm alright... phew. Okay, let’s finally go get that boat."

Tatl gave a soft nod, a flicker of pity in her glow. We started along the boardwalk. As we neared the door, it suddenly burst open—Frank charged out, arms wide.

I leapt back, heart hammering.

"Krikey! Yew brought back m’ captain AND managed to survive!" the man boomed in delighted shock. "I truly underestimated the two o’ ya."

"Uhhm yeah well…" I stammered, still startled. "We do what we can, right, Tatl?"

Tatl, who had darted into my cloak at Frank’s explosive entrance, didn’t respond.

"Strewth… honestly, I was frettin’ I’d sent ya off to yer deaths on a bloody fool’s errand. Ye’ve no idea how glad I am to see ya right as rain!" Frank beamed, waving us inside. "Come on now, I still owe ya both a nice steamin’ cuppa. Koume’s waitin’ inside too."

I followed him into the warm, oddly-decorated boathouse. Koume sat behind the counter, flipping through a worn book. Tatl cautiously emerged as Frank shut the door, then stomped over to the hearth to make tea.

"Ahh, so I see you made it back." Koume looked up casually. "I assume that means you want that boat ride, eh, little Hero?"

"Hey hey now, Koume! I owe these two some tea fer bringin ya back—don’t be rushin’ off just yet." Frank interrupted, holding up a hand.

I glanced at Tatl, who shrugged. Honestly, tea sounded great. My stomach growled loudly—I hadn’t eaten in days—and Frank chuckled knowingly at the sound.

"My my, now I know where all those earth shakes are coming from. Don’t you fret that rumbly tum of yours any longer, lil miss. I whipped up some fresh swamp cakes and gator bites to go with that tea—oughta patch you right up!"

The big man began pouring scalding water into prepared cups from a teapot that appeared comically tiny in his enormous hands.

"Um… gator bites ? I've never really heard of those." I questioned the strange host.

"Oh yeh, they're right scrumptious! Trust me, you'll gobble 'em right up."

Tatl spoke up finally, exasperated and impatient. "Link, we really gotta get going! The moon is only hours away from falling and we haven't even made it to the Deku Palace yet!"

"Eh? So the moon really is falling?" Koume exclaimed, disregarding her book. "I just thought my eyes were going bad!"

"Yeah, it's the Skull Kid's doing… and I'm the only one who can stop him. Only then will everything be back to normal, and I can get rid of this curse."

"Oh right, yes. I keep forgetting. Did you try the little musical cure that you did for me?" Koume asked and leaned over the counter top.

"Pfft, that only made things worse..." Tatl muttered before I could answer.

"Curses? Falling moons? What black rock have I been living under?" Frank bellowed as he set the cups of steaming liquid before Tatl and I. "You told me you were celebrating a birthday at your sister's, Koume."

"Now don't you go worrying about it, you lumbering beast. Young Link here will take care of everything, no doubt." The elderly witch confided.

"Let's hope anyway…" Tatl muttered, and flitted down to sip her tea.

"Heh! Whatdya know, a bona fide hero. Good on ya mate!" Frank jokingly thumped my shoulder, causing me to sputter and cough on the bitter tea. "Oh oh, sorry 'bout that lil miss...uhh here be those cakes and bites I promised ya."

After he set the two dishes full of thin white crackers and questionable patties of… something, I shoved a fistful of the first into my mouth and grunted in delight at the sweet delicate flavor compared to the strong and bitter tea. Tatl shook her head at my antics, but I was far too hungry to care.

"Ha! This sheila's sure got an appetite. How come you don't eat my food like she does, Koume?"

"Phah, if I ate your food in any fashion my heart would give out, you lummox!"

I gulped down some more tea as the two exchanged various insults, still unsure about braving the contents of the other dish. Tatl tried to politely sip from the cup twice her size, but managed a quiet slurp at best. I offered a piece of cracker to her, and she shrugged then took a mouthful of the tasty morsel.

As we finished the small, yet filling meal, I stood up to interject between the playful arguing of the two managers.

"That was nice and satisfying Frank." I nodded to the man who plodded over to take my empty cup.

"Pleased as peaches to hear ya say that. I can give you another fill up if ya like?"

"Oh no, I'm fine now. We really do have to get a move on, the daylight won't last too much longer." I patted my stomach, surprised at how full I was with such a small meal. "But that was a really good lunch in any case, and thank you for your gracious hosting."

"Think nothin' of it, just the basic Southie Swamp hospitality. Though I see ya didn't care much for the gator bites heh heh!"

"Well, I don't really know what a 'gator' is to begin with…" I replied bluntly.

"A gator? It's basically a giant water lizard." Tatl answered between mouthfuls of the cracker she kept.

"And it would just as soon as eat you as you did those cakes, heh heh. They're primarily up near the Deku Palace and those little shrubbies hunt them for sport. Since they can't eat the remains they ship the meat down to me. I sell it to passerby and adventurers, and I hear it's become a sort o' delicacy in Clock Town." Frank explained.

He wrapped up some of the uneaten gator biscuits in a handkerchief and handed the small parcel to me.

"Why don't you go on and keep this, maybe it'll keep you from starving out there or you can sell it off to one of the northies."

I hesitated for a second, but took the packet and stuffed it into my pouch. I thanked the kindly tour guide again and turned to the witch behind the counter.

"OK, I guess we're ready for that boat ride now."

"Hmph… and I was just getting to a good part..." Koume muttered and dropped her reading material. "Come along then, the boat's right out back."

I waved to Tatl for her to follow and she sighed, dropping the remains of her meal. We said our goodbyes to the kindly boathouse manager and went after the old hag, who was hobbling out the front door.

"Toodle-oo you two! G'luck on yer adventurin'" Frank bellowed out as we exited the home and walked around back.

Koume's boat was quite a sight. Vibrant colors of red, green, blue, and yellow were painted along the sides in wide stripes and ridges. On the bow of the boat was fixed a very sharp-looking polearm that stuck out over the water. There was a small cabin up top and a strange contraption connected to the aft of the ship. We trotted up the laid out gangway that led to the deck, and Koume's gangly hands untied the rope keeping the boat near the dock.

"So, little hero…" Koume turned her bulging gaze to me. "I'm assuming you want to head straight to the Deku Palace. I feel I must warn you, outsiders are strictly forbidden."

"That's where the monkeys told me to go, I don't have much of a choice if I'm to find Odalwa's lair." I shrugged at the witch.

"Why on green earth would you want to find that thing's lair? It would chew you up and spit you out in tiny pieces before you even got close!" Koume gawked, poking at me with a bony finger. "I know you're supposedly a hero, but….oh nevermind. I'm sure you have a way. It's not my job to question your abilities."

"Can we get a move on? It's late and the sun is almost setting! Stop gabbing and start sailing!" Tatl remarked in exasperation.

"Quite the firefly, that one. Very well, you stand out here on the deck. Watch for monsters, I don't want any scratching up this lovely paint job, you hear?" Koume sighed and headed to the helm inside the cabin.

I rolled my eyes at Tatl and drew my bow, ready for any threats. Swirls of light mist hung over the water and danced around the boat as it surged through the water. There was no other sound except for the strange contraption at the aft which quietly hummed, I assumed that it must have been the engine. Vines hung low from the branches high above, and gently parted as the bow of the boat moved down the river.

"Why is it still so quiet, Link?" The fairy whispered into my pointed ears. "Surely *something *is alive out there?"

"I'm betting the animals fled further south. They must have sensed the danger of the moon and Odalwa." I murmered, hoping that was the case. "Odalwa couldn't have killed everything…"

The boat was quickly picking up speed, and we were cruising at a very good pace in no time. Koume kept a watchful eye on the waters, and Tatl relaxed a bit. I listened intently with my heightened senses, ready with my weapon drawn. Canyon walls rose around us, creating a claustrophobic effect but also a relative safety from attack from the shore.

A deep gloom set in as we sailed further along the poison river, the air turning thick with a cloying, metallic scent that clung to the throat. Occasional bubbles broke the water's opaque surface with wet plopping sounds, and somewhere in the distance, a low, gurgling croak echoed from the trees, quickly swallowed by the silence. The oppressive atmosphere seemed to press in around us, making the boat feel smaller, more vulnerable with each passing second. Tiny, glowing red eyes peeped from a few bushes lining the bank, gazing at us in curiosity.

"We're getting near the palace, those are the deku." Koume called out from the helm, pointing at the bushes.

Red and orange colored leaves and trees dominated the scenery, and the stench was almost too much for my nose to take. The river had become completely corrupted by the poison created by Odalwa. Thick, purple sludge clung to the sides of the boat, and dissolving remains of dead creatures and plants floated in the putrid muck.

Ahead a short distance away rose an immense wall of rock, with elaborate decorations and huge paintings covering the stone. A cavernous entrance lay at the bottom, with torches cutting through the gloom of the darkening swamp. The river suddenly veered away, and Koume stopped the engine and drifted toward the edge of the bank.

"This is as far as I can take you, I'm afraid. Any closer and the deku guards would sink the boat."

"I guess this will have to do then, which is much better than I thought." I nodded to Koume. "Thank you, without your boat there would have been no way to get this far."

"And without you I'd still be a plant, fair trade. So go on now, get a move on. I'd rather not push these obstinate deku shrubs into attacking." Koume waved us off her boat.

As soon as we were on land the witch started up the engine and sailed away. The dank, smelly air and torpid darkness that surrounded us almost made me regret coming here. But I gathered my courage and moved toward the torchlight of the entrance ahead.

"Hoo hoot! Over here!"

I stopped in my tracks and Tatl drifted close to me. I looked around, trying to see ahead in the miresome gloom.

"No no, over *here *you daft child!" The voice called again.

I followed the source of all the noise through some shrubbery and into a wide clearing. Sitting in the center was a large statue of an owl with musical notes on the breast. An even bigger, strangely familiar owl was resting right beside it, staring at me with huge, wide eyes.

"Don't be alarmed, strange child." The giant bird spoke. "I've been watching you and your efforts ever since your arrival."

"You… you've been watching me? Why?" I asked with a bit of uncertainty.

"You stirred the winds of fate when you aided that witch, and removed the curse. Then when you transformed into that warrior, I knew that the guardians had sent you to save this world. And I have been called to help you." The owl recounted, gently bobbing its head. "This statue in my likeness represents an old way of travel. If you have an instrument, playing these special notes will call upon the power of my ancestors. The power will lift and transport you to this owl and others like it that you will find in the realm."

"Huh… well that's handy!" Tatl twinkled, her voice laced with sarcasm. "And oddly convenient…"

"Yes," the owl intoned, its golden eyes gleaming with solemn depth. "But night falls, and I must fly far to the south to hunt beneath the stars. I leave you with this: keep your courage, young one, and you shall surely succeed."

The owl spread its vast wings, casting long shadows over the clearing. The guardian's flight was both majestic and lonely, leaving behind a silence that hummed with meaning. A rush of wind thundered outward as it lifted from the earth, feathers glinting like burnished bronze. I shielded my face, the air thick with the scent of damp feathers and stirred loam, heart pounding as the wings vanished into the darkened sky.

"Well.... I guess that answers my questions. I was wondering what all those owl statutes were for…" Tatl mused. "So… will you play your thingy so we can finally get out of this dump now? Let's go back in time again!"

"Yeah, I think that's a good idea. Just let me memorize these notes…"

I studied the etchings along the statute. This was at least something I was very familiar with. Once I was confident they were committed to memory, I took out the Ocarina and nodded to Tatl, who moved closer to me. Raising the blue instrument to my lips, I closed my eyes and began playing the Song of Time and focused on going back to that first day.

The ocarina shone brightly as our surroundings faded into a pure white light, and we were quickly swept up in the currents of Time...

Chapter Twenty-Two

Realm of Shadows



The crazed man stepped through the spherical portal into a world of swirling blackness. A fierce wind, harsher than the wind from the last world, gushed forth in waves, almost as if in an attempt to blow the encroaching trespasser into oblivion. The sky above flickered with bleeding shadows, and the earth beneath him hissed at every step. Whispers tangled in the wind—remnants of the dead—pleading, cursing, warning.

Yet still, the man walked unhindered toward a large dark building, the tempest merely whisking his clothing. His warded presence stained the ground, leaving faint smudges of seething magic in his wake. The intensive darkness moved closer as if it were a living thing, trying to suffocate him. It recoiled from him, and still, he walked forward.

Black tendrils of lightning burst forth from the shadowy ground, wrapping around the man like thorns. With a wave of his hand, he cast away the dark energy, and laughed as the lightning exploded into bursts of crimson flame. And still, he walked forward.

A giant, locked door loomed before him, a final obstacle. He came so far, this blockage would be little more than a slight inconvenience. He raised his hand, concentrating pure blue energy within his palm—and the door shattered into nothingness.

The temple lit up with a faint, blue light when the man entered. Lingering purple mists softly drifted away with the outside air billowing in, revealing a large singular figure standing motionless in the center of the room. The man stopped in his tracks, recognizing it instantly: a Domigard. An ancient terror crafted solely to destroy intruders and protect sacred sites. Its armor bore sigils of a forgotten tongue.

If the door’s destruction didn’t wake it, the man hoped it was defunct. But the air felt tight around him—as if the guardian, though inert, was aware.

He stepped forward, carefully. Each step brought him closer to the machine, each one a test. The crystalline light of the room painted a deceptive calm, but to lower his guard now would be foolish.

He passed it. The Domigard did not stir.

Before him stood a shallow staircase, leading to a pedestal veiled in solid, pitch-black shadow. He could see nothing upon it—only feel it calling to him, tugging something deep within his chest.

There it was. Right before his eyes. His beloved mask.

He relaxed, momentarily distracted by awe. The pedestal hummed with presence. As he exhaled in relief, a gasp of breath echoed through the chamber.

The runes beneath his feet ignited.

The Domigard’s core awakened with a rising hum. Red light filled its eyes. The man dove as a blast of energy shattered the floor where he’d just stood.

He turned, his face grim. The Domigard was enormous—two meters taller than him. A boltspear in one hand. A gyroshield in the other. Its death glare burned into his bones.

It roared a metallic, jarring battlecry.

The man’s laugh echoed back, sharp and feral. He trembled with malice, and fire erupted from his hands. The guardian burned, but not silently—it retaliated with a white-hot bolt that scorched the wall behind him, splashing molten rock across his back.

He screamed. Leapt. Blocked the spear with a conjured sword. Knocked it aside. Was knocked in turn by the shield.

Rolling, dodging, ducking beneath the next swing, he moved with practiced desperation. His sword slashed against the armor—sparks flew but left no mark.

He remembered a weakness. He drove the blade into a joint. The guardian howled and dropped its shield.

He reached to lance his blade into the domiguard's vulnerability....but was too late. The boltspear pierced his leg.

The man fell, crying out in rage and agony. The Domigard laughed, a chilling, mechanical tittering. Its second strike came—he rolled, narrowly avoiding death. But the spear found his other leg, nailing him to the stone.

Pain washed over him like drowning.

His breath stilled.

He stared upward, barely able to think while his blood spread along the ground like ink. The Domigard circled confidently, knowing that it had won. It raised its foot and crushed his pinned leg, the bones shattering like glass.

Still, the man did not cry out again. He stared into the machine’s glaring eyes, defiant.

His gaze drifted to the pedestal… so close. And then… something stirred within him.

A whispering voice: We were never apart....

The familiar whispers revived a small part of his memory....and he roared. He would not be defeated here, not now. Power suddenly surged through him. A shockwave of shadow exploded outward, slamming the Domigard into the wall with enough force to break open its chestplate.

The man sat up. Bloodied. Furious....but alive.

He tore the spear from his shattered leg, dark blood gushing out. And smiling, he hurled it with perfect aim into the exposed chink.

The Domigard reeled, grasping at its chest in desperation and surprise.

A second later...it exploded into a burst of white-blue lightning.

Shards of molten metal rained around him. He shielded himself with one shaking arm. Then, silence. He looked again at the voided pedestal.

He would not die empty-handed.

Inch by inch, he dragged himself across the floor. His hands left trails of red. His lungs rasped. But he climbed the stairs. Up to the blackness.

His fingers reached through the darkness....and then he felt it....fingertips trailing along the cold, hard surface.

Memories surged—visions of fire, screaming faces, a world torn asunder by the mask’s power. His own clan, eyes filled with sorrow, killing him to save their people, sealing away the mask forever in this realm of shadows.

The mask pulsed a dark wave of energy against his touch, eager...yearning....

His hand closed around it: the heart-shape, the spikes, the eyes. So familiar....

He pulled it free and fell to the ground, splaying out, hugging the mask to his body and cradling it in his arms, as the last of his strength bled out of him. With a gasping whisper, he rasped out....

"I. Am. Whole."

The darkness in the mask began to radiate out, surrounding the man's body in shadowy tendrils...and the man heard a final, familiar whisper from the depths of his mind: And now, we begin again.

Chapter Twenty-Three

Palace of Fury



The world faded back into view as Tatl and I exited the timestream, back to the first day. A strange heaviness clung to my chest, the air colder than I remembered, as if time itself had stripped me of something.... But I lost the thought as quickly as it came as my soft boots landed gently upon the hard pavement of the tower plaza. I lowered the dimming ocarina as Tatl regained her bearings.

"I don't think I'll ever get used to that…" Tatl huffed and swayed midair. "How you manage to stay calm through it all is beyond me!"

"Trust me, you'll get used to it." I replied, checking around to see if anything had changed in the Tower Plaza.

"No, I really don't think I will. I just hope that song you just learned isn't as bad…. speaking of which, do you want to try it?"

"Hmm...I don't see why not…"

My gaze drifted to the construction crew hard at work in the center. Something about them caught my eye—an odd shift in their motion, or maybe the rhythm of their work. I couldn't place it, but it felt... off. Like returning to a scene I’d seen before, only now tinted slightly different. Tatl flitted into my line of sight, waving her luminous hands to get my attention.

"Hellooo what are you staring at? Let's get going!"

"Umm… right. Sorry...I don't know what came over me..."

I sheepishly looked away and raised the ocarina once more. Remembering the notes written on the stone owl, I performed the tune and waited for something to happen.

"Was… Was that it?" Tatl asked, shifting her head around. "I thought we were supposed to fl- WHOAAAA!"

She was cut off as we suddenly launched into the air, carried upward by a pair of large phantom wings. White feathers surrounded and engulfed us, and we both yelped in surprise. Our world rocked and kicked, but it was over in mere seconds.

We landed gently back in the swamp clearing beside the owl statue. As the phantom wings and feathers dissolved into nothing, I stumbled to the ground, the world spinning violently around me. Grass itched against my cheek while a rush of dizziness surged up from my stomach, hot and overwhelming. I pressed a hand to the earth, grounding myself as the echoes of flight slowly faded from my limbs and balance.

"Good gods...I was not expecting that at all!" I cursed, clasping my fingers to my head. "Are you ok Tatl?"

"Urgh… y-yeah?" The fairy moaned, falling to the ground beside me. "No...no, gurgh... not... really."

I slowly got to my feet, but the blood rushing to my head caused me to stumble and I latched onto the statue to keep myself upright.

"Whew… at least we made it back quickly in one piece. And the area doesn't smell as bad right now, so that's nice, right?" I tried to keep positive, looking around the clearing. "And there doesn't seem to be as much decay."

"Ughh… Maybe Odalwa hasn't made it here yet. Can...can you help me up?"

I floundered over to the fallen fairy and scooped her into my fingerless gloves. She mumbled her thanks, and after my vision stopped spinning I took a deep breath and walked toward the river.

"You, hooman! Hoalt!" A squeaky voice challenged in imperfect Hylian nearby.

I stopped, trying to spot where it came from.

"State yoor business for trespasseeng on Deku Territory!"

A dozen deku suddenly popped out of the trees with a cacophony of rustling leaves and creaking armor, their sharp wooden lances gleaming beneath the canopy light. The sound of their leafy plating scraping and crackling as they moved made my heart skip a beat, each step they took adding to the tension pressing against my ribs. More than a few of them looked sickly and about ready to fall over.

"Uhm, I'm here to defeat the monster. Have you seen it around?" I cautiously answered, and raised my hands to show I was unarmed.

"Moonster? There ees no moonster in the mighty Deku Territory. Ees poor excoose." One of the guards replied. "However, you doo noot seem very threatening, so you're weelcome to gaze in awe at our kingdom. But no going near palace! Understood?"

"Yes, understood. Thank you." I curtly stated.

The deku guard nodded, let out a curt, squeaky affirmation, and with a flurry of rustling leaves, the squad disappeared into the trees above. I exhaled slowly, tension still coiled in my shoulders, aware of how close that encounter had come to turning violent. Their pride was palpable—and dangerous. I groaned inwardly at seeing the extreme arrogance of these deku, and I started walking toward the toxic river bank. Unfortunately, the palace was where we needed to go, so I had to find some way inside those walls.

Tatl promptly flew out of my hands upon reaching the water, her balance had apparently recovered.

"What a bunch of morons… I never liked deku shrubs." The pixie grumbled. "Now...How do we get into to that palace?"

"Well, we could sneak in by scaling those cliffs…but they look too steep without a really long rope... " I pursed my lips in thought. "Or I could try out this deku mask to see if it does anything useful. I don't really like either option… But I can't think of anything else."

"Yeah, I guess you don't really have a choice. I doubt you'd be able to climb such a steep cliff, so I say try the mask."

I paused, unwilling to go through any more transformations, but I eventually took hold of the plant-like mask, took a deep breath, and put the cool wood against my face.

I was mildly relieved when nothing seemed to happen, and I released a small puff of air through my mouth. The mask's surface felt rough and grainy beneath my fingers, a little warmer than I expected—as if it held the sunlight I’d just felt on my skin. A faint tingling pricked across my cheeks, and I swore I caught the scent of crushed leaves and damp earth rising from the wood. Although I did begin to feel a bit more invigorated, and the warm rays of morning sunlight that managed to somewhat pierce the gloom seemed to absorb into my body. A few moments later I heard Tatl chime in.

"Well, it was worth a shot. Too bad though, you turning into a deku would have made this so  much easier!" Tatl remarked, observing my lack of any apparent change. "We should start looking for another way, don't you think? Hey, aren't you listening? Link!"

I blinked back to awareness, the echo of the mask's presence still humming faintly in my fingertips, and lowered it just as the impatient fairy yanked hard on my ponytail.

"Ow!" I winced. "Why do you always do that?"

She hovered with arms crossed, eyes narrowed. "Because you were off in la-la land again. You know I hate being ignored. And you looked like you were in a trance or something... Maybe you should leave that thing here."

"I wasn't in a trance," I protested, trying to shake the lingering warmth that still pulsed in my skin. "I was just… feeling the sun. It was like it got pulled into me, like I’m a plant or something. I feel great."

Her glare softened a little. "You do? Weird. You look  more refreshed. Maybe that mask has healing magic or something. Not that you were damaged much."

I glanced at the deku mask again, unease still prickling beneath my skin. Whatever it had done, it had changed something.

"I have no idea… but...it seems all these masks just have a mind of their own. Still, healing would definitely be a nicer touch than a painful transformation." I shrugged, then secured the mask to my belt. "If it does provide healing...then it will definitely come in handy! Maybe it'll be better than drinking a health potion."

"Alright, great...but healing powers won't get us inside the palace, I hope you have another plan…" Tatl pressed, hovering above my shoulder

"Ok ok I'm thinking, look around and see if you can find any possible entrances or secrets. There could be deku in every tree, so try to be... subtle."

I started walking along the bank of the river, trying to look innocuous while Tatl searched around the wall. My shoulders tensed beneath my cloak, aware of the prickling sensation that crept down my spine—as if something unseen was watching us from the trees.. The brightly colored orange and red foliage of the area was a little harsh on the eyes. The smell of death, while not as horrible as before, was still pretty intense. To distract myself before I got a headache, I kicked a tiny pebble into the purple opaque water and ripples expanded across the surface.

"Anything yet, Tatl?" I muttered.

"Nothing yet, there might be something a bit further from the entrance."

I casually walked further down the shoreline, keeping myself between the wall and river. The slow moving water flowed around islands in the middle, where wilting trees and flowers seemed to beg for deliverance. Swarms of bugs darted every which way between the gloomy mist and vines over the river. I swatted away a swarm that came too close, hoping that my small companion would spot something soon.

"Uhhh, are you ok Link?" Tatl inquired. "You're walking a little funny there."

"Hmm?" I turned to the tiny pixie. "No I'm not, I'm just walking."

"You're just… I dunno, swaying your hips and kind of… sashaying around. Like, more than usual. It’s weird—I mean, are you even noticing it? You weren’t doing that yesterday, and now it’s like you’re walking differently, like someone might if they were trying to show off or… I don’t know. It’s not bad, it’s just… not you . Are you feeling okay?" She gave me an odd look. "Did that deku mask fry your brain or something?"

"Pfft, no! I feel fine, Tatl. Stop watching me and watch the wall instead…" I snapped, though a ripple of unease crept through my chest. I hadn’t even noticed the way I was moving. As I turned from her, I tried to focus each step, willing my hips to stay steady. Was it the mask? The time magic? Or something deeper changing in me—something I couldn’t control? I shook the thought away, jaw clenched tight. Not now. I had to stay focused.

"Right...oooook then, whatever you say." Tatl mumbled and glided to my side.

I heard an amused huff escape her cantankerous form, but chose to disregard it and returned my attention back to the river.

There were very little signs of living fauna near the water, although birds and insects were chirping all around us. I saw a few small deku scrubs shuffling around across the river, and maybe a monkey or two in the trees. One thing that did catch my interest was a cave covered in spiderwebs near the deku on the opposite bank. An unlit torch sat beside it, and it looked as if it hadn't been lit or touched for years. I would just have to check it out in the future though, as Tatl had apparently located a possible entrance.

"Hey wait, I think I see something just up ahead." Tatl quietly spoke into my ear. "It's kinda covered by bushes, but if you walk a bit further you'll see it."

Sure enough, there was a small opening hiding behind a bright orange bush. I looked around to see if any beady red eyes were watching us. Unfortunately there were a few peeping out from behind a rock nearby, seemingly ready to spring out and attack should we make a wrong move. Seeing how we were outnumbered ten to one here, I deemed it unwise to do anything violent.

"What's the holdup? Get in there, Link." Tatl urged.

"There's a bunch of deku watching us, I can't just stroll on in right now. We should look for something better…"

A clamor of squeaking and clicking resounded from the other side of the river before we could start looking again. I peered over the purple mire to see a monkey start swinging towards the gate across on the overhanging vines. The deku tried to shoot it down, spitting rocks from their knotted mouths as the furry creature headed straight for the gate. I noticed that all eyes were focused on the monkey, and I decided to take the opportunity to move.

I pushed aside the spiny leaves of the bush and squeezed through the small opening, ducking down to avoid cracking my skull. The small tunnel was very narrow, and I could just barely crawl through it. Thankfully, the wall was not very thick and I reached the other side quickly, pausing before I crawled out.

"Can you go check to see if anything is watching this way?" I whispered to Tatl. "You're small enough to go unnoticed."

"Yeah, let me look real quick."

The fairy flew out and up, and was back in moments.

"Ok I think we're clear if we hurry. I think all the focus is on that monkey intruder." Tatl stated.

I nodded and peeked out of the opening, which sat on a ledge hanging over a large moat of poisoned swamp water. The moat flowed around a huge tree with high wooden walls of bamboo surrounding it. Large paintings, much like those on the outer wall, covered the wood with warrior deku figures and colorful plants. Huge branches extending from the tree palace, hanging high overhead. Large lanterns filled with what looked like fireflies swung from vines and ropes looped around the branches, providing an eerie green glow to the entire area. A bridge of gathered tree trunks led from the outer gate, across the toxic moat, up to a very well guarded inner gate.

"Ok, so there's still no way I'm swimming through that water. That gate would be impossible to pass directly anyway… now what?"

I sat back in the hole to keep a low profile as we figured out our next move.

"What if we climbed those vines to the top of the wall? Those branches up there look close enough to grab onto and walk across?"

"Oh, I hadn't thought about that. Good thinking!" I grinned, and peeked around the corner once more.

The deku guards were still focused on the outside, and I could hear more cacophonous squeaking and monkey calls. It had apparently turned into a full on brawl between plant and beast, which served our purposes just fine for the moment. I nodded to Tatl, took hold of one of the thick lengths of vine, and began to shimmy up the wall.

The climb was hardly difficult, and I was sure had I set a new record for myself at how fast I went. A few minutes later and I was at the top ledge, with Tatl rising up behind me.

"Ok, do you think you can make that leap to the branch?" A pale, tiny finger gestured to the branch a few feet away. "Or should we find another way? I don't want you falling to your death after we've come so far."

"No, I'm pretty sure I can make it. This is our only shot anyway, so why not take it?"

I judged the distance, focusing all my energy on the jump, and sprung off the stone wall. I caught the branch midair, the rough bark dug into my hands and I winced as I pulled myself up.

I brushed dust and particles of bark off my marginally cut fingers, while Tatl praised my prowess.

"Haha, you get better at jumping every day! Are you sure you're not becoming a grasshopper?"

"You know, at this point nothing would surprise me. But I hope not, I'd rather not become a bug." I chuckled at the thought. "The monkeys from before said that their prince was being held here, but where? This place isn't as small as I'd hoped."

"I wonder if they have any dungeons, oh wait…. probably not. I've never heard of deku taking prisoners. And yet, it's odd that they kept this monkey prince alive…"

"Hmm. If that's the case he must be important to them." An idea suddenly popped into my head. "The throne room!"

I dashed along the tree limb with superb balance, looking down at the palace grounds far below. Deku shrubs of all colors and sizes shuffled to and fro, and the guards were celebrating a victorious defense.

"Oh oh, look! There's the monkey prisoner, see?" Tatl twinkled for my attention. "He's being carried into the palace!"

Sure enough a squirming, pure white monkey wearing a crown of twisted leaves that had been gagged, hogtied and was being hoisted by a group of angry-looking shrubs. They disappeared into the tree, and musical pipes emanated faintly from within. A promenade of deku followed after the monkey, and the grounds were soon empty save a few guard patrols.

"Wow, that's lucky… Now's our chance to find a way in, Link!" Tatl said, flying down the giant trunk.

"Umm great! But how do I get down?" I hissed after her. "I don't see any windows up here!"

I guess I'll have to find my own way down… Great . I grumbled inwardly to myself.

I walked further along the branch and leaned against the rock-hard tree trunk. The trunk was smooth, like polished steel, no footholds to clamber down to. I was also standing on the lowest branch, so jumping down was out of the question since I was still several meters high.

I was so distracted in looking for a way down that I didn't notice Tatl had returned carrying vines. I nearly fell off the branch when the precocious sprite dropped them on me.

"Oof!" I exclaimed, rubbing my head. "You know, you could have said something before throwing these at me!"

"What? They were heavy." Tatl shrugged. "But there's your way down."

"Ugh… thanks. Can you help me tie these off?" I found and held up the ends, gesturing for her to loop them around the branch.

"Oh fine. I guess I have to do everything now…"

She took the vines and circled the branch, mock complaining under her breath as she gave me the ends to knot. I shook my head and did my best to create a solid anchor point, before leaning over the edge.

"Ok, here we go…"

Tugging on the vine and relieved the knot was secure and tight, I rappelled down the rough vine as quietly as possible. The deku were still distracted, so lowering myself behind the wooden walls was fairly easy.

Tatl rushed under my cloak after I hit the soft ground, hiding her shining body to be less conspicuous. I quietly crept along, heading towards the large corridor into the tree ahead. Seeing that the way was clear, I rushed inside.

The interior of the tree seemed to be devoid of any deku, and more of those firefly lanterns hung below the ceiling in chandeliers made of antlers. Loose, finely tilled soil made up the floor, soft and slightly damp beneath my boots, filling my nostrils with the smell of blooming earth and mud, which admittedly was a nice change from the stench outside. There were hallways and rooms all throughout the interior, each gently curving off from the main path. I hoped that the throne room was at the end of this hall, where the pipe music seemed to originate. My hopes were confirmed when I approached the rounded corner at the end of the corridor, hearing what sounded like a hundred voices cry out.

A booming deep voice rang out above the others, silencing the crowd and pipes as I sidled up to the corner.

"We shall punish this foolish monkey scum for his egregious crimes! He shall be made an example, to all the filth who would defy the might of the Deku Kingdom! We are the lords of this earth. NO ONE ELSE!"

Angry, dissonant chords from the pipes followed, and deafening cheers roared out that shook the walls. These Deku were completely  unhinged. My heart pounded in my chest, and I caught the gleam of frenzied eyes flashing in the torchlight.
