I backed away slowly, stepping carefully, as it was apparent that the monsters couldn't see me and I wanted to keep it that way.

"Tatl," I quietly summoned the fairy. "Do you know what these things are?"

"What?" The fairy peeked out from behind the cloak. "I've never seen anything like that…. what do we do?"

"I say we sneak around them, they can't see us…"

Not realizing that Tatl had given us away with her luminescent body, I jumped when the creatures squeaked loudly in alarm and began to move toward us like a blanket of pure shadow.

"Aaaand now  they see us." I reached for my bow and worked it out from under the cloak. "Let's see if they like fire!"

Tatl flew out from cover as I drew back the string, "Fire? What do you-"

She didn't have a chance to finish when the ring flashed with the first launched arrow, catching the magic bolt ablaze. Bright flashes of piercing flames incinerated groups of the dark balls as I shot arrow after arrow. The new ring I'd found was growing hotter and hotter after each fiery blast. Finally, after shooting off one last bolt, the burning projectile took out whatever few creatures remained and the room was empty save for us.

"I think that's the last of th-...Agghhh!"

I shrieked at the searing heat on my finger and frantically flung the white-hot ring to the ground, letting the bow clatter to the stone floor.

"What happened?" Tatl twinkled and flew out. " Did you get bit or something?"

I slipped my glove off and caressed my blistering finger, shaking heavy the hood from my face.

"No! The damn ring practically caught fire and burned me! It just caught me off guard..." I grumbled and stuck the throbbing finger into my mouth.

"You weren't the only one caught off guard! How'd you do that?" The fairy inquired as she focused her attention on the dimming ring. "I didn't know you could use fire."

"The ring is imbued with fire magic. I guess it affects magic weapons too."

"Odd… it's crazy how you find all these things. I never found anything like that before I met you, and we sure coulda used your luck...oh...I didn't mean-."

"Eh…" I shrugged and pulled on the glove and hood before placing the warm ring on a different finger. "It's a curse…"

Just then, a slow, steady shuffling grew louder as a massive shape began to materialize within the gloom of the temple. The stench of a thousand corpses filled my nostrils, thick and cloying, like rotting meat left in stagnant water under a summer sun. It triggered a sharp gag reflex and pulled an old memory to the surface—a battlefield outside Castle Town, where the wind had carried a similar fetid reek. My stomach turned as the air thickened, suffocating and heavy, sticking to the inside of my throat like tar., made even worse by the tepid air, and I knew... Odalwa had come.

Tatl chimed in fear and rushed back into my cloak, and the cursed being noticed the movement. I frantically searched for cover as the hulking monster lunged toward the me, and I barely managed to dive behind a hanging root before the jagged blade created sparks where I stood not a second before, knocking my bow across the room. I silently cursed myself for not picking up the bow sooner, hidden behind the camouflaged hood, while Odalwa moaned in rage of losing its target. Loud gasps of air sucked into the wooden mask as it sniffed around, hunting us, and I tightly gripped the witch's medallion that hung around my neck, holding my breath as the monster passed us by.

I waited for the beast to get some distance before daring to move again, and silently skittered to another tree. My blue fairy bow was lying on the floor directly across from me, unfortunately Odalwa was right beside it. I crouched as low as I could, and slowly tried to get a bit closer while looking for more cover. There wasn't much. From what I could see now that my eyes were more adjusted to the darkness, the high ceiling was held up by six stone pillars covered in vines that I mistook before as tree roots. Unlit torches in sconces were situated around the eight walls, which made the room a large octagon with two exits. One exit was where we entered, the other had no telling of where it led to and was unfortunately being watched by Odalwa. If I could only get to my bow without being discovered, I could at least fight back. I felt my small partner stir around my arm and I very faintly shushed her, thankfully she got the message and remained silent.

Other than the noxious, heavy breathing of the monster, the temple was deathly still and silent. I painstakingly inched forward bit by bit, each movement bringing me closer to either my weapon or to my doom. I could feel beads of sweat forming on my forehead from the humid chamber, and I tried unsuccessfully to swipe them away. I rounded the edge of the pillar closest to the weapon, and Odalwa, so focused on my foot placement that I didn't see the dry tiny root hanging near my head. The twig snapped as I brushed by it, a sound like thunder in the quiet chamber, and Odalwa unleashed a horrifying bellow and rushed forth, thrusting its blade wildly about towards the noise.

Abandoning my stealthy approach, I sprinted as fast as I could to the fallen bow, buffeting Tatl around within my cloak while doing my best to dodge the mad assault. I reached out for the magic weapon, letting instinct take over as I flipped it up into my hands, rolled backwards and aimed directly for the undead giant's mask. The bright, flaming bolt of energy lit up the room like the sun, accompanied by a thunderous crack  that echoed through the chamber and sent a rush of heat and air rippling outward from the point of impact. catching the monster's attention as it trampled towards me in blind fury. The bolt sailed through the darkness and exploded upon contact with the hard wood of the mask. Thick, acrid smoke filled the room, clawing down my throat and scalding my lungs with each breath. The stench of scorched rot clung to the air, and the heat surged in chaotic waves, making my head spin. My boots scraped blindly over the stone floor as I stumbled away from the screeching monster, heart hammering, senses overwhelmed by the searing, smoke-choked darkness. Aside from the flaming giant, seeing anything within the smoke-filled darkness of the chamber was near impossible now, and I fumbled around on all fours, feeling around with my hands as I struggled to breath. I looked back to vaguely see Odalwa tearing away its burning mask. It was bashing its way into pillars and walls, making the temple grounds tremble. I managed to spot one of the torches lining the walls, I had to see where I was going so I caught another bolt on fire and let it fly, setting the torch ablaze. Although the smoke refracted most of the light, I could at least see my surroundings now. I was also far enough away from Odalwa that I could shoot it again with more precise aim. I readied the bow, once more aiming for the mask of the flailing monster, and took the shot. Odalwa must have seen the arrow zipping towards it and raised its shield. The arrow was effortlessly deflected and immediately extinguished. I fired off a few more bolts but they were useless against the raised shield, and the monster began to move forward.

"Now what!?" Tatl shouted fearfully, now apparently out of cover. "What do we do? Run away?"

I glanced toward the exit . Odalwa must have read my mind because it looked at the exit too, and leapt up in an astonishingly agile move.

"Nope, not anymore!" I answered and backed into the wall.

I could swear I heard the monster wheeze out a heaving laugh and it stepped closer, blocking off any chance of escape with its blade.

"Well you have to do something! " The fairy cried, "Put on your mask!"

"Uhh I'll try, see if you can distract him!"

Tatl made a noise that was part fear, part annoyance, and part determination, and darted around Odalwa's head, who proceeded to swat at her like a fly. I groped at my mask and hurriedly slapped it to my face. After the now-familiar cracking and reshaping between forms, I rushed at the monster with sword drawn and shield ready, ignoring the burning in my lungs from the smoky room. Odalwa saw me coming but was clearly caught off guard, and raised its shield only just before I dealt a hefty blow. The impact shook my arm only a little, but I still kept swinging, dodging, blocking, and swinging again, caught within a deadly waltz.

After what seemed like hours, I finally managed to whittle away at the huge shield until it was nothing but splinters. Odalwa moaned in angry disbelief and jumped back. I dashed at it once more, but it faded into a dark mist, and my sword slashed nothing but smoke and air.

"What? Where did he go!" I called out to Tatl.

"Umm…. Ummm…" She looked and flitted around, "I don't know, I can't see anything in here! It's too dark...woah look out!"

I heard the whoosh just as my companion spoke out, and rolled to the side. My heavier weight made the maneuver more difficult and I didn't get very far, but I dodged the weapon just the same. I turned to face my attacker, which was a bulkier lizalfos in steel armor and a curved sword that was more sickle than sword, and it came at me once more. I knocked aside its blade, and tried to run it through. But it flipped through the air on powerful legs and nearly knocked my head off with a sharp attachment on its tail. I took a mental note and immediately attacked, not giving it a chance to recover. The lizalfos must've been expecting a deathblow with its tail strike, and didn't turn around fast enough. I sliced through the tail and left foot, spun, and with a twist of my wrist the reptilian head went spinning along the stone floor.

Suddenly, the lit torch of the room went out and we were cast in darkness. We began to hear an eerie chanting echo through the chamber, and the shadows seemed to coagulate and form into vague outlines of more lizalfos. One of them must have jumped at me as a sharp stinging pain drew across my shield arm. I lashed out with my sword and felt a cool splash wash over me, indicating a successful blow I assumed.

"Link, use your bow! Hurry!"

I heard the fairy and knew exactly what she was thinking, I plucked off my mask, heart pounding like a war drum in my chest, and awkwardly dashed away from the army of darkness. My breath came in sharp, panicked gasps as I felt my body twist and shrink back to its natural state, each bone and tendon pulling inward like a tightening coil. The sensation was no longer painful, but eerily smooth—like a memory being reversed. The sudden lightness in my frame made me stagger, and I couldn’t tell if it was relief or dread that filled me. My fingers trembled as I reached out to steady myself, the world tilting from the shift, the adrenaline clawing at my throat as shadows reached for me with hungry fingers. There was no time to think—only to flee, to regroup, to survive....to give me more time. Tatl's light helped a little in dodging shadowy assaults, but it wasn't nearly enough in the smoky room. Thankfully I soon felt the bow appear on my back again, and feeling much lighter on my feet I jumped forward and shot off an arrow directly behind me. Thin yelps of the incorporeal creatures filled my ears as my arrow burst into flames, giving me enough time to aim for another torch. Tatl knew my plan and rushed along the walls, stopping at the nearest sconce. I nodded, she darted away, and I set the wall ablaze. The shadowy mist was swept away by the brightness and more hollow shrieks cried out as the summoned creatures faded into oblivion.

Tatl and I set our minds on creating as much light as possible, and following the same method as before, the room was nearly as bright as day except for the middle of the chamber. The dark, billowing mist coalesced together in the center, and Odalwa reformed itself, its body stitching together in a grotesque ballet of twitching muscle and steaming ichor. Moaning in rage, the monster gripped its own flesh with clawed hands and tore chunks of purple, jelly-like matter from its abdomen and arms. The goop pulsed faintly, trailing threads of smoke and a noxious stench as it hurled the globules with savage precision. The sight turned my stomach—it wasn’t just attacking, it was mutilating itself to do so, like some nightmare caught in a loop of endless suffering. I dodged to the side and it missed me by a few feet. Only, as I realized too late, I wasn't the intended target. The torch was now extinguished and covered in toxic sludge, the monster was trying to plunge the area in darkness once more.

"Link, he's…!"

"I know I know!"

I had to act fast, so I shot arrow after arrow, each one white and brilliant, exploding against the creature. The blasts cracked through the temple chamber like distant thunder, echoing off the stone walls, but Odalwa didn’t flinch. The monster continued its grotesque assault, tearing globs of its own flesh to douse the torchlight, moaning with madness and fury. Each arrow left a scorch mark, a flash of hope—and then despair as the beast shrugged them off.

I grit my teeth and focused my will into the ring on my hand. The next arrow flared orange, a streak of fire erupting from the string—but even as the blaze licked across the monster's grotesque mask, it didn’t slow. The fire singed its hide, but didn’t pierce the curse that kept it standing. The stench of burning rot choked the air, heavy and acidic in my lungs. My heart raced. This wasn’t working.

Something deeper stirred in me. Desperation. Fury. I reached past the fire, past the fear, and willed the bow itself to respond—not just as a weapon, but as an extension of my soul. My grip tightened until my knuckles went white, and the string thrummed with an unnatural tension. I poured my full intent into it: kill this thing.

The arrow that formed wasn’t like the others. It shimmered to life in a shaft of radiant, kaleidoscopic light—each hue shifting like breath across water, impossible to name or hold in the mind. It vibrated with a sound I felt more than heard, like a memory just out of reach. Even Tatl gasped, her glow flashing in surprise.

With a cry that came from the very bottom of my chest, I loosed the shot. The arrow didn’t fly—it sang , tearing through the air like a falling star, and struck Odalwa square in the face. Time seemed to halt. The monster reeled, its limbs contorting wildly, its scream a raw, primal sound that shattered the air.

And then—light.

A blinding, rippling pulse surged outward as the arrow melted through its skull, tearing the darkness apart. The temple shook violently, dust and loose stones cascading from the ceiling, and I was thrown to the ground. For a moment, there was only ringing in my ears, white and absolute.

And then… something inside me gave.

It wasn’t pain. It was absence. A soft tearing, like parchment ripped from the spine of an old book. I felt a name vanish from my mind, a detail I couldn’t place—like waking from a dream and knowing you’ve forgotten something precious. Ear-splitting roars made me seize the sides of my head, a pulsing pressure building behind my eyes like my skull was being split in two. I lost my train of thought as I clapped my hands to my head.

I curled into a trembling ball on the floor, heart pounding, lungs heaving, every nerve alight with pain and fear. Beside me, Tatl writhed in equal torment, her glow flickering wildly. All I could do was endure, pray the storm would pass, and hold fast to the fragile thread of survival in the chaos. The white-orange flames engulfing the undead terror suddenly turned a sickly green, and erupted up into the ceiling. Then.... silence.

Thick, unnatural, the kind that presses against your eardrums and makes your heartbeat sound deafening. Smoke curled in slow spirals through the air, the only movement in a room otherwise frozen in aftermath. I stayed crouched, trembling, the stench of scorched rot and ash clinging to my lungs while my mind struggled to believe the monster was truly gone. Even Tatl, ever quick to speak, hovered beside me in stunned quiet. Only the distant drip of water and the faint crackle of dying fire reminded me the world was still turning.

My whole head was ringing as I stood up and looked around, the air still hazy with curling smoke and the glow of dying embers casting flickering shadows across the slick, damp stone. A faint chill began to seep  into the ground beneath my boots, making the temple feel more like a tomb than a battlefield won. The stench of burnt moss and scorched rot clung to the air. Nothing remained of Odalwa but that horrific mask, still smoldering where it fell.

Seeing Tatl still lying on the cold stone ground, a spike of worry pierced my haze—sharper than any wound I’d taken. For a breathless instant, the thought of losing her, after everything we'd just survived, after the way she'd called me her only friend... it made my chest tighten with something worse than fear. I knelt and gently scooped her into my hands, checking her over for any sign of injury.

"Hey," I said softly. "I... I think it's over. Are you alright?"

"What? It's over?!" she shouted, a little too loudly, blinking hard. "I can't hear you—my head feels like a scrambled egg!"

I winced as the vibration of her voice sent a throb through my temples. "I think we won," I repeated, louder this time. "See?"

I pointed to the center of the chamber, where Odalwa’s grotesque mask lay smoking on the baked floor like a discarded nightmare. Heat shimmered around it in waves, and the air above it pulsed faintly with an eerie, ghostly blue hue—as though the mask's spirit still clung to the world, unwilling to vanish.The glow wasn’t steady; it flickered like a dying flame underwater, casting long, distorted shadows against the soot-streaked walls. Faint motes of light—like ash suspended in magic—drifted lazily in the haze, spinning gently in the residual energy.

The dim sconces lining the chamber flickered lower in reverence or fear, and the blue light’s reflection danced in pools of stagnant water between cracked tiles, stretching the mask’s warped face into unearthly shapes.

It radiated menace even in defeat, a cursed relic refusing to die quietly. Tatl slowly fluttered up from my palm, wobbling in the air, her face stricken with disbelief.

"Wait… we actually survived?"

"Looks like it," I said with a half-laugh, still catching my breath. "I’m honestly amazed we’re still standing."

"Right…" she murmured, and her gaze shifted to my arm. "Except that there's a really big gash there. It's bleeding pretty badly! You should probably wrap it up with something."

I glanced down and grimaced at the ugly wound, but shook my head. "I'll be fine. I just… need to breathe some fresh air. Preferably less cursed and rotten."

She hovered closer, a rare flicker of concern in her glowing light. "You sure? That was… a lot."

"Yeah. I’m sure. I've been through worse. Are you alright?"

She hesitated, then gave a nod, her glow dimming slightly. "I think so. My wings feel like they’ve been rung out like laundry… but yeah. Still buzzing."

We stood there for a moment in silence, just listening to the drip of water and our own ragged breathing, each breath scraping up through aching lungs and tasting of ash and metal. The cool dampness of the stone beneath my boots made my bones ache, while the last embers cast weak flickers of orange light that danced across the walls like ghosts retreating from battle. I realized then how deeply I’d come to rely on her voice in the dark. The fight had nearly killed us both.... but here we still were.

"What about the Deku Princess?" she asked quietly, breaking the quiet with a gentler tone.

"Oh—right! I almost forgot," I muttered. "She’s supposed to be here somewhere, isn’t she?"

"Supposedly. We should check out that other passage…"

Tatl drifted toward the archway leading deeper in, and I lingered behind for a beat, casting one last look at the remains of Odalwa. Then I slumped my shoulders forward and sighed. Every inch of me ached, and more than anything I wanted to leave the foul temple. Still I followed after her, bone-tired and bloodied, but… I had done it. I passed through the fire, and came out victorious.

Chapter Twenty-Seven

Corruption's End

"Come on, let's go find that princess!" Tatl repeated as she flew over to the other passageway.

"Wait, you don't know if there's anything else we should worry about!" I called out, still apprehensive.

We had just defeated Odalwa—the monstrous warden of this corrupted temple, the source of the swamp’s decay. Now only scorched ash and that terrible wooden mask remained, a sickly totem resting in the pile where the beast once stood. I approached it slowly, the heat from the floor still licking at my boots, and stared at its twisted, burned expression. The carved wood was cracked and blackened, yet it still seemed to leer at me.

"What should we do with this mask, Tatl?" I asked, my voice quieter than I expected—hushed by something reverent or wary.

Tatl fluttered closer, her wings faltering midair before she forced herself forward. “I don’t know, I’m not touching it, that’s for sure. You probably shouldn’t either.”

But before we could decide, the mask pulsed.

A brilliant blue flare exploded from within it, bathing the entire chamber in blinding light. My body stiffened with instinctual dread as I stumbled back, throwing up an arm to shield my eyes. The light wasn’t just bright—it felt aware . Like something vast and watching had suddenly turned its attention to us. I gasped as the ground beneath us seemed to fall away. For one breathless moment, I thought I was being torn from my body.

When I opened my eyes again, the air was different. Lighter. Clean.

We were no longer in the temple.

Gone was the stench of rot and scorched stone. Tatl and I now stood upon a vast white platform suspended in the sky, surrounded by gently swirling clouds tinged with gold and lavender. A faint wind carried the scent of rain and something older—ozone and memory, maybe. The air here thrummed with silence, but not an empty one. It was sacred.

A strange vertigo swept over me as I walked toward the edge of the platform, peering over the side, and saw nothing but mist and infinite sky. I instinctively stepped back.

“Are we… dead?” Tatl’s voice was small, unsure. “What happened?”

“I’m not sure…” I said, slowly scanning the endless horizon. “I think we were transported. Wait… what’s that? Look there.”

A silhouette was rising in the distance—massive, slow-moving, and utterly surreal. Clouds peeled away from it like mist rolling off a mountain peak.

It was massive.

The being loomed above us, emerging from the fog like some forgotten god. Its arms hung long and low, fingers like carved stone. Its body was smooth and vaguely egg-shaped, head and torso one seamless form, reddish skin glinting faintly in the celestial glow. No mouth marked its face, only two deep, dark eyes and a beard-like fringe of green—like moss on ancient bark.

Yet despite its monstrous size and inhuman shape, it radiated a calm gravity. Like the stillness of deep forest waters or the hush of a mountain valley just before dawn. My fear didn’t rise; instead, I felt… humbled. Like I was in the presence of something that remembered the world before it was broken.

It didn’t speak, but I somehow knew it understood us.

"Huh...Do you hear that?" Tatl chimed in suddenly, breaking the serenity. "I think it's speaking to us!"

I raised a hand to my pointed ear to listen, but all I could hear was a very faint yet solemn melody riding along the gentle winds—something like a lullaby forgotten by time.

"It's saying… thank you… for freeing its spirit…?" Tatl said slowly, "And for your sacrifice…. call us…. together again? What does that mean?"

I didn't have any time to respond as the bright blue light flashed and surrounded us once more. It didn’t just shine—it wrapped around us like liquid sky, weightless and warm, pulling us up from the pedestal with a force that wasn’t physical but deeply spiritual. My stomach dropped, and a jolt of vertigo seized me as we were transported again.

We blinked back into the temple as if from a dream. I swayed slightly, a bit dizzy from the ordeal. A sharp tingling sensation swept through my body—warm, effervescent, like the feeling after waking from a long, dreamless sleep. Then, like sunlight banishing a cold fog, the pain and fatigue of the battle began to melt away. My arm, my legs, my face—all the aches and gashes I’d carried felt like they were gently rewoven, not erased, but lovingly mended. I let out a shaky breath, surprised to find it didn’t hurt. Even the deep, bruising throb in my shoulder had vanished.

Tatl floated beside me, blinking rapidly and then gasping. "Wait… Link, you're—you're healed! I think… me too?" She spun in a slow circle, her wings fluttering more smoothly, her glow brighter than before.

The heavy scent of death was also beginning to recede from the room, like a breath long held finally exhaled. The flickering torches seemed to burn more steadily now, casting golden halos through the mist. Relief bloomed quietly in my chest, and I turned to Tatl, my grin faint but real… tempered by a knowing dread that the battle's echo would linger within the both of us. Her golden light no longer fluttered with panic, but pulsed gently, like a heartbeat remembered. She drifted closer, brushing against my cheek in a fleeting, wordless gesture of comfort. I took a deep breath to steady my legs, still trembling from everything we’d endured, and met her gaze. In that quiet moment, we understood one another without need for words. Our bond had deepened—not through victory, but through survival. Then I remembered the sacred giant...

"So…what was that thing?" I inquired and stepped over to her.

"I'm not completely positive," she replied, watching me with a furrowed brow, "but I think that was the Southern Guardian…"

"That was a guardian? Geez...I'm glad it was on our side," I muttered, my voice low.

"Skull Kid wasn't on theirs though…. and we got banished for it. Anyway, where were we? Oh right, looking for the princess." Tatl began to drift toward the passage again, but her tone had softened. "Come on, let's go slowpoke!"

"Alright alright, I'm coming. Just let me grab that...mask… Where did it go?"

My eyes searched the center of the room, scanning for Odalwa's mask. The scorched stone beneath where the monster had fallen was still blackened, laced with glowing cracks that pulsed faintly like cooling embers. Wisps of smoke curled lazily upward, twisting through the heavy air. Yet, of the horrific wooden mask, there was no sign—only the lingering impression of magic, like the aftermath of thunder following a great storm. It was as if the mask had never existed, swallowed up by the blue light or spirited away by forces beyond reckoning.

"I dunno, maybe it was magic or something?" The impatient pixie responded, "Worry about it later, we have a job to do! I'm so ready to be out of this swamp!"

I nodded my head and moved on from the chamber, but not before removing the heavy cloak and rolling it up to tie around my waist as an awkwardly thick belt. But I was thankful that the weight was at last lifted from my aching shoulders, and I strode to the corridor. This new passageway we went down was overgrown with foliage creeping up through various cracks and holes. Vines as thick as rope twisted along the floor and walls, glistening faintly with dew. The air felt cooler here, damp and earthy, carrying the scent of moss and decaying wood. Every step squished softly against the moist stone, and occasional drops of water echoed from somewhere deeper within, lending the corridor a hushed, almost peaceful stillness. Although it was dark, a faint light gleamed from somewhere up ahead, making the path a little easier to navigate. As we got closer to the light source, shrill and desperate warbles from what sounded like a deku originated from the area ahead.

Finally we had reached the end of the corridor, and a partly opened stone door lay before us. The bright light of torches flickered in the room beyond, and I pushed all of my body weight, as pitiable as I was, against the door. With a loud grinding the door slid open, and the deku began shrieking in terror, which felt like a hundred knives digging into my brain. I hurriedly searched for the deku and found it inside a great wooden cage, huddling in a corner and shuddering with fear. From what I could see, this deku was not a common one. Ornate leaves flowed from its body like a resplendent dress, and it had several pieces of shiny jewelry tied in its long green leaves. I approached the cage slowly trying not to startle the poor creature any more than I already had. It stared at me with frightened glowing eyes and retreated to the back of the cage.

"Hello?" I spoke softly, trying to ease her fears. "Are you the Deku Princess?"

"N-n-no! Leave me alone!" She cried and did her best to curl into a small ball, which was impressively tiny.

"It's alright, I'm not here to hurt you." I reassured, "I'm here to rescue you."

The little princess paused for a moment, then gradually unraveled herself. Then she turned around and skipped towards me, but began to panic after getting a better look at her rescuer.

"You? N-no you must leave this place! You are a female, the monster devours females!" The princess whispered in urgent tones.

"You mean Odalwa?" Tatl chimed in, "Don't worry about that guy anymore, we beat him!"

"What?" The deku squeaked in surprise, "You two defeated the ancient terror?! You must be formidable indeed….wait…Where did you get that cloak? Either you are great warriors, or murderous thieves!"

"No we aren't thieves, your mother sent us to look for you. She thought this hide would help us find you." I explained while working to open the cage. "But your father is gearing up for war I think. Your mother said only finding you would stop him."

"Oh she must be worried off her stump, and my father...oh no!" She hopped nervously, "The one I came to investigate this temple with is the prince of the monkey tribe! He saw me get taken and must have run to my parents for help. Tell me, did you see a monkey there?"

"The only monkey we saw inside the palace was bound and being tortured—it was... awful!" Came Tatl's reply, "They think the monkeys kidnapped you."

"Oh dear...oh dear! You must take me back immediately!" The princess hopped out of the cage and scurried to the exit. "Well? Come on then!"

"Sheesh… not even a thank you." My companion muttered, her usual sass laced with a hint of exasperated affection.

I shrugged, but inside, a quiet ache lingered—a cocktail of relief, fatigue, and the strange closeness forged in shared danger. Tatl buzzed nearby, noticeably less brash, glancing at the back of my hand where dried blood still crusted from the earlier fight. Her usual quick wit was absent, replaced by a soft, wordless presence that hovered near my shoulder. For just a moment, her light dimmed to a gentler glow, like a candle flickering in empathy. I turned to look at her, and she met my gaze—something passed between us, unspoken but understood: we had faced death together, and survived. I could feel the bond between us grow tighter in that quiet space, grief and gratitude intertwining. I looked toward the Deku princess, now scurrying ahead with determined urgency, then back to Tatl. Our eyes lingered for one more heartbeat. We didn’t speak. We didn’t need to. And then, together, we left the dark temple, and we didn’t look back.

As we stepped out into the open swamp, the change was immediate and astonishing. The water sparkled, no longer choked with filth but shimmering like new rain. The scent of rot had vanished, replaced by the gentle sweetness of wet bark and blooming lilies. Palm fronds swayed in a warm, forgiving breeze, and distant birds sang like they'd been waiting for this exact moment to return. The very land seemed to exhale, shedding its suffering with every glimmer of renewed life. But the serenity was not complete—far above, the cursed moon still loomed like a cruel reminder. Its terrible gaze staining even this peace.

Still... I let myself breathe the fresh air. Just for a moment, as the princess approached us.

"Oh… before we move on, I want to ask your pardon for my rudeness." The tiny princess squeaked apologetically. "I am truly, eternally in your debt, human warrior, and I am ashamed that I didn't even ask your name…"

"My name is Link." I responded, and gestured to my partner. "And this is Tatl."

The Deku royal gratefully bowed her head to both of us.

"It is my absolute pleasure to meet you both. Now, if you'll forgive my boorish behavior, we really must be off. Please follow me, I fear we have no time to lose!"

She scurried with surprising speed across the bridge, and I took off after her with Tatl trailing behind. We all sped across the remainder of the lizalfos camp and dashed down the mountain like we were mad. We were stopped at the front gates by some very surprised deku guards, who were harshly berated by the princess, but let us all go in without further delay. The inner palace was still filled with incensed deku, but my breath caught in my throat at the horrifying sight of the imprisoned prince dangling by a rope over a bubbling cauldron.

The stifling heat hit me like a wall, and the acrid stench of burning herbs and monkey hair twisted my stomach, making me momentarily dizzy. My breath caught in my throat as my eyes locked onto the grotesque sight before us—an innocent life teetering over a boiling death. Horror and helplessness surged in my chest, paralyzing my limbs even as every instinct screamed to act. Beside me, Tatl gasped, her glow flickering erratically with panic, casting jittery shadows across the floor. I could feel her trembling near my shoulder, and without looking, I knew that her fear matched mine. The king, still at his throne in the back of the room, directed his underlings to lower the monkey into the cauldron while the forlorn queen stood beside him, looking away from the grisly scene. The princess saw the dire situation and shrieked as loud as possible, causing all eyes to turn to her as the room fell silent.

"What are you fools doing!?"

Shaking with rage, she hop-sprinted through the now parting crowd toward the hulking deku king.

"Father! How dare you treat this innocent prince so poorly!"

"Wha?" The king sputtered in shock. "Typha? You're-"

He didn't have a chance to finish as the tiny princess leapt at him and tackled the huge deku to the ground. The queen seemed to be overjoyed, but the crowd of speechless underlings watched partly in awe and mostly fear as the king was stomped upon by his daughter. Once she was finished "scolding" her father, the princess turned to the crowd, who all braced for a similar fate.

"What are you staring at! Release him at once!"

After a mad scramble, the monkey prince was immediately untied and released. Once he checked over his extremities to ensure he wasn't badly wounded, the prince rushed over to the princess and embraced her warmly.

"Thank the guardians you're alright, princess! I feared the worst when you didn't come out of that temple with me."

"If it wasn't for this brave human warrior and her companion, the worst would have surely happened." The princess spoke somberly and directed everyone's attention to me. "And thanks to them, all the poison that was destroying our home has vanished!"

The white-gold monkey hopped over to me and looked me over.

" You  defeated that monster? You don't look... very formidable… but ahh... appearances are deceiving. Not even my best warriors could harm the devil, but...somehow, you managed it! I guess I underestimated human potential…" The prince nodded and reached out to gently touch my hand. "Because of you, our world is saved. From both war and corruption. You will be forever etched into our history as the warrior maiden who brought about our salvation!"

"Oh no no! I only wanted to help, that's all." I protested, backing away. "But I'm afraid that I have to get going."

"What?!" The trampled king rose up and bellowed. "Not so fast, human! I can't possibly let the heroine who saved my daughter, and the entire swamp no doubt, leave without a reward!"

"No please, I don't need anything!" I objected and continued to retreat, "But I appreciate the thought..!"

The scrubs that surrounded me suddenly burst into cheers, their round eyes wide with admiration. Before I could protest, they lifted me up onto their backs and shoulders, their bark-like arms surprisingly sturdy. I tensed, unsure whether to feel honored or horrified, heart pounding with the sudden surge of attention. As they carried me forward, I caught Tatl’s glance—her wings fluttered uncertainly, mirroring my own unease—as we were paraded toward the towering form of their king. I was set down before the tree-like monarch, who was much larger than I previously thought and stood a good meter or so above me. Having never been rewarded by deku before, I was a bit wary of what was going to happen.

"Human…" The king knelt down. "If what they say is true, then my kingdom also owes you a great debt. Although, that cloak you're wearing does look familiar...is that..?"

"I gave it to her, Nuphar!" The queen interjected, "You weren't in your right mind, and I gave all hope to this Link….my faith was not misplaced."

"You went behind my back to trust a human, Leersia?" The king gawked at her, then bobbed his leafy head sadly. "You were right to do so….if you hadn't, I would have surely sealed our doom."

"You are too rash at times, Nuphar, but it is all well and good now." Leersia hopped over to me. "I thank you from the bottom of my heart, Link, but, I'm afraid we need that dinolfos hide back. It is a royal treasure after all…"

I agreed, and undid the cloak tied around my waist, gratefully handing the hefty hide to the queen. With its weight off my shoulders, I felt a subtle shift within me, shedding not just armor, but a burden of what we had endured in Woodfall. For a second I swore that I could still feel the heat of the battle clinging to the fabric, like an echo too stubborn to fade. In a way, I was happy to be rid of it.

"Thank you. Now we will return your old cloak, although I decided to have my handmaiden 'improve' upon it in case you returned successfully."

Leersia uttered a few rapid squeaks to her nearby handmaiden, who bowed and scampered down a small, hidden tunnel behind the throne. I exhaled slowly, heart still catching up to the present, and turned to Tatl, whose quiet, steady presence beside me grounded my thoughts.

A few moments later, the servant appeared again, holding my neatly folded cloak.

"And what a triumphant return it was," the queen continued, "So I am honored to let you have this small gift in exchange for your noble deeds."

The handmaid skittered over to me and raised the garment toward my hands. I picked it up and immediately noticed something had changed. It wasn't heavier—just smoother, richer somehow. I unfurled it and was pleasantly surprised to see that the inside was lined with iridescent scales similar to the dinolfos skin. And was, thankfully, much lighter.

"We lined your coat with our other great treasure. That hide came from a dangerous relative of the armor you borrowed. Although it is not as durable or powerful as its older cousin, those scales have a similar way of blending into the surrounding environment. Please, take it as a symbol of our everlasting gratitude."

I slid my arms through the sleeves and adjusted it, and was very pleased to find that the cloak was hardly a burden at all. The scales inside felt cool and comfortably smooth against my tunic, which was also vast improvement over the older dinolfos hide. Tatl glided around me, gently poking at the draping end of the new cloak.

"Hmm, yup! I think this will do." She smiled in satisfaction and landed on my shoulder. "Plus this is much more comfortable for me than that other nasty, thick coat."

I shook Tatl off, who playfully stuck her tongue out and fluttered behind me, and bowed to the king and queen.

"I realize this gift must be invaluable, and I thank you for your generosity." I stated, then straightened out. "But I must be going now, I'm sure I am needed elsewhere."

"Ah yes, this world is still in grave danger indeed." King Nuphar somberly bobbed his head in agreement. "But I fear that there is far too much for even you to handle, mighty Link. Reports of the great moon falling from the sky are very unsettling. There are also rumors that every region in Termina is drenched with chaos, especially in the Northern Mountains. Even so, I admit you have much courage to try, especially for a human. You are a true warrior, and we shall memorialize your deeds here!"

The throne room scrubs cheered and I cringed internally, hating the attention I was receiving. Yet I smiled out of politeness and swiftly walked away from the reunited family, through the crowded chamber, and out of the throne room. After I was out of sight, I heard the attention of the congregation shift toward the deku princess and monkey prince. Sighing in relief, I strutted out into the courtyard and confidently passed by the many guards, who stood straight and still until I was gone. Once through the main gate, I looked around and breathed deeply of the now fresh, marshy, air. It carried with it the faint trace of moss and damp earth, but also something cleaner—like a sigh of relief from the land itself. For a moment, I let the weight of everything fall away: the battles, the fear, the shadows of the temple. The air filled my lungs with a quiet sense of triumph and clarity, like I had earned this breath, this moment of stillness. Beside me, Tatl hovered without speaking, her glow soft and steady. We both knew the peace wouldn't last, but for now, it was enough.

Dawn was quickly approaching as the few stars I could see faded into the swelling blue of morning. Though the cursed moon still loomed in the sky like an open wound, a serene peacefulness had finally settled over the swamp. The land was healing, and in some way, I felt I was too. There was beauty in the gently swaying ferns and palm trees, the nearby warbles of skittering creatures, and the gurgle of the slow moving river. In that moment, I wasn’t just a warrior or a wanderer—I was someone who had helped bring a corner of the world back to life. And though the road ahead remained uncertain, I carried that restoration with me like a quiet ember burning in my chest. Yet I had to shake myself from my reverie and focus on our next objective. With another deep breath, I turned to my pixie companion.

"Well, I think we're done here. I say it's time to go back to the first day… there isn't much we can do now."

"Great… another ride through the time stream." Tatl groaned. "But yup, I guess we have to."

I reached down into my pouch and pulled out the precious blue instrument. Closing my eyes, I pursed my lips around the ocarina and began to play the Song of Time. The notes shimmered in the cool morning air, each one heavy with memory. As the melody reached its end, the strange pull overtook me—like a ripple in water tugging me backward. The world blurred and twisted, the sign of time unraveling like threads from a tapestry. I felt both dread and relief wash over me: dread for all that still lay ahead, and relief for what little peace we had restored. My heart clenched with a quiet fear—what if this was the last time the swamp would breathe easy? What if going back in time also restored Odalwa?? What if... each reset stripped a little more away from who I used to be? Yet there was also hope—fragile, persistent—that maybe, just maybe, I was learning how to carry these burdens despite their weight. Just before everything faded, I caught a glimpse of Tatl’s glow beside me—constant, comforting, like a star guiding me home. Then the light swallowed us whole.

Chapter Twenty-Eight

Blood Dawn

It was a beautiful morning in the small, peaceful village of Glendale. The sun was just popping up over the horizon, and early birds were chirping with playful glee as they chased their kin over a crystal clear lake. The blue skies were filled with big, white puffy clouds that were perfect for gazing at, and the town bells were happily welcoming the glorious spring morning.

Caros was just an ordinary man, with a serene life as a fisherman who cherished quiet mornings by the lake and the simple joy of watching dragonflies skim across the water's surface. He was also happily married to a beautiful woman with two strapping boys and two lovely daughters. Caros had just finished gathering bait worms from one of the local mud holes and was tying off a sack filled with the slimy creatures, when a loud crack like thunder sounded behind him. The simple man jumped in fear and surprise, slowly turning to see an unnerving sight. A painfully gaunt, masked man wearing blood soaked clothing had appeared from thin air, and was now lying on the ground face up a few meters away from Caros.

Being the decent, kindly fella that he was, Caros rushed over to try to help the strange man.

"Hey mister! Are you alright?" he shouted as he ran.

The masked man didn't answer at first, so Caros frantically checked to see if he was alive and searched for wounds. The man was breathing faintly, but there were gaping, bloody holes in the man's pant legs. Without a word, Caros ripped apart the fabric so that he could get a closer look and try to stop the bleeding. Caros was no healer, but perhaps he could sustain the man's life until the village doctor arrived.

Caros tried to tie off the large wounds, his hands trembling as he fumbled with the fabric. The blood was warm and slick, soaking into his sleeves. One of the legs looked grotesquely broken, the bone possibly snapped beneath the skin. Caros swallowed hard, stomach twisting at the sight. But before he could properly bind the injury, the limb began to contort and snap back into place with a series of sickening, wet crunches. He froze, eyes wide in disbelief as he watched the deep, gaping wounds slowly close themselves. The flesh knitted together with eerie precision, pushing out dirt and old blood like the body was rejecting its own trauma. It was like witnessing time reverse. Caros fell back onto his heels, gasping and pale, struggling to process what he had just watched. In mere moments, all traces of physical trauma were gone and looked as if nothing had happened at all, aside from the bloodied clothing and torn pant legs.

Suddenly, the man sat up without a word, startling Caros even more. The horribly wide, yellow-orange eyes of the mask turned to Caros, and a deep, powerful voice resonated from behind the heart-shaped visage.

"Where am I?"

"Y-you're in Glendale, mister!" Caros shakily answered. "I found you lyin' here covered in blood, so I figured I'd try to help a fella out!"

"I need no help," the voice spoke again. "Not anymore."

"Shyeah, you seem to be in fine shape now. My name is Caros, what's yours, friend?"

"My name...can I finally recall...?" The man paused, seemingly lost in memory. "Yes. Yes...I know now..."

Caros stared, a bit confused at the man's odd behavior, and gestured that he was waiting for the man to finish with a waving motion. The macabre mask began to resonate and became surrounded with a purple glow. The memories, long forgotten, returned in floods....dark...broken.... glorious . The eerie eyes suddenly lit up in a fearsome display, like candles within a carved pumpkin, and glared into Caros's widening eyes.

"I am called...Majora."

The last thing Caros ever saw again was the masked man raising his hands toward him, a dark flash, and then nothing at all...

Majora stood over the smoldering remains of the foolish villager, his breath slow and deliberate. The acrid scent of charred flesh curled into his nostrils, sharp and satisfying. In this singular act of ruin, there was a bitter joy—a twisted catharsis. The silence that followed the blast echoed louder than screams. For the first time in millennia, Majora felt whole. Seen. Not by kin, not by gods, but by the universe itself—as if the world had paused, watching, remembering. His vengeance had begun, and with it, a terrible sense of purpose. The mask blankly stared as Majora stretched happily toward the sky. Those moronic kinsmen of his, daring to shatter Majora's will! They had feared what they could not control—feared the ancient power Majora had uncovered. His creation, this mask of darkness, was meant to be salvation: the prototype of he called Fused Shadow, forged through dark intent but guided by vision. With it, Majora would have restored their true homeland, the land Hylians arrogantly ruled over in smug laziness. He would have restored the greatness of his people. But they had seen only danger in his brilliance.

The True Sheikah—his clan, his blood—had called him mad. Had turned on him. And in the end, they murdered him, and banished the mask into the Shadow Realm. Betrayers! Kinslayers!

The Sheikah Elders would feel his hate! Those traitors would perish in hellfire, again and again and again!

"Ha!" Majora laughed, raising his hands to the sky. "I'll show them. I'll show everyone how terrible my wrath will be!"

The earth began to rumble and dark foreboding clouds began to replace the fluffy white clouds as tendrils of darkness flowed from Majora, whose laughter only grew more sadistic and vicious.

The townspeople of Glendale began to scuttle about in nervous tension as the sky grew ever darker. After fire started to rain from said sky, the people shrieked in abject terror and fled in every direction. They failed to notice one lone, masked figure casually walking into town.

"My vengeance...hahhh... will begin with these pathetic villagers," Majora uttered beneath the mask.

He snapped his fingers, and suddenly a flaming whip was in his hand. Majora swung the whip at one unlucky villager, who was instantly cleaved in two and burned to cinders. The remains smoldered on the blackening ground as townspeople fled in horror. Majora's terrible laugh and the screeching townspeople could be heard from the farthest corners of the town, as its denizens were consumed in fires as hot as the sun.

Left and right, people were felled by the stranger's malevolent fury. Houses and shops burst into millions of burning splinters. Children vanished in flashes of fire, their laughter silenced in an instant, while women screamed as the heat devoured them like a storm sweeping through dry fields. Death and destruction followed in the stranger's horrendous wake.

There was no mercy, and no remorse in Majora. For too long had he suffered, for too long had he been helpless, alone, afraid and friendless. He had sacrificed everything for his people! And what did he get in return? Madness! Exile! Loneliness! Suffering!

Now at last, after ages of despair, Majora was not alone.

"Every! Single! Creature!" Majora screamed in wild vehemence, flailing his whip with each syllable. "They will suffer with me, and know my pain!"

Majora did not stop until everything around him was but ash and dusty embers. Then, and only then, did he nod his head in satisfaction, and disappeared into nothingness.

All that remained of the quaint, peace-loving village of Glendale was the wind and dust. Not even the lake survived, and was now a basin of cracked mud full of rotting fish. The skies were forever tainted with the color of blood, as though the heavens themselves bore witness to the horror and could not forget it, stained by the sheer ferocity of the massacre that had just occurred. As a final nail in the coffin, a curse was buried deep within the ground so that nothing would ever grow and flourish again.

Such was the wrath of Majora...yet... in the silent aftermath, even Majora's triumph rang hollow. The mask stared out at nothing, and the soul within him felt only the echo of his own desolation.



Chapter Twenty-Nine

Clock Town Corruption



The dawn of the first day began as usual. The gleaming sun shone merrily onto the Clock Tower as birds chirped throughout the plaza. The brawny construction crew hammered and sawed, and the early shoppers chatted and hurried into and out of the opening shopping stalls positioned around the area. Yet despite the normalcy of the scene, a faint unease lingered in my chest—a ghost of the horrors from the swamp. I stood beside Tatl, once again at the base of the immense Tower in the middle of Clock Town, wondering about our next move. for restoring peace to Termina.

"Yep." Tatl shrugged, "Another day, another adventure. What do we do this time?"

Shaking a mild dizziness away, I took stock of my belongings by rummaging through my belt pouches and was relieved to find everything still there from the day before, including the new and improved scale-lined cloak. Finding my inventory satisfactory, I looked around and tried to think.

"Hmm...well… didn't we hear someone say something about the north…?" I asked, turning to my companion.

Tatl was just about to answer when an inquisitive voice cut into our conversation.

"Hey, do you fine ladies need any help?" An earnest young man spoke up beside us.

I turned to tell the person that we were just fine when I recognized the intruder—my breath catching just slightly in my throat. There, standing in the morning light, was Ratt. That familiar mop of scraggly black hair, eyes brimming with helpful mischief, a young man of thin, lanky stature, and the familiar blue clothing of a Bomber with the number "3" sewn on the back of a white vest.

Something tightened in my chest, an unspoken mix of frustration, unease… and maybe something else. I also remembered the ratty kid's constant flirting. I wasn’t ready to name the feeling yet, but it still lingered like the last note of a song still echoing in my bones.

"Oh no, not you !" I groaned loudly and put a hand to my face.

"Wait, what? Have we met before?" The boy asked in confusion. "I think I would've remembered someone like you."

"Yes...no I mean! We've never met before!" I hurriedly babbled, my mind struggling to come up with an excuse to leave. "I mean I've seen you around, but that's it!"

I immediately remembered the small peck on the cheek the boy gave me, and a flicker of vulnerability surged through me, my cheeks flushing red with the memory.

Idiot, what are you doing?!  I angrily berated myself, mortified at the sudden warmth rushing to my face, struggling to hide the softness I hadn't meant to show.

"Hehe...ummm… right…" He nervously laughed.

Damn it! Too late! I mentally slapped myself, knowing the kid had noticed.

"Uh well, anyway… I just wanted to see if you needed any help since you look a little lost. Maybe I can guide you to wherever you're going?" He quickly changed the subject, sensing my discomfort.

"No thanks…" I declined and turned briskly away. "I think we have an idea."

"Hey wait, Link!" Tatl chimed and pulled my hand back as I began walking away. "This guy is one of those Bombers, they'll probably know more about weird stuff happening."

"I know what's going on, Tatl, we have to go north!" I argued, yanking my hand away in irritation.

"North? As in the mountains?" Ratt warned, rushing to my side. "Ohh no, you don't want to go there, you'd be dead or frozen solid before you could even get to the trails! The Pass is completely blocked with ice, rocks, and snow storms. The only people who can get through are the Gorons. And, if you don't mind my saying so, you're much better looking than a rock creature."

The boy smiled and winked at me, and I rolled my eyes and continued on. A mix of confusion, frustration, and a traitorous flutter of something softer churned quietly beneath my practiced indifference. I quickened my pace away from the youth, heart thudding faster than I liked.

"Okay okay, I'm sorry!" Ratt apologized and caught up to me. "But you can't be serious about going to the mountains, right? I wasn't joking about that, you wouldn't stand a chance!"

"I'll be fine, I've been through far worse I'm sure, including you . Now leave us alone!" I angrily chided, pushing the irksome boy away to get some distance. But even as I shoved him, my fingers lingered a heartbeat too long on his chest—just enough to spark another jolt of unease.

"Oof!" Ratt grunted, "Sheesh you're stubborn! H-hey wait!"

I ignored the boy and pressed on, but Tatl quickly dashed in front of me to block my path.

"Stop, you hard-headed goat! Don't you think we should hear him out? Look at where your one track mind has gotten you so far." The fairy flung my hair into my face.

"Why do you  want to listen to this kid?" I fiercely swiped the scarlet locks from my face and glared at Tatl. My voice wavered slightly, the tension building inside me threatening to spill. "Last time he almost got me killed, or worse. He's nothing but trouble!"

"Last time? What do you mean?" Ratt spoke up from behind. "You keep implying that you know me, but I'm sure we've never met. What's going on, are you on some of that new magic dust? That stuff will kill you, ya know?"

We were standing in the middle of the walkway, and I looked around to notice the area was getting crowded with more and more people. With a resigned groan, I pulled Ratt along behind me and into a more secluded and empty storefront across from the tower.

"Alright... look, you're going to forget this anyway so I might as well tell you." I sighed and released the boy. "We're trying to save this world, because in three days it's going to end. We can't do  that in three days, so we need to travel back in time constantly. The last time I saw you, you were being beaten by some gang members and I saved your life."

Ratt stared at me for a long moment, his playful grin faltering as uncertainty crept across his face.

"Ya know, I was only kidding about you being on drugs, but... now..uh I think you need to get some help."

I gave him an indignant shove once more, defiant heat flushing through me, and I took out my ocarina.

"I'm not on anything, you idiot. This is a special instrument that bends time… or something... like that. If I play a specific song on this, I, and whoever I happen to be with, get swept back in time."

Ratt stumbled slightly but kept his eyes fixed on the ocarina, his concern deepening.

"You know what? I'm tired of being patronized and treated like garbage by clueless morons," I snapped, my voice shaking slightly, more raw than I'd meant to let show.

Ratt flinched, the mask of confidence crumbling as he took a hesitant step back. The confusion in his eyes gave way to something softer—worry, maybe even regret. And in that flicker, I saw not the flirtatious troublemaker, but a boy who simply didn’t understand the weight I carried.

"Don't move. Just sit still." I growled and put the ocarina to my lips.

The notes from the Song of Time swirled around us like golden ribbons in a storm, and Ratt's features contorted from idle amusement to utter disbelief. His jaw slackened, his eyes went wide with terror, and he clutched at the air as the ground vanished beneath us. As we sailed through the endless whiteness of the time stream, his breathing turned rapid and shallow, and he trembled violently, mouthing frantic words I couldn’t hear.

Tatl and I braced ourselves—this was familiar ground—but Ratt crumpled the moment the world slammed back into place, falling to his knees and retching violently onto the cobblestone. I recoiled from the sour stench, watching him struggle to push himself upright, sweat beading across his brow, his lips pale and trembling.

"Wha...what was that?" he rasped, voice thin with disbelief and horror.

"That was time travel." I candidly stated, grimacing and stepping away from the pool of vomit spreading on the ground.

"Holy gods…" He put a hand against his forehead while eyeing his surroundings. His breath hitched, and a tremble rolled through his body as he took in the unchanged plaza. Then he gasped, his eyes widening in a blend of awe and confusion. "Wait...gods! A-a-are you a goddess?"

Tatl suddenly burst into uproarious laughter and flopped onto my shoulder, trying to speak but unable to do so without laughing. Her wings beat erratically with amusement. I, myself, couldn't help but smile at the ridiculous sentiment, though it felt like a hollow bell tolling in my chest. A goddess. If only he knew how broken I still felt, how even being called a goddess made me feel lesser than I was originally.

"No, pretty far from it. But now if you'd excuse me, I have a world to save. Enjoy the rest of your life."

Ratt grabbed my hand before I could leave. I whirled around, reflexively ready to shove him away into the walls of the Clock Tower. But his hand clung to mine—not just in urgency, but in unspoken fear. His eyes were wide, searching, almost childlike in their plea. His grip trembled faintly against mine, and something about his unguarded vulnerability—raw and exposed—made me hesitate. The anger in my chest softened, and my heart stuttered with reluctant empathy, shadowed by a pang of understanding I hadn't wanted to feel.

"OK, say I believe you now... but I wasn't joking about the danger in the north. Word is that the land is cursed, frozen into an eternal winter, and that there's nothing left! It's gotten so bad that even Gorons are migrating south, which has never happened before! If you don't believe me, you can ask the Gorons themselves. A bunch are here in town right now!"

Tatl, finally recovering from her laughter, breathed in deep breaths to calm herself. Her wings shimmered with a subtle glint of curiosity as she fluttered up from her perch to face me, her expression laced with both amusement and a trace of wary interest.

"Whewwww… Well, oh goddess? Should we take this kid's advice?"

"Fine.." I conceded, "We might as well. Where are these Gorons, Ratt?"

"Well I know a few of them are waiting to see the mayor." The lad smiled and held his hand out to me. "I can take you there if you'd like? That is, if you don't mind being around another clueless moron?"

"Alright…" I sighed in reluctance, and cautiously let him take my hand.

The tower plaza was gradually filling with eager people as more stalls opened or prepared to open for business. We weaved around the growing crowds toward one of the plaza exits. Ratt pulled me along confidently between buildings and horse-drawn carts loaded with goods. The city was lively and full of sounds. Music from a variety of instruments swirled amongst laughter, bells, and a thousand conversations under a clear blue sky and cheery morning sun. Yet beneath the warmth and joy, I felt a tight, uneasy knot in my stomach—a flicker of anxiety that wouldn’t quite go away. The crowd’s cheer felt almost too perfect, too unaware. I couldn’t shake the sense that this world, so full of life, teetered silently on the brink of ending. If I hadn't known any better, I would never consider that this lively world could be dead in just a few days.

We continued on at a brisk, yet comfortable pace, turning onto a new street with fewer townsfolk traversing the road. The buildings, utilities, and surroundings became more decorative and luxurious as Ratt led us to what I assumed to be Clock Town's wealthier district. Several guards looked our way, expecting trouble, and more than a few of the residents turned up their noses at us.

"Rich snobs…" Ratt muttered under his breath. "Someday I'll show them…"

"Show them what?" I raised a curious brow.

"Hmm?" Ratt seemed surprised that I heard. "Oh… it's nothing. I just don't like the huge difference in wealth here. These people just hoard everything to themselves, showing off to everyone else how rich they are, and let others less fortunate starve without a thought. My mom would…." His voice dipped slightly, the anger thinning for just a moment. "My mom used to bring me here sometimes... back when she was still around. She always made it feel like the world wasn't so cruel, even here."

His voice trailed off. I thought I heard a faint quiver in it, but he quickly changed the subject again once he saw me staring.

"Oh...it's...uh...it's nothing, w-we're almost there, don't worry. The mayor's office is just up ahead, just don't cause any trouble since the guards here are the worst. I've been kicked and pushed around by them plenty of times in this part of town."

He quickly shook his head and forced a laugh, trying to cover the slip. "Anyway, let's just keep moving. No need to dwell on the past, right?""

"Why? Do you  cause trouble? Maybe you go around flirting with their wives?" I said with forced levity, though the edge in my tone betrayed a deeper frustration I hadn't intended to show. The words slipped out sharper than I meant.

"No, they just don't like the Bombers. See, I technically don't have a home...or uh... money. That's how most of us Bombers are. Jim, our leader, is the mayor's son. His mother absolutely hates this club though, probably since the rest of us are poor and all. She...kinda believes we're no better than a murderous, thieving bunch of criminals…actually that's what she believes all poor folks are like."

Ratt spoke in cold, angry tones, lost in thought, and I felt his grip slowly tense around my fingers—a pressure that caught me off guard. There was a quiet intensity in the way our hands remained joined, and something in that touch stirred a warmth I wasn’t ready to name. A flicker of guilt, of tenderness, maybe even attraction—it all twisted together, leaving me breathless with confusion.. A quiet pang of sympathy bloomed in my chest—his anger wasn't aimless, it was shaped by pain, by a life of being overlooked. I found myself squeezing his hand back, just slightly, unsure if I meant to comfort him or anchor myself in the midst of his rising frustration. He then quickly snapped back to the conversation and relaxed his hand.

"But Jim, he scorned his mother's hatred of the lower class. Even though he himself is just a kid, he saw us street urchins as equals and decided to help out by giving us all food and stuff. One day he comes down to our hideaway, all alone, and asks us if we want justice. Pretty much everyone, having lost everything to the upper class, says yes. He then brings us these fancy blue clothes and says that we're apart of an underground crew that fights for justice and good. See, he got his father to somehow sign a doctrine that makes our crew an official 'secret society of justice forever'… or something like that. The guards absolutely resent us for that, and think of us as nothing more than a joke…."

As if on cue, I ducked as I heard a small stone whizzing through the air and narrowly miss the boy's head. I turned to see two guards in gleaming silver armor laughing raucously as the stone loudly clattered off into an alleyway. I furiously pulled my hand free of Ratt's and made my way to the guffawing soldiers in burning rage with Tatl following suit.

"Hey! Did you just throw a rock at us!? " I shouted out, feeling an inner rage boil over.

"No, don't!" Ratt quickly wrapped around my arm and pulled me away. "You'll only get us in more trouble than it's worth!"

The guards saw this and laughed even harder, nearly coming to tears.

"Wahahaha! Better listen to your weasel boyfriend!"

"Hahaha, yeah! You don't want any of this!"

"Let me go!" I furiously wriggled to get out of Ratt's surprisingly strong grip. "I can take them all on!"

"I...urgh...bet you can!" The boy struggled to keep hold of me. "But there's….ugh...more of them than us!"

"N-no! I'm… going to teach.. them a...gah!" I gritted through my teeth, unable to wrench free.

"Please...stop...whew…. I'm o-only trying to help!"

"Link, he's right, there's more of them coming!" Tatl beseeched, fluttering in front of me. "Remember we're trying to save them, not hurt them?"

By now I had managed to be pulled some distance away from the two chuckle clucks who were sauntering off, and finally ceased my attempts to pull away.

"Why should we let them get away with that?" I glowered at Tatl. "Those bullies don't deserve to be saved!"

"Look…" Ratt spoke softly as he loosened my arm. "As much as I want to fight them, violence won't solve this problem. If we fight, we'll be seen as the villains, and then we'll be imprisoned or…..executed. It's not fair, and it's not right, but it's what has to be done for now. It's how we survive."

I turned to look him in the eyes to protest, expecting to see nothing but defeated weakness, like the hollow gazes of others I'd met who'd borne too much pain for too long. But instead, I saw something else entirely. I saw a fierce, indomitable determination in his sea-green gaze, a reflection of something I’d nearly forgotten in myself.... It reminded me of my own first taste of destiny, the moment I stopped being a child and chose to become a hero, all those years ago when I witnessed the death of the Deku Tree, and I saw my reflection in a pool I mourned at in losing my only father figure...with a blazing determination in my eyes that would never be smothered, a fire that refused to die, even when the world tried so hard to drown it.

"Uhh...right..." Ratt coughed as if to clear his throat, shattering through my reverie. "Maybe, uh, we should get going before more guards harass us."

"Good idea." I shook myself back to the moment, refocusing on our objective. "Lead the way."

I let Ratt get a little distance before following after him, trying to gather my thoughts. Tatl dropped down onto my right shoulder and moved in close to my ear.

"Hey, what was that all about? Are you feeling OK?" She muttered quietly, a note of sharpness in her voice that wasn't quite concern.

"I'm...not sure. I feel like I know him…" I whispered, catching the faintest glimmer of suspicion in Tatl’s eyes. She hovered just a little closer, her wings fluttering in front of me, as if to put distance between me and Ratt. Her gaze lingered on him a moment too long, shaded with something like jealousy, or maybe just fear of being left behind.

"Well, you did save his life last time. So you do kinda know him." The pixie shrugged, "Maybe all this time travel is going to your head?"

"Hmmm… yeah you're probably right... Let's just keep moving okay?"

"Sure sure, whatever you say."

With a final inquisitive glance at me, Tatl rose into the air again.

Just up ahead, Ratt had stopped in front of a large building resplendent in banners hanging from a marble balcony, colorful masks in all shapes and sizes, and various statuettes. Two soldiers in gold-trimmed white armor stood guard at the heavy wooden door, glaring suspiciously at the three of us but thankfully staying put.

"So...Link is it? This is the place, I'm uh...sorry you had to deal with that back there. That's just how the west side is... but the Gorons should be in there."

"Thanks, Ratt." I smiled, nodding my appreciation. "I guess I'll see you around then."

"Yeah, maybe." The boy grinned, and headed toward an alleyway across the street.

I stepped up to the door, pausing in case the two decorated guards decided to confront me, and went inside when neither moved. The large wooden door was fairly easy to push open, likely the hinges on every door were well greased in this part of town, and walked into a large lobby with green flooring, comfortable-looking couches in the corners, and an impressive model of the entire town taking up the center of the lobby. A glossy, dark red desk took up the far end of the room with hefty doors on either side of it. A mousey, green-haired secretary sat at the desk, silently shuffling papers and letters into separate piles. She hadn't noticed me yet, so I stepped up to the desk and asked about the Gorons. Without looking up from her piles, she politely answered.

"The Goron visitors and their emissary are in an important meeting right now with the mayor. I'm afraid you'll just have to wait until the meeting is finished."

We both jumped as something in the other room crashed onto the floor with a resounding boom, followed closely by the loud exclamations of what seemed to be furious arguments.

"Ummm, maybe it's best if you wait outside?" The secretary nervously stated.

"That sounds like a great idea." I replied in agreement, remembering just how strong Gorons were.

Just as I reached the entrance, something big and heavy flew through the now destroyed door on the left side of the desk. It crashed into the wall with a groan, which turned out to be a crumpled soldier. A hulking Goron angrily stomped out of the ruined doorway and was trailed by two other, smaller Gorons. I expeditiously moved out of their way as they trudged out the main door. Two guards rushed out of the room to check on their comrade and a smallish figure peeked out from the demolished door. The man seemed extremely high strung, and had deep, dark circles beneath his maroon-colored eyes. His thinning blue hair was drawn back into strange, horn like shapes and he wore dark, officious clothing.

"Ohhh dear… what else could possibly go wrong…?" He sighed in exhaustion and put a defeated hand upon his head.

"Mr. Mayor? What happened in there?" The secretary cried out.

"Ohhh…. just Gorons being Gorons. I wouldn't worry too much, I have a feeling they'll be leaving soon….I hope." He mumbled that last part to himself.

Seeing my opportunity to catch the Gorons, I dashed out the door in pursuit. Thankfully they didn't get very far, and I rushed before them and confronted the apparent leader, who halted and peered down at me in confusion. Townsfolk rushed to get away from the strange, potentially dangerous sight, and the cowardly guards kept eyes on us from a distance.

"What do you want, tiny human? Come to gawk at us like the others?" The massive Goron, who was easily three times my size, questioned.

"I've heard you had some trouble up north, brothers!" I tried to sound as aggressive and intimidating as I could in my effeminate voice, though a flicker of self-consciousness tugged at me—an awkward reminder of the strange dissonance I still felt inside my shifted form. "I want to help!" I declared, but the words trembled slightly in the air, caught between defiance and something deeper. A mix of desperation and conviction burned behind my eyes. This was more than bravado. It was a plea to matter, to fight back against helplessness. It was always my destiny....to take on burdens no one else could, to rise when others fell, even when I wasn’t sure who I truly was.



The Gorons were silent, likely contemplating if I was insane or joking, but the leader finally spoke up.

"Tiny Human, not even our fiercest warrior could save our home. He was mighty indeed, and take no offense, but you are not even half his size…" The mountainous creature mused. "I must thank you for your kind gesture though. It was the first offer we received in this wretched city."

"I understand, brother. But I can assure you that I am capable! Surely there must be a way I can prove this?"

"Hmmmmmmm…." The Goron grumbled in deep thought. "You speak like our own kind, have you... dealt with us before?"

"Yes, as a matter of fact, in my homeland I was made a Sworn Brother." I replied, as confidently as I could manage.

"...You? Are a Sworn Brother?" They all seemed surprised, and the leader spoke up again. " Either you are a deplorable liar, or our knowledge of humans is sadly defunct. Are you not a…hmm what do they call it...mother human?"

"No...I mean- yes...ugh. Look, things are different where I'm from, I was accepted as part of the Goron family for saving their land."

"How odd… Very well, we actually have a more immediate problem you can help with. Solve it, and you will have proven yourself."

"No problem, brother. Tell me what you need?"

"Hmmmm…." The Goron spoke a bit uncertainly, "The human chief here refused to help us. It is fortunate you offered to help though, one of our young was stolen from us last night as we rested from our long journey. We know it was a group of humans and followed them here, but we are now lost and frustrated in this horrid city."

"I'm very sorry that such an evil crime was committed by my kind. I shall do my best to right this wrong, and bring your child back, or die trying!"

"Good, I pray you find him, kind, er...brother." The Goron leader nodded his satisfaction. "The child is critical to our future survival, especially if Snowhead is truly lost to us. You have been entrusted with a great burden, tiny human—may your courage carry you through. We shall be outside the northern walls of this awful city, away from this toxic air. Find us there, should you save our young."

With that, the Gorons all tromped off toward the northern park, parting the small stream of timid people like boulders in a river. I decided to go find Ratt once more, who seemed to be my best chance at finding this lost Goron kid. I turned to ask Tatl her opinion, only to discover that Ratt had been standing beside her for who knows how long.

"Heh, Sworn Brother, eh?" Ratt teased, his eyes glinting with mischief as a crooked grin tugged at his lips. He rocked back on his heels slightly, arms crossing with playful confidence.

"Yeah...um.. How long were you eavesdropping there?" I asked in slight annoyance, walking over to them both.

"Pretty much the entire time, you're pretty brave for blocking off an angry Goron like that. I was simply standing right here as...I dunno...back up? Someone had to pull you outta the way in case they decided to keep going."

"I have a feeling I'd be the one saving you… again," I retorted with a teasing smirk, catching the faintest blush flicker across Ratt's face before he looked away, suddenly fascinated by the ground.

"Anyway, I guess you spared me the inconvenience of tracking you down. I assume you heard about this lost Goron. Do you have any idea where this kid is?"

"Nope…" Ratt shook his head. "But I think I know who to ask. That is, if you want my help."

"Hmm…." I put a finger on my chin, pretending to weigh my options. "On one hand, you are  pretty annoying. But on the other, you seem to know what you're doing… Yeah, I guess you can help this time."

"Oh come on already!" Tatl loudly interjected, flying in between us. "Get a room, you two, or let's get going! We're wasting daylight!"

"Right. Sorry… enough playing around." I agreed, embarrassed at my own immaturity. "Where do we go, Ratt?"

"Well, the Goron said that their kid was stolen by a group of humans, right? I know a place where stolen things have a tendency to turn up. I have to warn you though, it's not exactly the safest place in town…"

"I highly doubt it'll be more dangerous than I am," I replied, but the words felt strange in my mouth—like I was borrowing someone else's voice. A flicker of doubt passed through me, quickly buried beneath my usual bravado.

"Yep, we can handle anything you throw at us. You have no idea what we've been through." Tatl nodded, adding her own input.

"You know, strangely enough I believe you." Ratt conceded, suddenly smiling with enthusiasm. "I gotta say, you two have definitely made my life more exciting!"

Chapter Thirty

The Wild Side

The sun had reached its apex by the time we left the lavish neighborhoods of west Clock Town, and the soothing coolness of the morning had been replaced by a humid heat. Although the terrifying moon had reappeared in the sky, looking almost as big as its heavenly counterpart, no one seemed to notice or care. The cobblestone streets crowded with townsfolk and tourists only seemed to increase the muggy temperature to a sweltering oven.
