"I wasn't lying, goatbrain." Tatl chimed, flitting in closer. "This is Link, now let's-!"

The pixie went silent when we all heard several voices approach, and I wasn't going to wait around to let them find us. Especially since with each passing minute, I was growing weaker and more fatigued. I groaned in frustration and gripped Ratt's arm tightly and began to sprint down the street, dragging him along after me in the opposite direction of the advancing pirate rabble.

"Hey wait! What..? Stop!" Ratt loudly objected.

I ignored his cries to go back, but he eventually simmered down as we fled through twisting alleys and winding streets slick with rain. Each footfall sent a jolt of pain up my right side, the wound throbbing hot and deep beneath my tunic. I was for once grateful for the downpour, not just for the cooling effect it had on my shoulder, but for the haze it cast over the city, masking us from the Blood Wolves' eyes. We had kicked the nest, and they would hunt us down like their namesake. If Lukhan lived—and I feared he did—he wouldn’t stop until I was back in his grip. He wasn't Ganondorf, but the dread that coiled in my stomach said he was close enough.

Eventually, after what felt like an eternity of weaving through the labyrinthine backstreets and narrow passages of the city, we emerged into the edge of the shopping district. The cobbled roads were slick with rain and lined with shuttered stalls and closed shopfronts, their signs creaking faintly in the wind. A few townsfolk darted beneath awnings or held sacks over their heads as makeshift umbrellas, their eyes briefly scanning our disheveled forms before quickly looking away. No one wanted trouble. Especially not the kind trailing behind us.

I could barely keep my feet under me. My legs trembled with every step, my breaths were short, shallow, and rattling. My tunic clung to me, soaked in both blood and rain, the poisoned wound in my shoulder now radiating an inferno that pulsed with every heartbeat. Tatl clung to my uninjured shoulder, shouting something I barely heard through the pounding in my skull. I staggered into a side alley, vision swimming, and collapsed against a crate slick with grime and water, using it to stay upright as the world tilted and darkened around the edges.

"Link, take off the mask! Your body can't handle it anymore!" Tatl exclaimed in worry, trying to peel my face off with her own hands.

I nodded and shakily put a gauntlet up to my face. Ratt only glanced at me before starting to make his way out of the alley, but Tatl rushed over to stop him.

"Hey, where are you going? You still gotta take us to that Goron!"

"Not without Link, Tatl. Thanks for rescuing me and all, but this guy here is a jerk! If you really are her friend, you'll come help me."

Before he turned to leave, I managed to pull my mask off, fingers trembling as they gripped the cold, wet edges. The magic surged violently through me, twisting my form with a sharp, breath-stealing pain. My bones compressed, muscles shifting, armor straining against a reshaping body. I let out a strangled cry, the effort shredding the last thread of strength I had left, and began to revert back to my female body—shivering, rain-soaked, and barely conscious as nausea and exhaustion crashed over me in waves. Having no energy left, I collapsed to the watery ground, unable to move.

"Link?! Link was that really you?? Gods—you're hurt... you're really  hurt!" Ratt's voice cracked as he dashed to my side and dropped to his knees, cradling my head gently from the cold, rain-slick stone. His hands trembled as they brushed soaked hair from my face, and I could see the shock and guilt etched into every line of his expression. "No, no, no... stay with me, okay? You're gonna be fine. Just—just stay awake. Please."

I opened my mouth to answer, but I couldn't manage to get anything out other than a gasp, my throat tightening as a bitter copper tang coated my tongue. Pain pulsed in my skull, my limbs went numb, and the cold, slick stone beneath me seemed to rise up like a wave. The world blurred and tilted, swallowing me in black. quickly noticing my vision begin to darken. The last thing I saw before blacking out was Ratt's face etched with worry as he leaned over me…



Chapter Thirty-Three

The Great Escape



"How's she doing, Anju? Any improvement? Has she woken up at all?"

"I don't know, the wound was frightfully infected when you brought her to me. Looks like the work of some kind of toxin... I've done the best I can, I'm afraid. All that you can do now is wait."

"We can't wait, lady! We have to get to the mountains by tomorrow morning!

"I'm sorry, Tatl, really… but it's a miracle your friend was even breathing by the time I cleaned her wounds…."

After faintly hearing bits and pieces of conversation that sounded far away, awareness gradually came back to me in rising waves—like seawater lapping against a fractured hull. I felt the cold press of damp blankets against my skin, the weight of exhaustion like stones on my chest, and a slow throb behind my eyes. Every breath was effort. Every inch of return to consciousness was a climb up from drowning. My body felt like every inch of it had become a wrung out dishrag, and I couldn't move my arms or legs. I had no clue where I was, and all that I did know was that I was lying on something soft and wrapped in blankets. Which definitely wasn't like the stony street that I remembered collapsing on. Did I get moved somewhere?

My eyes slowly opened, taking their time to adjust to the flickering warmth of a burning fireplace and the golden glow of several large candles. The faint scent of beeswax hung in the air, mingling with the smoky tang of firewood, and the crackle of flames provided a steady rhythm beneath the low murmur of voices. Shadows danced gently on the walls, giving the room a dreamlike quality as my blurred vision tried to bring it all into focus. I could hardly move anything at all, but I glanced around as much as I could. Ratt paced anxiously, wringing his hands and casting frequent glances toward the bed; Tatl hovered mid-air, her glow flickering with agitation; and Anju stood with arms crossed, her brow furrowed in deep concern. The three of them clustered together in the dim, candlelit room, speaking in hushed but urgent tones. I assumed we were in the Stockpot Inn, and judging from the conversation, I had nearly died from...poison? So Lukhan had poisoned his blades then. Typical of an honorless thug...

I tried my best to rise from the bed, but a searing jolt of pain flared through my shoulder, and my muscles trembled as though each fiber had forgotten how to obey. All I managed was a feeble twitch of my arms, as if gravity itself was conspiring to keep me pinned. That slight movement was enough to attract their attention however, as they all rushed over to me.

"Link! You're awake!" Ratt breathed, his voice cracking with emotion. Tears pricked at the corners of his eyes as his tense shoulders finally sagged, overcome with relief. "Oh thank the gods…"

"You had me worried sick, dummy!" Tatl exclaimed, her voice trembling slightly as she tapped my nose in mock admonishment. Her glow flickered unevenly, betraying the lingering fear beneath her words. "Stop trying to die on me, okay? Just… don’t do that again."

"Careful, you two. She still needs time to recover." Anju, the redheaded innkeeper, gently warned before looking at me. "How do you feel, dear?"

I opened my mouth to say that I felt like I'd been through a wheat grinder, but the words clung to my tongue like glue. My throat burned with dryness, and frustration pricked at the corners of my mind—how could I not even manage a sentence? My body, weak and uncooperative, reminded me just how close I’d come to the edge. I tried sitting up, but was gently kept in place by Anju.

"No no, Miss Link! You mustn't try to move, dear. I still need to stitch up your shoulder. I'll go get you a cup of water for your throat though..." Anju patted my leg beneath the wool blankets, then turned to leave. "Ratt, please don't let her move. I'll be back in a minute."

I heard the door open and close. Then Ratt approached me again, pulling up something wooden to sit on.

"Hey… I'm sorry I was so rude to you in that alley," Ratt began, his voice softer than usual, a flicker of guilt in his eyes. He rubbed the back of his neck awkwardly and avoided my gaze for a moment before finally meeting it with a look of sincere remorse. "I didn't know it really was you…but, I mean, that was amazing! You have all these awesome magic weapons, time traveling flutes, and shapeshifting masks! I'm not sure what Tatl meant about your curse, but... you're incredible! As for all that back there...well, I can't thank you two enough for saving me."

"Hah! Saving you? I regret breaking you out of that dungeon already—do you have any idea how close Link came to dying? And now you're sitting there grinning like it was all some grand adventure! It's your fault Link almost died, you little toad! If it weren't for you, he wouldn't be lying here!" Tatl angrily accused, slapping the boy in the head.

"Ok...yeah… I deserve that," Ratt murmured, his voice low and heavy with guilt. His brows pinched together and he rubbed his arm, eyes flicking briefly to me before dropping again. "If it wasn't for my stupid fight with the Blood Wolves… you'd probably be in the mountains by now. None of this would've happened."

I slowly turned my head, inch by painstaking inch, to scold Tatl and tell her the blame was my own. Yet, my voice refused to cooperate with me, so I tried my best to force my face into an angry expression. All of a sudden the door opened, interrupting the quarrel, and in came Anju carrying a stone mug of water and a small leather satchel. She walked over to the bed, gently lifted my head, and carefully tipped the lifegiving liquid into my mouth.

"Alright now, not too fast, dear. Drink slowly… that's it."

The water tasted infinitely sweet and felt like a cool, soothing river flowing through the parched desert of my throat. For a brief, precious moment, I felt relief ripple through my chest—a fragile comfort that stilled the storm of pain. It was difficult for me not to try to gulp the whole thing down, but I heeded her instructions and sipped slowly. I was glad I did, because as soon as the liquid hit my stomach, I felt nauseous. After I coughed up the water remaining in my throat into the cup, the kindly innkeeper pulled it away.

"Ok, I hope that feels a bit better." Anju said as she set the mug down on a nearby table, and opened up the tiny satchel. "However, I must stitch that shoulder up before it becomes infected again."

She moved to my right and took a curved bone needle from her satchel with some thin twine. I inwardly flinched as the tiny point pierced my skin, but hardly felt anything at all as the twine pulled the skin over the wound. A competent innkeeper, a skilled physician, a diligent sister.... Anju moved with the quiet confidence of someone who’d carried others through pain like this before. Her touch was steady, her voice gentle, and even her frown seemed to promise safety. what wasn't this woman good at? With a slight tug and snip later, Anju sealed the wound and re-bandaged it.

"There you go, now all that you need is a few days of rest. But please, don't go playing in that dreadful sewer again, young miss. You were very lucky to come out with only an infected scratch. And Ratt, shame  on you for taking her there in the first place! I swear I don't understand you boys and your disgusting hideouts! It's bad enough that Jim sneaks around down there, but involving her in your schemes is appalling!" Anju chided the sullen-faced boy, thumping him with her finger. "Now... I have to go back to work downstairs, someone is bound to show up in this dreadful weather. If you need me, I'll be at the desk in the lobby. Oh, and if you get hungry later I have soup cooking in the kitchen. You know where that is, Ratt."

With that, Anju quietly shut the door, leaving the three of us to talk. Seeing the slight confusion in my eyes, Ratt gave a sheepish smile, his brows knit together with concern, and rubbed the back of his neck before beginning to clarify Anju's previous statement.

"Yeah...I had to tell her a little white lie about us playing in the sewer. She would've turned us away if we mentioned anything about the Blood Wolves. Her mom, the mayor's awful wife, has a little deal with them. Basically they have free reign in their territory as long as they don't cross lines, and the town guard won't harass them. All in the name of 'avoiding a costly war' in her terms. Anju is the exact opposite of her mother, but she would've refused to deal with you if you were connected in any way to those brutes."

"Oh...thank you…" Was all I could manage to utter.

I inwardly groaned in irritation as a dull throb pulsed from my wound, echoing with each frustrated heartbeat. How long was it going to take to even move? My arms felt like lead, and a faint ache curled through my limbs, sharpening the helplessness that gripped me.? How badly was I injured? What time was it? I couldn't even see a window. I had places to get to, a Goron child to rescue… if the Gorons were even still there…and I had to get to those northern mountains.

"Hey, Link, don't worry." My fairy companion rubbed my forehead, noticing the frustration in my eyes. "I know you must be fretting over the Goron and the mountains. But, you have no idea how close to death you were. You need rest, ok?"

"No...ugh...I have to...get up!" I gasped, struggling to rise.

"Link please, we're serious." Ratt put pressure on my good shoulder to keep me pinned. "You're gonna need at least half your strength. This may be a safe place for now, but as soon as we leave, the Blood Wolves are gonna be onto us and plan another ambush."

"Ugh...fine." I relented, suddenly feeling thirsty again. "Water...please?"

"Good, and yes of course!" Ratt happily obliged and returned the cup of water to my lips.

I managed to drink down a few sips, until the ground started to rumble. Ratt pulled the glass away, standing up from his chair and glanced around apprehensively.

"What is that?"

"The moon, idiot." Tatl stated, almost nonchalantly.

"The moon? Like that creepy-faced moon we saw yesterday? So… it really is gonna fall unless you two stop it…" The concerned boy ignored the fairy's insult.

I feebly nodded and Ratt sat back down in despair.

"Man… So, everything the Bombers have been fighting for… all the wrongs needing to be made right…. it doesn't mean a thing after all. We're doomed anyway..."

"Pretty much." The obnoxious fairy sneered.

"No." I muttered hoarsely in disagreement, giving Tatl a stern look. "It...does matter. This world…*huff*... isn't over yet."

"You really think it'll survive? Even if you guys manage to stop the moon? I mean, look at all the evil this world has in it, and what good has this world ever done for you? Look at yourself, Link. You're lying on what we thought was your deathbed, barely able to move or talk! All because of those villains you're trying to save…-sigh-... I don't know how you do it….or why."

Ratt was silent for a while, just blankly gazing at the floor. I tried mustering what little strength I had to speak.

"I...do it because...of people like you, Ratt. Yes…-huff- there is evil...and corruption. But, there...is also a lot of...good, and -huff-... purity. We have to...fight for it…-gasp-... If not, what else do we have?"

The strain of speaking for so long was, pathetically, far too much for my body to handle. Exhausted, I shut my eyes and focused on calming my heavy breathing. Ratt remained silent, as did Tatl. The only sound in the room was the gentle crackling of the lively fireplace, and would have almost been peaceful if not for the subject of doom looming on everyone's thoughts. A faint peel of thunder rumbled outside, and I suddenly felt a light touch on my good shoulder. Opening my eyes and tilting my head to the left, I saw Ratt with renewed determination burning within his eyes. His face no longer held the awkward smirk that seemed permanently plastered on his lips, but a serious, willful grimace that seemed misplaced on the normally light-hearted boy.

"You're right, Link. I know I've been a burden on you and Tatl...but I want to be better. I've tried to make this town better, I've helped a few people, sure...but it's nothing compared to what you can probably do. If you had to, you could probably save an entire kingdom!"

"Umm….I have…" I muttered weakly.

"Ha, exactly! You'll have to tell me about that story later… But, well...if it's not too much to ask...I want you to train me. If you, uh... want to that is…"

"Pfft! Train you? Why would Link waste any time on you? You're just a street urchin. Haven't you done enough to him?" Tatl bemoaned and flew in between me and Ratt.

"Tatl...I know I've been a terrible friend, I do. I can take your abuse. But Link can't defend herself, so cool it on the insults ok?" Ratt sternly upbraided the white fairy.

"What are you talking about, moron? I'm not mocking him. I'm telling you to step off!"

"You keep calling Link him ! I know it must be a jab at that mask form, but now is not the time."

"Ughh you imbecile! Link is a man!  The mask form is his real form ! Remember the curse I was talking about?"

Ratt was abruptly taken aback, looking down at me, then at Tatl, then back to me.

"Link… is Tatl bothering you? I can make her wait outside if you-"

"Put me outside? I'd like to see you try! I may be small, but I've knocked out badbats  worse than you!"

Tatl angrily swooped in front of Ratt's face, her wings buzzing with irritation, while Ratt clenched his fists and leaned forward, his jaw tight and eyes narrowed. The room crackled with their unspoken challenge, but I quickly broke the tension the only way I could. With a few soft coughs, I managed to get their attention again and Ratt leaned over me, while Tatl fluttered close to my face.

"Are you ok, Link?" They both asked in unison.

"Wa..ter…" I wheezed and, after Ratt poured a little of the life-giving fluid into my mouth, continued with an explanation. "Tatl is...right...I was a man… Skullkid…*huff*...cursed me, so here I am…"

"Oh… Wait, what? You… were actually transformed into a girl ?" Ratt dubiously responded, but after double checking  my serious expression, he sat down. "Holy cucco…why? And how? Aren't skull kids normally...like... powerless forest creatures? I've heard stories of them pulling pranks… but, well… never  anything like that."

"He has this powerful mask, and uses it for cruel pranks." Tatl chimed in and paraphrased my story, with her tone thankfully less accusatory towards Ratt. "I know, cuz... I was Skull Kid's friend… once anyway. Basically me, my brother, and Skull Kid were playing in the woods one day. We found Link here riding this awesome horse, ambushed him and stole the horse. Link followed, and bibbity bobbity boop, Skull Kid cursed him. Now the only way Link can return to his former body is through his mask."

Ratt rubbed his temples thoughtfully, his eyes wide and brows furrowed, as the weight of the story settled on him like a heavy cloak. A trace of disbelief flickered across his face, quickly replaced by something deeper—shock, maybe, or awe—as he looked from Tatl to me and back again, trying to fit the pieces together in his mind. I looked up at Tatl, who had guilt written over her petite features. I knew she still felt bad about her part in everything. I was about to say something to console her, but before I could, Ratt slapped his knees in conviction and rose from his creaky stool.

"Link… we're going to find a way to save you." The willful boy leaned over me to look me in the eye. "First of all, I believe your story. Mutoh, the person I went to see the other night, was also transformed into something, a man-bull thing, and said something about a wicked trickster wearing a dark mask. This monster must be the one causing the moon to fall, too! I can help you, but you just gotta train me to fight like you can! I am ready and willing to learn."

"Ohhh no. You're not tagging along." Tatl refused before I could utter a response. "We have enough problems as it is, ok? Ok. Good. Glad we solved that."

"What can I do to prove that I can help?" Ratt pleaded, more to me than Tatl.

"You know what? How about you start by finding a way to heal Link? Pfft... Oh, wait, if you leave you'll be caught by your friends. Yeah, go do that." The fairy sarcastically replied.

"Alright. Hold on, Link. I'll be back soon."

W-wait it's pitch black outside! I was only kidding abo-!"

The door opened and shut with a soft click  before Tatl finished her sentence.

"Welp...he's as good as dead…"

"Why did you… do that?" I scowled at the fairy, feeling my anger rise.

"I didn't think he would actually go out there ! I'm sorry, I'll go get him real quick."

Tatl zipped over to the door, and I heard her loud attempts at opening it.

"Stupid door! Just….open…! Ughh! Why... won't... you...open!"

A few minutes of pulling, shoving, and kicking passed until the pixie finally gave up on her futile attempts at opening the door.

"I can't get it open…" Tatl sadly stated as she returned to my side, her wings drooping a little. "I guess I shouldn't have been so harsh… sorry." She hovered lower, her glow dimming slightly, a flicker of genuine regret crossing her usually brash voice.

I sighed at my companion's appalling behavior, and closed my eyes. If Ratt didn't return with something helpful, if he returned at all for that matter, I would need more strength to go find him or the goron. If there was still time to do anything at all.

Wait… what time is it?

I opened my eyes and glimpsed Tatl sitting beside my head.

"What time is it… anyway?" I inquired in a frail voice.

"Oh, yeah… well, it's definitely after dark. You were out for a long time…"

"Great…"

"You know," Tatl shuffled closer to my face, "How come it's always the second day that gives us the most trouble? Is it the rain? Or is the entire world out to get us on this particular day?"

I had to smile at her observation, it seemed odd that we were always up this same creek every cycle of the second day. Yet, I could see a kind of dark humor in it as well.

"Ha… yeah. I guess we're… just lucky." I breathed in response, suddenly feeling the exhaustion from so much conversation take over. "But I'm... feeling… really tired. I'm gonna… just take a...nap…"

My eyelids fell shut like heavy stone doors and I was fast asleep in moments. It felt like only a few minutes passed when I heard Tatl call my name and felt the warmth of her tiny hand patting my shoulder, rousing me from a dreamless sleep. The scent of old wood and faint herbs filled the air, and I blinked against the soft amber glow of candlelight flickering on the inn’s wooden walls. and felt someone pat my shoulder.

"Link, hey Link! Wake up, Ratt actually pulled it off!" Her excited voice echoed in the small room.

My eyes opened again to see Tatl hovering over my face, and I turned my head and noticed that the triumphant boy stood beside me, holding a bottle of something shiny in his hand.

"Is that…?" I inquired in apprehensive excitement.

"Hehe yup! A pink fairy." Ratt chuckled, opening the bottle to release the tiny helper. "The Great Fairy let one of her children come with me. But it was weird, she acted like she knew you two already?"

"She remembered us? Wow! Most forget we even exist… it must be because she's the Great Fairy." Tatl presumed with a shrug as her kin fluttered to me.

"Yes, the Great Mother remembers you saving her from certain doom." The pink fairy spoke in a sweetly child-like voice. "She also desires to repay the favor!"

The healing pixie swirled around me and immediately set to work. A soft pink glow radiated from her tiny body, leaving behind a trail of sparkles that melted into my skin like warm raindrops. I felt a tingling warmth sink into my flesh, knitting torn muscles and cleansing the lingering sting of poison in my veins. My breathing deepened, the ache in my bones slowly receding as strength trickled back into me like sunlight returning after a storm. My fingers twitched, then flexed. My chest loosened. And then, with a tremble, I sat up, gasping softly. The blanket slipped from my shoulders, and a sudden draft chilled my now-sensitive skin, making me acutely aware of my bare arms.

Looking down, I felt a cold spike of vulnerability shoot through me as I realized I was wearing nothing but a simple, brown bra. My skin prickled with goosebumps from the drafty room, and I scrambled to pull the bedsheets higher to cover myself. Embarrassed, Ratt quickly turned away and dashed over to a nearby table where my clothes were placed, dry and neatly folded. Keeping his face turned, he handed the garments to me, and I swiftly pulled the brown tunic over my head just as the tiny healer finished her miracle work.

"Pfft...show off…" I heard Tatl mutter under her breath, clearly annoyed by the pink fairy's useful magic.

"All done! Mother will be happy that I was able to help!" the pink fairy cheerfully hummed, either not catching Tatl's comment or choosing not to care. "But now I've gotta get back to my family. If you would kindly let me out, please?"

"Oh yeah, no problem!" Ratt obliged and opened the door.

As the fairy exited with a polite 'thank you,' I pulled my legs—thankfully clothed—out from under the blanket and set my bare feet onto the cool wood flooring of the room. I gently rose, testing my balance, still wincing faintly at the lingering soreness in my limbs. Tatl bobbed in the air, but something in her movements felt gentler than usual—like a flicker of relief disguised in playful energy.

"You're okay!" she blurted, her voice just a little too loud with emotion. "Well, for now anyway.... A-at least until I have to come save you again, haha!"

I looked at her more closely—she was hovering a little too low, her light dimmer than usual, and there was a hitch in her voice she couldn't quite hide.

"Oho you're so funny, Tatl," I replied with soft sarcasm as I walked over to the table holding the rest of my gear. "But I think it was Ratt who came through this time."

"What? I didn't do anything… if anything I was just making up for getting you in that position in the first place," Ratt said with a touch of guilt.

"Shyeah! You did cause us all that grief!" Tatl flitted before him, but her tone had softened just slightly. "But… you did throw yourself to the wolves—literally—in order to help Link. I guess that counts for something. But you're still a moron."

I caught a flicker of something strange in Tatl’s eyes—maybe a hint of respect, or even gratitude.

"Don't worry, Ratt. She'll warm up to you eventually," I said with a small smile, sliding on my scaled, green cloak and gloves. "You should've seen us when we first met. Hmm… actually, now that I think about it, we haven't really changed much heehee!"

"Hey! That's only because you always do dumb stuff!" Tatl huffed. "Like... blabbing your mouth while we should be moving on! We only have one day left to get to those mountains, you know?"

"Ok ok, I hear you. Don't worry though, I've got my ocarina still. Even if we don't make it to the mountains, we'll try again next cycle," I said while pulling on my boots and slinging the lustrous bow around my back. "Ratt, if you would, please lead on and take us to the kid?"

"Yeah, no problem! It's...ah... good to see you up on your feet again. We just have to get to the west market. The guy there is open all night, which is honestly perfect timing, I'd say."

Ratt waited for me to gather the rest of my things, then opened the door. We quietly left the room. I considered thanking Anju again for her immense kindness, but the urgency of our situation held my tongue. She was likely asleep anyway. I would find a way to repay her...truly...when I could.

The inn was silent, though candles burned in wall sconces that cheerily lit the quaint second-floor hallway. The faint creak of ancient floorboards echoed beneath our steps, mingling with the subtle scent of old wood and melted wax. A trail of damp puddles along the hardwood floor, likely left by Ratt, led downstairs into the main lobby. No one manned the front desk at this hour, so we slipped out the front door and into the sparsely lit streets lying under a black, cloud-smothered sky.

"Ok, so it shouldn't be long if we keep to the main streets. Everyone's asleep, so it'll be easy going," Ratt said as we started walking. "I didn't see any sign of the Blood Wolves. Hopefully they gave up for the night. Speaking of… how did you escape from their boss? I've never met him personally, but I've heard he's practically unbeatable! Some say he wears armor blessed with dark magic."

"Well, funny story actually. He kinda just... gave me my mask and told me to entertain him."

"Hahaha what?! I bet you did just that! I wish I could've seen the surprise in his eyes as you gutted him like the swine he was…"

"Umm, actually he was pretty quick on his feet... and probably the toughest human opponent I've fought in a long time. I didn’t get a killing blow, but it seems he almost did with those poisoned blades. Honorless scum…" I growled in contempt.

"Hey, I'm just glad you got away—and got us all out alive, for that matter." Ratt paused, eyes lingering on mine with a flicker of awe and something deeper, a yearning. "But I was serious earlier when I asked you about the training thing…"

He rubbed the back of his neck, voice softening. His eyes looked deep into mine, stirring that weird sensation in my chest once again.

"I want to save people. I want to do what you do. You're... you're like the kind of hero I always imagined as a kid—strong, fearless, someone who makes  things right. I want to learn how to do that too."

"Look kid, you helped Link out a ton…" Tatl cut in, "But I don't think you would survive one minute as a—"

"Ratt…" I interrupted with a weary sigh. "You don't want my life. Being a warrior means committing yourself to a life of violence, and pain. Just look at where it got me…"

I gestured to my cursed body, but the boy simply shrugged.

"I see nothing wrong. So you got turned into a female  warrior. So what? That's not stopping you from saving an entire world. So why would I stop asking you to train me to do the same?"

"I...ugh…"

I had no response. The kid sounded just like I did when I was younger—back when I was a child just beginning his adventure in Kokiri Forest. I may have been Ratt’s age in body, but I was at least double it in mind.

"You're way too headstrong for your own good." I conceded, "I... suppose I could show you a few things… But you aren't coming to the mountains with us. You need to stay in town where it's relatively safe…"

"...Safe? Ohhh not for you, I'm afraid…"

We all stopped in our tracks to search for the disembodied voice of Lukhan, who must have been hidden in the shadows ahead. Unfortunately, dozens of angry, raggedy pirates slowly stepped out of nearby alleyways and closed storefronts, all rushing to surround us. I cursed our rotten luck as I took a more defensive stance.

"You see, Sinrah. I own this city. I have men in every district, and when I don't… well, everything is for sale, even loyalty. My influence strikes fear into even the mayor himself!"

Lukhan finally revealed himself with a slow, deliberate step into the amber glow of a burning street lamp. His presence was heralded by the metallic hiss of twin scimitars unsheathing, the sound sending a chill down my spine. A faint, acrid scent of smoke and blood clung to him, as if the violence he wrought followed him like a shroud. He smiled, cold and predatory, the expression twisting the raw, unbandaged wound across the left side of his face—a wicked, jagged cut that traced his cheek like a grim badge of vengeance. Thirty meters away, he simply stood there....silent, looming, terrible.

"Ah yes, do you like this little gift you've left me with? I rather fancy it myself. In fact, I fancy it so much I may just share it with you! Your companions, however, will be slaughtered in front of you. Much like you slaughtered my best man. Rastil will rest easy, knowing you suffered before your slow, painful demise."

"Link!" Tatl hissed urgently, "Play your ocarina...hurry!"

I nodded, and from the look on Ratt's face I knew he understood, too. We all huddled together as the pirate thugs closed off any escape route. Lukhan approached slowly, wary of any surprises. I carefully went for my instrument, watching the boss like a hawk. His malicious smile widened as he saw me reaching further into my cloak.

"Ah yes, show me the warrior! I would relish another duel, haha!"

When my hand came out with the ocarina instead, Lukhan's cocky smile instantly twisted into a snarl. He roared and came sprinting toward us, but the instrument was already to my lips. I played the Song of Time with my heart racing and eyes closed. Each beautiful note seemed to echo out in waves of azure molasses. The world itself seemed to slow down, and all noise faded into the background…

When I finished the magical tune, my eyes opened to see Lukhan and his blades inches from my face. My galloping heart skipped a beat, expecting a killing blow. But it was too late for his strike to connect. The town around us swirled and stretched into white lines, which expanded until all four of us were engulfed in an ocean of white. Lukhan's eyes bulged with fear and shock, and he screamed in rage as he began to fade from our sight. The last traces I saw of him before completely disappearing were his eyes, focused on mine and filled with a furious, immeasurable hate...



Chapter Thirty-Four

Deserted


The sight of immense cliffs and towering stone formations greeted Majora's gaze, the baking heat pressing down on him like a physical weight. The scent of scorched stone and dry, bitter sagebrush filled the air, evoking a wave of sun-bleached memories from his youth. on his return to the land of his ancestors. A cloudless blue sky hung over a sun-blasted wasteland, all without the hint of a breeze to ease the relentless heat pouring from the sun. Despite the harsh landscape, Majora welcomed the familiar surroundings of his childhood and took a deep breath. The scents of dry dust and acrid desert flowers filled his nostrils, and a smile crossed Majora's lips from beneath the dark mask.

"Home, sweet home. Almost."

Spotting the faded symbol of a circular, cyan eye that marked the trail to his village, Majora widened his smile and started down the path.

The canyon trail was only a few feet in width, with steep cliffs on either side creating a maze of claustrophobia. Although it was the main road to the village, the path looked as if it hadn't been used in years. Sharp stones from broken cliffsides lay strewn along the road, along with patches of weedy, thorned shrubbery. Cracked and broken sculptures, carved into the cliffsides by the slaves, depicted faceless, yet powerful figures—legendary warriors and ancient sages of Sheikah lore, their features long since worn away by time and neglect.

"Fools. All of them," Majora uttered. "No need for the dead to be remembered."

With a wave of his hand, dark energy surged into the rock and obliterated the remains of the carvings, creating a vast cloud of dust within the canyon. The statues wouldn't be the only victims this day. Majora planned a similar fate for his former tribe. All he wanted was strength for his people—he gave them the solution to their problems! The council asked for a tool that rivaled the very essence of the gods, an equal to the Triforce itself. Majora and his acolytes created that power, but what was their reward?

"Banishment! Death! Madness!" Majora shouted into the echoing trail, gently caressing the mask he wore. The mask pulsed faintly with a malevolent aura, exuding a subtle, dark residue that shimmered like smoke in the air. It was feeding off his fury, amplifying it. "I created this from my own soul!"

The wrathful man marched forward with a determined pace, unfazed by the ocean of dust obscuring his vision. Soon the path cleared and began to incline up a hill. Majora knew he was close; the slave quarters were situated just at the top of this ridge. The Sheikah city lay just beyond, and sweet revenge would soothe Majora's tortured spirit as he tore the high council apart with his bare hands.

Upon reaching the top, Majora was taken aback by complete silence. He looked around at the empty huts and broken architecture, a stark contrast to the once lush and thriving quarters. There was no life whatsoever. The state of the area almost appeared as if a revolt took place long ago, but how? The slaves were utterly devoted to their Sheikah masters, who were revered as gods. No, it was impossible! Gerudo were foolish and simple, but not so much as to risk the wrath of True Sheikah magic. Something else must have happened. Majora ran down the path to his former village. This road should have been swarming with people.

"Impossible! Did they know I was coming?" Majora gasped as fury rose within him. "Curse them! Curse them all!"

Sure enough, the entire village was deserted, just as desolate as the slave quarters. As he dashed past buildings toward the high council chambers, Majora met the same stillness that seemed to haunt the entire region. Not only was this formerly bustling village devoid of people, but it was completely stripped of resources. The only remaining sign of civilization was bare, ruined infrastructure.

"No. No it cannot be. Gone... all gone." Majora collapsed to his knees on the cracked, lifeless ground, his breath catching in his throat as a tidal wave of grief and fury crashed over him. The sun above seemed to burn with cruel indifference, and his fingers dug into the dusty soil as if trying to anchor himself to a world that had betrayed him. The mask began to exude that same oily shadow, hungrily drinking in his anguish and radiating a low thrum of dark energy. "They cannot escape me. I will find them! Rrrraaaaagghhh!"

A violent shriek escaped Majora's throat as he allowed his body to be overtaken by pure malice. Cold, shadowy energy seeped from his body and extended outwards. Rocks and pebbles floated into the air as ethereal darkness covered the area, creeping up the walls of the surrounding buildings. The very air itself began to vibrate and hum with power. Finally, the dark energy reached the perimeter of the town, and Majora closed his eyes, unleashing his will into the earth. The entirety of the ruins was instantly vaporized in a single deafening, catastrophic explosion, and Majora lost consciousness as the wave of pure darkness washed over him.

Narri was a young Gerudo huntress-in-training and often came to the Cliffs of Despair for practice. Prey was scarce here, which made the challenge even greater, and more fun. She had done this run many times with her mother, but this was the first time Narri came by herself. It was the first of many coming-of-age trials that the young Gerudo would face, and she was shaking with nervous anticipation at proving herself worthy of adulthood.

Narri hunkered down at the base of a rock upon seeing the fresh tracks of a coyote, her keen eyes narrowing with practiced focus. Though still considered young, she had spent countless hours tracking desert prey alongside her mother and sisters, learning to interpret even the faintest impressions in the dust. The spacing, depth, and freshness of the prints told her the animal had passed through moments ago—and it was alone. Her pulse quickened at the thought of proving her skill without guidance for the first time. Using the sensing techniques her mother had taught her, Narri removed the silk bandana covering her face and closed her eyes to "feel" the desert. The blistering heat of the noontime sun, arid breeze, rustling of the sun-bleached grass—and for some reason a peculiar sense of uneasiness throughout the entire area. The huntress opened her eyes to search around. Something was wrong, but she did not know what. She tried to sort the strange feeling out, until a flash of gray fur darting behind a boulder caught Narri's attention.

The coyote!

Narri repositioned her bandana over her face to muffle her excited breathing. This was her chance! She crept closer to the opposite side of the boulder, carefully balancing each step to remain silent. Taking up a loose pebble in her left hand and hoisting her spear in the right, Narri prepared her strike. Just before she threw the pebble to startle her prey out of hiding, a massive explosion rocked the earth and not only threw Narri to the ground but caused the coyote to flee in terror. Narri lifted her head to see a bright purple flash of light rise into the sky below the old ruins just before a cloud of dust swept over the cliffs.

Shaken, a bit terrified, yet angry at losing her prey, the young Gerudo stood to her feet and began walking through the thick blanket of dust to investigate the explosion. Her great-grandnana had told Narri and her sisters stories of the ancient ruins where their gods dwelt on earth. Of how the Gerudo were faithful servants and were granted a peaceful life free of thirst and starvation. Some Gerudo were even taught how to use the shadow magic that the gods often wielded. That was before a huge war was waged on the sacred lands of Hyrule, when her great-grandnana was a small child. The Hylian gods must have been victorious, since no one had seen or heard anything from the old gods for nearly a century. But why was there activity here now? Had the gods returned at last? Curious, Narri made the hike to the ruins.

The sun was nearly to the horizon by the time Narri reached the edge of the ruins. The fog of dust had settled into a slight haze, so the huntress could see what awaited her. A vast crater stretched before Narri where the ancient ruins once were. Sinuous markings within the crater snaked toward the epicenter of the devastation, where the Gerudo saw a faint humanoid figure. Narri quickly rushed to the fallen being, sliding and hopping down the walls of the depression to see if it was alright, or at least worthy of looting. The coyote was a good prize, but the possibilities of this creature being related to the old gods was historical. Her people would recognize her as an adult for sure, and then she could at last explore the world on her own!

When Narri arrived at the center, she was surprised to find an odd masked man lying unconscious. The tendril-like markings etched into the rock seemed to emanate from him like rays of winding light. Narri bent down to see if he was alive, her heart pounding with a mix of awe and apprehension. Could this truly be one of the old gods her great-grandnana spoke of? A sense of reverence and ambition welled up within her—if she brought back proof, her place in Gerudo society would be secured. With trembling fingers, she searched the torn clothing for any valuables.

"Hmm… Nothing. Maybe this mask will be worth something."

Narri spoke to herself as she reached toward the odd, heart-shaped mask. However, as soon as she touched the cold wood, the man's hand shot up and grasped her arm in a vice-like grip. Narri screeched in pain and fear as the grip tightened, nearly crushing her bones.

"What are you doing, slave?" the masked man spoke.

"Oww, ow, ow I-I was just checking to, owww, see if you were unhurt?!"

"Lies!"

Narri suddenly flew several meters and crashed to the ground. Her spear had fallen quite a distance away, but she couldn't leap up to retrieve it as she was held down by some unseen force. The masked man rose from the ground and was standing over her in the blink of an eye.

"Are you... a god?" Narri gasped in pain, struggling to move.

"To you I am, slave," the man stated imperiously. "You may be of use to me. What happened to my home?"

"Your... urgh... home? You lived here? Auuuughh!"

Narri shrieked as a flash of purple shot toward her, severing her left ear and slicing the silk bandana from her face. The man slouched as he dropped his radiating hand, clearly weakened by something.

"You… should be grateful I'm in a gracious mood today. Your kind must have forgotten how to behave. From now on you will address me as 'Master,' and speak only when I give you permission. Now, I'll ask again. What happened to my home?"

"I-l-l don't know, uh...m-master! The gods disappeared almost a century ago! I'm sorry!"

"A century? You don't happen to know where, do you?"

"No, I don't know anything except for the stories my great-grandnana told!"

Majora glared at the quivering slave girl in contempt. Such an impudent creature, speaking to him as an equal. Even in his weakened state caused by his uncontrolled outburst, Majora was far stronger than this worm. She was definitely of the Gerudo though, with tanned skin, scarlet hair, and a well-muscled body suited for hard labor. Yet Majora had no use for a slave—what he needed was information and a safe place to recover his energy. This girl could take him to her home to rest, and perhaps to one of the slaves who knew the cause of his people's disappearance.

"Hmm. You will take me to your village to see your elder."

"Yes! I can do that, but my great-grandnana is—"

"Silence," Majora interrupted, shooting a tiny bolt of energy into Narri's arm. "You will remember to hold your tongue, or you will lose it."

"Aghh aghhh! Yes, m-master!"

Majora gestured at the desperate Gerudo to rise off the ground, removing the unseen magic bindings. Narri immediately flung one hand to her bleeding head while searching for her severed ear. Majora kicked the girl harshly in the calves and motioned for her to move on.

"Forward, slave."

Narri tearfully obeyed, every step a struggle against the trembling in her legs. Her vision blurred with tears and the sharp sting of pain in her head. She wished with every fiber of her being that she had ignored the explosion and hunted the coyote instead. Her heart ached for the safety of her family—her mother’s strong arms, her sisters’ laughter, the warm light of home. And above all, she clung desperately to one hope: that she would live through this nightmare.



Chapter Thirty Five

A Rocky Start


The dawn of the first day began again as usual, with birdsong weaving through the crisp morning air and the scent of dew-laced cobblestones rising in gentle waves—but Ratt, Tatl, and I were far too on edge to enjoy the sunshine and cheery morning. The phantom sting of Lukhan’s envenomed blades still clung to my shoulder. The echo of his cold, sardonic voice flickered at the edge of memory like a shadow that hadn’t quite vanished. The warmth on my face felt almost insulting after what we’d just survived. We had been only seconds away from certain death, and I quietly thanked the gods for our escape. All three of us swayed unsteadily as we regained our bearings from the rapid shift through time—that nauseating tumble through space that left our limbs tingling, our stomachs roiling, and a cold rush lingering in our veins like the echo of some deep, cosmic current... Tatl and I were more familiar with it, but Ratt still struggled to remain upright.

"W-whoa, for a minute there... I thought... we were finished." Ratt gasped, stumbling a step before bending down and clutching his stomach. His face had gone pale, a cold sweat glistening along his brow, and his eyes darted around as if expecting the pirate lord to leap from the shadows. His voice trembled slightly when he added, "W-what happened to Lukhan?"

"I don't know, but I'm glad he's not here..." I said, though my voice shook with something closer to wariness than relief. That was far too close for comfort. I could practically see the raging hatred in his eyes still lingering before me. I grasped at the shoulder where his blade met my flesh yesterday. Still healed...thank the gods... I quickly looked up to Tatl to make sure she was also unharmed.

"Are you okay, Tatl?"

"Yeah, and I think we're all lucky to be alive. In any case, we should probably get out of town as soon as possible in case they come looking!"

Tatl fluttered around my head, casting frantic glances at the nearby rooftops and alleys. I found myself scanning them too, half-expecting Lukhan's shape to materialize from the shadows, blade drawn and memory intact. Her wings trembled faintly, betraying more fear than her voice let on. Then her tone shifted, just a little too eagerly—almost like she was trying to move the conversation past the terror still clinging to all of us.

"Oh... right! The Gorons must be looking for their kid about now! Remember that guy you mentioned, Ratt? Do you think he still has the Goron child?"

Ratt, still hunched and pale from the twisting effects of time travel, grimaced as he swallowed down the bile rising in his throat. He wiped his mouth on his sleeve, then paused, blinking hard like he was trying to remember where—when—they were. His voice was hoarse when he finally answered.

"I'm pretty sure he does. And I gotta agree with you on this one, Tatl. We need to get out of here, and fast." He took my hand like it was the one stable thing left in a world gone sideways, gripping it with trembling fingers. "C'mon. He's just south of the shopping district."

We raced through the plaza, which was steadily filling with bustling shoppers and bright-eyed tourists, their cheerful chatter clashing with the raw tension still tightening in my chest. The scent of baked bread, crushed flowers, and woodsmoke hung heavy in the thick morning air—so warm and inviting it felt like a cruel joke. It was as though the world had shrugged off the darkness we’d just endured, refusing to acknowledge the terror that had clung to our skin like ash.

Beside me, Ratt weaved through the crowd like someone born in these streets, his grip on my hand a lifeline as we threaded through narrow alleys and between carts piled high with goods. His focus never wavered. Not until we reached a street so silent and grimy it felt like it had been forgotten on purpose.

Iron bars barricaded the windows of several buildings that sat in a jumbled row, with each door sporting multiple locks made of solid steel. The building we finally stopped before had a metal sign reading "The Curiosity Shop" written in ornate gold lettering, dulled by years of dust and neglect.

"Here we are, I've known this guy for a long time," Ratt began in a hushed tone, matching the silence of the empty corridor. "He's the only pawn shop in town, and he owns most of these buildings—used to run with the thieves' guild before he went legit, or so he claims. He has contacts all over Termina that sell or trade all kinds of valuable artifacts to him. Geroh may seem like a thieving lowlife at first, but trust me, he's got a heart of gold."

"I trust you, but let's try to hurry." I nodded, warily glancing around. The hairs on my neck still hadn’t settled, something was off.

Ratt continued to hold my hand, his grip steady but warm, as he walked up and rapped his knuckles on the iron-reinforced door. The tension in his shoulders hadn’t eased, and I could feel the unspoken urgency in the way his fingers curled just slightly tighter around mine. For the first time I was actually grateful for his comforting presence. A few seconds later, a thin, nasally voice sounded within.

"Ratt? Is that you? Whatchoo want?"

"I want to know if you have any Goron kids?"

"Goron kids? How can I have any kids if I ain't got a wife? 'Specially a Goron, ya dunce! The only kid I ever gotta deal with is you."

"C'mon Geroh, I know someone sold you a Goron kid recently."

"...Maybe they did, maybe they didn't. Why d'you care anyhow? This another one of your 'hero' escapades?"

"Look, you know as well as I do that this town is already on the brink of anarchy. If the Gorons end up declaring war on us because you stole one of their young, this town won't survive, taking your business with it. You don't want to risk losing all of this, do you?"

Ratt gestured with his arm at all the buildings along the street, and the heavy door finally opened after six loud clicks, revealing a short, chubby man with neatly combed brown hair and a short-trimmed black beard. The smell of oil, dust, and old parchment wafted from inside.

"Harumph…you always did have a good head on your shoulders, kid. Come on inside. And uh, bring your company in too."

Geroh waved us in and held open the door while glancing suspiciously at Tatl and me.

There were no windows inside the structure, but it was well lit by dozens of candles and torches. The walls had several large crates hastily stacked against them, with the back wall featuring a solid steel door, which looked much like a safe. The middle of the room was empty aside from a few wooden chairs and a green plaid sofa. A glass table in the shape of a rupee, supported by jade figurines of goddess-like women posed in flowing robes, sat at the very center. The front door shut with a quiet thud, and Geroh fastened all six locks again before turning his attention on us.

"Please, uh, have a seat."

Ratt proceeded to sit on the sofa and I followed suit. Geroh plopped down in one of the chairs and continued to stare suspiciously at me, his narrowed eyes flicking over my gear while his stubby fingers tapped a slow, rhythmic beat on the armrest.

"So, uh, who's your girlfriend? Don't think I ever seen her before."

"Wha? She's not my girlfriend! I mean she's a friend, but we aren't together, or anything like that!" Ratt answered in a rush, a tinge of red burning in his cheeks.

"Hehe sure sure, kid. Why is she here then?"

"Her name is Link, and she's uhhh... an emissary for the Gorons up north. They aren't happy, Geroh. They know you have their child, so they sent her to reason with you."

Geroh’s brow furrowed deeper. Then his eyes widened, and his posture stiffened as a flash of alarm crossed his face. I could see the moment his confidence faltered, like a mask slipping—revealing the glint of fear behind his bluster. His fingers twitched slightly on the armrest, the bravado draining from him as his growing suspicion gave way to defensive fear.

"Whoa whoa, I never stole no kid! In fact, I only bought him so's I could get him back to the Gorons all quicklike!"

I decided to play along with Ratt's ploy, and spoke in a more authoritative voice.

"You're lucky that they sent me ahead of them for a diplomatic solution. A preemptive strike force is waiting just outside of town right now. If I were you, I'd hand the boy over immediately so I can return him."

"OK OK, you don't have to threaten me any more lady! I'll go get him, he's probably still sleeping like a lil' boulder. Gimme a sec. You come with me, kid, I'll need a hand hauling him out. Oh and if yer girlfriend and her sprite steal anything, I'm charging Mutoh double for anything she takes, yeah?"

The pudgy shopkeeper hoisted himself up and retreated to the back door, the heavy clinking of a large ring packed with keys of all shapes echoing through the room as the metal glinted faintly in the flickering candlelight. Ratt followed and disappeared through the doorway after Geroh freed the three locks guarding it, then the door closed with a heavy, metallic clang behind them.

"Ok...so what's the plan here? We get this Goron kid back to his parents, convince them to help us up the mountain, then what? We aren't taking Ratt with us, are we?" Tatl spoke up, lightly landing on my shoulder.

"My guess is that we'll figure it out as we go. And no, we've already put him through enough danger. I'll just have to convince him to stay in town somehow."

"Good luck, he seems bent on following you like a lost puppy. Pretty sure he likes you."

"No he doesn't. He knows I'm a man—at least, I think he does.”

Unless... maybe he doesn't?  The thought sent a ripple of unease through me, and I quickly pushed it down.

“He just wants to know how to wield a sword. That's all that's between us."

"Pfft. I bet he does…" Tatl mumbled.

I didn't have a chance to retort as the vault door swiftly opened, followed by Ratt and Geroh rolling a wooden barrel filled with what sounded like heavy stones. The shopkeep waved for me to come look and I stood to oblige him.

"Lookee here, there's your lost Goron."

Sure enough, I peered inside to find a smallish Goron child quietly snoring, seemingly unaware of his situation.

"How long has he been sleeping?" I asked.

"Ever since I got 'im. Sako- er, I mean, the one who brung him said the kid was asleep when he found the hefty boy."

"That's a bit odd, but at least he's here. The Goron's fury will be sated, I'm sure." I replied officiously, taking note of Geroh's slip.

"Good, them's the last thing I need jumping down my throat."

"Whoa whoa whoa! That's great and all, but how do we wake him up?" Tatl interjected.

"That I do not know." Geroh shrugged. "I tried all sorts of stuff, no luck. I dunno how anything can sleep in a barrel like that. I just figgered you'd know a trick, being ...ah...emissaries and all."

"Hmm...I could try something." I replied, the Song of Healing coming to mind.

I retrieved the Ocarina from beneath the cloak and brought it to my lips. Ratt seemed confused and inched closer to my side, probably worried that we'd be whisked through the timestream again. I gave him a reassuring pat on the shoulder and began the mystical tune, hoping it would wake the snoozing Goron. The soft notes swam around the room like graceful swans in a tranquil lake, their echoes lingering in the stillness—but when I was finished, the child continued to sleep. A flicker of frustration stirred in my chest, the silence that followed pressing heavier than before.

"Well… that was certainly something. Instead of waking 'im up you probably made him even more sleepy. I know it did for me, heh heh." Geroh yawned in mock exhaustion, stretching his arms overhead with an exaggerated groan and giving his belly a lazy scratch.

"It was worth a shot, Link." Ratt consoled as I rolled my eyes at the dealer. "He's a heavy one though, how can we get him to his kind? Do you have a cart or something, Geroh?"

"Eh, I s'pose I could lend ya a pushcart or somethin'. But uh…. not fer free. I’ll trade ya, how about that shiny pendant yer wearin’?”

The dealer pointed to my chest and I looked down, seeing the pendant Kotake had given me a few days ago glinting in the soft light. It was a strange charm—a smooth grey stone cool to the touch, faintly humming as if alive. A tiny, blood-red ruby gleamed at its center, surrounded by flecks of deep purple that shimmered like ink in water. A looped piece of thread was securely wrapped around it, forming a necklace. It had always pulsed faintly against my chest, like it was drinking in the air around us. Kotake had given it to me as a shield against Odalwa’s tracking—something to mask my presence, to keep the monster from sensing me through the mists. I remembered how it had comforted me in the worst parts of the swamp, a quiet talisman that made me feel less exposed, less hunted. Letting it go felt like peeling off a layer of protection I didn’t know I still needed. But with him defeated, its purpose had faded into the past.

“That’s a fair trade I suppose, here.”

I undid the leather knot and handed the medallion to Geroh, and he looked it over carefully. With a nod of satisfaction, happy to feel the quality of the stone and craftsmanship, he started towards the front door.

“Alrighty, fair’s fair. You all stay put, I’ll go get that cart ready fer youse."

Geroh unlocked the front door again and walked out, leaving the Goron with us.I sat down on the dusty wooden floor and leaned back on the barrel. Tatl flew into the barrel with the child and Ratt plopped down beside me to sit cross-legged, kicking up a tiny poof of dust.

"See? Told you he was trustworthy. The kid’ll be back with his people in no time, and then they’ll bring us to the mountains. With luck, we’ll be there tonight!" Ratt grinned, his voice brimming with pride like he’d somehow arranged the whole thing himself.

"Ratt, you know you can't come with us up there. It's dangerous, I told you that," I reminded sternly.

"Yeah, you wouldn't last two seconds… actually probably less," Tatl added, echoing inside the barrel with a tone that stung more than it needed to.

"But I thought you were going to train me?" Ratt’s voice faltered slightly, more uncertain than defiant. He picked at a loose thread on his sleeve, not meeting my eyes. "I just... I thought maybe I could finally be more than what I was."

"I can't train you and look after you. What if I'm fighting a monster and you get in the way?"

Ratt put a hand on my knee, hesitant but hopeful. A warm rush stirred in my chest—confusing, unexpected. I glanced away quickly, pretending to brush a stray speck from my tunic, willing the heat in my face to settle. It felt like keese swarming in my gut, an anxious flutter I didn’t want to name.

"I'll be fine," he said softly. "I've survived practically all my life on these streets. I know how to hide, how to run away… but for once in my life, after seeing you, I want to learn how to fight back."

I swallowed. Why does that look shake me? A heartbeat later, I suppressed the fluttering sensation and gently pushed Ratt’s hand away.

"I don't want to be responsible for your death, even if you do know how to run and hide."

"What if you end up almost dying? Like last time? You might need my help again," Ratt retorted.

"That's what he's got me for, genius," Tatl interrupted, flitting out from the barrel to stand on my other knee. "We're both grateful for what you did last night, but this is our adventure, our lives on the line. It's just better if you stay out of our way."

Ratt’s grin faded. He drew his hand back into his lap, his eyes darting briefly to the floor as his shoulders slumped. The vulnerability he’d let show was quickly tucked away, replaced by a colder mask of indifference—but it was thinner now, fraying at the edges.

A pang of guilt crept into my chest, quiet but persistent—I hadn’t meant to hurt him, only to protect him, but the line between the two was blurring. A trace of disappointment lingered in the downturn of his mouth, like a question left unanswered.

"So, you aren't going to train me then?"

"No... I didn't say that."

"Then when? How can I learn if I'm stuck here?"

I sighed, then looked around the room. There was a large amount of empty space between the boxes and the centerpiece furniture. Plenty of room for a bit of light sparring. I stood to my feet, causing Tatl to take off, and held my hand out to Ratt to pick him up.

"How about now?"

Ratt looked up, took my hand with a smile, and nodded eagerly.

"No time like the present."

He pulled himself up, his grip warm and sure, and I guided him away from the barrel.

"OK, first things first: your stance. There's a defensive stance and an offensive one. I'll show you defensive first."

I planted my feet shoulder-width apart, my stronger left leg slightly behind the right. Ratt mirrored me instantly, eyes focused.

"Yep, that's right—if you're left-handed. Are you?"

"Oh, no I'm not. Should I swap feet?"

"Yes. And when you do, shift your weight just behind your toes. That way, you’ll be quicker on your feet. And keep your shoulders square to your opponent."

Ratt nodded and adjusted accordingly, furrowing his brow with intent.

"Now, put your hands up to defend your face, but keep a loose fist."

He raised his hands, though slightly off-center. I stepped in to correct him, guiding his arms gently. His messy black hair fell into his eyes, which glimmered with nervous excitement. The eager way he held himself made something flutter in my chest again—protective instinct, maybe... or something else… I pushed the feeling down again, more aggressively this time.

His oversized blue shirt and trousers sagged slightly on his lean frame, making him look more like a kid dressing up to play hero than a fighter in training. Still, he grinned at me with wide-eyed resolve, like a puppy ready to chase a stick. Ratt’s shaggy black hair making him look even more playful.

"Alright, looking good," I said, smiling despite myself. "Now try to look a bit more... tough."

Ratt furrowed his brow and curled his lip into a little snarl—a valiant effort.

"Now, I'm going to punch at your right side. Sidestep left with your right foot, and grab my arm to block. Got it?"

"Got it."

I lunged with a light jab. Ratt flinched, late to react, and my fist tapped his ribs. He still managed to grab my arm in time, completing the move—if clumsily.

"I wasn't ready for that," he said with a sheepish grin, rubbing the spot. "But did I do it right?"

"Not quite," I said, chuckling softly. "But you're getting there. We’ll get it."

His grin returned, wide and earnest, and I could see how badly he wanted this—wanted to be something more than just the scrappy street kid. And in that look, for just a heartbeat, I felt the flicker of something warmer, messier, and much harder to ignore.

As I shifted to show him the next position, a sudden clink rang out beside us—the Hero’s Mask had slipped from my belt and tumbled to the wooden floor, landing face-up between us. I froze.

Ratt stooped instinctively to pick it up. "Whoa, I probably knocked that off, sorry—"

The moment his fingers touched the mask, a jolt of magic surged between them both. A flash of golden light burst from the carved eyes, and Ratt recoiled with a sharp gasp, yelping as if burned. The mask thudded back to the floor, its edges still humming faintly, a whisper of energy curling into the air.

“Wh-what was that? What just happened?” Ratt stared in wide-eyed horror at the mask, clutching the hand that had touched it. His fingers trembled.

“I… don’t know. I’ve never seen it do that before,” I said, crouching quickly to retrieve it.

But Ratt didn’t move. He kept staring at his hand, dazed. “I… I saw something. Just for a second. A castle. It was… it was raining. And I heard a girl’s voice. She was calling out—calling your name. I think she was crying.”

My heart tightened, though I didn’t know why. “You heard someone calling me?”

He nodded faintly, eyes distant. “Yeah… I didn’t recognize her. But it felt... important. Like she was in trouble.”

I crouched and picked up the mask again. The carved face was still warm beneath my fingers, as if it had absorbed the heat of that moment. A hollow weight settled in my chest. Whoever Ratt saw—whoever she was—I knew that voice once. I was sure of it. But the memory was locked away, just out of reach.

Ratt rubbed his palm again and looked at me. “It didn’t feel like just a vision. It felt like… like I was supposed to hear her.”

I met his eyes and gave a slow nod, more for his sake than mine. “I'm sure it was just a weird residual effect of the magic in this mask...” I said, though I wasn’t sure what it meant.

Still, as I strapped my Hero’s Mask firmly back onto my belt, I couldn’t shake the feeling that there was something important that I was forgetting. What was that voice he heard? Who did it belong to?

I glanced at Ratt, who was still staring at the floor, his brows furrowed in confusion and wonder.

“Are you okay?” I asked softly.

“I think so,” he murmured, blinking as if waking from a dream. “That was just... a weird feeling is all.”

I pulled my lips into a tight smile as I brushed some dust off my former, familiar features etched in the wood and strapped the mask firmly back onto my belt. My hands lingered there a moment longer than necessary.

“Well, whatever it was, we’ll figure it out later. Let’s continue where we left off, if you still want to keep going…?”

Ratt nodded and shook himself out of the daze, taking position again. We resumed the motions—I would strike, and he would take my arm. Slowly but surely, he began to get the hang of it. When he nearly perfected the maneuver, I saw a hopeful gleam in his eyes. That spark of determination again, catching fire. I couldn't help but grin back at him as he held my arm in a secure grip.

Just then the heavy door swung open with Geroh loudly grunting. One look at us and he shook his head with a knowing smile.

“Oh don’t let me interrupt! I see the two of ya are learnin’ some smooth moves, eh? Hahahah!”

Ratt flinched and let go of my arm at once, the motion sharp and sheepish. A rush of heat crept up my neck, and I suddenly found the floorboards terribly interesting, cheeks flushing with a bashful red as Geroh’s gaze swept the room. I straightened quickly, brushing imaginary dust from my gloves, trying to recover a sense of composure.

"Anyways, I got that cart all ready for youse guys. Just, uh, return it when you're done, kid," he said with a wink. "Here, I'll help ya move this thing onto it, free o’ charge. The emissary and her fairy can wait outside, youse both watch the cart, eh? Don’t want no one takin’ off with it. This part of town ain’t, uh… exactly peaches and cream, ya know?"

I was all too eager to walk out of the building with Tatl hovering beside me, the warm glow of the morning sun brushing my face like a balm. Just outside the door stood a large pushcart with four thick wooden wheels. It looked sturdy enough—probably used for hauling crates, barrels, or whatever other illicit goods Geroh dealt in when fewer eyes were watching.

“Sooo how was your little training session?” Tatl suddenly cut in, sarcasm dripping from her tiny mouth. “I saw the whole thing hehe. You sure you wouldn’t rather stay in town and pick flowers for him? Maybe go on a romantic getaway before the apocalypse?”

“What are you talking about? He just wanted to learn how to fight.” I shot a glare at her, hating that she saw more than I wanted to show. “Look, you know as well as I do that he won’t survive with those pirates looking for him. He needs to know how to defend himself.”

“Riiiight, so all that blushing was just for defense, huh? I saw the way you two looked at each other. You’re practically glowing.”

“I was not blushing,” I muttered, far too quickly.

“Sure you weren’t,” Tatl giggled, doing an exaggerated spin midair. "Just sayin’, he might not be the only one who needs a little protection if you catch my drift.”

I was about to shoot back something sharp when a loud laugh erupted from within the shop, followed by the heavy thuds of wood and metal scraping across the floor. Geroh emerged, pushing the barrel ahead with a grunt, and Ratt right behind him—his face crimson, eyes locked on the ground as if hoping it might swallow him whole.

Whatever Geroh had said during their short walk, he was clearly proud of it. The man was still chuckling, nudging the barrel into place on the cart with a final shove. Ratt barely glanced up as he moved behind the cart to steady it, his cheeks still glowing, and not from exertion.

"Alright, kid, be sure to bring that thing back. And don't get into too much trouble, yeah?" Geroh called out, casting me another wink.

Ratt rubbed the back of his neck and muttered something under his breath, eyes darting to the side with a sheepish smile that vanished almost as quickly as it appeared. He glanced off toward the cart as though its wooden frame held the answers to his embarrassment. I caught that flicker of warmth before he buried it, and I scowled grumpily. There was no way I was going to fall for this scrappy kid. What was I even thinking?

My chest tightened with something sharp and unwelcome. It was infuriating—how easily that dumb grin could undo me. I hated that my thoughts even flickered that way, hated how they made me feel softer, smaller... like the girl everyone kept assuming I was. Like something delicate instead of dangerous. This wasn’t me. I wasn’t here to smile and blush and wonder what someone thought of me. I was here to fight. To fix what was broken.

"Don't worry, we've been in enough trouble," I stated, the edge in my voice harder than I meant it to be.

"Ha! I bet you have..." The stocky shopkeep looked me up and down and laughed before walking back inside. "Good luck, and thanks for taking that kid off my hands."

The door shut with a heavy thud and the locks clicked into place. Ratt seemed eager to be moving on, so I moved to his side to help him push the heavy cart.

"Ready?" I grunted with a shove of the cart. "We're going to the north side, that's where the Gorons said they'd be last time."

"Uhh yeah, that's fine. We'll have to take the main streets though."

"Oh great…It'll take all day to get there!" Tatl groaned. "Why do we have to keep dealing with these tourists?"

We both ignored the fairy and began pushing the cart. The wooden wheels creaked forward with surprising ease, and we rolled into the now-crowded streets, swallowed by the mingled scents of roasted nuts, animal dung, and overripe fruit. Shouts and laughter tangled with the clatter of hooves and jingling coin purses, the noise washing over us in chaotic waves. The going was agonizingly slow, and grew ever slower as the day progressed. The cacophony of a thousand conversations, not to mention the constant juggling of people bumping into us, made me wonder how the heavy Goron child could possibly be sleeping through the trip. However, we eventually made it to the much quieter northern park as the sun lingered above the western horizon, the trees casting long shadows over the area. Both Ratt and I were gasping for breath and I wished I had used my mask for extra strength. A flicker of stubborn pride kept me from reaching for it earlier, but now that pride felt a little foolish in the face of my aching muscles and burning lungs.

Tatl sat on top of the cart, throwing tiny pebbles she had gathered from the road into the barrel out of boredom. Yet we finally reached the north gate after a grueling journey. The guard posted at the gate looked rather disheveled and banged up with dents the size of a small dog in his chest plate armor, a sight that made me pause—was he brave for still standing, or just too stubborn to know when to retreat? and accosted us before we could get through.

"H-hey! Where are you kids going? Haven't you heard? Monsters are everywhere outside of town!"

"Yeah, but we have important cargo to deliver. If you don't let us through then people could die!" Ratt rushed to explain, stretching the truth mildly.

"Right. Well then you wouldn't mind me checking this cargo…" The guard immediately peeked inside the barrel and suddenly leapt back in fearful surprise.

"T-that's the baby Goron! What a-are you doing with it?"

"We're taking him back to his people, you better let us through before things get any worse." I calmly explained between heavy breaths.

"Huh? How did you…? Gods what am I doing? Go go go! Get that thing out of town! I'm not gonna stop you, I learned my lesson when I tried holding back the other Gorons this morning!"

The guard rushed to join us behind the cart and began to frantically push it out the gate. We joined him in forcing the cart just beyond the gate, and the guard gave one last oomph and pointed in the direction of a plume of black smoke coming from a copse of trees as he walked back inside the gate.

"The other Gorons made camp over there, but I recommend you just drop the cart off right at the first tree and run back. Those Gorons aren't as friendly as the old stories say they are. The really big guy almost killed me this morning!"

"I think we'll be fine, thanks." I waved back as we continued to shove the cart.

The cowardly guard muttered something rude under his breath about dumb kids deserving death. I rolled my eyes but bit my tongue—no use wasting breath on someone who'd already lost face to a pack of angry Gorons.

"OK...almost there you two...ungh!"

"Yeah. Almost. My legs feel like chu jelly…" Ratt huffed.

"Speak for yourself! I'm so bored I might just fly off and fight those monsters myself—and honestly, I’d probably get there faster than you two." came a high-pitched voice dripping with sarcasm from within the barrel.

The little white pixie leapt onto the rim of the cart and stretched languidly.

"At least we're almost there—though I was starting to wonder if you'd be pushing this thing all the way into tomorrow. Seriously, Link, ever heard of using your magic mask for something useful ? Or are you saving it for dramatic effect? You'd be much stronger with it on."

"I don't...need it, Tatl. I can push it just fine." I puffed, "Why don't...urgh... you just enjoy the free ride?"

In truth I just didn't want to deal with the pain of transformation, my body had been through enough for one day. Besides...finding a hiding spot to change would just take more time.

"Eh, suit yourself. I'm actually enjoying myself!" Tatl shrugged and jumped back into the barrel.

The sky grew dark as the sun dipped beneath the skyline, and crickets began to chirp peacefully as the cart rumbled slowly to the trees.



The sweet evening air filled my heaving lungs, mixed with the mildly spicy scent of pine needles—a strangely calming aroma that settled my nerves, reminding me for a fleeting moment of my old home in the Kokiri Woods. The sounds of faint, forlorn chanting could be heard within the grove as well rumbled past the first trees. A bright warm glow hinted at a large bonfire burning in the woods and the rhythmic vocal tones grew louder the further we went.

The cart suddenly creaked loudly and a crack could be heard from one of the wheels. The heavy barrel slid off the frame with a deafening crash with a tiny squeak sounding from inside it as the right wheel essentially splintered to pieces. The melancholy voices immediately turned to angry bellows as what sounded like a rock avalanche thundered towards us. My breath caught in my throat, instincts screaming to run—but I held my ground, heart hammering, hands twitching toward my satchel out of habit. This wasn't a battle I wanted, but I would be ready if it became one.

"What the…! Intruders? Thieves? Don't let them escape!" A deep, authoritative voice boomed.

I rushed to the barrel to try dumping the slumbering Goron to show that I came in peace. The kid plunked onto the ground just in time as three massive Gorons crashed through the branches, surrounding us.

"State your business or else, humans!" One of the stoney giants bellowed.

"Brothers! I bring you good news!" I bellowed up at him in turn. "We found your stolen child! We have brought him back to you in a show of good faith!"

I gestured to the ever-sleeping child and the speaker lumbered over to him in shock.

"How… did you know we were looking for him?" He asked with an astounded expression.

"It's a long story… but the important thing is that he's here, and safe."

"Hmph. Were it my judgment alone, I'd grind you into gravel where you stand. Humans lie with honeyed tongues and take what is not theirs. But the chief alone will decide your fate. Move—before I change my mind."

The speaker hoisted the child into his arms and walked back towards the fire while the other two motioned us to follow him. The sharp tang of smoke and crushed herbs thickened the air as we stepped deeper into the grove, and the weight of a dozen silent stares prickled along the back of my neck. A large bonfire, with flames reaching at least five meters into the air, sat at the center of the clearing. Several Gorons were crowded around something near the fire, an altar maybe, only briefly looking at us before continuing their melodic chanting and waving herbs through the air.
