A very ancient, haggard Goron slowly ambled with a stone cane over to the leader with the child from a spot looking over the huddled group. The smaller elder exchanged quick words with the younger in hushed tones, the two of them likely trying to decide on if we were a threat or not. A few minutes later, an agreement was apparently reached and the elder goron looked to us. He walked towards us with his painfully thin legs visibly shaking beneath his massively bulbous body, but he didn't falter. The ancient chieftain's hunched shoulders appeared as if they bore a thousand problems, and the deep cracks in his face creased in thought as the elder looked us over. I stood a little straighter under his gaze, feeling as if my every secret might be drawn out and judged. Something about him made my palms itch with unease, like I was a child again standing before the Deku Tree after doing something wrong. The younger Goron carrying the child was much taller physically than the elder, but the chieftain carried himself in such a way that demanded respect. After looking at me with faded blue eyes, he finally spoke in a frail, whispy voice before reaching into a pouch to withdraw a lens in the shape of an eye.

"So… no matter who or what you say you are. “We will find out the truth. And if we do not like what we see… you and your friend will die."

My stomach tightened, a cold knot twisting behind my ribs. I instinctively shifted my weight, one hand brushing near my satchel where the mask waited—familiar, dangerous, reassuring. I kept my face calm, but the Elder Goron's eyes made me feel exposed, as though even my heartbeat might betray me.



Chapter Thirty-Six

The Stone Warrior

The bonfire’s light cast long, flickering shadows across the twilit grove, turning the moss-covered stones and gnarled roots into shapes that felt older than memory. Two Goron guards flanked me, their grips like iron clamps on my shoulders—unyielding, unshakable. I didn’t struggle. I knew better. Every inch of my body warned me that a single twitch could lead to shattered bones.

Around us, a low chorus of deep voices rumbled in the dusk: chanting, humming, something between mourning and ritual. I couldn’t see the source, but I felt the weight of it, vibrating softly through the earth beneath my boots. The ground thrummed with sorrow—slow, steady pulses like the heartbeat of something ancient and grieving. It was as if the very mountain remembered every loss ever suffered, and was mourning anew.

Each vibration carried something deeper than sound—grief, longing, a quiet despair that seeped up through the soles of my feet and wrapped itself around my chest. It wasn’t just the air that was heavy—it was the feeling of losing something precious.

I couldn't help but feel an oppressive sadness tighten around my own emotions, sinking into me like cold water.

But I didn't dare move to see what was happening, for fear of my bones being crushed with just a simple gesture from one of the massive hands keeping me still. The elder Goron, who I assumed was the leader of the tribe, slowly approached with a strange, yet somehow familiar, lens held in his gnarled, stony hands. The artifact shimmered faintly in the firelight, and it reminded me of something I had found in my past...but I couldn't place it.

Most of the Gorons I could see in the camp, younger and heartier, stood a meter or more above my height—yet the hunched elder's faded blue eyes were level with mine. Almost face to face now, he studied me with a weathered intensity that made my skin prickle.
Tatl hovered silently near my shoulder, unusually quiet. I could feel the tremble in her wings—not from fear, but from something deeper. She was feeling it too: the strange pull of sorrow that had thickened the very air here.

Then, with great care, he raised the lens between us.

It was definitely familiar... but also unlike anything I had ever seen. The frame was forged of dark volcanic iron, warped and weathered with age, wrapped in threads of silver that glinted like frost under the firelight. At its center pulsed a deep crimson gem, shaped like a watchful eye, its surface alive with shifting light. Runes spiraled along the metal edge—ancient script that shimmered faintly as if reacting to the presence of magic.

When he looked through it, the world felt like it was bending around me.

My own reflection shimmered in the gem—no, not just shimmered. It changed. Something beneath the surface stared back at me: not quite my face, not quite a stranger. The air grew heavier, and for a fleeting second I felt exposed—not just seen, but known.

Boromu's brow furrowed further, the lens trembling slightly in his grip. He lowered it slowly, as if reluctant, then cast a glance down my frame, pausing as if confirming something. Then he raised the glass eye again, the gem flashing with internal light.

"Curious... in all my years I've never seen such...."

His gravelly voice trailed off into muttering, thick with wonder and unease. He slipped the lens into his sash with a reverence usually reserved for sacred relics, his sagging lips twisting into a strange pout.

"Elder Boromu, what is it? What did you see?" one of the guards asked reverently, clearly surprised.

"This human... there is a strange conflict within them. Two souls shifting back and forth between this one, and a warrior male garbed in green. How could this be?"

The elder came closer, and I caught the heavy stench of sulfur on his breath. I tried not to gag as he came within an inch of me, inspecting me with a gnarled finger pointed at my face.

"I'm not... from around here. My name is Link. I came from a land called Hyrule. I was riding my horse through the forest when I was suddenly ambushed by a Skull Kid wearing a strange mask. I tried to fight, but ended up getting cursed into... well, what you see now."

When I mentioned Hyrule, the Gorons holding me notably stirred. Boromu merely gazed on with those old, weary eyes.... but he looked away at the mention of Skull Kid, giving me a moment to breathe freely. But when he turned back, something in his expression had hardened.

"Skull Kid... yes, I am familiar with his violent tricks. He came to our village days ago and demanded we serve him. I refused... and we've been suffering since. An eternal winter has fallen on our beloved mountains. Where there should be summer warmth, there are now blizzards and ice. We believe he tampered with our Divine Beast—a relic of a bygone era that controls weather."

He paused, his gaze narrowing as he studied me anew.

"And you say you came from Hyrule..."

There was a note of unease in his voice. He turned slightly away, as if grappling with memory.

"Our ancestors fled Hyrule long ago, seeking peace. That land was torn by chaos—wars, gods walking as men, men playing at gods. It was a place where stone cracked and rivers ran backwards. Many still speak its name only in whispers. That you survived such a place at all is... remarkable."

Boromu looked to the chanting circle, where the earth softly rumbled outward. The scent of scorched pine lingered faintly in the cold air, curling around the flickering shadows like smoke from a distant fire.

"Our greatest warrior, Darmani, went to confront the Skull Kid at Snowhead Temple, where we commune with the Beast. He sought to calm Goht and end this unnatural winter... but alas, he has met a terrible fate. I tell you this only because the lens does not lie. And according to the lens, you are trustworthy—however strange your cursed soul may be."

His eyes drifted back to me with a forlorn expression, his lips twisted into a mournful curl. The firelight etched deep lines into his stone face, and the weight of memory seemed to sag from his shoulders.

"Darmani, our last hope, is dying. Slowly turning to stone and crumbling under a curse. Our priests cannot undo it; the magic is too strong. We came to Clock Town seeking help, thinking the humans might have strong remedies... but they proved to be treacherous thieves. They stole my son, for reasons I still do not understand. Their ways are strange to us. They value gold over honor. Material over Spirit."

The wind shifted, carrying with it the scent of pine smoke and crushed herbs. The chanting in the distance deepened, as if the grove itself leaned in to listen.

Boromu's old, faded eyes locked on mine, and I felt like my entire soul was laid bare beneath them—past, future, and everything in between.

"And yet, you, a soul conflicted by curses as well, who came from the war torn land of the ancients... returned him to me. I must ask, and you will answer truthfully... why?"

I hesitated. For a heartbeat, the question echoed through me.

Because it was the right thing to do? Because I wanted to protect something? Because I couldn't save myself?

But all I said was:

"Because no one else would."

Boromu studied me for a long moment. Then he nodded once, slowly.

"Come. You will see Darmani. If the gods have placed you on our path, we shall follow it to the end."

The elder motioned with a wave of his hand, and the others released their vice-like grip on my shoulders. I rolled them back with a wince, only now realizing how tight their hands had been against my narrower build. The ache lingered like phantom bruises.

Boromu began his slow shuffle toward the chanting circle, and I followed close behind. The vibration grew stronger with each step, resonating through my boots and up into my spine. Yet the chants did not grow louder. It was as if the Gorons were no longer speaking to each other, but to the mountain itself.

Then, all at once, the chanting stopped.

The silence was absolute. Even the wind seemed to still. For a breathless moment, the grove felt like the eye of a storm—expectant, reverent, unnerving. The Ocarina in my satchel pressed gently against my hip, warm and faintly pulsing, as if aware of what was to come.

When we reached the edge of the circle, the assembled Gorons stepped aside in solemn unison. I crossed the boundary, and the earth gave a soft groan beneath my feet.

At the center of the circle lay a massive Goron, unmoving. His form stretched long and broad, his bulk weathered by snow and time. He was so still, he could have been a sculpture—but he was no work of art. This was a body resisting death with every grain of stone. Most of his skin had turned to a dark, mottled grey, fractured like cooling lava. Only a few patches of the original russet-gold peered through near the joints and chest. Tiny flakes of crumbling dust fell from his shoulders with each subtle tremor in the ground.

His face was locked in an expression of grim defiance—or was it pain? I couldn’t tell. Not until I stood before him did I realize how large he truly was. Even lying down, he towered over me.

The scent of burning pine and smoked sage still lingered in the air, curling low like ghosts around the stone circle. Clay pots of incense had been arranged with care near the giant's head, their embers glowing faintly as they sent delicate ribbons of smoke drifting through the cool breeze. The fragrances mixed with the earthy tang of moss and fire-kissed stone, creating a quiet sacredness that clung to the skin.

Boromu raised one arm slowly and gestured toward the fallen warrior.

"If you truly believe that you can help us, do so now."

My thoughts went to the Ocarina resting in my belt pouch, and I gingerly pulled it free, feeling the smooth, cool material against my fingertips. It pulsed faintly with memory. Tatl, uncharacteristically quiet, hovered near my shoulder, her wings a faint glimmer in the dusk. She said nothing, but her silence was weightier than words. When I brought the Ocarina to my lips, she floated back and gave me space—a rare, reverent stillness.

I knew what I had to do.

The notes of the Song of Healing flowed out in quiet ripples, soft and mournful. The melody hung in the grove like mist, echoing between the trees and the hearts of those gathered. Not a whisper could be heard. Even the fire seemed to bow to the music, its flames stilling just slightly with each note.

When the last note faded into silence, nothing happened at first.

The Gorons glanced around, unsure. The quiet felt heavier now, expectant. Then, a thin crack of light shimmered along the fault lines in Darmani's petrified skin—subtle, but unmistakable. Gasps rippled through the circle.

As if summoned by the song, the stone began to loosen. It crumbled and flaked away like old bark shedding from a tree, revealing the golden-brown hue of Goron flesh beneath.

The circle held its breath.

Darmani twitched. Barely. Then again. A finger curled. A massive chest lifted in a shallow breath.

And then, as if released by some ancient spell, the crowd exhaled in unison as the fallen warrior began to breathe again on his own.

Darmani opened his eyes, slowly, as the last of the stone crumbled away. Tatl drew close to me and with a relieved smile, released a held breath of her own.

"Link... you did it! The song worked this time!"

The Elder Goron's throat grumbled in relief, staggering up to Darmani's head. With a gnarled hand, Boromu brushed debris off the giant's face, smiling with a mouth that had hardly any teeth left.

"Darmani... what a gift this child has brought us. We are saved!"

But the moment shattered.

The giant opened his mouth as if to speak, but suddenly he gasped in pain, clutching at his side with a ragged, rattling breath. The sound was wrong—wet, labored, desperate. Boromu's smile froze and fell away as he looked where Darmani was grasping. His eyes, so recently bright with hope, turned to dread.

I followed his gaze.

Where once there had been only stone, now there was a deep, open gash. Blood, thick and dark blue, welled from it in sickening pulses, spilling across the mossy earth like ink from a cracked vessel. It soaked into the soil, steaming faintly in the cool air.

"No... no no no," Tatl murmured beside me, her wings dimming, her voice shaking. "That wasn’t supposed to happen. He was supposed to be okay!"

Boromu waved his cane at the circle, barking orders, calling for herbs, a dressing, anything to stop the flow. Gorons rushed forward with armfuls of green-smoked leaves and thick bandages, their heavy steps thudding desperately through the soil. But I knew. I could see it in Darmani's eyes—glassy, unfocused, already beginning to slip.

I knelt beside him, barely breathing, and raised the Ocarina again with trembling fingers.

"Please," I whispered, as much to the gods as to the instrument. "Not this. Heal him! Please...!"

I desperately brought the instrument to my lips again. The Song of Healing spilled out once more, trembling and raw. My breath hitched with every note, my hands unsteady, tears stinging behind my eyes. The song was slower this time—not a melody, but a plea. I played it again, and again... but nothing answered.

Around us, the circle of Gorons fell into a mournful silence, their expressions stunned and helpless. Some had fallen to their knees. Others covered their faces with thick hands. Even the fire seemed to dim.

But even before the final note echoed into silence, I felt it. The stillness.

Darmani exhaled one last time. A soft glow began to rise from his chest, pale and golden. The wind caught it, swirling the light upward as the massive form of the warrior began to dissolve, fragment by fragment, into shimmering dust. Darmani's eyes looked up at Boromu with a deep sadness—a sense of failure, of hopelessness—resonated from them. His lips parted, as if to speak, but no words came. Only a shuddering breath. And then... the light in his eyes faded, like coals cooling in a hearth.

"No..." I choked, my voice breaking.

I reached out without thinking, as if I could hold him here a moment longer — catch the light before it slipped away. My fingers brushed through warmth, through dust and radiance—until they met something solid. The sensation jarred me: not the hot, living skin of a warrior reborn, but the cool, resolute edge of carved stone. My hand, trembling, rested not on Darmani’s chest, but something else.

The light swallowed him.

Within seconds, only a faint outline of his body remained—and then, nothing.

Nothing but a single object remained, cradled beneath my trembling hand—resting gently where his heart had been.

A mask.

It bore Darmani's likeness in stone: solemn, strong, unyielding. The features were carved with grace and power, frozen mid-roar, like a silent monument to a warrior who had fought to the very end.

I curled my fingers around it, lifting it into my hands. The weight was immense—far heavier than its size should allow. The stone was still warm, as if holding the last breath of the one who had worn it.

One of the younger Gorons let out a choked sob and fell to his knees, pounding the earth in rhythmic grief. Another tore fistfuls of dirt from the ground and pressed them against his brow, weeping openly. An older Goron sank to his haunches and began to sing, low and broken—a mourning song that trembled through the grove like the dying echoes of a bell.

The silence was no longer reverent — it was hollow, raw, and vibrating with everything they had just lost. I took up the mask and held it close, its edges rough beneath my fingers, its weight deeper than stone. I didn’t know if I had just been given a weapon, a grave marker, or the burden of a dying warrior’s final wish. But I could feel it—etched into the stone, humming against my chest—that this was not the end. It was a beginning. And it wasn’t mine alone.

Chapter 37

The Mask of the Mountain

At first, there was nothing but silence. Even the roaring fire seemed to silence itself, feeling muffled in the heavy air. And then, a single snowflake fell.

Just one, drifting quietly from the darkened sky above the grove, landing without ceremony on the back of my hand. It clung there for a heartbeat—fragile, precise—before vanishing into my skin like a breath forgotten. Then another. And another.

Within moments, the first snows had begun.

It wasn’t fierce. Not yet. It was gentle, almost reverent, as though the mountain itself was bowing its head to grieve. The embers of the sacred fire crackled softly behind me, casting a fading warmth on my back. Around the circle, the Gorons remained kneeling or standing in stunned silence, their broad forms hunched beneath the weight of the moment.

Darmani was gone.

And in his place, I held a mask. As I stared at the mask, a tight knot of guilt twisted deeper into my chest. Darmani’s bravery left an echo in the air—reminding me uncomfortably of all the things I had failed to protect, all the lives slipping through my fingers like sand.

I hadn’t moved in what felt like hours. My hands still cradled the carved stone, rough and warm with lingering spirit. It didn’t feel like a mask. It felt like a heart carved hollow, still echoing the last breath of its owner.

A few snowflakes had settled on my head, melting immediately. The cold bearing down as if Darmani was the last bastion against the onslaught of winter. I let it. The cold seemed fitting.

Boromu stood nearby, his cane driven into the soft earth, his cracked eyes staring not at me, but at the hollow space where Darmani had vanished. He hadn’t said a word since.

The other Gorons were just as silent, but some of them held each other, others were broken down on the ground, faces in their hands. A young one pressed his forehead to the frozen earth, humming low and wordless. An elder had curled into himself, hands clutching smooth prayer stones etched in deep sigils, lips moving in a whisper too quiet to hear. Another Goron, broader than the rest, sat motionless with his hand outstretched toward the empty air where Darmani had disappeared, as if unwilling to believe the space was empty. Their grief filled the grove not with sound, but with presence—a pressure in the chest, a stillness in the trees, a heaviness in the snow as it began to gather.

Even Tatl seemed frozen—not from cold, but from reverence. Her wings fluttered just once as the snow began to fall, then stilled. The usual sharp glint in her voice had been smothered by the weight of what we’d witnessed.  Her glow dimmed to a pale shimmer, hovering uncertainly beside my shoulder. In that moment, even she seemed too fragile for words.

It felt like time itself had stopped. The snow fell in slow spirals, each flake tracing its own path toward the earth like forgotten prayers. The air tasted of smoke and frost. The fire crackled behind us, brittle and subdued, casting weak shadows across the grove. No one moved. No one breathed loud enough to disturb the hush.

Until Boromu finally moved.

The elder exhaled slowly, the sound more like a landslide than a sigh. Then he turned to me—not with authority, but with something heavier. Expectation. Hope, maybe. Or resignation. The furrows in his stone face were carved deep by grief, yet something flickered there—a dim ember refusing to die.

"If you carry his mask," he said, voice rough with age and grief, "then you carry what remains of him. Whether you asked to or not."

I didn’t answer. I wasn’t sure I could. My throat was tight, my thoughts brittle.

Snow began to gather in Darmani’s empty space—the last mark he’d left behind as he lay dying. It filled the depression slowly, gently, as if trying to erase the memory of his existence. But I couldn’t let it. I couldn’t look away. The swirl of snow blurred the edges of the hollow, like time trying to wash over pain too fresh to bury.

The grief that weighed on this grove wasn’t mine alone. It clung to my shoulders, settled into my lungs, mixed with the steam of my breath. I needed space to think, to understand why I felt so connected to these Gorons—why it hurt so much to watch them break.

Tears welled behind my eyes before I realized they’d been building. I turned from the fire’s last embers, retreating to the edge of the grove. There, beneath a leaning pine glazed in frost, I stopped. My hands clutched the stone Goron mask, cold and sharp like it was Darmani's resolve. Its expression—frozen in strength, carved in roar—felt like a question I couldn’t answer.

The chill seeped in through my boots and into my chest, a creeping cold I couldn’t shake. Snow settled across my shoulders like quiet hands. I shivered hard, and then I felt Tatl’s glow at my shoulder—a faint pulse of warmth against the wind, like the last ember in a fading hearth.

“Link… are you okay?”

Her voice was soft. Not teasing. Not biting. Just… worried.

I shut my eyes and looked away, jaw tight.

“I… I don’t know,” I whispered, my strength breaking. “This… this wasn’t supposed to happen. I keep losing, Tatl. I keep trying and nothing works. Ever since I left Hyrule... it’s like the gods are angry at me. Like they’re taking things away from me. One by one.”

My voice faltered, choked by the sharp sting rising in my throat. “And maybe... maybe they are. Maybe I turned my back on what I was meant to be. Maybe I abandoned the very path they gave me, and now they’ve abandoned me in return.”

I could feel it, like a door had quietly closed somewhere far behind me. A divine silence. Not punishment. Not wrath. Just absence. The terrifying weight of being left alone—not by people, but by purpose.

The mask remained in my hands, unmoved. But something in its silence felt familiar. Like it knew that same emptiness.

And all I could hear was the wind whispering through the pines and the snow collecting the heavy silence like stones—patient, inevitable. It was as though the world itself had run out of answers. I stared into the mask, and the mask stared right back, almost as if in defiance to my weakness.

And then, it pulsed.

A slow, low vibration thrummed through my palms—not painful, but resonant, like a struck bell echoing through stone. The mask shimmered faintly, its eyes briefly catching the starlight. I gasped and almost dropped it.

"Did you feel that?" I whispered.

Tatl hovered a little closer, her glow dimming in awe. "Feel what? Are you—"

But before she could finish, the world shifted.

A rush of heat filled my chest, then my skull. The wind around us seemed to stop entirely. I blinked—and the pine forest vanished.

I was standing on a mountaintop.

Snow swirled in blistering waves around me. A horn sounded in the distance, deep and mournful. Goron voices echoed in a ritual chant, and then shattered into screams. I turned—behind me, a temple of stone and ice cracked open as a monstrous shape emerged, bound in chains of lightning and frost.

Goht.

I felt the bitter, biting cold of the mountaintop as if it were my own, tasted the coppery tang of blood from a wound I hadn't earned, and knew the grief and fury of a warrior staring down his final battle, knowing he would not survive, yet fighting all the same

I could feel the memory like it was mine . The cold. The fear. The duty. I was seeing through Darmani’s eyes—his final memory, left behind in the mask like a song trapped in stone. His last desperate stand. His failure. His sorrow.

And beneath it all... a plea.

The vision fell away as quickly as it had come. I staggered forward, heart hammering in my chest. The mask’s warmth faded, but the echo remained.

Tatl hovered close again, breathless. “Was that…?”

I nodded.

“He wants me to finish it. He wants someone to carry it through.”

The mask rested in my hands, still and heavy once more. But it no longer felt like just a relic. It felt like a bond. A burden passed through stone and time.

And I knew, whether I was ready or not—this was the path I would walk.

My fingers tightened around the stone edges. Without thinking, as if guided by something deeper than will, I lifted the mask.

"Link, wait—"

Tatl’s voice didn’t reach me in time. The moment the mask touched my face, the world twisted.

A surge of heat slammed into my chest. My arms jerked backward, spine arching unnaturally as a tremendous force tore through my muscles, pulling my body outward, upward, wider . My skin split and reshaped itself in impossible ways, bones snapping and thickening, pain laced with something almost euphoric. My tunic burst at the seams. My boots cracked open. The mask fused to my face like molten iron—and then, like stone, it became me. My mind splintered under the surge of raw strength, both terrifying and exhilarating. Link—my true self—was slipping away, replaced by a powerful certainty that burned in every muscle and bone.

When I hit the ground, it cracked beneath me.

I gasped, but the sound that escaped my throat was no longer mine. It was a bass-heavy grunt , deep and gurgling like a landslide. I looked down—my arms were huge. Thick slabs of muscle covered in rough stone skin. My chest heaved, wide as a wagon.

“Hurr… what… happenin’…?” I mumbled. Even my voice was different—deep, guttural, and dim. My mouth wasn’t moving the way I expected. My tongue felt too big.

"Oh… holy gods," Tatl murmured, darting around my shoulder. "You're... You're a Goron! But... wow. A huge  one."

I blinked slowly, my vision strange and heavy—like everything had slowed, just a little. My thoughts felt... distant. Sluggish. Like someone had packed cotton around my brain.

I looked down at myself—at the broad, domed chest rising and falling like a boulder shifting with breath. My arms were massive, corded with muscle that looked less like flesh and more like carved basalt. My fingers ended in thick, ridged knuckles, like hammers shaped from stone. My once-loose tunic was now tattered cloth clinging awkwardly to the edges of a rocky torso, and my boots—what was left of them—had split wide to reveal massive feet ringed with stone-like ridges.

A glowing sigil, faint but pulsing with each heartbeat, burned softly on my shoulder. My entire body radiated heat, like smoldering stone after a volcanic surge. I could feel strength in every movement, but control was slipping away, thought by thought. I was hulking. Heavy. A wall of living rock.

Somehow, it all felt familiar.

My thoughts were thick. Like packed snow. But there was fire in my veins now. Pride. Duty. Something primal. The mask had given me this form for a reason—and I would use it. Smash ice. Protect tribe. That’s what Darmani wanted. That’s what I wanted . Right?

I notice the brothers standing behind me, looking at their hero reborn.

Elder Boromu speaks, his voice quivering with pride.

“Darmani? Is that… -no, no you’re different. You wear green garb and strange armor. Are you… are you truly that human who played the melody that heals? We all felt its power… heard its wisdom. Darmani passed, but not in a way any of us thought possible in a long, long time. He gave his strength for you to borrow as gratitude for healing his spirit, through that mask. Through you… he can save us!”

I felt honor and pride well up deep within my stones, my deepest hearts, and I raised a gigantic fist and roared back against the winter creeping up on us. I would be victorious! I would win! I would fight all threats that came my way! Suddenly I almost remembered what I was doing just moments before.

I turned to Tatl, confused. She hovered in silence for a moment, then groaned.

“Oh no. Not just a Goron… You’re him . You’re Darmani. Or, uh… something very close. Just… maybe not all the way there. ”

"Not, Darmani…no. Link, uh..I am… Huh...?"

I scratched my enormous head. My arms felt like cliffs. My hands—barely hands—were slabs of stone wrapped in muscle. Something was fuzzy. Not right. Thoughts made no sense. But I remembered that I had to smash winter! Break the ice!

"Me… s’posed to smash ice now, right?"

Tatl buried her tiny face in her hands. “This is going to be exhausting. ”

Already, I could feel something shifting inside me—sliding deeper. Thoughts grew slower. Simpler. Each word like a boulder I had to roll uphill.

I blinked. Tried to count. Wait… why count? Numbers were hard.

The world felt louder. Heavier. My heartbeat thudded in my ears like war drums.

Time passed oddly. A few minutes, maybe more. I tried to remember what I was doing… then forgot what I was remembering.

"RAHHH! WHERE ICE? ME BREAK BAD ICE!" I bellowed suddenly, slamming my fists together with a sound like thunder rolling through stone.

Tatl flinched, wings buzzing with alarm. Her glow flickered, unstable, and she backed away slightly. "Okay, that’s new. Link? Can you still hear me in there? Please, say something normal. Say anything."

"Link? Me Link! ME STRONG ROCK GUY LINK , HA!"

I laughed, big and echoing—like boulders laughing. Joke was strong. Me strong. Joke good.

But Tatl didn’t laugh.

She zipped in front of my face, her wings trembling now. "No no no—Link, come on. Look at me. Please look at me. You’re scaring me. This isn’t you."

Her tiny hands reached forward, as if trying to grab my attention, to shake me out of it. Her voice cracked. "You’re losing it. You have to take the mask off before—"

I try swat annoying bug away, flashy fairybug, urgh! Too bright. Too fast. No thinky.

Her light darted out of reach, her voice rising in panic now. "No—don’t do that! Link, please! You’re slipping too far—don’t leave me here alone!"

The strength shake. My knees fall. Cracks through vision like stonebreak.

I fall. Grow weak. Lose seeing… fall…

A deep groan escaped me as my body lurched forward, the mask peeling off my face. The world tilted. I collapsed with a thunderous thud, cracking the frozen dirt beneath me. A plume of powdery snow burst outward from the impact, and for a heartbeat I felt like the mountain itself had dropped through my chest.

The strength drained from me like sand through open fingers. My breath came in short, ragged gasps. The mask… it pulsed once beneath me, a strange, low throb like a heartbeat caught in stone. It was warm—not comforting, but alive, like a soul remembering it had once breathed. The sensation ran up my spine like an echo, not painful, but not gentle either—more like a distant voice calling through bone.

A final surge of heat spread through my chest like a dying heartbeat. My body began to shrink. Stone skin softened, splitting like a shell. Limbs curled inward, bone and sinew twisting and pulling tight as if retreating from the world. My spine bent sharply, ribs aching as my frame folded into itself. The weight of that other form peeled away in layers, and my mind reassembled itself in jagged flashes—thoughts stuttering into words, language reforming like ice cracking into sharp patterns.

Then came the sudden cold.

The sudden absence of that hulking strength was dizzying. Where once my center of gravity felt like a boulder, now I was a tangle of delicate limbs and aching joints. My breath fogged in the air. My shoulders folded as snow began to gather on me. My body shivered so hard I could hear my teeth knock together. I felt exposed. Small. Like a leaf that had just fallen from the tree I had been part of seconds ago.

I lay there, panting, my fragile body curling in on itself. The mask rested beside me like a spent heart, still faintly warm against the frost.

"...Tatl?" I croaked.

She hovered above me, blinking rapidly. Her glow was dim, uncertain. “Oh thank the gods... You’re back. Just barely.”

Her wings trembled midair, and she darted in close, circling me once with nervous urgency before settling just beside my face.

“I didn’t know if you’d come back,” she whispered, her voice cracking. “You were gone, Link. Like… really gone. I was calling you and you didn’t even blink…”

I blinked slowly, breath still shaking. My limbs felt like water, my muscles empty of anything but exhaustion.

“I thought I’d lost you,” she murmured, barely above the hush of the wind.

I remembered the sudden compulsion to put on the mask, my own arms betraying me as they forced it to my face. Tatl’s voice struck me with how much I scared her, and I recoiled from the mask that lay silent on the cold ground.

“I didn’t mean to…” I rasped.

Tatl hovered a little closer, her voice now more firm, but gentler than before. “I know. I know you didn’t. But next time, promise me something.”

I glanced up at her, barely able to nod, my head still swimming from the effects of the change.

“Don’t put it on unless we absolutely need to. I…um… we  can’t afford to lose you. Not like that.”

I swallowed hard, the chill creeping back into my skin as the mask lay silently beside me. I glanced at it, then back to Tatl. I could only reply with…

“I promise.”

I groaned. My limbs trembled with the last of the lingering memory of Darmani... a memory of something ancient and terribly powerful. Lying in the snow, feeling painfully small and exposed, I understood something terrifying—how easily I could lose myself, not to darkness or evil, but to the simple comfort of unquestioned strength.

“We’re going to have to be… very careful with that thing.”

Tatl crossed her arms, frowning with concern but trying to keep her voice steady. "You were... completely gone, Link. I don’t even think you heard  me anymore. A few minutes more and you might’ve stayed gone..."

I turned my head toward the mask, picking it off the ground and turning the heavy stone over in my hands. It looked harmless now—just a stone carving. But I could almost feel it watching me.

I could still feel the echo of weight in my shoulders. The deep-throated roar in my ears. The mountain-heart pounding in my chest.

Part of me missed it. The strength. The certainty. The fury. It reminded me of those early moments after the curse—when everything felt out of control, and I would have given anything just to know  what to do, to have purpose again. There was no fear in that form, no doubt, just motion and force. It was like being held in the arms of something terrible and vast—but safe from the cold of uncertainty. And now, stripped bare and small once more, I felt its absence like phantom limbs aching to be filled.

"It felt so... easy," I whispered. "Like I didn’t have to question anything. Just act. Be strong. Be sure. "

Tatl's voice softened, landing beside my shoulder, her wings fluttering gently as if weighed down. She looked tired—emotionally drained—her light dimmed to a soft, flickering glow. There was worry in her eyes, but also a fragile relief, like someone who had just pulled a friend back from the edge of a cliff. "Yeah, well. That kind of power always  feels easy at first. It's not meant to think. It's meant to destroy ."

I nodded faintly, still staring at the mask. My breath clouded the air as I gazed over the edges of its worn stone features. Part of me missed it, missed the strength, the righteous fury... the sheer force of will.

And that scared me more than anything else.

Suddenly, strong arms wrapped around me—like stone warmed from a fire and reverent—and I was lifted as if I weighed nothing at all. A dozen Gorons had gathered around, encircling me without my notice, their heavy brows furrowed with awe and something deeper. Their touch was gentle despite their size, like mountain winds cradling a falling leaf. One placed a hand softly on my back, steadying me not as a stranger, but as kin.

I was carried back to the bonfire, its flames now crackling with renewed vigor. Sparks danced upward into the night like prayers rising skyward. Around it, the circle of stone guardians gathered. Their feet were planted like roots of a mountain, their fists resting over their hearts.

They hummed a deep, resonant chant that vibrated up through my spine and into my ribs. It wasn’t a song made for the ears. It was for the soul. Each note reverberated through the snow-laced air like the pulse of the earth itself. I felt it stirring something in me—something old, something I didn’t recognize as mine, and yet remembered all the same.

Tatl hovered beside me, silent but glowing warmly in the firelight, her presence a small anchor in the midst of so much reverence. She looked not at me, but at the Gorons, eyes wide with awe. Her wings flickered gently, as if moved by the music.

The chant rose with each breath the Gorons drew, echoing into the cold air and grounding itself into the very earth beneath us. It carried weight—like stone on the heart—but also comfort. I didn’t understand the words, but I knew the meaning. Honor. Grief. Hope.

Elder Boromu stepped forward, his cane tapping once against the wood of a fallen branch as he lifted his voice. His face looked older now, lined deeper with sorrow—but behind his eyes, something fierce still glowed.

"Link… Hero of the Draumorim, bearer of Darmani’s final breath, one who heard his call and answered with a roar. I ask you this—if the soul of our brother lives in you still, if his courage has found new flame in your heart, then speak now. Will you save us?"

The heat from the bonfire wrapped around me, breathing warmth into my frozen limbs. My body still trembled from the transformation, but something inside me had settled. My heartbeat slowed. My breath returned.

I stood, slowly, legs wobbling beneath me like a newborn foal, but I stood. Around me, the Gorons watched with quiet intensity—no longer strangers. Brothers.

“I will, Elder,” I said, my voice steadier than I expected. I met his eyes, then turned to the others. “You have my word.”

“Then come, brother, rest by the fire. Regain your strength.”

The bonfire crackled warmly, sending dancing shadows across the clearing flattened by heavy feet. I nestled in beside it, the massive bodies of the Draumorim gathered loosely around the flames in a quiet, protective circle. Their presence—solid, unmoving—brought with it a strange sense of peace. I felt folded into something ancient and enduring. For the first time in what felt like ages, I let my limbs relax.

Warmth seeped into my bones, washing away the last tremors of the transformation. I watched the flames curl upward into the snowy sky, their golden tongues flickering in the dark eyes of the Gorons who now regarded me not with suspicion, but with respect and quiet camaraderie.

It felt like family. Not the kind born from blood, but forged in silence, in danger survived, in promises made beneath sky and stone.

Elder Boromu shuffled to my side, settling onto a carved stone seat with a low, gravelly grunt. He didn’t speak right away. Just stared into the fire with a heaviness in his eyes that matched the snow-laden skies above.

"You came to us in the middle of sorrow, child," he said eventually, his voice a rumble that seemed to shake loose the snow in the trees. "And gave us hope. But I must know—who are you, truly? What path led you from the land of chaos to this moment, here, now?"

I nodded solemnly, the fire's warmth banishing the doubt in me.

And I told him everything.

The words poured out of me—not rehearsed, not crafted. Just raw and real. My journey through the forest, the ambush, the Skull Kid’s cruel laughter and twisted jokes, the curse that reshaped my body and severed my ties to home. I told him of the Ocarina I had lost, the time I had stolen back when I reclaimed it, the southern swamps where I had found rot and horror, but also healing and beauty. I spoke of my struggles with Lukhan, a crime boss in Clock Town, of my time with Ratt, and how we found his son. And finally, I mentioned my fear of losing the flickers of myself I still wasn’t sure I’d recovered.

Boromu listened with a heavy stillness, only his eyes moving in the firelight, glinting like slow-cooled lava. When I finished, he leaned in, placing a stone-weighted hand on my shoulder. It was solid. Grounding.

“Loss never becomes easier,” Boromu said softly, his eyes reflecting a lifetime of grief. “But we, the Draumorim, carry each other's burdens. That is the true strength of the mountain. That is why Darmani trusted you, even beyond death.”

"You are no longer a stranger to us, Link of Hyrule," he continued. "You are Draumorim now. You have earned the name Rohmar , in our tongue—Stonebrother. And the mountain will remember you. Take peace now and know you are safe, with us, Rohmar Link."

Something uncoiled in my chest. Rohmar. It settled into me like it had always been there, hidden beneath the noise. Not a title. A truth. The Draumorim began a deep, rhythmic song of acceptance around me. The very earth quietly vibrated with their sound, and in a way it was deeply comforting.

I smiled. It was small. It was weary.

But it was real.

The chant around me resonated deep into my bones, not just a sound but a heartbeat shared among many. It thrummed low and ancient, as if the mountain itself remembered my name now. The firelight danced across the stone faces of the Draumorim—faces no longer wary, but open, grounded, proud. I caught Tatl’s quiet shimmer from the edge of the circle. She didn’t speak. She didn’t need to. Her light pulsed once, steady and warm.

And for the first time since leaving Hyrule, the emptiness inside me filled with something new, solid, and warm: belonging.

Chapter 38

Footfalls in Frost

I was mostly asleep—half-dreaming, half-floating—wrapped in the smoky warmth of my dinolfos cloak, when I heard, or more like felt it: the sound of heavy, deliberate feet crunching against the frost-bitten earth. Slow. Measured. Getting closer.

The hairs on the back of my neck stood on end.

My eyes snapped open, instincts coiled tight. I sat up fast, breath caught in my chest, scanning the dark perimeter of the Draumorim’s grove. For a fleeting moment, I forgot where I was. Everything felt too quiet. Too still.

The fire had burned low—just a cradle of glowing embers now, pulsing like the last heartbeat of a sleeping dragon. Their red light danced across the snow-dusted clearing, casting long shadows across the stone bodies of the Gorons slumped nearby. From where I sat, they looked less like people and more like statues—hulking shapes etched from iron and stone, motionless in the heat-flicker of dying flame. Their stone-skin backs glinted faintly in the low light: some like weathered cliffsides, others marbled with veins of dark copper and grey quartz, each scar a testament to the harshness of the mountain’s love.

The silence was so complete it almost rang in my ears—until the sound of footfalls returned. Crunch. Crunch. Crunch.

The largest Goron warrior, who had captured me earlier, emerged from the treeline, his figure sharp against the dark—massive, shadowed, his breath huffing in misty plumes. He didn’t speak. Only dipped his head and moved directly to Boromu, his boots sinking deep into the frost-laced earth with each step. Even the rocks seemed to tremble as he passed.

Boromu, seated like a boulder worn smooth by time, turned to hear him. The brother leaned in, whispering something too low to catch. The elder’s brow furrowed, as if the mountain itself had shifted beneath him. No words passed his lips, but something ancient stirred in his throat—a low chant, gravelly and deep, that rolled out across the camp like a tremor echoing through stone.

At once the camp began to wake.

Two more Gorons appeared at the tree line, dragging a stiff, snow-dusted figure between them. Human legs trailed through the powder, leaving a wavering trail. The shape stumbled and twisted, trying to push back against the Gorons’ iron grip, even as his strength faltered.

And then—when the flicker of firelight caught tangled, familiar dark hair, my heart stuttered as recognition hit me—relief flooded through my limbs, chased immediately by a fresh surge of worry.

Ratt.

He looked like he’d clawed his way through a storm—his cheeks raw with windburn, lashes crusted in ice, lips split and tinged blue. He wore a large, poorly fitting cloak that was torn open at the shoulder, exposing pale skin beneath, and his unprotected fingers twitched with the onset of the cold. His black boots were coated in snow, laces dragging, one of them half-untied like he’d been running until he collapsed. But the moment Ratt saw me, his posture shifted. Just a little.

Despite everything, a crooked grin tugged at the corner of his mouth, wild and stubborn.

"Well," he muttered through chattering teeth, eyes locked on mine with exhausted relief, "so much for stealth."

Before I could respond, Boromu’s faded blue eyes flared like tinder struck by flint.

"Ahhh... more human treachery," the elder growled, his voice thick with pain. "Here to steal my son again as he slumbers in cursed dreams?"

He pointed a finger at Ratt’s chest—thick, stony, accusatory.

"No more. You won’t harm us again, human. Bury him in the earth, brothers. Let the dirt consume his deceptive mind."

I was on my feet before I could think, heart slamming against my ribs.

"Wait—wait, he’s with me!"

The Gorons paused. Tension thickened like steam in frozen air. One warrior, towering with arms like granite pillars, growled low.

"Spies are not brothers. They bring ruin to kin."

"He’s not a spy…" I stepped forward, planting myself between Ratt and the circle of stone. "He wouldn’t hurt us. He came for me."

Boromu’s voice was slow and seismic, but clear. "If the Stonebrother vouches for him... then let him speak."

The Gorons hesitated, then finally released their grip. Ratt stumbled and brushed himself off, teeth chattering.

"Thanks," he muttered to me, quieter now, almost sincere. Then louder, with his usual edge, "Look, I wasn’t spying. I was following."

"Why?" I asked, arms crossing—part irritation, part bracing against the cold. "I told you it was too dangerous out here!"

"Because you’re in danger. Again."

He rubbed his arms, pacing a slow, uneven circle on the frosted ground. His boots crunched faintly with every step. "Lukhan’s still after you. He remembers something went wrong… not the details, but the feeling. That you cheated him. And now he’s losing his mind over it."

My stomach clenched, a cold knot twisting deep inside.

"I overheard some of his thugs talking about it," Ratt went on. "They were drunk and extra loud. He’s offering a huge bounty for anyone that finds you. Doesn’t even know why—just needs to get you alone and 'rip the answers out,' they said."

A ripple of growls rolled through the camp. The Draumorim bristled. Some stood slowly, their massive hands clenching into fists, the tension thick in their wide, armored shoulders. One Goron’s eyes flared like embers stoked by wind, while another’s nostrils flared sharply, teeth bared in the beginnings of a snarl. The older warriors, the largest among the group, exchanged hard glances, the kind that spoke of scars and battles already fought. Even those who remained seated stiffened, their backs straightening like pillars bracing for impact. The youngest among them, an adolescent about my size who had stuck by Boromu's sleeping son like a personal guardian, gripped the edge of the cart a little tighter. His jaw set tight, mirroring the hardened expressions of his elders as though instinctively taking on their fury.

Ratt held up his hands slightly, voice dipping. "He thinks you’ve got something. Power. Magic. He’s hunting you with everything he’s got. Him and every dog he keeps on a leash."

Tatl hovered to my side, her glow hardening. The embers cracked behind us.

The cold felt suddenly sharper.

"Look—you can’t go back to town, I can’t go back to town. They’re hunting all of us, Link. It would be far safer if we traveled together." Ratt’s voice was quiet but steady, more reasoned than pleading. It made sense. It made too much sense.

"Hagh… fine," I muttered, my breath fogging in the dim air. "You can come. But you have to stay out of any fights if we get into any. I can’t—"

The words choked in my throat. Darmani’s loss still carved deep, like a wound that hadn’t scabbed over. I could still feel the pulse of his last memory echoing through the mask strapped at my side. The thought of losing Ratt too—another soul brave enough to stay close—was almost unbearable. Because if I lost him too, I wasn’t sure there’d be anything of me left worth saving.

My voice softened, brittle around the edges. "I just don’t want you getting hurt."

He didn’t reply. But he looked at me in that way he sometimes did—sharp eyes, intelligent, as if seeing straight through all my defenses. It unnerved me more than any enemy.

I turned my gaze skyward. The horizon had begun to shift from obsidian to slate, a dark grey hinting at the promise of dawn. The stars above flickered faintly, the last holdouts against morning. Time was pressing in on all sides. If Lukhan really was hunting us, it wouldn't be long before our presence here put the Draumorim here at risk.

No more needless death. No more hollows filled with snow.

"We should pack up," I said, turning to Elder Boromu. "Move out to the mountain. Is your son awake yet?"

Boromu’s massive shoulders sank visibly, grief pulling at him like heavy stone. His voice lowered, rumbling with old pain. "No… he still slumbers. I had hoped that returning him to us—returning him to me—would be enough. That hearing my voice would stir his soul. But alas, he and Darmani were bound tightly. He cared deeply for the boy. The silence has been long."

Boromu’s gaze drifted to the mask at my side—Darmani’s carved visage still locked in a roaring defiance against death itself.

"Perhaps," Boromu rumbled slowly, "he will respond to you… while wearing Darmani’s power?"

"Ohhh no, we’re not doing that again!" Tatl darted between us like a spark, her wings a blur of frantic energy. Her glow pulsed with urgency, casting flashes of light across our faces. "We almost lost Link last time! I don’t care how much Darmani meant to the kid—what if she doesn’t come back next time? If Link dies, the whole world is lost, what then?"

Boromu raised a gnarled, stone-scarred hand, a slow gesture meant to calm more than command. He nodded gently.

"Be at ease, little sprite. I hear your worry, and I share it. There is another way—one we intended to try before my son was taken from us."

But I didn’t answer them right away. My hand had already drifted to the mask at my hip, fingers brushing its carved edges, feeling the cold weight of it pulse faintly through the palm of my glove. The mask throbbed like a second heartbeat—dormant now, but waiting.

There was power in it. Not just strength, but certainty. When I wore it, the world made sense in brutal, simple terms. Enemy. Obstacle. Path. It dulled everything else—the fear, the guilt, even the fragile threads of identity that still held me together. I didn’t have to feel the things that confused me. I didn’t have to remember what I’d lost.

But I also didn’t feel myself .

I remembered how the thoughts had slowed, the words becoming fewer and further between. How my limbs had moved without hesitation, but also without nuance. It had been like sinking into stone. Comfortable. Heavy. And terrifying.

I stared down at the mask, its eyes empty and wide. Darmani’s courage was still in there—I knew that. His honor. His grief. But so was the threat of losing me.

And the worst part? A small, traitorous part of me wanted to give in again. Just for a while. Just to stop feeling so damn much. It was terrifying, how much I wanted to lose myself again, to escape into strength that asked no questions and demanded no truth. The mask promised oblivion, a soothing void where fear and confusion couldn’t follow.

I swallowed hard and tore my hand away, as if the mask had burned me.

"There has to be another way," I said quietly, not meeting Tatl’s eyes. "There has to be."

Boromu’s expression didn’t change, but something softened behind his eyes. A flicker of understanding. Or maybe… respect.

His voice grew quiet, touched with sorrow. "Our home has a sacred place… a chamber of awakening. It is a quiet hall built into the heart of the mountain, a place for meditation, for communion with the spirits and the breath of earth. When Darmani left to confront the Divine Beast, my son—Maro—fell into a deep slumber. Grief weighed heavily on him, and the loss of Darmani was like a mountain falling on his heart. One of our reverend Elders suggested placing him in the chamber, where the mountain's spirit might guide him through his sorrow."

Boromu’s gaze darkened. "But before we could seal the chamber, the thief struck. While Maro slept in mourning, defenseless and alone, he was stolen from us."

He turned, his eyes sweeping across his gathered kin—each one standing silently, fists over hearts, heads bowed to the past.

With renewed resolve, he faced me once more. "If even in the sanctuary of the grove we are hunted and tormented, then there is no point in pleading to the world beyond. We will do as we always have—solve our own struggles, protect our own blood."

He lifted his chin. "Brothers, gather your gear. We return home. This time, we will be victorious—or we will be extinguished with the rest of the world."

The response was wordless but immediate. In a flurry of motion both swift and quiet, the camp stirred to life. Great packs were hoisted, carved tools and prayer stones wrapped in cloth. One of the Draumorim rolled slowly through the fire pit, quenching the last embers with a hiss and a gust of ash, leaving behind only the faint warmth clinging to the stones.

I shivered as the heat fled the grove with the embers being extinguished. Snowflakes caught on my lashes. My breath curled in the air like smoke.

Turning, I stepped closer to Ratt, who was still pulling his cloak tighter with trembling fingers.

"How… how are you feeling? Do you need anything?" My voice came out gentler than I meant it to. "You look half frozen to death."

He gave a crooked smile that didn’t quite reach his eyes as he shivered. "I’ve been worse. B-but if you have a s-spare magic coat in your pocket, I won’t s-say no."

I couldn’t help but return the smile, heart softening at his resilience—even beneath frost and fatigue, he still found a way to joke. That stubborn, crooked humor of his had a way of piercing through the cold. I looked down at my gloved hand where the enchanted ring still rested, faintly pulsing with a dormant heat. It hadn’t been tested much, not really—but something about it always felt alive when I was in danger.

I hesitated, quietly watching the Draumorim move around with disciplined precision. What if it hurt him? What if I couldn’t control it? The thought of fire engulfing and consuming his skin made my stomach twist—but the way he shivered, the way his breath came in ragged clouds, I knew I had to try.

I focused my will into the ring, steadying my breath. At once, it flared to life—its jewels sparking with sudden crimson light, like coals catching flame.

"Here," I said softly, offering my hand. "Take it. Maybe this ring will help warm you up? I’m… still not sure what it does. But I hope it doesn’t incinerate you."

"Haha—I’d take b-being set on fire over having my arms rattle out of their sockets."

Ratt reached out slowly, his bare fingers trembling as they brushed against mine. The moment he made contact, I willed warmth into him—gently, intentionally. The ring pulsed, and a trail of soft red flame curled upward from our joined hands, licking across his arm in a ribbon of glowing heat.

He yelped and pulled away instinctively. The flames vanished with the broken contact, and he stumbled back a step, eyes wide.

"Y-you know," he stammered, examining his unscathed arm, "I was kidding  about the fire thing! Are you sure this is safe?"

"No idea," I admitted. "Did you get burned? If you did I'm sure one of th-"

"No, no—actually... It feels great." He interrupted, looking over his arm in amazement, and then grinned as if remembering a fond moment in the past.

"Like when I got to take a real bath once. A hot one. Gods, that was the best day of my life." He chuckled weakly and waved off my concern. "Let’s do it again. Seriously."

I exhaled in relief, letting the tension ease from my shoulders. Once more, I pressed my intention into the ring, and again the red flame unfurled—dancing over his arms and shoulders like a shawl of living warmth. This time, he didn’t flinch. The flames didn’t burn—they glowed softly, casting golden-orange light across the snow.

Ratt stopped shivering. His breath no longer came in shudders. He stared at our hands in awe, his expression uncharacteristically quiet as the fire licked gently around him, warming him from the bones outward.

He looked up at me, and for a moment, didn’t speak.

The cold wind still whispered across the clearing, but between us, there was only the hush of firelight and shared silence.

I felt that warmth blooming in my chest again, the flutter of keese attacking my guts, and I pulled away with a disconcerted gasp. Why did this boy always make me feel like this? What was wrong with me? My pulse thundered in my ears, my throat dry. Why did this moment—this quiet intimacy—unravel me more than any danger? Why did I crave it even as I fled from it?

It wasn’t just nerves. It wasn’t just fear. It was something far more dangerous— hope.

Hope that someone could see me through this cursed form. That someone could hold onto who I was even as I unraveled. And that hope was painful. Because every time I felt it, it reminded me how far I’d already drifted from who I used to be. From the hero I once was.

The warmth around Ratt faded when I pulled my hand away abruptly, the glowing tendrils of flame shrinking and vanishing like a dream ending too soon. He blinked in confusion, his expression turning soft with concern.

"What happened? Are you ok?" he asked, voice gentler than I expected.

"I’m… fine. It’s nothing." I forced my tone flat, the softness retreating as quickly as the heat. I didn’t trust it. I didn’t trust myself.  "Are you warm now?"

He rubbed his arm, eyes still on me. "Y-yeah? I’m ok now, heh… well should we…uh, get going?"

But his voice faltered. Not from cold this time, but something quieter—something searching. His gaze lingered longer than it should have, scanning my face as if trying to read a language half-forgotten. There was hesitation there, barely veiled; a pull he didn’t yet understand.

His eyes—those sea green, intelligent eyes—betrayed something deeper than curiosity, or confusion… beneath it all was a glimmer of fondness. Maybe he didn’t know what it meant yet. Maybe he hadn’t figured it out himself. But it was there, just behind the way his breath caught when our hands met, the way his shoulders had dipped not just from relief, but something softer. Something warmer.

I turned away before either of us could speak, trying to bury the heat still curling under my ribs. My ponytail caught on my bow and I flung it behind me angrily.

He didn’t understand. How could he? He didn’t know what it meant to lose everything you were, to lose your face, your body, to feel your mind slowly slip away. To want someone and be terrified of being really seen.

And goddess help me, the way he looked at me—like I was still just me —was more dangerous than any curse. I couldn’t give in any more to this, I needed discipline, order, willpower. I had to keep myself whole before losing everything I was, or else this world would die along with everyone in it… including Ratt.

So I rushed away—too fast, too sharp—pretending I had something urgent to do, anything that could excuse the sudden heat rising behind my eyes. The tribe was already mostly packed, but I threw myself into movement anyway, half-heartedly checking bags and stomping down snow, needing the distraction like a shield.

“Stupid… stupid, what am I doing…” I muttered under my breath as I kicked at a pile of powdery snow gathering on a young sapling. My voice cracked at the edges.

Tatl floated up beside me, her wings humming low. "Link, what’s going on? Did that kid say something to you? Do you want me to smack him around a bit?"

I jumped a little—I had almost forgotten she was there. Her tone was sharp, but beneath it, I could hear the flicker of worry. The white fairy’s wings trembled midair, and she darted in close with a soft chime.

"No… he… urgh… nothing happened," I said, too fast.

My throat tightened. My fists clenched so hard my knuckles ached. It was easier to lie than explain the fire curling under my skin.

"I’m just… frustrated. With losing Darmani. With having another cursed form shoved onto me."

My hand gripped the Goron mask hanging from my belt, my fingers curling tightly around its jagged stone edge. I let the pain bite into my fingertips. It was easier to blame the mask—this heavy, unfeeling thing—than admit what was actually burning under my skin.

In truth, I was grateful for it. Grateful for the strength it gave me. Grateful for the way it buried my emotions under slabs of stone and muscle. It was like armor I could slip into whenever the world asked too much of me. Whenever I was afraid. Whenever I felt too much.

Especially now, when feeling too much might be the most dangerous thing of all. It left me open, weak, unfocused. I was so tempted to press the cold stone to my face and bury myself beneath a mountain of strength—let the sheer weight of that other body shield me from this trembling self I barely recognized anymore.

Who was I even trying to protect anymore? Myself? Ratt? This world? The lines were blurring. I used to know what I was. A swordsman. A hero. A man tempered by fire and steel. Now I was none of those things—just a ghost flickering between forms, between faces. And the mask… the mask didn’t ask questions. It only obeyed its nature. It didn’t ask who I was becoming. It didn’t care.

“Link, I know all this is… hard. But you’re not alone, you know?” Tatl’s voice was softer now, brushing against my thoughts like a hand reaching through the dark. “You don’t have to carry this by yourself this time.”

Despite her brashness, the gentle hum of her wings felt like a steadying hand, reminding me quietly that I wasn’t alone.

"You’ve basically got a whole army  of Gorons who’d probably die for you. And that kid... as annoying as he is... nearly froze to death just to warn you. That has to count for something."

Her words pressed gently into the hollows of my chest, but they didn’t fill the space. Not yet.

I didn’t respond at first. My eyes followed the Draumorim as they moved methodically around the grove, sweeping away traces of their presence with branch and stone. The fire was buried. The tracks smoothed. But it was like trying to erase footprints from wet clay. The signs were still there if someone knew how to look.

And Lukhan knew  how to look.

I rubbed at my temple, the tension in my head blooming like a migraine behind my eyes. I didn’t want to feel any of this—grief, fear, longing, hope. But it clung to me like snow melting down my spine.

My hands trembled, just a little. The kind of tremble you only feel when you know you’re standing on the edge of emotions that could unmake you.

“I… know that, Tatl. Thank you.” My voice came out rougher than I wanted. "I’ll be okay. I promise. Don’t worry about me."

A lie, again. But I needed to believe it long enough to move.

"Let’s just get to the mountains and stop this cursed winter. I’m sure Boromu would let Ratt stay with them too, if I asked. That way we could finish healing the world like that mask salesman said, and I can end this curse without worrying about him getting hurt. At the end of this maybe then I can finally go home to where I belong."

The words tasted strange. "Home" no longer had a shape.

I paused, my breath misting in the quiet air, caught in the brief silence before the next storm.

"I’ve learned my lesson..."

But even as I said it, a part of me whispered back:

Not enough.

The words echoed like footsteps on frozen stone, distant but unrelenting. I shoved them down, deep, where they couldn’t bloom into doubt. Not here. Not now.

Boromu had stepped beside me—quiet, steady—his presence like the hush before snowfall. I hadn’t noticed him approach, but his scent carried earth and ash, and the quiet gravity he held was as familiar as the mountain itself. How long had he been standing there? Had he heard everything?

I hated that thought. But he gave no sign that he had, offered no judgment. Instead, he only looked ahead and motioned to the shadowed treeline, where the snow gathered like a breath waiting to be exhaled.

“Rhomar Link,” he said, his voice a low rumble of ancient stone, “the path ahead is the direction of the mountain. If we are to make it to Draumor by nightfall, we must begin the journey. I fear this snow will only slow us down further… but we will follow your lead. Let Darmani’s spirit guide you, and you will find your way home.”

Home.

I nodded once, the word once again stinging more than it soothed. I scanned the camp—the Goron brothers were ready, solemn and quiet, their preparations finished. The fire pit had been flattened and brushed over, the snow swept clean, but still, the earth held memory. Tracks too wide to hide. Evidence of life that would not be erased by branches alone.

I looked toward the trees and found Ratt standing apart from the group, leaning against a frost-laced trunk. His arms were crossed, but his gaze was fixed on me with quiet worry. I met his eyes for half a breath—then looked away before either of us could speak.

“Okay. Let’s start moving, my brothers.”

My voice came out flat. Cold. Like iron hammered into a blade. Resilient. Or at least pretending to be.

The sky was bleeding into a pale, bruised violet, the color of old sorrow. Dawn crept up slow and silent, veiled behind clouds thick as wool and heavy with warning. A storm was coming—we could all feel it. The cold was sharpening, not easing. The quiet pressed down, too complete to trust. Even the snow, which drifted in gentle spirals, felt like it was holding its breath.

I raised my hand and signaled forward, stepping beside Boromu as the caravan began to move. The Draumorim followed in silent rhythm, a procession of living stone, their footsteps heavy but sure. The cart carrying Maro rolled behind us, the boy still curled in his deep, silent sleep, guarded by the youngest of the tribe. The sight of him—so small, so still—sent a quiet pang through my heart.

The cold deepened as we walked. Flurries stung my cheeks like tiny needles. I reached for the mask at my side. Its surface was cold to the touch, but the promise of strength beneath it pulsed faintly like a heartbeat in stone. The mask didn’t ask who I was. It didn’t care what I felt. It just gave me something to be that wasn’t... this. The rough, carved edges dug painfully into my palm, a welcome distraction from the ache tightening my chest.

I could wear it, become the mountain again—lose myself inside its silence, where nothing could touch me. Where love and fear and longing could not follow.

But no. Not yet. That strength came with a cost I could no longer afford to pay casually. I needed to stay present. I needed to remember who I was.

Ratt kept his distance, trailing behind the group near the cart. I caught glimpses of him chatting with the young Goron pushing it—light words, a half-smile, shoulders hunched against the cold. He laughed once—short, uncertain. Like a bird chirping trying to join the flock, but not quite finding its place.

I turned away quickly, pretending not to notice, pretending it didn’t echo in the hollowed-out chambers of my chest.

I pushed my boots harder into the snow, let the cold bite deeper, welcomed it. It kept me sharp. It kept me focused.

No more distractions.

Just the mountain. Just the path ahead.

The trail bent upward, narrowing into a slope choked with crooked pine and half-buried stone. Trunks lined either side like ancient pillars, their bark laced with frost, their branches heavy with snow. The wind had quieted for now, but I could feel it waiting. Breathing. Watching. A presence, not just a pressure.

The only sound was the crunch of feet in powder and the distant creak of trees groaning under winter’s weight. Somewhere above, a hawk cried out—sharp, brief, and alone. The sound pierced the stillness like a blade through cloth, then vanished into the hush. Light filtered down in slanted beams, pale and cold, gilding the ridge in silver and sorrow.

It would have been beautiful, if it didn’t feel like the mountain was holding its breath.

Boromu walked beside me in silence, his great frame moving with a kind of reverent stillness. His breath steamed out in low clouds, curling around his beard. Once, he glanced skyward and murmured something beneath his breath—low and gravelly, like earth remembering its dead. A prayer. Or a warning.

I didn’t ask. I didn’t need to.

Behind us, the Draumorim moved as one—quiet, solemn, their feet sinking deep into the growing snow drifts. Their shapes looked carved from the mountain itself, but even they carried tension in their shoulders now. The silence between us wasn’t peace. It was vigilance.

Ratt trailed behind, near the cart, wrapped in cloak and uncertainty. His steps were steady, but his eyes never stopped moving. Once, I felt his gaze brush the back of my neck, but I didn’t turn. I couldn’t. Not now.

As we crested the next ridge, the world unfurled beyond the tall pines.

Mountains loomed in every direction—towering cliff faces, sweeping ravines, and jagged peaks dusted with snow like ash on old bones. The mountains looked like the ribs of a giant laid bare to the cold, as if the land itself had died and we were marching through its remains. Dawn had arrived, but the sky wore a deep slate gray, heavy with brooding clouds that shed flurries like whispered curses. The air was thinner here, and the light diffused through the snow-heavy veil, softening the world into something dreamlike.

What lay before us was breathtaking, even in shadow. This place held a kind of sacredness, a hush woven into the ridges and slopes. It felt older than time.

Far below, forests of pine and spruce blanketed the foothills like sleeping giants. Their emerald needles were crusted white, boughs bending under winter’s weight. A wide valley opened beneath us, and at its edge roared a mighty waterfall—its cascade disappearing into a cloud of mist that billowed like a dragon’s exhale. The water glittered with an inner light, carving silver lines through the landscape as it fed the winding rivers and creeks that stitched through the forest beyond.

It was beauty carved from stone and breath. Alive, yet silent. Harsh, yet beckoning.

Boromu stood beside me, his voice a gravel-smooth murmur over the wind. “Our home is just up those falls, Rhomar Link. There is a great hotspring at the heart of the monastery. We call it Vah Kel'Darah. In the Hylian tongue, it means Sacred Life from the Mountain Deep. From it, the mountain breathes. The warmth keeps our home alive—our crops, our young, even the old ones who dream beside it.”

His gaze darkened, jaw setting like a landslide. “But this cursed winter creeps deeper with every hour. If we do not stop Goht, even Vah Kel’Darah will freeze… and with it, all we built will vanish.”

The Draumorim had begun their descent into the valley, broad backs bent slightly against the chill wind. Their silhouettes moved slowly, like migrating stones. I lingered at the ridge, my eyes still locked on the beauty below—the frozen rivers, the breath of mist, the distant plume of smoke curling up from a lone cottage far out in the trees.

I understood why they chose this place.

They came from fire and ash, death and destruction. But here, there was water. Motion. Abundance. A mountain that breathed and gave life.

Ratt’s approach broke the quiet.

“H-hey, Link,” he said gently, voice careful, eyes searching. “Are you okay? Did… did I do something to upset you?”

His words were hesitant, but earnest. Honest in a way that pierced the frost I’d layered over my thoughts.

It stung—because he truly meant it. He truly wanted to help. And it would have been easier if he didn’t.

That only made the feelings twisting inside me more intense. More impossible. Like a vine of warmth trying to grow in frozen ground.

The kind of feelings that weren’t supposed to take root in someone like me. Not a hero. Not a sword. Not a mask.

I couldn’t meet his eyes. My breath fogged between us, caught in a gust of wind that scattered the flurries like ash shaken from a dying hearth.

“No,” I said, too quickly. “I just need to concentrate on my task. Don’t worry about me, ok? I’m fine. You just focus on staying alive.”

My voice was cold, clipped. Sharper than I meant it to be. I turned away before I could regret it, falling into step beside Boromu.

“Right… sure,” he mumbled, clearly hurt but quickly masking it with a forced smile.

I caught his smile out of the corner of my eye—but his eyes… they sank. Like he’d just swallowed something bitter. My heart clenched, then turned away. I didn’t want to feel that guilt. I didn’t want to feel anything at all.

The snow thickened in the air around us, as if the mountain itself had taken notice. I pulled my cloak tighter and walked faster.

Tatl flitted beside my ear, voice low. “Hey Link, you sure you’re okay?” she whispered, settling onto my shoulder. Her tiny hands braced against my collar. “I mean I’m all for ditching him, but he’d probably die out here alone. You want me to tell him to scram anyway?”

“No…” I whispered back, watching the fog of my breath melt into the wind. “I don’t want him to freeze to death. He’s… fine.”

I glanced back once. Just once. He was still walking, hands tucked in his sleeves, shoulders hunched against the wind. Alone, but not by choice.

“I just have to keep my mind sharp and focused,” I said softly. “Not worrying about his safety is all.”

But the truth clung to my heart like the frost clinging to everything here. I was already worried about him.

We continued on our way down into the valley in a single file, the leader being the largest Goron, who I had come to know as Gromi. The further we traveled into the valley, the more uneasy the atmosphere felt. The wind rose sharply, tearing through the trees with renewed force, carrying with it a whisper of ancient sorrow—a warning, or perhaps a prophecy of what lay ahead.

The flurries thickened with every step, whirling in spirals that bit at our faces and buried the trail behind us. The sky had vanished into white, and the wind howled with the voice of something ancient and relentless. I could feel the mountain shifting, watching, as if it knew we didn’t belong here. The sky bled into a bruised violet, the color of old sorrow.

Somewhere ahead, Boromu raised his arm and pointed to the rising smoke of unseen warmth curling faintly into the storm. Shelter—if we could reach it in time.

And behind me, through the veil of snow, Ratt’s form trudged forward—smaller than he had seemed before. But still there. Still following.

The silence felt like a breath held in my chest—too long, too tight—waiting for the moment it would all shatter.

Chapter 39

The Flame Hollows

As we traveled down the slope, the wind started to blast us in waves of snow.

It didn’t rise gradually—it struck. Sharp, sudden, biting. Laden with frost and something older. Snow peeled from the trees in choking clouds. My cloak snapped against my body like a sail, the fabric clawing at my arms. I pulled it tight, heart pounding beneath layers of wool and dread.

The clouds above had changed.

No longer gentle gray. They churned with bruised violet and sickly steel, twisting like coiled serpents across the peaks. Thunderheads high above moved like predators, slow and full of purpose. The cliffs and jagged ridgelines were beginning to vanish beneath a crawling veil of white, their shapes dissolving into the white horizon.

The blizzard was inevitable. No longer a threat—an arrival. We had to find shelter, and soon, or else we would all be buried under snow and ice.

Tatl darted beside my face, wings shimmering like shards of starlight, frantic and stuttering in the wind. Her voice trembled as she fought the gale. "Link... that doesn't look good."

I looked up. And in that moment, I saw it.

A wall of white—not mist, not fog, but solid wind—an avalanche of air and frost hurtling toward us from the far side of the valley like a colossal hand descending from the sky.

Boromu stopped abruptly, planting his feet with the weight of stone. He lifted his head and let out a low groaning call that vibrated through the rising wind—a sound like ancient earth shifting in its sleep. The caravan of Draumorim paused, then moved with calm precision, gathering into a defensive circle around their elder. I shielded my face from the snow’s bite and pressed forward. The brothers parted the way for me, their expressions grim, as Ratt and Tatl stayed close at my back.

“What do we do now? Should we find shelter?” I asked, my voice barely audible over the shrieking wind.

Boromu nodded, concern weighing heavily in his old, frost-lined eyes.

“There is a passage…”

Boromu's ancient shoulders slumped slightly as he spoke, as though the very weight of the mountain rested upon him. His voice was strong, but carried a deep sorrow—the choice he offered was one he had hoped never to make.

“An old proving ground—sacred to us. It was sealed when Goht began to rage. Monsters had found their way into the chambers, and Darmani was forced to seal the exit to protect Vah Kel’Darah from desecration. But the entrance lies here, in this valley. If we pass through it, we will reach Draumor—our monastery, our heart. Yet it will not be safe. I fear the creatures that claimed it still linger there.”

He turned to face me fully. “But with you—and Darmani’s spirit—guiding us, we have a far better chance in there than out here.”

The snow angled sideways now, stinging like sand—sharp, blinding, relentless. Each gust was like a fist, knocking breath from my lungs and slicing at exposed skin.
