The snow bit harder than arrows, burying us slowly, mercilessly. My bones felt brittle, close to shattering. The horizon vanished beneath the storm’s veil, swallowed whole by white fury. Trees around us became ghostly silhouettes, half-seen phantoms shifting in and out of the swirling gale. The air itself was an assault, stabbing into my lungs with every breath, sharp as broken ice. It smelled of copper and cold iron—like blood on a frozen blade.

“That sounds w-way better t-than out h-h-here!” Tatl stammered, her glow dim as she dove into the folds of my cloak, wings shivering against my chest.

I could barely feel my fingers anymore. A deep ache had begun to settle in my arms and legs, creeping in like frostbite. I clenched my jaw and focused my will into the ring on my hand. The gem flared to life, and a sudden bloom of warmth spilled around me—soft orange flames licking over my clothes and skin without burning. It felt like being cradled beside a hearth, like the memory of a fire in the deepest night. I exhaled a shaking breath of relief and almost forgot about Ratt.

“S-so d-do we have a p-p-p-plan?”

Ratt stumbled up beside me, his voice ragged from cold. His face was red from windburn, lips cracking, breath huffing in pale clouds. I stepped slightly closer, letting the heat from the ring spill toward him. He didn’t lean in—but I felt the way he eased as it reached his side.

“We’re going to pass through some caves, I think. Right, Elder?”

Boromu nodded slowly, his great brow furrowed beneath a growing crust of snow. The Draumorim had formed a tight cluster behind him, massive bodies huddled together like boulders weathering a storm, their faces turned to me—not with doubt, but with weight. Expectation. Trust.

“We will pass through the Flame Hollows, brothers,” Boromu intoned, his voice steady against the wind. “A path once sacred—now deadly, and sealed. But today… it opens again. Rhomar Link will protect and defend us.”

The expressions of the large and imposing Gorons that surrounded us were taut with unease. I could see the flicker of hesitation in their eyes, even among the most stalwart of them. This was no ordinary path—it was one they had deliberately sealed away, a wound in the mountain left to fester in silence. But now, with the blizzard bearing down like a beast from the heavens, there was no other path forward. Only in returning to that place of trial could we hope to survive.

With a grim nod from Boromu, the Draumorim moved forward as one. Their discipline was swift, practiced—born of centuries surviving a world that was rarely kind.

“Gromi, take the lead. You know where the entrance lies here!” Boromu called out over the roar of the storm.

The burly Goron who had apprehended me the night before grunted, stepping to the front of the caravan with grim purpose. He unwound a thick coil of rope from his travel pack and secured it tightly around his waist. Without words, he passed the other end to the next brother in line, who did the same. One by one, the Gorons formed a living chain—binding themselves to one another in a silent pact of survival, no one would be left behind.

The brothers encircled us, shielding us from the worst of the wind. I felt like I was inside a massive turtle shell, protected on all sides by stone and willpower. Their faces were drawn tight, breaths misting in the freezing air. Even the hot-blooded Gorons were shivering now, their volcanic cores no match for this unnatural chill. It made my stomach twist, knowing that if I failed my brothers would die slowly by freezing to death.

I was endlessly grateful for the ring—its warmth was more than comfort. It was life. Without it, I could feel my own bones locking up, my joints going stiff. Within the enchantment’s embrace, a soft orange flame curled outward like a hearthfire wrapped around my form.

Tatl had taken refuge inside my cloak, her tiny body tucked beneath the layers near my back. I could feel her faint weight riding against the hero’s mask I carried there—our strange and terrible burden.

But Ratt… he was still shivering. Violently. His lips were pale and his jaw clenched as he trudged forward beside me, teeth audibly clicking.

The heat didn’t reach him. Not fully. The magic clung tight to me alone. My pride fought me, even then—as I wrestled with my emotions, but I looked at him, saw that he was suffering. Ratt’s breaths came in ragged clouds, his shoulders hunched painfully inward as if the very air were knives pressed against his skin. Each step looked painful, every breath a wince. I swallowed the tight knot in my throat and offered my gloved hand to him. He blinked, surprised, his expression softening as he hesitated. Then, wordlessly, he took it.

His fingers were ice. But the moment we connected, I pulsed will through the ring again—extending the warmth outward, willing it to encompass him as well. A bloom of orange light flared softly around us, like sunrise caught in snowfall. The warmth surged through the air between us, wrapping us both in a protective veil.

Ratt inhaled sharply, relief flooding his features. His shivering slowed. The tension in his shoulders eased.  As the gentle flame spilled between us, I felt more than warmth—I felt connection, a tether of golden heat binding us together. The glow rippled softly, matching the rhythm of our intertwined breaths, as if the ring itself recognized our closeness.

Around us, the nearest Gorons felt the warmth too, leaning subtly inward. Even Boromu stepped closer, his stone face tilting slightly toward the glow.

For a moment, there was no storm. Just warmth. Just breath.

I didn’t let go of Ratt’s hand. But the moment my stomach started to twist again I steeled my willpower and looked forward, hardening my resolve to see us safely through the mountain. If there was going to be a fight, I needed to be ready… not distracted like an idiot.

We kept moving through the intense howling wind, one foot at a time, the rope between the Gorons tugging like a lifeline in the whiteout. My cloak snapped around my legs, my boots nearly vanishing beneath the snowdrifts, but finally we saw it—a stone archway carved into the cliff face, half-buried beneath a mantle of ice.

The group disengaged the circle with practiced ease, tightening formation into double file as we approached. The entrance loomed above us like a waiting maw, its teeth formed by icicles hanging thick from the arch. But the way forward was sealed—entombed in a thick wall of solid ice that shimmered with a pale blue light, nearly opaque and hard as metal.

Boromu stepped forward and placed a heavy hand against the surface. Frost spread beneath his palm. “The breath of the mountain has stopped here,” he said, voice heavy with quiet reverence and sorrow. “Only strength and stone may undo what has been silenced.”

The storm howled behind us, the snow slashing like knives at our backs, but for a moment, all was still. I stepped closer, eyes tracing the runes carved faintly into the frozen arch. They pulsed softly, barely visible beneath the ice, like a heartbeat slowed to the edge of death.

Tatl peeked out from my collar, her wings brushing my neck. “You’re not seriously thinking of putting that mask on again, are you?” she said, half a whisper, half a plea.

“I have to.” I kept my voice low, not looking at her. “There’s no other way.”

There was a wingbeat of silence, then a flicker of movement as she flitted around to face me. Her glow was sharp, her wings a blur in the bitter air. “You almost lost yourself last time! Do you really think it’s worth the risk?”

Boromu’s gaze settled on me—deep, patient, sorrowful. “Only you can choose, Rhomar Link. But the mountain must breathe again… or we will not survive the night.”

I reached down, my fingers brushing the jagged stone of the mask at my belt. It was cold, but pulsed faintly with something deeper—something ancient. I could feel Darmani waiting.

Tatl's wings buzzed frantically, shimmering with a fragile, anxious light.

“Please, Link…' she pleaded softly, voice tight with genuine fear. 'Come back to me this time. Don’t lose yourself again.'

“I’m still me,” I said quietly. “I’ll come back. I promise.”

Tatl hovered in front of me, silent now, her light dimmed to a faint glow. I met her eyes for just a moment. Hurt flickered there, raw and unguarded, but she didn’t stop me.

I took a breath—deep, sharp—and pressed the mask to my face.

Pain. Heat. Weight. But not like before. The agony was there, yes—but muted, familiar now. A rhythm my body had begun to remember. Like pulling on old armor and letting it fuse with muscle and marrow. The rush of stone wrapped around my limbs, thickening me, grounding me. My thoughts dimmed, simplified. Not dulled. Focused.

Strength returned.

I felt it in the creak of my spine, the swell of my chest, the tightening of fists like boulders. I opened my eyes, and the world answered with silence and weight. Every sound deeper, slower—like I’d fallen into the breath of the mountain itself.

The warrior stood again. And I knew what I had to do!

I stepped forward, the earth groaning beneath me, each footfall cracking frost like eggshell. I roared—low and resonant—and slammed my fists into the frozen gate. The impact shook the stone around it. Cracks spiderwebbed instantly, veins of light against ice. I struck again. And again. Until the wall screamed and shattered, shards exploding like crystal rain.

From the breach came warmth. Real, living warmth. It rushed over us like a sigh from a sleeping volcano—sulfur, smoke, iron. The smell of something ancient and sacred.

The Flame Hollows breathed, fighting back against the frozen gusts behind us like an army unleashed against its enemies.

Behind me, I turned just enough to see Tatl hovering, her light dimmed and hesitant. Her tiny form trembled—not from cold, but something unspoken. Her voice didn’t come. Only silence, small and echoing.

Ratt stood beside her, snow clinging to his lashes and shaggy black hair, eyes wide—not in fear, not in surprise, just… almost in awe. Seeing a true Goron must be a real reward for that kid!

“Let’s move,” I rumbled, my voice now carved from stone. “The mountain breathes again.”

Inside, the air changed immediately—still freezing, but no longer biting. The wind no longer screamed. It was a breath held in stone, ancient and waiting.

The cavern swallowed us in silence. The only sound was the crunch of boots and stone-shod feet against the frost-veined path. My footsteps echoed dully, like the mountain was listening.

Blue crystals lined the walls in fractured veins, their glow faint but alive. They pulsed dimly in rhythm, like a heartbeat long buried beneath the earth. The light shimmered against the frost-clung stone, cold as moonlight and just as distant. When it caught the frost, it turned the whole passage into a corridor of ghosts.

The path beneath us bore the memory of reverence. Curling etchings danced across the floor—ceremonial designs now half-swallowed by grime and shattered rock. This had been a sacred place once. I could feel it in the weight of the air. In the way sound refused to rise above a hush, and yet there was something vibrating...calling almost into my very bones. A song of passage, a stonesfeel of home...

But whatever else it once held had been violently stolen.

Deep gouges tore through the stone—long, chaotic, angry. The claw marks of something fierce. They didn’t follow the flow of the path—they slashed across it, as if the thing that made them refused to respect its purpose. Scratches scarred the walls, some blackened with soot, others split by weapons or other tools of destruction. The smell of scorched minerals lingered faintly, beneath the dust and smoky ice.

My breath puffed in great plumes as I moved. Each inhale filled my chest with the cold weight of history, and something else—something darker. Not a memory... A warning.

Tatl drifted beside me in silence now, the edge of her glow brushing faintly against the crystals as we passed. She said nothing. Perhaps she understood it too: that this wasn’t just a cave. It was a place that remembered being holy. And I resented what had been done to it. The enemy would pay with broken bones and split necks.

I tightened my fists. My arms no longer ached. My legs no longer trembled. The mask had made my body strong.

But even stronger was the pull to protect this place. This mountain.

Let the monsters come.

I would meet them with stone and fire.

"Yeeeah… I don’t like this," Tatl muttered at my side, her voice tinny and uneasy. "This place puts me on edge. It just feels like something is waiting to ambush us… Link, don’t you think you should take that mask off now?"

"No," I rumbled, slower this time. "I like it. I need it, Tatl."

I pushed forward with forceful strides, daring anything in the dark to try me. My shoulders rolled with power. I would defend my brothers. I was  the mountain.

Ratt’s voice crept up behind me, low and cautious.

"This is the proving ground filled with monsters?" he asked, scanning the gouged cavern walls. "Well… at least this place is somewhat warm."

I hadn’t even noticed. It was warm—but something felt wrong. Like the dying embers of a once roaring inferno. The rock under my feet was solid, grounding. Good. But I still felt the wrongness. It was as though the mountain’s heart was locked in a quiet battle—its sacred pulse faintly whispering beneath the dark corruption that smothered it. The very air felt like a prayer gone unanswered, a temple forgotten by the gods.

My brothers fell in line behind me as I walked the path forward. Several of them removed glowing crystal rods from their packs, illuminating their paths forward in the dim light. They were just as uneasy, their faces stretched with worry and fear as their heavy footsteps synced with mine. The fairy and the kid followed too. The glow ahead was red—firelight. But something inside me knew this place was sick… not right.

We walked for a time. The quiet thrum of heat hummed through the floor, through my feet, through my bones. I listened to the vibration… felt pulse of mountain.

Would crush enemy.

Eyes forward, smash threat…

And then—

“Link, take that mask off now! It’s been too long!” Tatl shrieked suddenly, darting in front of my face. “You’re losing it!”

Her voice stabbed like a jolt. I blinked. Slowed. The world felt… dimmer somehow. Heavier. But her wings shimmered like memory. My fingers twitched toward face.

Wrong. Something was wrong. The fairybug was right… I was too deep. Not safe. Take off. I reached up, gripped my beard.

And pulled.

The transformation ripped through me like being cracked open by a hammer. Stone sloughed from my body in an unseen avalanche. My limbs shrank. My chest caved inward. My thoughts flooded back in a rush, tangled and sharp. Pain flared through my whole body as if it had imploded.

“Uughnn… that… that didn’t feel great…” I choked, collapsed onto my hands and knees. My breath came out in shudders.

The air remained cool, but the heat beneath my palms surged like buried embers—too raw, too alive for bare skin to hold.

Boromu’s voice called out, echoing faintly through the corridor. “Rhomar Link, are you well?”

I pressed a hand to my chest, feeling it rise and fall like a stranger’s. The heat throbbed against my skin. My heart thundered in my ears.

“I-I’m… uhh… I’m fine, Elder,” I managed, my voice thinner now. “Just… trying to get used to it, is all.”

I tried to stand. My legs were weak. Ratt was already there, his hands around my shoulders, grounding me.

“Easy,” he whispered, worry on his breath.

I steadied myself, shook my head once, scarlet hair whisking from my vision, and gently tapped his hand to remove it from my shoulder. He let go too quickly, as if afraid he’d done something wrong. His face darkened with guilt.

I looked away, jaw clenched.

Idiot, I cursed myself . I am an IDIOT.

The mask beckoned me like an old, dangerous friend as I placed the stone features on my belt, next to my Hero’s Mask—comforting in their familiarity, seductive in those promises of strength without pain. But every heartbeat echoed with Tatl’s fear, reminding me how easily I could lose myself, swallowed whole by the mountain’s fury or a warrior’s pride.

The others caught up to us, the ground quivering as they drew near. The stony faces of the Draumorim softened slightly as they watched me, their gazes filled not only with expectation, but quiet reverence—acknowledging the sacrifice, and silently promising to share the burden. Boromu shuffled in with his cane making solid thuds on the stone, parting through the line towards the cart with his slumbering son. The young Goron who stood at my height, pushed the cart more easily now across the smoother cavern floor towards the Elder, though his wide eyes betrayed his fear. The crystal glow painted his cheeks in soft blue as he glanced around the darkened chamber, clearly uneasy. He had probably never set foot in the Flame Hollows before.

“Tumar, has Maro stirred?” Boromu asked gently, his voice as tired as the wind dying within the gate.

“No, Elder… he has been as silent as the mountain,” Tumar answered, his tone subdued. His voice lacked the gravel and depth of the older warriors, but it carried a quiet strength of its own.

“I feared so…” Boromu murmured, his gaze lingering on the boy sleeping in the cart.

Around us, the others were catching their breath, their broad shoulders rising and falling like bellows. Many leaned against the cave walls, eyes closed, arms slack. The imminent threat of freezing to death over, the silence of the corrupted halls was beginning to seep into their bones.

Boromu turned slowly to me, his heavy footsteps echoing against the etched floor. His faded eyes held both worry and weariness.

“Rhomar Link,” he said, “we must rest. We will need all of our strength for the trials ahead. I fear the mountain’s heart grows still beneath Goht’s corruption. And I sense… we are not alone here.”

A tremor passed through his voice—small, but it reached me. Even Boromu, ancient and tempered as he was, felt it: the presence that lingered, like a wrong note echoing through sacred halls.

“Up ahead,” he continued, “there is a chamber of meditation, used by our young as the first rite to connect with sacred Snowhead. We can seal ourselves within. It will offer sanctuary to rest in peace.”

He lifted his cane and gestured down the corridor, his expression solemn.

“We will stop there for a time. Regain our strength. As we are now, we are no match for the shadows that stalk these halls.”

I nodded, grateful for the pause. My arms ached from the weight of my form, and the hunger gnawed at me like an echo in my gut. . I vaguely wondered if I was able to eat rock as in Goron form—or if I’d even want to try—but the thought passed quickly.

We pressed onward.

The silence in the halls deepened with every step, broken only by the soft rattle of wheels and the distant hiss of cooling lava veins. The mountain no longer roared. It whispered. And the whisper was wrong.

The passages widened into vast, echoing caverns veined with molten arteries. But what should have been a roaring forge of life felt... wrong. I could feel the heat—yes—but it was uneven, unfocused. Not a broiling heart of a mountain… but something strangled. Something decaying.

Rivers of once-living lava crawled in sluggish streams along the channels, their surface crusted in flaky obsidian scabs. The color was all wrong—no fierce gold, no blazing red. Only a muted, muddy orange glimmered through the fractures. The veins pulsed faintly beneath the cracked stone like a heart trying to remember how to beat.

It felt like walking through the ribcage of a god that had recently stopped breathing.

Boromu furrowed his brow, placing an ancient hand on one of the walls. His stone-scarred fingers brushed the blackened surface, reverent and mournful.

"This place once roared with heat," he muttered grimly. "Now it fades like a dying heart. The corruption reaches far here… even the breath of Vah Kel’Darah grows shallow."

Behind us, the Draumorim walked slower now. Their proud frames dimmed by something more than weariness—grief. Their gaze wandered not forward, but upward, to the stalactites and carved reliefs that once marked this as sacred ground. The loss wasn’t just physical—it was spiritual.

Even Tatl said nothing. She drifted onto my shoulder like ash on cooling coals, her glow dimmed. She didn’t fidget. She didn’t tease. She only rested there, quiet and watchful.

"Not far now. We will rest at the next chamber. Let’s move, my brothers. Time for mourning will come later," the elder sighed, a long landslide of a breath.

I swallowed the tightness in my throat and pressed on, taking the lead again. Sweat beaded on my temples, but I didn’t complain. I welcomed the heat, no matter how strange it felt in here. It was better than the strength-sapping blizzard outside. It felt… earned. If nothing else, it reminded me I was still alive. Still moving.

The shadows danced against the walls with every ripple of failing magma. Somewhere deep in the rock, I thought I heard it—like a groan. A low, vibrating sorrow. The kind of sound stone makes when it’s trying not to break.

As we passed under a steep archway with a familiar symbol of an eye and teardrop carved above it elegant, flowing lines. That symbol had always meant hidden truth, sacred witness. But here, it felt like a cry frozen in stone.

We ran into a solid obsidian door, flawless and lightless, absorbing the flickering glow around us. Elder Boromu took out the sacred Eye of Truth from his waist satchel, his hands steady despite the tremble in the air. He held it up to his faded vision, the lens catching the light in a single flash. After a moment of searching, he placed his ancient hand on the smooth obsidian.

A pulse. A soft ripple of blue light shimmered outward from his palm like water disturbed in a bowl. With a low, resonant grinding of stone against stone, the door began to rise, vanishing into shadow above us.

The air inside shifted.

It was cooler in here. Not the life-giving warmth of fire, but the heavy, dormant pressure of something long buried. The walls arched into a high dome, and the ceiling had been carved and painted with faded murals—spirals of snow and ice, rising flame and heat, figures of Goron pilgrims bowing before the mountain. Life flowing abundantly in a continuous arc from the heart of the mountains. On top of a the tallest peak stood a lone figure of an animal... yet not quite animal. It almost looked like a machine or statue of a four legged beast of burden. A quiet reverence lingered here, dulled by time but not yet erased.

In each corner of the chamber stood what looked to be Sheikah Stones, but larger—shaped like seated Gorons. Their broad shoulders and thick arms were stylized into the stone itself, each one wearing a mask adorned with the Eye and Teardrop. But the shape was different—sharper, angular, echoing Goron craftsmanship. The ancient alliance made manifest in stone.

These statues almost felt... awake.

There was a sense—just beneath hearing. A pulse in the rock. The silence here was not mere quiet—it felt sacred, mournful, like a held breath in a room of silent prayers. The stone walls, etched with memories of devotion, seemed to whisper softly of hope still flickering, though buried deep beneath sorrow.

“We will rest here, Rhomar Link,” Boromu said quietly, as if speaking too loudly would disturb the slumbering spirits carved into the stone. He turned, eyes shadowed. “Gromi, take Korozi and Belgor, and ensure the doors ahead are sealed.”

“Yes, Elder.”

Gromi—the towering brother who had once dragged me into their camp—grunted low and signaled two others. Without a word, they moved into the corridor beyond, the glow of their crystals bobbing like will-o'-the-wisps before vanishing into the dark. The sound of stone groaning shut came soon after, echoing like a distant memory.

I let out a breath I hadn’t known I was holding. The stillness was thick but not dead. It was watching.

“It is done, Elder. Korozi, set up camp, everyone gets rations.” Gromi’s voice rumbled low like rolling boulders. He turned toward me, his face weathered but earnest. “Rhomar, it may not be very tasty for humans, but we do have a type of bread that you both may be able to stomach if you are hungry. It’s important that you all keep up your strength. The path only gets more brutal ahead. Especially for a human.”

My stomach gave a sharp pang at the mention of food… I must have been far hungrier than I realized now that we had a moment of peace and safety.

“Thank you,” I said, bowing my head slightly. “I’m sure your food will be just fine. I appreciate the generosity.”

Gromi nodded once with a quiet grunt and turned to help the others. The Draumorim moved with quiet efficiency—despite their size, there was grace in how they handled the space. Belgor unrolled thick hide mats from a weathered pack, each marked with geometric red-and-black patterns. Korozi, stocky and broad-chested with an intricately braided beard ringed in bits of obsidian, tended to a small campfire built within a carved stone basin, stoking it with chunks of slow-burning coal that hissed faintly as they caught. The air smelled of mineral smoke and warm earth.

Tumar hovered near the cart, his young face tight with anxiety. He kept stealing glances at the mural above, then back to the older Gorons, his posture stiff with the pressure of expectation. Though his limbs still carried the weight of youth, he held himself as tall as he could, as though his spine alone could carry the honor of the tribe. Maro remained as still as a boulder in the cart.

Tatl poked her head out from my cloak, her glow dim but steady. "That bread better not be made of rocks. I swear if it cracks my teeth, I’m going to scream."

Ratt let out a soft laugh, wiping any frost that lingered from his cheeks and hair. "After that hike? I’d chew a tree stump if it came with salt."

"Haha Tatl, you don't even eat! Why would you care?" I laughed and gave her a playful tap with a finger.

"Hey I eat! You just never notice. I don't need as much as you huge lumbering humans." Tatl rolled her eyes and pushed my finger away gently.

I smiled, the weariness briefly softened by their banter. A portlier Goron named Dolmi—his arms tattooed with silver spiral bands and his eyes almost comically large—handed out dense, clay-colored loaves from a leather pack. The scent was earthy and faintly sweet, like roasted chestnuts and ash.

Ratt took his with a skeptical glance. "Looks like a rock. Smells like a rock. Here goes nothing."

He bit in—and blinked.

"Okay that’s… not bad actually. Kinda nutty. And spicy?"

"Mountain pepper-root," Dolmi rumbled helpfully. "Grows in the ashfall. Warms the chest."

Tatl took a hesitant nibble from mine, then widened her eyes in surprise. "Well, paint me surprised. Not bad for boulder bread."

I settled down beside Ratt on one of the thick hides. Heat curled around us in gentle waves, cocooning us momentarily in a peaceful, almost sacred hush.

The Gorons moved slower now, exhaustion beginning to catch them. Gromi sat against the far wall, arms crossed, his heavy lids fluttering as if in meditation. Korozi rubbed at his knees and murmured something in a rhythmic chant, the words low and ancient, like stones grinding underwater. Even Belgor, stoic and thick as a gatehouse, took a seat and traced an old carving on the stone floor with a calloused finger, lost in thought.

In the corners of the room, the ancient Sheikah-Goron effigies still watched, their silent masks reflecting the firelight and crystal rods with a dull gleam. Faint vibrations still hummed from within them—steady, patient, as though waiting for someone to speak the right word.

I watched them. This wasn’t just a rest—it was mourning. This place, once sacred, had been defiled. Their silence wasn’t just tiredness. It was grief. A quiet vigil for something they all felt.

I decided to take a chunk of the hard loaf. The crust cracked apart like a soft clay brick, flaking gently in my gloved hands. The inside was dense—spongy like moss and a deep volcanic gray. I took an experimental nibble. Surprisingly, it was tasty, with a hint of oaky spice and a slow-burning heat that bloomed across my tongue. I took a bigger mouthful, and my stomach growled in gratitude. The bread was heavy and tough, almost like dried meat, and every chew fed something deeper than just my body. It reminded me of hearth smoke and old forest bark—simple, honest things.

Beside me, Ratt had gone quiet. He chewed slower, distracted, then began to hum.

The tune floated gently out of him, soft and sorrowful—a lullaby woven from glass and elegance. Each note drifted like currents in still water, brushing against the edges of memory like wind through an old curtain. It was beautiful in its simplicity, ancient in its grace. My breath hitched, caught on the edge of recognition.

I knew that melody.

Not the name. Not the shape of it. But something inside me stirred—like a memory half-frozen, beginning to thaw.

I turned to him, my brow furrowed. "Where did you learn that song? It sounds… familiar. What is it?"

He blinked, startled by the question. "Oh. Uh… I dunno, actually. It’s just… been in my head since yesterday. Just lingering in the back of my mind... You know?"

I nodded slowly, the ache in my chest returning, I felt like I was forgetting something vitally important.

"Interesting… I swear I’ve heard it before… somewhere…"

Ratt looked down at the bread in his lap. His fingers were still now. He spoke more quietly, like he was speaking to himself.

"It makes me feel… sad. Like this place. Like something old was lost here. I don’t know why, I just… felt like it was right to hum. Like it belonged here. Something royal and noble to sing into this place."

I swallowed the lump in my throat with another bite of bread. "Sing it again," I said, voice hoarse. "Please. I don’t know why, but… it’s calming. I need to hear it."

One of the brothers passed around a large heavy stone flask, and I took it with both hands and swallowed a mouthful of pure, fresh spring water. I passed it to Ratt, and he smiled with a flicker of something solemn behind his usual smirk. After a few swallows of the revitalising water, he began to hum again—this time louder, surer. Each note lingered like a quiet echo, curling gently around memories buried too deep to face. I felt the ache of her absence, the gentle sadness of a goodbye left unfinished. The lullaby wrapped around me, soft as snowfall, warm as tears. The Draumorim turned their heads, listening with eyes closed, reverent.

The sound moved through the chamber like water rippling upward. It didn’t just echo—it filled the space. Sank into the bones of the stone. A melody of peace, but not without pain. It felt like starlight in winter.

A name surfaced in my mind. Just barely.

When Ratt finished, he let out a breath and whispered—barely audible, but I caught it.

"Zelda."

My hand froze. My entire body went still.

"Wait," I said sharply, turning to face him fully. "How do you know that name?"

Ratt’s eyes widened. "What name? Zelda?" He hesitated, clearly uncertain. "I… don’t know. I just think of that name when I hear that song. It fits. Like a memory trying to come through a fog. Why, who is Zelda? Do you know them?"

My mouth went dry. I looked into the flickering firelight and saw her—not her face, not exactly. Just the shape of what we’d shared. The ache of walking away from it.

"She…" I paused, searching for words that didn’t exist to describe how I was feeling. "She was a princess I once saved. We were close. Maybe more than close. But I chose to leave. I couldn’t—" I faltered. The truth was heavier than I expected. "Ugh… nevermind. It’s in the past."

Ratt looked at me carefully. Not with pity. Just understanding.

"You… couldn’t be satisfied in a time of peace," he said gently. "There was too much pain."

The words hit like a hammer to the chest. My eyes widened—not in anger, but in raw, unguarded shock.

How could he see that?

He shouldn’t have been able to. Not unless… he felt the same way somehow?

The firelight flickered between us, casting long shadows that danced across the ancient stone walls. Around the chamber, the low murmurs of the Gorons had faded into the hush of rest, but between me and Ratt, something raw and electric still lingered.

I looked down at my hands—slender, with fine wrists and graceful fingers, delicate in a way that I still wasn't used to. The fingerless brown gloves clung tightly to my skin, worn and weathered from the road. A Hero... That title meant less and less with every step into this frozen, cursed land. But somehow—here, now—his words made it feel less like a wound and more like a scar. Something that had bled… but was now starting to heal.

For a breath of a pause, I couldn’t speak. The fire crackled softly beside us.

And for the first time in a very long while, I felt like someone finally understood.

"Y… yeah," I finally whispered.

It was all I could say.

And somehow, in the echo of that quiet, it was enough.

The heaviness of the chamber and memory weighed on me, and I took a final bite of my portion of Goron bread, chewing it in silence. The flavor lingered—smoky, nutty, warm. It clung to my mouth like the heat of the fire still radiating from the center of the room. I held it there, letting the comfort settle as if to anchor me in the now.

“Alright, well if you two are done making out, I’m gonna get some sleep,” Tatl grumbled in irritation, fluttering off my shoulder in a blur of white gold. She curled into a glowing ball on the nearest bedroll, her wings twitching faintly like the last flickers of a firefly.

I frowned at her, exhaling with a slow sigh. The weight in my chest hadn’t lifted—if anything, it had simply rearranged itself. I swallowed the last of my bread and rose to my feet, moving toward the bedroll beside her. The stone beneath me felt colder now, even with the chamber’s residual warmth pressing into my skin.

I wasn’t tired. Not even close. The memory had shaken me loose. My mind was racing with too much I couldn’t untangle—anger, longing, sorrow, fear. All of it mixing in my blood like coals refusing to die out. This meditation chamber, carved for peace and self-reflection, only amplified what I was already carrying. It didn’t soothe me. It made everything louder.

“Yeah, that’s a good idea. I haven’t slept in days, it feels like,” Ratt said quietly after a long pause. His voice was softer than before, worn down by the day. He stood, brushing crumbs from his gloves, and walked slowly to a bedroll farther off.

I watched him go. Just for a second. I didn’t want him to leave. I wanted him beside me—to feel his warmth again, to borrow just a little of the steadiness he always seemed to summon. But the pang of guilt twisted deeper. Anger followed it, and I shut my eyes hard against both.

No. Not now.

We were still in danger. This place was still corrupted. And sleep—even restless, haunted sleep—was something I had to force if I wanted to stay strong enough to keep him... us... alive.

So I lay back on the hide mat, my bare fingers curling against the stout leather, and willed myself to stillness.

The chamber sighed around us, deep and old.

Somewhere beyond these walls, the mountain slowly died in silence.

To be continued
